author: Jnekka
title: Keep the Harry Potter’s coming!
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 5, 2019
content: Of course I love anything to do with Harry Potter.  I do wish this was written into a book (instead of a play), but loved it anyway.  The only other thing is I wish it was read by Jim Dale (which is the only reason I gave it 4 instead of 5 stars).

author: Melvin R. Grover Jr.
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: It was a good read after you got past the format.

author: Marshall
title: Fine book, Good play, Disappointing as part of the Harry Potter Saga
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2016
content:
This was a fun read, it was engaging and as ever J.K. Rowling demonstrates an impressive ability to bring her magical world vividly to the imagination of her audience. I also expect that it makes an excellent play that I hope someday to be able to see. This  was a fine book and a good play. However, it was disappointing as a new installment of the Harry Potter Saga. Now, it is hard to fault Rawling for this, as my objection really boils down to her previous work simply being TOO good. It would be hard for any book, much less a play, to hold up to my expectations and unfortunately this play did not.

Below are some of my concerns, to name but a few <Spoilers from here on out>:

The utilization of the time turner trope, unsurprisingly, opens up a large number of plot holes (how do the effects of manipulating the blanket propagate forward without other effects, like there being an Albus and Scorpius or Delphi's machinations; why can't someone at any point in the future make a new unlimited time turner and render all futures unfixed etc.).

Many of the portrayals of characters are disappointing to those of us who grew up with them (the idea that counterfactually Diggory could become a death eater, that Professor Longbottom would not have a more active role at Hogwarts in dealing with the situation, that Harry's scar could start hurting (despite the Horcrux in him being destroyed) is deeply implausible).

author: N. Acosta
title: Enjoyed
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2017
content: This is not a typical Harry Potter book as it's a screenplay. It's not as in depth as I'm used to, however, it was nice to see where some of my favorite characters ended up. I'd have liked to see a movie version as reading a screenplay doesn't have the same effect as watching it put together. This was a play, which sadly I could not see.

author: Mthomas
title: Good read! Once you get over the format of ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Good read! Once you get over the format of it being a play it's a fast read! I don't care for the play format but still worth reading if your a HP fan

author: Leanna
title: I can't compare this to the original series, but it was a fun read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I gave this book four stars because I did legitimately enjoy reading it, and I would recommend it to other Harry Potter fans (and maybe some non-fans!) to read as well. I won't compare this to the original series, because that'd be like trying to compare anything with perfection in my world. There were some things that did bother me about this book though, which I'll get to in a bit.

I'll start with what I liked:
It has been nine years since the last Harry Potter book came out, in which I stood in line dressed as Luna Lovegood nervously avoiding everything in fear of spoilers, and as a die-hard fan I loved the excuse to return to a world I almost feel that I grew up in. I liked reading this play because I've always been eager for more Harry, and this gave me more Harry.
I actually thought it worked well as a play, too. Plays/scripts will by virtue of their format not be able to offer as much detail and description as a book might, especially when reading a script vs seeing it as it was meant to be seen. But GIVEN that it's a play and that has to be expected, I appreciated the description that was included. There was enough in there for me to smile along with a new favorite character (Scorpius) and I definitely cried at the end, but I cry at a lot of things, so take that with a grain of salt.

And the things I DIDN'T like are more because of that die-hard HP fan thing, but I'll give an overview anyway:
Some of the plot points in this book just don't WORK, given the story's previous canon. I won't go into too much detail, because spoilers, but trolley witches? A certain office that seemed far too easy to get into? A kind of major relationship that seems much too far-fetched to ever be considered reality in this universe? I don't know. I just kept pausing while reading this and thinking, but, wait, THAT'S a bit contradictory.

I don't know if I'll return to re-read this many times, but I have no regrets about my midnight trek to buy it among my fellow book-lovers, and I will probably still see the play if given the chance.

author: C. Springer
title: Great, Smooth Read. Genuinely Entertaining.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
I don't understand these 1-2 star ratings, I really don't. I thoroughly enjoyed this script book. It might not have been on par with the original Harry Potter series, but it was good in its own right. The pacing was smooth for me, even if it moved a little fast in the beginning. But this isn't a novel, it's supposed to be made into a play. Which is why I understand the pacing and not going into huge details about each year.

[spoiler]Being a Slytherin myself, I love that Albus was sorted into the greatest house and made quick friends with Scorpius. He struggled with the placement, but came to realize it was were he belonged in the end.[/spoiler]

I was hooked on this from the first page and finished it within the second day of owning it. I grew up with Harry Potter, but I wasn't overly excited for this script book since it isn't an actual novel. But it was a pleasant read and I'd recommend it to any fan of the series. Definitely a great insight into what our favorite characters have been up to since leaving Hogwarts. I would love to see this play!

author: Wesley L. Duffey Jr.
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: Being based on a play, it was a little different than a regular book, and sometimes hard to follow.

author: drebbles
title: Not as good as the books but worth reading
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2016
content:
Harry Potter, The Boy Who Lived, is now a grown man with children of his own who are now attending Hogwarts.  Harry's childhood was not easy and it appears that his son Albus is following in his footsteps.  Albus is sorted into an unexpected house at Hogwarts and his best friend is Scorpius Malfoy, son of Harry's longtime enemy Draco.  Albus has long struggled with being the son of the famous Harry Potter, but this time his struggles will put him - and those closest to him - in very real danger.

I admit that I had mixed feelings about buying “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child”, knowing it was a play and not a book, and - while was based on her ideas - it was not written by J.K. Rowling.  After reading it, I still have mixed feelings.  To be sure, the story is a good one with Albus struggling in his father's footsteps just as Harry struggles to be a good father (as he says at one point he did not have any good examples to follow growing up).  Albus's friendship with Scorpius is well done - I never thought I would like a character whose last name is Malfoy but Scorpius is delightful - in fact, I think he is the real star of the play.  Besides the expected Harry, Ginny, Ron and Hermione, many old favorites appear in this play (some briefly) and there are some poignant and scary moments.  But in the end, this is a play not a book and lacks some of the character development that was in the books. Albus and Harry's relationship is realistically done but I would have liked to have seen more of James and how Albus gets along with him.  Classroom action is pretty much nonexistent in the play.  I found that the play, which is split into two part and is meant to be seen on two separate nights, is overlong (so much dialogue for the actors to learn, especially the young ones!) and feels like it could have used some editing (perhaps with some of the alternate worlds in the play).  I was never bored while reading the play; it just seemed a long play to be sitting in the audience watching.  Having said that, I would certainly go see the play just to see how they pulled off some of the magic - I bet it is awesome to see in person!

“Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” is not as good as any of the books in the series, but Harry Potter fans will enjoy it if only to see what Harry, Hermione, and Ron are like as adults.

author: Adrian Diaz Gonzalez
title: While I liked the story somewhat
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2016
content: Ok, I read the Harry Potter series a while back, basically as they came out, it could be just the way this is written (play vs novels) and the way I usually consume the material; so please take with a grain of salt.  While I liked the story somewhat, the character development was not as great as I'd come to expect, and yes, a Play won't allow for this, but I still thought they were somewhat single dimensional.  You'd love this as a Potter fan, and it definitely talks about characters we loved in the past in a somewhat new light, but if you're going there hoping to revisit the old school and the loving moments, it may not fit everyone.

author: Jenny R
title: A very fun read if you're looking for a new story about the wizarding world and not a new "Harry Potter" novel
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
I have been a fan of the Harry Potter books forever, and I really enjoyed this play. I went into it with an open mind and realized that the play itself was based on a story and not directly written by J.K. Rowling. I felt that it was quite fast moving and I did miss the rich full detail of the original series, but I understand clearly that this is a play, just the dialogue that misses the richness that is filled in by the visuals of watching a play in person. Additionally this wasn't a complex novel, it is the script of a play so the long meandering conversations and slowly developing story that I love about the original books was definitely missing. Again, I don't count this against the play because that is just not what a play is.

I found myself filling in a lot of the missing bits with my own visuals in my head. After having read the books so very many times, J.K. Rowling's original descriptions left me a wonderful imaginative landscape to watch this story play out in. I think as a free standing play without the knowledge and history of Hogwarts, the wizarding world and the characters themselves, this probably comes up short. As a piece of the Harry Potter universe, it was a fun jaunt through nostalgia and I actually found the plot to be unexpected and entertaining.

I read the play for entertainment and I definitely got what I was looking for. If you're looking for a significant addition to the Harry Potter novels akin to another book, you will be disappointed. If you're looking to read the script to a play that tells an interesting story about the goings on of several familiar characters and how life has changed since the original books, then this is a fun read with surprises, laughs, and lots of nostalgia.

author: Greg Welk
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2016
content: Nice entertaining read. I didn't think it would work for me to read a script but it worked.

Also, I thought the characters were a little one dimensional, but a good actor could probably round them out.

content: If you liked the harry potter series, you will love this book. It brings back all the feelings from the original series. However, this book will not bring new fans to the table. Its a short read and worth the money

author: Alisha
title: but it's a good read on its own
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2016
content: It's not up to par with the rest of the series, that's for sure, but it's a good read on its own. I'd put off reading it after hearing some negative reviews, but I gave it a chance and found it pretty good. Some of the plot was fairly predictable or read like fan fiction, but I enjoyed the storyline.

author: Amazon Customer
title: It wasn't as good as Rowling's novels
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content: It wasn't as good as Rowling's novels, and there were a couple of points that were odd, but if you're willing to move beyond that I thought it was an excellent play.  As you're reading it keep a performance in your mind and you should enjoy it a good bit.

author: Cassie R.
title: Very strange but very enjoyable
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I'm not sure how I feel about this. I really enjoyed it and I read it straight through completely captivated but also what the hell did I just read? The storyline itself was a little strange and almost read like fanfiction. It wasn't what I expected at all but it was entertaining enough to keep my attention and I really wanted to see how it ended.

As for characters I really enjoyed Albus and Scorpius. They're friendship was amazing and I would read many more books about them. I also enjoyed the interactions between Harry, Ron, Hermione, and Draco. There where times when I wasn't a huge fan of the way they acted but they did come off as true to character. Delphi was a very interesting character and I'm not sure how I felt about that or her.

This is not exactly how I thought the trio and their children would end up, and I have many of my own headcanons for how I wanted things to be. While this book doesn't follow any of my own wants it was still a wonderful story.

As a whole I really enjoyed reading about these characters and their world again. I would definitely want to see the play preformed if I ever had the chance. It was different from the original series but at the same time it held the same magic and tied into it well.

author: Katherine Parker
title: Worth the wait!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: I knew it was a screenplay, but I can't help but imagine what a fan-freaking full-length book it would have been!

author: Dg
title: good book....
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2016
content: only 4 star because I like a book reading format not a script format.  I wish it came in a choice. so a little disappointed.

author: Amy Landers
title: Harry is back!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
I am a huge Harry Potter fan. I fell in love with the books. After reading the reviews, I was disappointed, and was prepared for the worst. I am truly glad, that I read some reviews. Knowing this, is not in traditional book form, prepared me for this format, and limitations, compared to the original series.
Honestly, I really enjoyed it! I was once again, brought back to the world, of wizards and muggles. Of course, I would have liked to read more about my favorite characters, it was still fun! I hope it brings you the entertainment and closure, it brought to me! Enjoy!

author: Bear
title: Must be read with realistic expectations.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: This book met my expectations for what I thought a "script book" might be like. Skimpy in detail, and loaded with theateresque, dramatic dialogue (which again, is what I was expecting). That being said, I think this script book told a good story. It took me about 4 hours to read, and I didn't want to put it down. If the average, diehard, HP fan reads this book with realistic expectations, I think he or she may find it enjoyable. The one thing I didn't like about this book is how rushed it was. And I couldn't help but think the whole time how awesome it would have been if JK were to make the cursed child into a 3 or 4 book series with all of the same magic that came with Harry Potter.

author: Viola Stough
title: Enjoyed the book very much, would go to see the play.

content: From the first sentence you recognize J. K. Rowling and it feels comfortable. I had never read a play before so that was different. Overall I enjoyed the book very much. I would defiantly go tho see the play.

I liked it, i know a lot fans did not but both my daughter and I liked it.  We were aware that it was the play script, so that wasn't a surprise
There are some parts we could do without , that I won't give away but other than that we have no regrets.  It was an easy read too.  No more than a couple of hours.

content: The books hold interest better. That being said, it is very good. I don't get time to read like I used to.

author: Dorine White
title: Odd, but okay
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2016
content:
This tale was different enough to be a refreshing addition to the Harry Potter world. Told as a screen play, the story is written in four acts, two parts. It does lack the intensity of previous works, and the world building is all left to the readers imagination. Hopefully you already know the back story, so the images come in loud and clear.

What I liked the best was the way the story looks into the world of the now and the what if? The book starts 19 years after book 7. Harry and Ginnie have three children, and this story is about boy number 2, Albus. Even though written through dialogue, the reader gets a good feel of the angst that surrounds Albus' life as he is always compared to his amazing father. So here we have the present.

Albus is best friends with Draco's son, Scorpius. They are both in Slytherin and spend all their time together. As their years as Hogwart's pass, and they do, real quick, Albus becomes more and more disassociated with his father. When a time-turner is found, Albus thinks this is his moment to outshine his dad. Together, Albus and Scorpius set out to save Cedric Diggery.

So, now we come to the what ifs? The first world we glimpse is one where Hermione and Ron never married.That idea alone is enough to stir up loyal fans. The wrongness comes through in the relationships as Ron has no humor and Herminone is a mean, Defense Against the Dark arts teacher. Then it gets worse. Another fiddle with time brings the reader to a time where Harry died and Voldemort rules,  plus Delores Umbridge runs Hogwarts. Just these two peeks into alternate worlds is fabulous.

Then things get worse and wham, the author's throw in a twist and betrayal that I didn't suspect. Nicely done. I think Harry Potter fans will enjoy this look into Harry's life. The fact that it is written as a screenplay is odd, but okay. I give it 4.5 stars!

author: Kindle Customer
title: A Rainy Day Read

author: Zach Richards
title: A Good Book
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
content:
Let me start by saying that if you are looking for a good book that is Harry Potter themed (but not too much like Harry Potter) and you are okay with reading scripts, then you should absolutely buy it.

I bought this book seven hours after it was released, and I read it twice in my room before I came down for breakfast. I was so intent on reading it that I just rushed through it and loved it. But after I went back and read it again and again, I had to notice some differences and things that I didn't like about it.

Although this is a great book and the script line makes it seem really interesting and good, I was definitely not reading the same type of story as Harry Potter, and it is clear that this was not completely written by J.K. Rowling. It was really good, but in a very different style and I noticed several times that it would give information that was completely wrong from the Harry Potter series or things that they just made up. The characters acted in different manners and sometimes things happened that just didn't make sense. Also, I loved the time travel, but we have a whole other book about time travel in the third movie, but it tied in with the plot better. I know that Albus wanted to show to his dad that he is also good and can do things, but I just can't see why he'd risk his life to save the son of someone who had rejected him.
I loved the party with Snape in it, and I loved that they introduced new characters, but the Cedric Diggory turning into a Death Eater because he lost the Tri-wizard Tournament is a bit much, as well as the part with Padma getting married to Ron. Hermione going with Krum made Ron jealous! If he went with Hermione why on Earth would that mean that he is jealous of Padma! She is in Ravenclaw and he probably hasn't spoken mroe than five words to her in all their time at Hogwarts. I am also a little bit disappointed that they left out almost all of the kids besides Scorpius, Albus and Rose form the story. I would have liked to hear more about them. Albus is always talking about how he hates Hogwarts, but we hardly even get a view of what is making him hate it, except for a tiny bit at the beginning. And Voldemort having a child... it just seems like a joke to me, because I just finished the Deathly Hallows for the 50 thousandth time, and she is pregnant NOWHERE unless somehow magic makes a baby disappear and appear out of thin air, but let's be honest folks. Also, how can Delphi fly? It says that she learned it from Voldemort, but he can't fly without a wand. The Death Eaters and Voldemort can turn into those black-ball-spirit-things, but they can't just glide without a wand.

But honestly, if you don't focus on that stuff and you're not looking for something EXACTLY like Harry Potter, then this book would be great for you. The script adds a lot of suspense to the story sometimes in the way that it's written and has a pretty good storyline. I absolutely loved it (apart from the mistakes) and gave it a four star because I don't want to be those rude people who just give it one stars. Yes, no story is perfect, but no story is done without work. It doesn't help anyone to get feedback from people after they've spent a year on a book to be told that it is terrible. I liked the book, and I hope that you did (do) too.

author: Melissa M.
title: Almost
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 1, 2016
content: Good, but not JK

author: JDS
title: Why is this not a novel? A fantastic read but u must remember this is just a script!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I'm so not giving away spoilers I hate that. And I'm sorry if my review may not make sense. It's an emotional night. So here it is... This would have made a fantastic book. It really would have. People need to remember this is not a novel but a play. It was fantastic and if you start this book realizing that it is not a novel but a script/play you will get why I gave it only 4 stars. This is the bones of a novel, the heart. What's missing are the things that make Harry Potter books phenomenal. The tiny and huge things we love. Those descriptions of things that make our imagination run wild! But this script has the one ingredient that all of Harry's books have. The actual story.  The core of the book. It really is fantastic to read about the world of the grown ups and to see how they cope through the children they have. To see how different their children are and to see who they become. The story really is only the minimalist part of any Harry Potter books. It has magic but not what's expected. Not what we've been so spoiled by Ms Rowlings.  And how could it. The book is the play that is in production in England. I find myself without the proper words to describe this manifesto maybe because of the nostalgia I felt as I watched my child's excited face as she got the book she waited for so long for. And was brought back to myself pre children waiting for my Harry book and spending the night reading it. The main focus of this book is children and parents. And how the past affects the future. The author nailed it. I so wish I could give it a five star ratings but the thing troubling me is that this totally could have been a novel beloved by everyone because the story was perfect. It needed the extras the wild, magical beings describe like they have been in the past by JK Rowling. So it leaves me totally wondering why it wasn't a novel??? Over all it truly was wonderful. If you are an adult who read the books and has a child who loves the books as well, then this story will effect you and make you emotional. It is a fantastic read, and I hope that the author turns it into a novel. Enjoy!!!

author: Kyle Shultz
title: A fitting epilogue.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
An eighth Harry Potter story. At best, this sounds too good to be true. At worst, it sounds like a misbegotten cash-grab. Add to that the fact that the story was to be a play, not a novel or a film, and you have one of the most eyebrow-raising announcements in recent memory. So is "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" a worthy addition to the wizarding canon, or a complete dud? I'd have to say it falls somewhere between those two. I'll stick to mild spoilers only as I explain, but if you're determined to be completely surprised, I advise you to go in blind and form your own opinions. The book/play is definitely worth buying.

First, the bad. I don't really understand what's become of J.K. Rowling in recent years. She transformed the literary and cinematic realms with her Potter books, pioneering fantasy trends that continue to this day. I suppose she's trying to make stage plays more popular now? Not sure if that will take off, and it's kind of unfair for the many fans who can't afford to go see the play themselves. Those people are stuck with reading the script, which requires a lot more imagination to really enjoy. There's very little of Rowling's great descriptive prose on display, mostly just dialogue - and it's unclear how much of that was actually written word-for-word by her personally. It sounds like her style; I'll say that. But reading it definitely pales in comparison to reading an actual book. Frankly, I'm disappointed that Rowling hasn't taken the time to flesh this out into a novel. The same goes for the other Potter-related fiction she's written lately - the pre-Fantastic-Beasts pieces on Pottermore, to be precise. It's like reading pitches she hasn't bothered to turn into real books. Obviously, when you're as famous as Rowling, you can get away with posting your world-building notes online or having somebody else turn a story idea into a script and still have millions reading the stuff...but it smacks of laziness on her part, in my opinion.

Also, if you come to this book hoping for a new era of Harry Potter, you're going to be disappointed. This book is an epilogue to the original series, not the start of a new one. There's nothing ground-breaking. The mythology is not expanded, and the new characters spend most of their time dealing with the legacies of the original cast. I'm gratified that the wizarding world will be built up by the Fantastic Beasts film(s), but there's a lot of untapped potential in the modern Potterverse that isn't even touched in "Cursed Child".

So, basically what you've got is a skeletal "tribute" story that's not quite meaty enough to qualify as an eighth Potter book. What is there left to like, then?

What makes "Cursed Child" work despite all the strikes against it is what it does with the aftermath of the original stories. If "Deathly Hallows" had to have a follow-up in the first place, then this is a surprisingly good one. It's certainly an improvement on the frequently-criticized, rushed epilogue to "Hallows". This is basically an expansion of that last chapter, exploring what it's like for Albus Potter to grow up dealing with his famous dad's legacy. And it's very believable in that respect. True, Albus doesn't come across as likable until near the end of the book, and even Harry shows some striking flaws as a father. But given where both these characters are coming from, these problems make sense. It's not the forced "happily ever after" of the Hallows epilogue; it's complex and realistic. Plus, there's a very sympathetic, funny character in play in the form of Scorpius Malfoy, Draco's son. He ends up stealing the show, and is arguably the hero of the story in his own right. His lines made me laugh out loud more than once, and convinced me that to whatever degree Rowling was involved in writing this story, she's clearly still "got it".

The story, once you get past the awkward format, is gripping - I devoured it in one afternoon. There are quite a few surprises in store for hardcore fans. And on the whole, the tone is very appropriate for those who have "grown up" along with Harry. Fans who are now adults can relate with the themes explored here, even when characters mess up pretty badly. Harry certainly made plenty of his own mistakes over the years, and occasionally acted like a jerk. So I'd argue that it's worth giving Harry's progeny a chance, even if you don't take to him at first. At the very least, read it for Scorpius. I'm not saying you definitely won't be disappointed, but there are far worse ways for a Potter fan to bide the time until Fantastic Beasts gives us a more weighty addition to the Potterverse.

One final point - one or two people have criticized the fact that Albus and Scorpius aren't a couple (they're both portrayed as having female love interests). All I'll say on the subject is that it's refreshing, in an age obsessed with "representation", to see a strong friendship between two males depicted without any romantic element. I imagine many readers will find it disgracefully "heteronormative", but I liked it very much.

So, overall, I recommend this book. Just don't expect more from it than what it is - an enjoyable farewell to Harry Potter that doesn't disgrace the legacy of the original seven books, even if it does little to advance that legacy.

author: P June Mott
title: A potter look at time travel
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content: Enjoyed the book. Scripts require a bit of work.  Particularly enjoyed the ramifications of time travel.  Made me think of Time and Agsin.

author: PNWonderlander
title: Mischief Managed, At Last
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
After several hours of what felt like racing hippogriffs through my my head and holding on by the tips of my fingers, I reached the words "The End." Its been a while since I have read with such childlike voracity...not since the first time I read the original HP books at least. Never have I been so absorbed in my mind, removed from the world, or have experienced physical gasps of surprise and an influx of heartbeats. I'll deliver the ugly first: technically, the play is no masterpiece. It does not compare to the original story, and I am almost certain nothing will. But what I find extraordinarily transforming, striking, and satisfying about Cursed Child is its finality. I didn't realize when I finished the Original 7 that there was so much missing--so many words left aching to be delivered, resolutions to be undone and rewrapped. I felt my breath escape me within the play's pages. Moments and scenes left me achingly pounding and gloriously hungry.

What I love most--Cursed Child reintroduced all of the important characters and shuffled them off them with more care. Within the pages I heard voices of people I believed we would no longer hear from--and took them away just as gently...like catching a fish, tenderly unhooking it's squirming silver body, and laying it in the water again, witnessing its shimmering scales slink away. This time, I think, it was easier to leave the Wizarding World because I knew I had to.

Parts of the story itself felt a little overdone and rushed, but you must keep in mind that this addition is originally intended to be watched, not read, with delivery fitting under a specific window of time. For this I know I did not experience the full breath and absorption of Cursed Child during my read-through, and I am sure live-performance characteristics such as dialectic nuances and set transformations would definitely expand this work even more, but just reading the play itself took me back into this world of magic, mishap, and mischievousness that Potterheads are long-time familiar with. I am curious how the experience of watching it live differs, and cannot wait to see it when I have the chance.

Cheers to Jo and the team..the Wizarding World has gained a new accolade for its trophy case, another hidden passage way through which we may apparate home.

author: Sharon K. Harper
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2017
content: I'm anything harry!!!!

author: Kailyn B
title: Love hate relationship
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016

author: Melissa Burgos
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2016
content: Book jacket was not intact

author: Lulu Lopez
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2016

author: Habeas Opus
title: Excellent for what it is!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2016
content: I wasn't sure what to expect from a stage play, and I can't say I was disappointed...but I would have loved a novelized adaption of what really is a well-conceived and potentially complex story.  The plot is great, with laugh-out loud moments and real character development, but it just felt so rushed.  Makes me long for one of those sprawling 8-900 page novels with all the tiny details and languorous exposition.

author: Anthony L. Sprague
title: Is it worth while... Yes, but not how you might have hoped...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: The biggest difference I found in comparrison with all the other books, was that this was indeed a script... So if you intend on reading/buying this book you need to keep that in mind. Some people have even been saying that this does not live up to the hype, but I think it does ... it just suffers the fact that people are expecting it to be less like a script and more like a normal Harry Potter adventure ... If you are willing to get past the "Script" format though it does give a nice read. Perhaps not the conclusion or continuation we hoped for, but still fun none the less.

author: eonate
title: Honestly terrible writing but my inner child just had to have it
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2016
content:
So many plot holes! All I could do was focus on the plot holes while reading. And terrible writing style. It's just bad to begin with, and changes in obvious style at some point. Goes from absurdly bombastic to like casual at some point

Still, as a HP fan for literally like 17 years, I just had to get it. Although honestly I don't consider anything past the epilogue canon ;P

author: Amanda Bosch
title: I have to say I actually liked this. Yes it was odd to read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2016
content:
I have to say I actually liked this. Yes it was odd to read, but it is written in play format. Many of the characters were different from the original books, however I found that the 20 year time lapse could account for this. (At least it did in my mind)
I also wanted to say I liked the concept for the kids in this (I'm trying to avoid spoilers so bare with me.) Also I find the main antagonist's origins very plausible. Considering the obsession factor of the mother in that situation I could see it.
Overall I can't say much without spoiling it. But it's worth the read and for any die hard fan it's an interesting take!

author: Daniel Bratton
title: Strange but Good
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 3, 2017
content: Interesting read

author: mmcape
title: Enjoyabe , but don't expect the richness of a novel.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: Enjoyable- but know you are reading the script for a PLAY or you could feel much is missing. Recognizing that this is a play,  it was fun to be back in the world of Harry Potter and experience this next episode in their lives. What is missing is the depth of characters and, because it is a script and not a  book, know that the dept and nuisances will be added by the actors in the play.

author: A. Miller
title: Great life lessons
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2017
content: I enjoyed reading about the adventure of the next generation of wizards. The family lessons are commendable. It was an interesting take on changing the past and what it may do to offset the future. Well written.

author: Pearl
title: Very little justice done to what should have been a great story.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2016
content:
Giving this book only 4 stars is probably the result of my not having ever read a screenplay edition before...it may also be that this wasn't only J.K. Rowling's work, but rather a cooperative effort. The story itself, dealing with Harry's son, Albus, might have been everything I'd hoped it would be, had it not been for the problem that, in my opinion, the writing did not hold true to the standards to which I have come to look forward with Ms. Rowling's work. Differences in writing skills aside, I tried to see beyond the inconsistent style, to the meat of the story.

Dealing with the relationship between father and son, Albus' rebellion against who he felt people expected him to be, as Harry's son, and his discovery that he was more like his father than he thought, does make for an interesting evolution of the HP saga. In this tale, however, Albus just seems more like a pouting, rebellious child who feels put-upon by having a famous father. Unlike Harry, he seems to lack the noble character of his father at first, preferring a pity-party over 'sucking it up and dealing with' his life.

Albus doesn't seem to have the soul-deep, innate sense of honour that defined Harry (not to mention thevery deep type of person he appeared to be in the last scene of Deathly Hallows, both in the book and movie), and yet the reader is supposed to just love the little guy to death, simply because he's Harry's son? The blurb of the book indicates that we are to feel compassion for this child who is finding it hard to fill his father's shoes, but I stopped feeling sorry for him early on, even though there were still times that I sympathized throughout the story.

There was very little in this book that "fit" with the HP saga, from the grown up versions of Harry and Ginny, Ron and Hermione and Draco and his family...oh, yes and speaking of which, what was with the very thinly veiled inference to Scorpius' attraction toward Albus? If you're going to have the character gay, be up front about it...or if he wasn't (he did have a crush on Lily), at least delve a little deeper into what that attraction actually was: admiration? envy? brotherly love (sure didn't seem that way)? or maybe just a preteen questioning where his psyche lies? Better yet, leave it out altogether, because all it did was detract from the side-story of a deep friendship developing between two boys whose fathers were, at one time, enemies.

Now, this sounds like I didn't enjoy the book, but in truth, I found a lot to like about it, even if it wasn't very J.K.-ish.. However, to agree with another reviewer, it just seemed more like fanfic. Had it followed the character of the characters more closely, and played true to what we HP fans already know about the wizarding world after around twenty years or so of visiting, through books and movies, the book could have been exceptional. As it is, it was simply a pretty good read, IF you'd never been introduced to Harry and the gang.

This should have been a GREAT book, but there was no justice done to it.

author: Jennie T. Vander Helm
title: Interesting but disappointing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2016
content: After seeing the Harry Potter movies numerous times I decided to read this new book.  I was disappointed in the way it was written, in play form.

author: G-
title: A fun read for this HP fan.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: It was fun and mostly because I wanted the story to go on. Isn't that what a good story like HP gives you the desire for? If your a fan and realize it is a script not a fully developed novel then I think you will enjoy it. It closed out the story pretty well and honestly I believe Harry' story is done. I wouldn't mind if JKR went back someday and wrote a proper book for this story but I am fine with what we have. I hope I get to see this on stage that would wonderful.

author: Lowell C. Steward

author: Drew M

date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2016

author: Amazon Customer
title: Writting style different
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2016
content: The style of writting was much different then other books, so whatever you heard people say about it it's true. However it's still a great addition to the story of Harry potter.

author: Stuart
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: More of the same with the next generation.

author: Product Defender
title: Accio Nostalgia
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2016
content: Nostalgia draws you in, and nostalgia keeps you reading.  Book physical quality was in perfect condition, no damage or blemishes what so ever.  Be prepared for the format, presented in play script making it much more segmented requiring a more unique approach to reading then a typical Harry Potter novel.  It has plenty of the previous elements that make you love Harry Potter books but it just isn't the same deep connection as previous installments.  I still enjoyed the experience

author: Patricia Villali Koett
title: It's a good addition to the world of Harry Potter.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2016
content: Filled with the standards that make JK Rowling stories connect with readers ( family relationship and dynamics, friendship, expectations of one self and surprise twist) the story does not disappoint. I see the appeal but would have loved to have the story developed as a full novel. It seems that keeping the secrets has worked because to this day I had yet to be spoiled and am thrilled that I got to experience the story without spoilers. Of course the ending is satisfactory and I look forward to more from this world.

author: Jenny Guidry
title: Missed the depth of her novels
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2016
content: The story line was just as good as her original works, but because of the play format I missed the depth from the novels that draws you into that magical world.

author: Carroll Thronesbery
title: A good sequel
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2017
content: It starts out a little slow, but picks up nicely in classic Harry Potter style, with excitement and all the pieces fitting together just right.

author: Lisa Joyce Steele
title: A fitting epilogue
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: While I certainly missed the fullness of Rowling's writing style as demonstrated in the first seven novels telling Harry's story, I'm willing to look beyond that & accept this story as an enjoyable epilogue.

author: Incognetojen
title: The original series was better
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2016
content: It was an OK read.  The original series was better

author: Megan
title: Keep going
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 5, 2019
content: To be honest, it was difficult at first. Don’t read it directly after the series. Give yourself time to curate your journey. It is, of course brilliant. Keep going. Give yourself time. Understand it’s called the “cursed child” for a reason. Now you may proceed. Enjoy the journey.

author: Stephanie Farley
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2016
content: Not what I expected but I really enjoyed it.

author: Jordan Lopez
title: Wonderful to get back into the Harry Potter world
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: Wonderful to get back into the Harry Potter world, but it's hard to compare anything to the original. Harry Potter fans of all ages will enjoy it simple due to the nostalgia that arises. Unfortunately it left me wanting more, and only increased my want to be brought back into a world of witchcraft and wonder. For those on the fence, enjoy the magic, as brief as it may be.

author: pianomac
title: OK, but not all by Rowling.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 3, 2017
content:
This will of course be snapped up by the millions of Harry Potter fans, so criticism doesn't have much point! Since J.K.Rowling is not here the sole author, there are places where her voice doesn't come through completely, and there are a few disparities with the previous books. This is, after all, a play script. For example, previously the two Weasley twins ran their joke shop. but now their younger brother Ron is shown as the proprietor. Interesting characters from previous books are unmentioned.
  Of course scientific analysis of fantasies is rather pointless - who cares? -  but it occurs to me that all the various creatures described in earlier books could have been created by wizards and witches, and that includes elves, gnomes, trolls, giants, hippogriffs, centaurs... all are derivatives of human beings, designed for either usefulness or just whimsy.

author: Maya123
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 17, 2016
content: Wasnt like the others

author: Samantha McManus
title: Good story, but not great.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
content:
Let me preface this by saying I am the HP generation- I read each book as they where released in my preteen years.
I was excited about Cursed Child and had high expectations that were not met. Overall the story is good- I thought it was going in one direction and they threw a curveball in which was refreshing. It was also fast paced and a quick read. However, I felt as though some of the character choices didn't make sense and the book was still reliant on Harry.
Logistically, I am fascinated to know how they pull this off on stage as the scene is constantly changing. Some people may not appreciate the script (vs a novel) but I have a theatre background and liked reading it with each characters voice.

A good script, but don't get too worked up about it.

author: Crystal
title: Read a lot like published fanfiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2016
content: You can tell that Jo wasn't the main author here. Read a lot like published fanfiction, to be perfectly honest. Overall, it was an interesting story, and I'm glad to add it to my Wizarding World collection

author: Brenda Harrison
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 31, 2018
content: Arrived on time in good condition. No problem there. Just a disappointing story.

author: C. Rogers
title: Nice to extend the Harry Potter line, but nothing like the originals.
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2017
content:
I'll preface this by saying, I'm not a literary genius by any stretch of the imagination.  I enjoy reading, and thoroughly enjoyed the original Harry Potter books.  That being said, I enjoyed this "book"/playscript for what it was... just an added story to the Harry Potter storyline.  Nothing particularly special, no sense of continued wonder that was built through the original books.  I think that's one of the things I loved about the original books, there a constant sense of "ooooh, where is this going next?" and general speculation from book to book.  This was more of a short story, that didn't have that sense of wonder for me.  It told a pretty good story, but it definitely began and ended for me.

It took me a while to write this review.  I think after reading the Deathly Hallows, my imagination came up with an idea of what would happen to Harry and the rest of the gang.  Where they would go, and what they would do.  This book destroyed that, and I think that gave an immediate negative bias toward the story.  I had expectations that weren't met, but that shouldn't weigh in on whether it was a good story or not.  Here I am a year later, and I can say I did enjoy the story.  If you have similar thoughts about what happened to Harry and the gang after the Deathly Hallows, let it go before reading this.... read it as objectively as possible, and let it sit for a while before you really judge it.

author: Shy G.
title: My Thoughts on Harry Potter and the Cursed Child
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content: Very enjoyable. But this absolutely could have been another few books with more detail given.

author: Jessica
title: Interesting
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
content: It was different reading the story in play form but the story was exciting and kept me reading on and on. I'd love to see J.K Rowling's come out with a series with this new generation of wizards.

author: Frieda
title: I enjoyed it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2017
content:
I guess I don't like the script version of the story, it would have been better with a normal book script.

Having said that, I really enjoyed the story and the insight Harry and Albus have to learn about each other is wonderful.

author: Amazon Customer
title: HP fans enjoy!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2016
content: The HP fans in the house were eager to read the last book.  A light and quick read!  Can't say anything bad as I am a true fan!

author: S. Lauderdale
title: I want more!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content: I enjoyed this very much! It reminded me of how much I miss JK' s wizarding world and how much I wish there was more to come.

author: Jordan
title: It's really not that bad.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: I understand why people are upset that it is in the form of a script, but Rowling never mislead the fans to think it was gonna be anything other than that. Many say it is as bad as fan fiction, however, I feel they are not reading it like a script but like a book. A story plays put much differently on stage and in a script than in a book where the author controls everything and let's you peek inside the characters' heads. Is this the best story the Harry Potter Universe has to offer? No. Is it bad enough to be called fan fiction? Definitely not.

author: BGG
title: Eh. It had a beginning, middle and end.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2018
content: Reading script format was weird but the plot/storyline was unique. So used to audiobook with Jim Dale reading. Thumbs up.

author: KM
title: A nice trip back into the land of Hogwarts
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content: After reading reviews, I had decided NOT to read this book, but then a friend who is also a big HP fan read it and enjoyed it, so I gave it a go. I enjoyed it thoroughly. Maybe because I had low expectations for it? I think if you are reading this expecting it to be as good as or exactly like any of the original 7 books, you will be disappointed.  But it was enjoyable, and a great way to revisit the world of Harry Potter that I love and miss. It definitely has limitations being written as a script, and it isn't on par with the novels by any means, but it doesn't mean that it doesn't have value of it's own. Is it the kind of fleshed out 8th book that JK Rowling would have written if she were to written a full novel on her own, of course not. But it was fun to read, fun to get a bit of Harry Potter back and I devoured it in one sitting basically. Glad I read it , despite the negative criticism surrounding it. I especially have to laugh a bit at everyone whining about Harry's "moral integrity" and that this character would NEVER do this or that.... which come on, is ridiculous...  did we all forget what a whiney, surly, self absorbed JERK Harry was for book number 5? yeah. he doesn't always take the high road. I guess I read this more as a story about the kids than a deep dive into the psyche of Harry, Ron and Hermoine... there are parts that I rolled my eyes at, but for an entertaining few hours, which is basically what I am looking for in a book, it was perfect.

author: CKeeney
title: Decent read
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2016
content: I enjoyed it but would have liked it a bit better if not presented as a play.  I love the characters as always. I would have liked to have had a bit more development in the scenes. Not much suspense and scenes ended quickly with little real drama. Still.....it is another Harry Potter book

author: Amazon Customer
title: A very good book to read
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content:
A very good book to read. Back into the world of Harry Potter.
Only negative thing about the book is that it is written in screen play style.

author: Dilabel
title: Good
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2016
content: I would of like it much better if it would of been in a reading format opposed to the play script.  I liked the story line.

author: MJ
title: Writing doesn't feel like JK's
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
content: Firstly, I know JK wasn't the only author of the book. I liked the book but it just didnt feel like reading one of the other harry potter books. While reading, I could actually tell which parts were wrotten by JK and which were written by the other authors. Her voice and candor as an author just feels so familiar; I didnt get that connection with this book

author: Wayne-daniel Berard
title: Cursed Child Succeeds -- Eventually!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content:
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is a lot of fun -- after the first several scenes. Avoiding spoilers as much as possible, I think it safe to say that the major interpersonal conflict in the play's plot could have been established much more quickly; the beginning I found tedious and repetitive. Once this was out of the way, however, the pace moves along quite nicely. There are flashbacks to the books/films which are brief enough not to slog things down, but that, as a fan, I found delightful. A major event in one of the books/films is a primary vehicle for plot advancement here; this is done quite well, when it could have easily been a retreading disaster.

That being said, of the two main characters, Albus Potter and Scorpius Malfoy, the former, though the main figure, is wooden and, frankly, not that interesting. Scorpius is the real scene-stealer; he's quirky, extremely likable, and much more real than his counterpart. He truly made the play for me.

Like the books themselves, much is predictable here. One can see immediately who the truly menacing character will turn out to be; the "true meaning" of the curse over the child is patently obvious (to everyone but those on stage). And when, oh when, will Ron Weasley's character be allowed to be anything more than comic relief? Still, if you love the series, this book will grab you at least by Act Two, and provide you a fun, engaging, and entirely worthwhile experience. At first, I felt prepared for disappointment. By its finish, I was psyched for the inevitable film -- and the next installment!

author: georgia pelletier
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2016
content: I enjoyed the book, but wasn't crazy about haven't it in the stage plot.

author: Kat_Kit
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2016
content: Ron became the comic relief, other than that the book came pristine

author: Rebecca L. Bowen
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: Because of it being a play, it didn't read as smoothly as if it had been prose.

author: Alec Applebaum
title: Once you get used to the format its a good read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: The neat thing about this book is how it approaches the classic material from a different viewpoint so to speak.  Would I have liked it better as a straight story? Yes, but I still enjoyed it and would recommend it if you are already a fan.

author: Paul Jutras
title: there a new potter in Hogswarts
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
the play script format of writing took a few chapters to get use to but as I got more into the story the more I pictured in my head what it might look like on stage.  I do wonder if Rowling had more to do with the story if Harry would of ended up with the job he got as reading the original books I always pictured him becoming Hogswarts dark arts teacher.  I found that the children  James, Al and Rose charming  and family structure only hinted at in the epilogue of the deadly hollows book/movie expanded on to be great to read about.  I really like  Harry and the lot including Draco Malfoy as adults replacing their childhood problems with new ones as they try to deal with things differently that the old Ministry of magic had.  i do give it 4 stars because I did really like it but unlike the other Potter books that I read in a day I did not love this one and found myself able to set it down.  like films such as Back to the Future or season 5 final of My little pony the more Al and Scorpius time travel the worst  things change for the present.

makes one wonder if a new Harry Potter movie will come out of this or not.

author: Talysha09
title: but still a fun adventure.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: The story was a little strange, but still a fun adventure.

author: Sarah
title: I thoroughly enjoyed this book
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2016
content:
I thoroughly enjoyed this book. I will say, however, that it feels a little bit like fan-service. That being said, it was a pleasure to read and the storyline touched on many memories from the original book series, using them as a point of reference for much of this adventure.

As an avid Harry Potter fan, I think this was a great read and I look forward to someday seeing the screenplay!

author: Lanin D. Thomasma (lanindt@juno.com)
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content: Bummer about Ron.

author: Laura Snow
title: Cursed,child review
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Pretty good of course prefer never format but good story lines . Overall enjoyable

author: Bear
title: ... All our yesterdays have lighted fools the way to dusty death.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: While the pacing of the play seems a bit choppy and the characters are not developed as deeply as could be done in a novel format, this script brings to life both Harry Potter's younger son, Albus Severus, and Draco Malfoy's son, Scorpius. The two become unlikely friends facing not only the usual causes of teen angst, but also the shadows of their famous (or infamous) parents. When they learn that Cedric Diggory's father still blames Harry for the death of his son, the two hatch a plot to "set things right", only to learn the hard way the dangers of trying to rewrite history. In the process, both learn what their true selves are like and what the people around them really mean to them.

author: Shawna Uldrick
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 24, 2017
content: Pretty good

author: J. White
title: I’d recommend to anyone who has read the series...
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 12, 2018
content: I recently read all 7 of the Harry Potter books and got this as a Christmas present. A lot of people I know said it was garbage and that it was frustrating to have 7 books as Harry grew up but not for his son. I get that, but it’s not the same thing. I thought the book was good, there were some things that bugged me I suppose (referring to Hagrid’s cake as saying “Happy Birthday Harry” was the first). I concluded it would’ve been better if J.K. Rowling had written it alone. You get used to the play format - it’s very easy to read. It was nice to have a reunion with everyone. Overall, it’s not amazing but if you’ve read the original books, why not read this one? Oh, and if you’re like me, the hard cover copy lines up perfectly with the hard covers of the original series, so that’s a nice bonus :)

author: Lesley W Christien
title: A short but lovely visit back to the Wizarding World
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: It's a play of course, so you are reading dialogue and stage directions, but it is an adventure that lets you peek into the next generation. Short but bittersweet. I hope I can see the play.

title: This was too shallow
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 28, 2017
content: The novels developed the characters so that you could visualize them. Okay, it helped that the first movie came out shortly after the novel, but it was more rich in details. That being said, it was an enjoyable play to read. It would be great if the original cast could be brought together with the new actors & actresses and make a full screen movie of this, developing the characters a bit more.

content: I liked the characters and the story. I dont give 5 stars because they didnt expand the universe, only stuck to spells, characters and locations of the past

author: Jinny
title: Great to be back in that world again!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
The stage directions do take some getting used to, my son is 10 years old and while he says he is following it, it does look like it is a bit confusing for him. As a play it can't go into much depth, so it's more like HP lite. While I wish it had been written in a book format with more character development, there were several unexpected plot twists that kept me entertained. Overall, it was a fairly quick read. Despite the story wrapping up almost too neatly, I still thoroughly enjoyed it. I just loved being back in that world again!

For parents, I think this book is more geared toward a slightly older audience - at least one who understands the birds and the bees! I don't think it is any darker than any of the other HP books, but (I don't think this is a spoiler but just in case stop here)

there are questions of paternity that may bring up some interesting conversations for those of us with slightly younger kids!

date: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2017
content:
Do not expect this to be another book in the Harry Potter series. As a screenplay,  it is mostly dialogue. It is not the richly written book that the rest of the series is. Much of the richness comes from actually seeing the play (which I have seen in London). It is based on the series but is not written by  J K Rowling.

After a brief time, I got used to the format and enjoyed the story. But without all the descriptive portions, I found it to  be easily forgettable. In fact, I had not remembered much of the plot so re-read it prior to seeing the play.

The book kept my attention and tied up some loose ends from the Harry Potter books. You can definitely tell that J. K. Rowling didn't write the book by herself, which probably upsets the  purists, but I was just happy to have another Harry Potter book!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Great Script!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2016
content: While it was clear this wasn't JK Rowling's work (she just has a way with words...), it was wonderful and comforting to revisit these beloved characters. The story was clever and well-written, and I was able to clearly visualize everything. I read it in one sitting, so it definitely had me engrossed (and it was an easy read). I know others have complained about the play format, but I knew when I ordered it that it was a script, not a novel. If you are a big Harry Potter fan, I recommend at least giving it a shot. I think you'll enjoy it.

author: Mike Scott
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016

author: Molly
title: I expected to hate this but I kind of liked it
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content: I expected to hate this but I kind of liked it. First of all, it isn't really by J. K. Rowling and it isn't (much) about Harry Potter. It's about his bullied and alienated son Albus Severus. The only surprise is how beastly Harry and his wizard demographic turned out; prepare to be disillusioned. There is much time traveling, Back to the Future style (trying to fix bad stuff in the past). This gets annoying after a while. The final father-son confrontation is predictable but satisfying. The dialogue is well-written. Not sure how kids and real fans of Harry Potter would take all this...

author: Lucas P.
title: CRAZY BOOK
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: This book was a journey. I laughed, I cried, and I was very very confused. This script took about 2 1/2 hours to read, and I didn't enjoy every second of it, but it was fun to read. Some things were weird and it didn't really have the same "Harry Potter" vibe as the other books. But, of course, this is play and is meant to be performed, and the visual is a crucial part to the story. I'm sure that just the script doesn't do the play justice. Overall, I loved reading this, and I was pleasantly surprised with all the plot twists. I would definitely recommend this book to Potter lovers that appreciate different forms of art.

author: Granny Gee 50
title: Enjoyed the read....

author: thehogwartsreader07
title: Interesting book...but not truly the "8th HP book."
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Going into this, I knew that this book was only "overseen" by JKR, and not really "written." I waited at a bookstore until midnight to get it.

I must admit, I quite liked it. I am a tried-and-true Potterhead, and even though it wasn't written by JKR herself, the book did stay somewhat true to the characters, etc. To me, it did feel like a couple books crammed into one. There could have been so much more character development and scene development going on. BUT, you have to remember that THIS IS A SCRIPT FOR THE PLAY, and not an ACTUAL BOOK. I could tell that JKR's writing style was somewhat used, and the story was actually really interesting.

There were some things that I didn't quite understand that could have been explained a little more: see below (spoilers).

WARNING: SPOILER ALERT

1) Voldemort and Bellatrix Lestrange had a daughter who was born before the Battle of Hogwarts. How did no one know about her??? She made an appearance in the 8th book, and nobody knew who she was to begin with!
2) The whole thing where Harry and Albus don't get along well. That's not cool.
3) Severus Snape makes an appearance. He is not true to his character in the book series, and it kind of made me a little upset that he wasn't all snotty, sarcastic, etc.
4) Dolores Umbridge runs basically a cult at Hogwarts where they pretty much worship Voldemort. It's not cool, and kind of degrades the image of Scorpio (Draco's son...who the students call the "Scorpion King" when Albus and he go back in time).
5) The Time-Turners I actually liked. What I didn't like was how someone "made" a TT out of metal. It wasn't very believable.

So, all in all, I did like the book. It's hard to consider it the "8th Harry Potter book" because it just isn't JKR's writing style. It was very good and entertaining, but it did feel slightly rushed. I do recommend buying it to read it because it was interesting and you learn a lot about some of the characters that you didn't know before.

title: I find it hard to keep with the constant jumping ...

content: I find it hard to keep with the constant jumping around of time.  But it is Harry Potter and I will read it anyways.  With that in mind I think I would have preferred to get this from the library before I would have considering buying it.

title: it leaves out all of what I consider being the great parts of a written story
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2016
content: It was very Harry Potter. It was also relying on us to know Harry Potter. Written as a script, it leaves out all of what I consider being the great parts of a written story. There is little exposition (because that is what a script requires) and I think I missed that. As a story, ​it was enjoyable but very predictable. I think it is a valuable edition to the series and am pleased to see Rowling branching out into other forms of storytelling and her promotion of a less popular art that needs a champion. All in all, don't miss out on this story if you like the Potterverse.

author: soulsurfingrev
title: It's Great, But With A Few Exceptions
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content:
I'm 12 years old and I'n writing this review with my mom's account. I got this book from Amazon a few days after it came out and read the whole thing in one day. I would have rated this book five stars, but I only rated it four for a few reasons-
* The book is written in script format, since it was based off a play, which is kind of annoying, but once you get used to it it's just as good as reading a normal book.
* Some bits of the story, like the Trolley Witch, seem a bit ridiculous (but isn't the whole Harry Potter series that way?)
* Rose Granger-Weasley and James Sirius Potter are barely in it, and Teddy Lupin isn't in it AT ALL.

But overall it's great <3 It's really cool to read about Harry, Ron, Hermione, and Draco (unfortunately, Neville and Luna aren't in it) in the future and it was also really cool to learn more about their kids (especially Scorpius)

I would totally recommend buying this book if you're a Harry Potter fan!

title: I'm a true Harry Potter Fan

author: Sabrina
title: All you original HP Fans it's worth a read. :)
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
It was far better than I though it would be. I was against pre-ordering since this is just a printed script but I bought it today anyway. If your hoping for a full fledged novel this might not be for you but it does have a interesting story.

This story takes place years and years after the events of the original series. The characters from the original books all have children who don't always seem to follow in their parents footsteps. Albus Potter and his father's relationship is strained and becomes even more so strained throughout the script.

Scorpius Malfoy is a charming character and by far my favorite in this story. Albus and Scorpius becomes friends and go on a journey to try to save someone from the past. This doesn't go according to plan.

I've read some reviews that say this story is very fanfiction like and though I can see where these are coming from...there is still some magic in this story. This is coming from a 90's kid who read the books when they first came out. Give it a try.

The character development could stand a little... development, as well. That's not to say the story wasn't wholly enjoyable in and of itself. We were both on our laptops looking for tickets to the West End production within minutes of finishing. So if you're a Harry fan, you'll definitely want to pick it up.

author: L. Cooper
title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child - whens the movie going to be produced?
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2016
content:
This is a play script, not a book. But still it reads like it fits right in with the other Harry Potter novels. Basically, the story starts off right where the postscript of the movie Death Hallow part 2 left off, with Harry, Ginny and sons at Platform 9 3/4 as Albus Severus Potter prepares to leave for his first year at Hogwarts and is worrying about being sorted into Slytherin.

I will try to avoid spoilers, but let's just say Albus makes best friends with Scorpius Malfoy, who seems to have fallen far from his father's and grandfather's tree.

There's a timeturner involved, a prophecy, and the return of Voldemort.

That should be enough to get you hooked.  For me, I am waiting for the play to come to the USA and then I have to figure out how to secure some of the tickets which will may be sold out for decades in advance.

And if you figure it out, tell me who the cursed child is supposed to be.

title: while it's a great story, it's not the same
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2016
content:
I was very excited to read this new Harry Potter book!

Having high expectations, even though I knew it wasn't solely written by JKR, I read it in one day.

The way I describe it as such: while it's a great story, it's not the same. The flow and way the characters act do not correlate with the original books. You can tell that JKR didn't write a lot of it, it just doesn't have her flair (her imagination is there,  but character development was very much lost).

That being said, good story,  but don't go in comparing it to the other books, if you compare it,  you'll be very much disappointed.

content: I'm a huge Harry Potter fan. When I first heard about a "new" Harry Potter book, of course I went crazy about it. But when I discovered it was some kind of script, I was not so crazy about it anymore. Afterwards, a lot of friends who read it recommended the reading. Even so I was incertain about the book. Anyways, I finally bought it and read it in no time. And, even though the book have a very interesting story, it's not Harry Potter style at all. It was not written by J.K Rowling and yes, it is a play's script, which means it's a very straightforward narrative. The lack of details and descriptions made me not fall in love with this book. It coud be an amazing story if written by J.K. Rowling, but as it is, it's not. So, if you don't want to dive into the magical world of Harry Potter through a rich detailed novel, only want to know the "whos", "whens" and "hows", I think you could like it better than me.

author: Destiny Jade
title: Nice moments, too little detail
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: Let me start off by saying I am a huge Harry Potter fan. I did however, brace myself prior to reading this book. I was aware that J.K. Rowling was most likely only minimally involved and that it wasn't going to read the same since it was a screen play. I think that knowledge and preparation made it easier for me to enjoy this book. The biggest issue with it? That was probably the fact that it tried to do so much with so little. Plays have to be short enough to sit through, yet this one spanned great amounts of time and jumped around. It therefore lacked the detail necessary at times to make plot twists believable. I found myself sitting there wondering 'how?' and 'why' way too many times. I think that was the hardest part for most Potter fans and why so many say it reads like a fanfic. It simply doesn't take the time to develop and explain things and simply relies on people taking everything in stride. That being said, I felt there were some truly 'Harry Potter' moments. I got a little teary eyed and nostalgic at times, and that is really why I enjoyed it. I would not recommend comparing this to the books. There is no contest. It has no where near the talent in it that they did. That being said, it certainly has a place in the Harry Potter world.

content: The story of albus and Scorpio are fun.  It's nice to see the aftermath of Harry Potter coming to terms with the s***ty situations fumble sore put him through.  Time travel however is a tired plot device and the story could have made better use of it like in what was in the third book

author: Thoughtbloom
title: Go in with an open mind . . .
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2016
content:
This was a really great story about overcoming the past, family, and the power of friendship. The beginning was a bit slow as they set up the characters of Albus Severus Potter and Scorpius Malfoy. The second half bumped up my opinion of the book considerably once we got into the meat of the plot. It just took awhile to get there. Basically, Albus Severus is trying to go back in time to right a wrong of his father's but ends up messing up the fabric of time. I really enjoyed seeing how small changes altered the current reality so much. The friendship between the two boys was really great and reminded me of the trio in its strength and resolve. Some of the older generation felt a bit out of character at the beginning but I feel like the characters kind of found themselves again but the end of the book.

This isn't really just another Harry Potter book so don't expect it to be like the other ones. Go in with an open mind to a slightly different writing style, an entirely different format, and new characters. It is a good read but some die hard Harry Potter fans might be a bit let down if they were really looking for a direct continuation of the seven books JK Rowling wrote about Harry Potter.

content: I don't understand why there is so much hate on this book. Is this the best Harry Potter book from the series? No. But it is a nice addition to the world of Harry Potter characters and to me it reads quite nicely. Though because it is written as a play script, you have to read it back as such. Going into this book knowing that it will and should read differently is the key. The story itself I think is above average with enough plot twists to keep the readers (at least me) interested and flipping through the pages. You can't be mad at JK for licensing out the story because we've all wanted another one so badly and she wouldn't write more. So this is the next best thing, take it or leave it.
