author: RDD
title: A Nice Return to the Wizarding World
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
J.K. Rowling's return to the Wizarding World in "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child - Parts One & Two" picks up with the epilogue from "Deathly Hallows", where Harry and Ginny's youngest son, Albus Severus Potter, prepares to leave for Hogwarts. There, he makes friends with Draco Malfoy's son, Scorpius, as the two bond over being outcasts who inherited legacies from their parents. Without delving into spoilers, the story primarily focuses on family relationships and the idea of sins of the father passing on to the subsequent generation. Harry, despite having a rich surrogate family, struggles to be a good father. In fact, all of the main characters who grew up during the original novels struggle in adulthood, likely a result of childhoods that were filled with danger and war. Despite this, they still care about their own children and want to shelter them from growing up with the struggles they endured, though they often go about this as blunderingly as Dumbledore in "Order of the Phoenix".
There are several nice callbacks to the original novels, with cameos and even significant roles from old favorites. Professor McGonagall gets to chastise Harry and friends as adults, saying to Albus, "The lesson even your father sometimes failed to heed is that bravery doesn't forgive stupidity" (p. 201). Rowling also knows when to let the full weight of a scene play out and several scenes return to the most poignant and tear-inducing moments in Rowling's original seven novels. Finally, the title itself is something of a riddle, leaving it up to the audience to determine just who is the "cursed child" as there are many candidates. "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" continues the rich world Rowling introduced in 1997 and will leave the audience begging for more stories of Albus Severus and Scorpius.

title: A bit mixed, but generally positive.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 2, 2017
content: This play has received a lot of mixed reviews from people. I definitely enjoyed reading it, but it wasn't exactly what I expected. I loved reading Rowling's style and delving into the magical world of Harry Potter and his friends, but it just didn't flow as easily as the other books in the series did. The characters also seemed a bit off and a little one-dimensional compared to the rest of the series. Perhaps it's because we only had one volume to get to know the characters as opposed to the seven in the original series? Perhaps it was the format of a script rather than the traditional novel? Perhaps there was too much hype about the fact that there was another book in the series? I'm not sure. I'm glad that Rowling wrote this script though, it was nice to have some new Harry Potter back into my life.

author: Greggorio!
title: THE MAGICS BACK AND ITS GREAT!!!!!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
THIS MUCH PUBLICISED story of the sons and daughters of Harry Potter, Ron Weasley and the one and only Hermione Grainger, is certainly an enigma.  Some readers will love it, some will hate it.  Some (or most) will probably fall approximately into the middle.  Personally I take it for what it is – the script for a play which has huge entertainment value, a surprisingly strongly emotional ending, as well as a plethora of plot twists and turns along the way.  It is certainly well structured, avoiding the tediousity (is that a word?) of unnecessary lessons and introductions and steep learning curves and exams that we all have fond memories of, and instead, focusing on the relationship (or in some cases, the lack thereof) which make up life in the world of witches and wizards.

Oh, and there’s an adventure to be had, too, and its a doosie.  As i mentioned above, once the story gets going, the plot twists and turns more frequently than the mighty Amazon River.  Naturally it is not as deep or as moving as the full length novels which created this extraordinary and world changing legend.  The star of the show is undoubtedly SCORPIUS, the lone son of Draco Malfoy.  And what a sad story *that* is.  He (SPOILERS) befriends Albus Potter (son of Harry and Ginny) in chapter one and the reader doesn't look back.  Some of the lines he comes out with will make all readers, especially adults, burst out laughing over and over again.  Once you get used to the writing and publishing style of the book, it becomes a joy to read.  There is no great depth here, so adjust your mind set from the great times and adventures of books 1 through 7 before commencing.  New characters are a bonus, especially one in particular (SPOILERS) whom the reader will meet and be suitably impressed with on the Hogwarts Express.

Having said that, it *is* hard at times, thinking of the world saving trio of Ron, Harry and Hermione as grown up adults, each with adult and muggle based responsibilities of their own to manage and deal with.  What is not difficult to accept is the rambunctious goings-on of the two main characters studying magic (as a part time hobby) but also managing to saving the world, and coincidentally preventing the dreaded the return of You Know Who in the process.  Scorpius is a gorgeous character, full of life and live, and wisdom, and enthusiasm to make things right, even if he hates the Greatest Wizard The World Has ever Known Who Happens to Be His Father.

The utlimate solution to the puzzle of preventing the return of You Know Who is brilliant.  In typical JK fashion, hints are scattered throughout the book for the eagle eyed observer to pick up and analyse.  I am thefirst to confess I did not see it all coming, but i much prefer to  sit back and enjoy the show instead of wasting precious amounts of mental concentration trying to predict what is about to happen.

So the book is finished.  I loved it.  As i have said above, it is not as long, deep or complex as the classics from the past but its a great way for veterans to extend the most unique fantasy universe ever created.  If nothing else, once read, it gives the reader strong encouragement to revisit the wonder, excitement, pure innocence and absolute genius of the original books sooner than you normally would have.  And that can’t be a bad thing, can it?

Four stars for this fantastic but slighty short read.

author: Pete S
title: A great addition to the Potterverse, but remember it's a play script
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
I feel like a lot of the reviews forgot that this is a script for a stage play.

The dialog is a bit corny, as plays tend to be. They don't have the luxury of movie closeups and have to be oddly descriptive in dialog.

It's a good story and I imagined it on a stage as I read it, which is the main reason I think I enjoyed it so much. It added a new layer to the life of Harry Potter and gave excellent context for the lives of the characters after the last book.

Part 2 was far more exciting than part 1, but both were very enjoyable.

There are 2 reasons why I knocked it down a star...

1. There's a contradiction with the last book on Harry's scar.
2. Ron's character feels... Off... From how he was portrayed in the books.

Aside from those 2 things, I highly recommend this to any Potter fan but I urge you all to remember that this is a play, not a full book, and to keep that in mind as you go through it.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Remember, it is a play...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
I could not wait for this book to arrive.  Then I saw the ratio of 5 stars to 1 star reviews.  I was nervous.  I decided to go into this book understanding that this was not part of the original seven books.  It has Ms. Rowling's name on it but it is not solely her project.  I am glad I took this stance before cracking it open.  I enjoyed it while I was reading and am happy to add it (as a companion piece) to the rest of the collection.  The more I think and talk about the book, though, the more excited I get.  I mean, it's Harry Potter!

I do understand why some have said that there is little to know character development.  Things move quickly - almost whiplash-inducing quickly - but, again, this is a play; a script and (much like a movie) three hours cannot be spent on character evolution.  As an admirer of the original series, I missed "growing up" with Albus like we did with Harry but I was also thankful that, as the reader, I was spared the nitty-gritty details and was placed directly into the story.  Besides, it picked up precisely where Deathly Hallows left off.

I laughed more than I expected and there was definitely a few instances where I sighed and placed my hand over my heart at the mention of certain characters.  I would like to see the performance.  Given the stage directions, I think it would be an experience for the senses - as it does not just seem to be visual/audible cues.

I recommend this book to the lovers of the HP series so long as you do not try to fit it in the same pretty and precise little box.

content: I know, I know...it's Harry Potter.  I am a big fan too but found this script (I liked that it was a script) was rather messy for her normal fare.  It got better as one got into it, but didn't ever like Harry again.  Good story and plot as always though.  I can't in my wildest imagination think of sitting through five hours of it in a theater however.

I think younger teens will enjoy this more than adults who grew up with the original stories directly from J.K.Rowling herself.
It was definitely worth taking time to read and visit the magical world of Harry Potter that we all love so much.

This is not a novel, not JK Rowling, and lacks the magic (ahem) that came from discovering the wizarding world and Hogwarts in the original series. This will remain separate from the true Harry Potter series in my mind. I feel that one can appreciate Cursed Child on its own if one has appropriate expectations. I wouldn't turn down tickets to the play! ;)

author: Whowouldn't
title: Worth every minute. Will finally quench peoples Harry Potter thirst once and for all.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
4.5

I actually really liked this—for what it is. It was a quick nostalgic read. I loved the classic Harry Potter characters and found myself really enjoying the new characters, as well. The story was solid enough and just the right length. It definitely concludes the story/series, especially those few pages at the end of the last book. So, I'm glad everything was neatly wrapped up. (And finally puts this beautiful series to rest) We were able to visit the wizardly world one last time.

**really fantastic - really puts you back into JK Rowling's world.

author: Adrienne
title: So this is what's it like when J.K. Rowling writes fan fiction.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
You know, this was fun. In its way. In a way of two very excitable Potter enthusiasts writing a fanfic and getting J.K. Rowling's approval to produce it on stage. All good fun. Just not Harry Potter as we know it. MILD SPOILER. When Hermione took on Snape's personality, though, they just about lost me. In no way, never, ever, ever, would Hermione turn into that of a bitter waspish witch (meant in derogatory terms here, pardon), even out of unrequited love. Never. Not our champion of justice and equality for all. This was the most glaring flaw I could find. Oh, and I STILL can't figure out who the Cursed Child is. Delphi, I suppose. But it just doesn't feel like the answer. It will much better play than it did a book, hopefully.
SERIOUS SPOILER. Voldemort and Bellatrix, though. Eww. I once wrote a Mugglenet editorial on that very point (sadly, lost now), but still. The very idea.

While I am a fan of the original Harry Potter stories and would have given every one of them a 5-star rating, I had no such expectation for "The Cursed Child."  When I read it, I was pleasantly surprised.  It has many of of the intricacies of plot twists, the creative wizardly content, and elements of real mystery that the original Potter stories contained.

author: TMan
title: Flaws and all, this Potterhead LOVED it!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content:
Let me begin by saying that I am a HUGE Harry Potter fan. The first book came out when I was 13, and the first film at 17, so I spent much of my teens and young adult years completely immersed in JK Rowling's world.

Seeing as this totally influences my objectivity of writing a proper review, my personal opinions of "The Cursed Child" should be taken with a grain of salt.

I personally loved this addition to the wizarding world that JKR created. It was lovely to be able to see the characters I grew up with as adults and get to know their children. Part of what I loved about this play is that despite the grand instances of fantasy, there were very relatable themes present throughout the script. Preteens/Teenagers struggling with who they are and their place in the world, parents facing challenges in connecting with their children and worrying about screwing them up...people trying to do their best to live a solid, good and productive life.

I have read the endless complaints surrounding the script, from the text not being reflective of the world JKR gave us to dramatic plot points being a bit overkill considering the context. Was it a bit heavyhanded on plot? Yes. Did it provide us with numerous instances where our characters behaved completely out of character? Absolutely.

But at the heart of the script, found within even its more hair pulling plot points, I saw the soul of what lead so many of us to fall in love with Harry Potter in the first place. In my opinion, the play remained loyal to what the original series was able to achieve, and that is why I consider myself a fan of the new play.

Scripts shouldn't be seen as the full picture. Reading dialogue and character actions in script format pales in comparison to seeing the play acted out. It's a completely different art form, and what talented actors are able to do with script material when put to action goes above and beyond what is being depicted in just the written script. Those of us only able to read the play aren't able to see the art form as its intended, which must be considered when properly reviewing the play.

So I loved it. I read the entire thing from start to finish in a matter of hours, and found myself laughing out loud and shedding more than a few tears throughout the experience.

From one Potterhead to another, I wholeheartedly recommend "The Cursed Child"...provided everyone remember that reading a play's script and actually seeing it performed are two entirely different things.

author: Sarah
title: Great next adventure
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: It was wonderful to revisit the world of Harry Potter. I have it 4 stars only because I found it a tiny bit predictable. It was a wonderful read and very enjoyable. I would highly recommend it.

author: Peachmoutain

date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content:
Good book, not as good as the first ones.  It is written in play form, which is not bad, just different.  Interesting to see how
Harry and Ron's lives changed as they got older and how their kids lives were progressing.

author: SearFoxx
title: I had to get used to reading Ms. Rowling's ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2016
content: I had to get used to reading Ms. Rowling's work in a screenplay format. Beyond that, I have found it very enjoyable.

author: K.Gau
title: Surprisingly Good
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: I delved into this book with mixed feelings. I had high hopes for this book but had also read many negative reviews. Having read it today I can tell you it is the worth reading. For me personally this story confirmed many theories I had about the plot and characters and also surprised me with many unexpected plot points. This is also a book of contradictions. While some characters are barely involved and remain very two dimensional, others are explored vividly and very well fleshed out. For me the biggest disappointment in the story was the main conflict which at times was redundant, predictable and a bit ridiculous. However, the relationship explored between Harry and his son Albus is what makes the book worth reading in my opinion, and is well explained. For many Harry Potter fans who have their own ideas of what happened after Dealthy Hallows you may be disappointed. However, if you read with an open mind I think for most this will be a great read and addition to the Harry Potter world.

author: JFR
title: Not nearly as bad as some of these "die-hard" fans want you to believe
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 1, 2018
content:
To start: IT'S NOT THAT BAD.

As with the rest of the reviewers, I too am a huge Harry Potter fan. I've read the books and the entire lot of content. After reading the reviews, I didn't even want to read the play. I put it off for some time. But finally, I decided to sit down and read it.

So, a few things:

Most of the characterization is fine. Albus says things a misunderstood teenager would say. Harry says things an overworked adult with a teenage son would say. In my opinion, nothing about their interactions seems unbelievable. Thinking Harry would not say certain things says to me that the reader has no children or doesn't understand how difficult being a parent can be. Those two aside, the other characterizations seem fine too, even Ron getting drunk at his wedding.

Over all, I thought the play was fine! My biggest issue was the general plot---the whole idea of the "cursed child" (I won't say more as not to spoil) seems unrealistic (humorous for a fictional series about wizardry). I don't see that storyline fitting in with the original series. That was my biggest problem with the play.

That aside, I found the characterization believable. Give the play a chance. Will I consider it cannon? Probably not, but certainly still worth a read for any Harry Potter fan.

author: brxey
title: 3.5 Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content:
So here's the thing-- this has to be taken for what it is. 1-J.K. Rowling didn't actually write this--she was working on fantastic beasts at the time and was kind of just an advisor for this project. And 2-this is really meant to be seen on stage.
The story itself is not that believable to me; having read the original books, there's a lot that doesn't add up. If you read this with the mindset of enjoying it like non-canon fan fiction I think it's more enjoyable.
When seen live, I've heard the effects they use for magic are astounding and I think that is probably the main selling point of the actual play. In terms of reading this I think the best part is Scorpius Malfoy. Everything he says and does is great--which probably has a lot to do with the fact that we knew pretty much nothing about him from the original other than his name.
All in all, for a die hard fan it's worth a read, and for someone who is only a casual fan or has only seen the movies, this might get confusing because there are some characters and events mentioned that weren't in the films.

author: JSiv
title: Want to see it on stage
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
I've seen and heard a lot of negativity about the plot, but rave reviews about the actual performance of the play. I hope I get an opportunity to see it as it's meant to be.

 As for all the bad comments about the plot, no, it wasn't the best story in the world. It definitely doesn't live up to the magic of Rowling's seven book series, but you know what, I don't care. It was so much fun to be able to escape into this world again for the telling of a new story. This world was my childhood and teenage years, and now, as a man of nearly 30, I'm still proud to be a Potterhead, and I'm so thankful that we got this glimpse into what the future holds for those witches and wizards we love so much.

I can't wait for the definitive edition to come out, when I will a physical copy on my shelf right next to Deathly Hallows. I love Harry Potter, and I ALWAYS will.

date: Reviewed in the United States on July 21, 2017
content: Wish it was the story rather than a script.  This is not the book.  Still a great story.  Fast shipping, as described. Recommend seller!

author: J. Wilbur
title: Interesting Diaspora
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2016
content: THIS IS NOT A NOVEL, nor is it written by J.K. Rowling. With that said, it's not bad either. As a play, it would be awesome. If you're looking for a new Harry Potter novel, this is garbage. Keep in mind that this was always intended to be a play & it's fine. The Cursed Child tells an interesting and fairly subtle story about tolerance and acceptance and dealing with expectations...complex philosophical machinations that show sure signs of Rowling's involvement, but this is a script & therefore almost exclusively dialogue without all the internal trepidation & rumination that colors a novel. This is peppered with cameos from many of the beloved Harry Potter characters which is great for the nostalgia factor, but not so peppered with the side-plots and quirky creatures/plants/spells/red herrings that Rowling was able to populate the novels with. If you can take it for what it is, this is a good addition to the larger world.

author: John M. Vizcarra
title: Fun story, less fun format.
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2017
content:
When I heard there was a new original Harry Potter play in London, I was pretty excited. These things generally make their way to my coast. Unfortunately, it appeared I would have to wait a long while, with no touring show planned for the future. To mollify the US crowd, the powers that be put the script into book-ish form and released it into the wild.

I picked up my copy and sat on it for a while before I got around to reading it. When I finally picked it up to read, I was a little worried I might have lost interest in it; I was fairly meh about the recent Magical Beasts film, and thought I had grown out of Harry Potter’s world.

I did find myself a little confused at the beginning of the book; there’s some odd time-movement and jumping around, and a rush to establish the characters and their basic motivations, but it rather quickly fell into a fun pace that had me reading with rapt attention. The book is told in 4 acts, and it was a superfast read, getting through one act each in four sittings.

The familiar characters are there, along with a bunch of new ones. This is clearly the next generation of Harry Potter, and absolute proof that there are some fun stories to tell - if Rowling feels like telling them. This particular story was rather attached to the previous Harry Potter books, meaning it would be pretty confusing to someone who had not read the previous 7-book series. And the chief concept of the story is recycled from Prisoner of Azkaban, but the overall story doesn’t feel derivative. It feels more like it’s inspired by the established world from the previous books.

All in all, it’s a fun, fast read and leaves you begging for more. My main issue is with the structure of this play-turned-book, which reads like a script, but is distracting in how much of the hand-wavy magic it leaves to stage direction to figure out. I had a hard time believing this would be a good play to watch. That’s more of an issue with the interpretation of the play into book form, but I still found it distracting.

date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2016
content: This was a great follow-up to the Harry Potter series. While I don't normally read plays, I couldn't have hoped for anything better. It was an intelligent way to get a peek into Harry's future without  tainting his rich history and instead creatively tying in some of the more memorable moments of his childhood. The play was enjoyable and I was happy with my purchase.

author: Amazon Customer

author: Marilyn Dabady

author: carol irvin
title: Harry changed his mind -- how you get into this 8th version of the story
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2016
content:
I tried reading this but I don't like reading plays. They are meant to be performed. So I switched to listening to it instead on audiobook. That was a much better choice and I scarcely realized it was a play after a short while. So that is the way to solve that problem if you too do not like reading plays. They are very unlike novels.

As to the book itself. I realize as other reviewers have pointed out here that there are some inconsistencies with this book and the epilogue of Book 7 of Harry Potter. However, I'm willing to give some artistic license as the changes aren't that great. The biggest change is that Albus Potter has been brought up in the shadow of his father, Harry, in this work whereas Harry was quite clear at the end of Book 7 that he was going to become as little known as possible.

In this book he and Albus have a significant problem primarily caused by Harry's gigantic reputation. Harry also works within the Ministry of Magic with Hermione and that was also not his stated direction.

So, he changed his mind. That's  all you have to tell yourself to get into this 8th version of the story.

Is it as good as 1-7? It would be just about impossible for it to be so because we are revisiting the main characters as adult parents with children away at Hogwarts. The adventurers become Harry's and Draco's sons who become best friends. They try to bring Cedric back to life by using a time traveling device. They feel sorry for Cedric's father who has never recovered from his death in the earlier books.

That is the gist of it. The audio narrator was quite good and Rowling, as usual, knows how to keep a story rolling along. I just enjoyed having them back but never expected it to be the same as it was. What else is the same as it was? Nothing.

author: Ryan Tester
title: AWESOME
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2016
content: I don't know what you 1 star review people read but I think you guys read an entirely different book than I did. I can't wait for a movie if there's going to be one.

author: Kevin Coffield
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2016
content: I really liked the s

author: Monica
title: Not the best but still a great read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2016
content: Ok

author: Bob Thanasiu
title: Excellent story, but prefer novels over screen plays
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Excellent story, but prefer novels over screen plays. I feel the strychnine flows better as a novel. Besides that the story is excellent and suppress the early novels nicely.

author: Caitlin Mae
title: A fun read for a longtime Harry Potter fan
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: It was great to come back to the Wizarding World and revisit some of my all time favorite characters. As other reviewers have written, some of the dialog and actions of the characters don't seem true to form (What's with everyone saying "Thank Dumbledore!" instead of the typically used "Thank God!", I mean they knew Dumbledore personally, how has he become a new catchphrase?) but I was able to put that aside and still enjoy it. Some of the Time-Turner stuff did not jive well with me as they seemed to behave differently and cause alternate timelines instead of the linear loop style from PoA. I did wonder where the hell Hugo was, I don't think we saw him or Victoire or Teddy once. But it was fun and I'm happy I enjoyed reading it. It's almost like it exists on an alternate timeline where I can appreciate its existence but not completely attach it to the original series.

author: MJKpink
title: A great new chapter
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: I didn't know what to expect of this. I either was going to be highly entertained or rolling my eyes. I'm glad to say this was a great read! I got into the Harry Potter series through the movies rather than the books, but it's a series that's dear to my heart. This new play was a continuation of that story, filled with callbacks to the original series and tons of character nostalgia. If anyone grew up loving this series, this new story will be easy to enjoy

author: Sinder
title: It was good, but not great!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: The magical world of Harry Potter is back! It was a fun read and I loved it! But I can see how some May not like/enjoy it!

author: Allison
title: She was very happy with the
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2016
content: Purchased for my niece. She read it in two days. She was very happy with the purchase

author: Teah
title: Not a s good as the other books
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Not a s good as the other books, can tell that JK Rowling didn't write it. Thought they could have taken the time to write it in a story versus a play. I love Harry Potter so I enjoyed the book, just wished it was a "typical" Harry Potter book!

author: K. Doyle
title: Exceeded expectations
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2016
content: Came in with low expectations, so I was quite pleased. Fun romp of a story that readers of the original series will enjoy. Definitely hard to put down. Follows the same style as the original books pretty well, despite not being the original author's sole work.

author: J. Beard
title: Enjoyable light
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: After the uber dark end novels, nice to have a bit more lightness, albeit in the midst of difficulty, from the next generation of wizards and witches. The script format leaves a great deal to the imagination and makes for a quick afternoon's read. It will likely be the most substantial play a lot of kids ever read, Shakespeare notwithstanding, so I'm glad it wasn't over-cluttered with stage directions.

author: Stephanie Linn
title: Ehh... not my favorite..
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
doesn't really feel like harry potter. didnt really grab my intrest too much. kinda boring,  apart from the mischief.
I would recommend this to my friends,  but i was very disappointed by this book.

author: Mac14
title: I'm glad I read it
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: I'm glad I read it, and will probably read it again. Would absolutely love to see the play. However, you can tell that this isn't just J.K. Rowling's writing. The characters have lost some of their charm from the original 7.

author: Sacha Steel
title: fun to read
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 25, 2016
content: This book is a great bew edition to the harry pottger series. Its a real page turner, but it loses its 5th star because of the way its written. If you ignore the format it becomss a great book. I myself as a 11yr old loved it and would reccomend it to everyone i know. The new charecters have a big additude and are another reason this book was great.

author: J Holt
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: Good to be back....but it's just not the same!

author: Rosanna
title: "Play Format"? not to sure about!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Was kind of hard to read it in "Play Format".  I'm so use to J.K. Rowling incredible detail and flow.  Still, I loved the story line. The twists and turns were unexpected.  I look forward to reading more from J.K. Rowlings. Maybe another series like Harry Potter?

author: Jennifer B
title: Good extension of the series
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Good if you like the Harry Potter series. Wished it was longer.

author: Natasha De Almeida
title: Magic and closure
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2016
content: Always having loved the Harry Potter series I must say that I was expecting something along the same style of writing as before, even though I knew it was a play! However magic, danger, struggles with relationships were all included, without the background of description, and the warmth of imagination. As a prolific reader I did enjoy reading it, as I did find closure, thought it a good way to end a series. I honestly just wish it had been in the same style as the others, I would have been more satisfied

author: Sherrill Jordan
title: Better than expected
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2017
content: I knew it was written as a play so I thought it would be weird but the more I read the more I wanted to read. I wish it was longer and I didn't like the ending. I hope a movie is coming soon!

author: Marc B.
title: Good book
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2016
content: A good book

author: Amazon Customer
title: Is not as good as the previous book since is a theater script ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
content: Is not as good as the previous book since is a theater script but your imagination can fill the description that is missing... and is still  a Harry Potter story... :)

author: suhailk
title: Another time travel fic
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2016
content: Decent character development and plot. The story felt rushed, but I guess that's what you get from a theater play.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Good read for people familiar with theatre. No regrets.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2016
content: I knew it was a theatrical script going in, but I would've liked a little more exposition and character development. This and the fact that Harry is not the lead character makes it feel a little distant from the rest of the Harry Potter universe.

author: Dr Jacques COULARDEAU
title: Without the special effects, it is frustrating
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content:
I can’t resist and I will start with the new triad J-K (Rowling), John/Jack (Tiffany) and Jack (Thorne) like an echo of another trinity Jesus-James-John, the master/teacher/rabbi, the brother and the youngest apostle hence the son, presented as such by Jesus to his mother Mary from his cross. I will not follow that line with this new volume but it is constantly present, especially with the two boys Albus and Scorpius who are always running after a third one like Cedric twice and then Delphi both the predator and the prey of the two boys trying to deal with another triad, herself, her father Voldemort and his arch enemy Harry Potter and to move away from the ill-fated triad James Potter Sr., Lily Potter and Harry Potter. It could only lead to a catastrophe since then Voldemort would be building a quartet with the three Potters.

First of all it is a strange book indeed since it is a play and not a novel. So we get no descriptions, or hardly any since stage directions are not as good as prose. It is essentially a dialogue between or among two characters or more, cut up in rather short scenes. You have to rebuild everything in your mind’s eye, if you have a mind and if you have an eye in that mind and thirdly if you can, because it is hard to know the precise intonations intended in these dialogues and at times the meaning depends on these intonations. In other words you, Harry Potter addicts, are going to be frustrated and maladjusted in this dry scenario.

The second remark I will make is that what we read implies a tremendous level of special effects. That is easy in a film or TV series but on a stage…? So you will never get the real thing if you can’t see it on stage and if they do not propose a capture of the play on DVD, a real capture with no re-mastered special effects. Some of them are not very creative. Shape-shifting and shape shifters have become very banal and common place after “Supernatural” (How many season already?), “The X Files” (quite a few seasons too, and they stopped though they are speaking of starting again and they may even have) and “Fringe” (and they have come to an end or the end) or some copy cats of these. And that is of course in the line of vampires who could turn into bats or werewolves who could turn into wolves precisely.

The third element is that this play is un-understandable if you do not know the whole saga. First there are many allusions to event of the previous volumes, the old volumes, and you have an obligation to remember, a duty of memory. But what’s more, the author uses a time-turner to make us go back to old events that are revived that way.  You better know what she is speaking of and in some scenes, the very same way as in Back to the Future you may have two, or why not three though the author avoids that potential possibility, different identities and ages of the same characters. And what’s more  modern identities are crossed with and by contradictory feelings towards the other characters, feelings coming from the past, like how the Potter side reacts to that poor Draco Malfoy. You better review and revise your summaries.

The next remark has to do with some political science fiction resulting from travelling in time and changing history, the famous butterfly effect. We are thus able to visit what the modern world would be if the dark forces were to win, if Voldemort were able to win, like Trump, le Pen or Brexit. If they do, the only solution is to push them around, filibuster them if we can and neutralize them if possible. Can you control a tempest coming from all the frustrations of people in front of the establishment: frustrated in their minds by gross lies and promises that were not held; frustrated in their feelings by the insecurity they feel in front of the changing world they do not understand; and frustrated in their deeper impulses and desires by a world in which genders are multiplied from two to more than a dozen and in which gender orientation is a multiple choice challenge with more than one answer to every stage: the gay feel besieged and become aggressive; the straight feel menaced and become uncertain; and all other colors and options feel queer, bizarre, strange and kind of disoriented.  And Pride is by far not enough to make the world change smoothly.

But political science fiction comes basically, I think, from deranged and corrugated minds: Albus and Scorpius are out of their minds when they want to change the past.  No one can remake history, not even by remembering it which is anyway a reconstruction to make it palatable, digestible and if possible haunting. But it is funny to find out the best intentions in the mental world of two teenagers may lead to the worst nightmares in the life of everybody, the same way as Brexit leads to a chasm of chaos to the point of pushing it back two years and then now three years and in a month or two to four years and after some rounds of negotiations it will be recognized as the perfectly good bad idea. Imagine Voldemort and his Death Eaters and all his dung beetles ready to do the worst crimes for a pellet of cow pie.

The fifth element is that the story is funny and very sentimental if not sentimentalese. That will be the last remark of that type I will make. And this remark leads to the main content of the book as I see it.

The central question is the conflict between the deficient father Harry Potter and his second son? The author does not insist or harp on the first son, a certain James Potter Jr., and thus does not really capture the problem of the younger son. Being a younger son is a real – I mean R.E.A.L., real – curse in itself. Think of Abel when God decided not to favor the first born Cain. At the end there is an allusion to that James Jr. seen as at peace with the father of the two sons, Harry Potter, by Albus Potter, and Harry Potter’s response is then that in fact there is no real relation between him and his elder son. But at the end, that’s too late and it requires a lot more exploration.

But the author, with her two male sidekicks, is a woman, probably a mother and she probably believes she knows what it is to be a parent, forgetting that being a mother has little to do with being a father and she has no direct experience of this father status and men generally cannot really speak of it because they are like afraid of being misunderstood when they start telling you they love their sons, they want to hug them and cuddle them as long as they can and they have to break that desired relation, both mental and physical, by far too early for them, but most of the time too late for the son: in other words they do not know how to shift from the relation of a loving father who expresses his love with physical and mental closeness to the relation of a loving father who expresses his love with concern, support, encouragement to get out in the world and sow their wild mental and physical oats in all social fields. And sure enough Albus Potter and Harry Potter are both incompetent and how they come to some kind of understanding is superficial and purely verbose.

She misses many things and particularly that whether there is a conflict or not, the son will end up either doing some of the things the father did, or not doing some of the things the father did, or doing some of the things the father did not do, or not doing some of the things the father did not do. And most of the time some of each of the four options. That is called transference, positive or negative transference of positive or negative elements. It works both ways from the father who tries to transfer things onto the son, and from the son who tries to be free to choose what he accepts and what he refuses.

The author even goes further and brings together two sons of two fathers, the two sons living a conflict with their respective fathers and the two fathers inheriting an old conflict between them they try to project (transference again) onto their respective sons. She very wisely makes the two boys best friends at first sight. She systematically calls that friendship and calls them friends, but they are best friends and that is love, but I guess in her mind love has to do with desire and impulse and signifies sex, marriage and children. That’s how she deals with Ron and Hermione for example. The girl is a potential mother with all it means. For Albus and Scorpius there cannot be any kind of turning the other into a mother. More about that in a moment. To end up on the transference from Harry to Albus it is simple. Harry declares his fright in front of pigeons, and Albus declares at once they are innocent – go tell that to the guardians of the cathedral in Wells who have invested on falcons to purge the site of its pigeons, or to the managers of airports who also use falcons to clear up the zone of the airport of its pigeons – and as a negative transference he will be a pigeon race manager. That kind of final solution of the conflict is rather trite, and Scorpius does not deserve the same treatment since we do not know his ending, showing that the relation between the two boys is insignificant for the author and she tries to cast it into a block of heterosexual concrete.

We have to understand their dialogue in 2016 when the relations between males, two males or several males, or actually between females too, two females or more, are just the crucial social question of the moment after for example the decision of the US Supreme Court on the subject. I will only take some examples from the end of the book, but it is present all along.

Page 265 Scorpius says: “So we hide in a hole?” Albus answers: “As pleasurable as it will be to hide in a hole with you for the next forty years . . .” Then Scorpius retorts: “If I had to choose a companion to be at the return of eternal darkness with, I’d choose you.” In the situation they are in, either this is serious and then the words have a clear meaning: it is a declaration of love on both sides, or it is humor but due to the situation it is really very dark if not black humor. Let’s say, serious or humorous it is nevertheless homoerotic.

Page 300-301 Scorpius says: “I asked out Rose Granger-Weasley.” Albus responds: “And she said no.” Scorpius retorts: “But I asked her. I planted the acorn. The acorn that will grow into our eventual marriage.” That is erotic indeed and, on the side of a dating failure, it is rather male-dominant, maybe even slightly phallocratic. But later on Albus says: “I honestly thought I’d be the first of us to get a girlfriend.” And Scorpius responds: “Oh, you will, undoubtedly, probably that new smoky-eyed Potions professor – she’s old enough for you, right?” Albus reacts: “I don’t have a thing about older women!” And Scorpius can add: “And you’ve got time – a lot of time – to seduce her. Because Rose is going to take years to persuade.” Albus can have the last word: “I admire your confidence.” In this passage they set their orientation as being heterosexual, though Scorpius is rejected – but is he really – by his first “date” who says no of course, and Albus does not seem to be in a rush to get one. In other the two boys have closet undetermined sexual orientation and follow in public some kind of heterosexual game that does not seem to be urgent or really serious. The author is exploiting neither side of the coin that has to do with gender orientation.

I can assure you at 14 they are obsessed by it. And they are indeed.

Page 302 we have this little scene:

“Scorpius reaches in and hugs Albus.
Albus: What’s this? I thought we decided we don’t hug.
Scorpius: I wasn’t sure. Whether we should. In this new version of us – I had in my head.”

It is obvious the heterosexual version of the two boys is the “new version” of them. Then the old version, or the previous version was rather gay, and now they still hug and the play makes it longer than a casual hug between two brothers or cousins. At least Scorpius wants it and takes the initiative, and Albus does not refuse it and takes part in it, accepts it. Is that going to be an orientation, or a gender? We definitely need to get more on those two pubescent teenagers.

After saying all that let me conclude. This play will both exhilarate AND frustrate you. But that’s too bad. Let’s hope we SOON get a DVD capture of the stage production.

Dr Jacques COULARDEAU

author: Judith A. Gutlerner
title: So much fun to read abiut the characters all grown up
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
content: So much fun to read abiut the characters all grown up. I wanted to know more abiutnthe characters, but in this setting it was difficult. You can't really know waht someone is thinking and feeling as clearly when it is a play script. Potter fans will love it though.

author: Sue Demers
title: Otherwise good.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: I would have preferred it was written as a story and not a play.  Otherwise good.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Easy to read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2016
content: Could picture the story.  Easy to read.

author: Olivia J.
title: Not all that I hoped for, but still worth a read
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 12, 2016
content: This play wins many nostalgia points, but otherwise falls short of expectations. The storyline feels silly and pointless and the "twist" is neither shocking nor surprising. It also lacks that certain something in the narrative that J.K. Always brought to the books that leads me to believe that her involvement was less than they let on - and I don't think this is only attributable to the fact hat it's a play and not a novel. However, the emotional story between father Harry and son Albus feels genuine. It's worth a read, but I would say it hardly felt like the "eigth installment" in the HP series.

author: Hiller1313
title: I liked it. Not as good as the original series
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2016
content: I liked it.  Not as good as the original series,  bit still an interesting read.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2016
content: This small book is good if you're familiar with the original books.  I think there's enough background information in it to entertain someone who hasn't read the series.  I found it fairly predictable but also entertaining.

author: Karen W.
title: The book is in excellent condition and arrived in a timely manner
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2016
content: Hard to rate. The book is in excellent condition and arrived in a timely manner, but I'm not really enjoying it.  It doesn't absorb me like the novels did, as it's all dialogue and stage direction.  Hard to get into.  I knew the format going in but wasn't prepared for how little I care, as I'm a big HP fan.

author: Stacey
title: Let me start off by saying I love Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2016
content: Let me start off by saying I love Harry Potter. I grew up reading these books from the day they came out. That being said, I read the reviews on this and noticed most people were discouraged by the fact that this was set up like a play and the JK Rowling did not actually write this book. I knew going into it what to expect because I read reviews about the book. I knew how it was set up and still decided to read it.. and I think it delivered. There were some plots that I had not expected and I thought it was sweet how they included the older characters. This was a VERY quick read because it reads like a play.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Ni2t bad for a script
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2017
content: This script was a good read. I hope the play makes it the USA so I can actually see it.

author: Deann Holmes
title: I thought it was a bit weird at first with all the jumping back and forth early Harry to latter Harry but all in all I felt it w
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2016
content: I was a little leery about buying this since it was not written by Rowling but I thought I would give it a go.  I thought it was a bit weird at first with all the jumping back and forth early Harry to latter Harry but all in all I felt it was a good story and I would like to see the play.

author: Diana S. Long
title: Very enjoyable
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2017
content: There will be some spoilers involved in this work if you haven't read or seen any of the Harry Potter series/movies.  I really enjoyed the play.  The author makes use of a time-turner in this play so we do make a few trips back in time, pairing up of characters unlike H.P. Many intense moments and plenty of action  Highly entertaining, would love to see the actual theatrical production.

author: Nicole Hewitt
title: I enjoyed this!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2018
content:
So, I know a lot of people have really strong feelings about this book (mostly negative), but I went in knowing those qualms and I have to say that I enjoyed the story. I read that a lot of people didn’t feel like the characters from the original series stayed true to themselves, but I don’t know that I think that’s true—they grew up. They changed. If Harry and Hermione and Ron were the same as they were as teenagers, I’d start to worry a little. They seemed like… parents to me. Not perfect parents, but I haven’t met any of those yet, so I was okay with that. Obviously, since this is a play, we don’t get the roundness of characterization that we’d get in a book, but I expected that as well. I enjoyed the story and meeting the next generation of Potters (and Weasleys). I give it 4 stars.

I really wish I could see the production, though. Maybe someday.

author: Treva Lee Lewis
title: It was good..
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content:
It was good...but not her best.
I did not like how Harry was portrayed as an adult.  Rowling needs to stick with writing solo.

author: Rachel
title: Couldn't put it down
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: Although nothing can recapture the magic of the original 7, this is a fairly satisfying follow up.  Characters reunited, familiar lines retold, complexities added to the old story. Overall, I think it was a plausible story in the Harry Potter universe, but only just.  I thought the premise was a stretch, and the reveal of the true villain came too late.  I also thought it tried too hard to rehabilitate Draco and Snape.  Their characters weren't true to the original.  Still, felt like I was a child again, reading the whole book in less than 12 hours.  I would love to see the play.

author: rmay
title: Hogwarts Revisited
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2017
content: I found myself wondering how this play could possibly be staged for it has much of the rich imagination of the original series. The narrative is just as magical as the novels, and I loved both the new generation of wizards and the evolved versions of our original three heroes. The only disappointment for me is that the story doesn't continue. This episode focuses primarily on Albus - perhaps James and Lily will get their moments in the spotlight as well? We can only hope.

author: Ben Hunter
title: A good way to stay connected to the HP world and ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2017
content: Enjoyable but fails to capture the magic of the original series. A good way to stay connected to the HP world and follow the stories of our childhood heroes. The play format is easy to read but the lack of description and narrative text makes even the most exciting passes a little flat. Worth it if you're a fan. Not a good way to get into Harry Potter if you haven't read the originals, start from the beginning as this one will spoil several storylines. Enjoy!

author: Kevin Zhang
title: This is confirmed canon and written by Rowling by JK Rowling and an interesting post-Voldemort story
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 13, 2019
content: Ah, you whiny, whiny "fans." JK Rowling is not a screenwriter nor a playwright! How foolish can some of you be to think this is even a BOOK? It's not! It's the script of a PLAY. Book 8? Don't be ridiculous and be quick to label like you do everything, simple-minded fools. This does happen after Book 7, DECADES after and is not a whole, new, central, important big story from either Books 1-7. The fact is this is her story, she created this story, and cowrote it with Jack Thorne(How much, we don't know) and CONSIDERS it CANON. She is a novelist of great imagination and is continuing Harry Potter not for the same reason - she was driven to write Harry Potter and now, much of her motivation is to entertain the fanbase generated from it. This was a story that she had planned out from the beginning, indeed the last chapter was the FIRST she wrote, LITERALLY(Well at least a first draft). So, continuing from that, she will not be as you expect. What do you expect anyway? Can you put it in words? No? You're looking for general fluffy wonder as you expected from the books. JK Rowling is not a saint, she sends tweets with a LOT of political frustration, tweets back spiteful posts occassionally with profanity, softly retaliating against it, and has more of an original interest in adult novels now - crime, drugs, rape, poverty - things she cares about, and poverty - something she relates to. She never thought of herself as your babysitter sitting you down at storytime, she writes what she will. She is still reasonable, JK Rowling, but perhaps some of you ought to shake your misconceptions.

author: Chris Jones
title: Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2017
content: This was great some things were a little wrong like belittling Oslo dead not in askaban but over all it was good!!

author: Biscuitpants
title: Fun and Fast Read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
I was nervous getting this book because of the abundance of negative and luke-warm reviews, but decided to pick up a copy anyway. That was a decision that I do not regret at all. This is a fun, quick read, that introduces fun new characters, while bringing back the characters we all already know and love.
 There is plenty of magic and fun in there, and it made me curious to know how they can pull it off on the stage. I'm trying to sell a kidney so I can afford to see Hamilton, I may have to sell off the other one to fly to London and see this play, I imagine it would be well worth it!
Anyways, this is an exciting addition to the Harry Potter cannon. They mix in the new with the old perfectly. I would definitely recommend this one to any Harry Potter fan!

author: Naghmeh
title: The only thing is that I do like the rest of the books more than this one
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2018
content:
It was well written.
And written as a play didnot bother me at all.
The only thing is that I do like the rest of the books more than this one.

author: Bryan Chirstopher Bacon
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2016
content: Overall just a fun, quick read!

author: Beverly
title: Love me some Harry!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: I gave it a four because it wasn't long enough! It took a few scenes to get used to the format, but then I was off and running!

author: dianna winters
title: Love of the magical world
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2016
content: I love the way JK Rowling is able to transform everyone, young or old that read her books into that magical, mystical world she has invented.

author: Sheila Deeth
title: The darkness of book 7 with the innocence of book 1?
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2016
content:
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is a fun continuation of the Harry Potter mythology, but it’s a play, not a novel, so it’s a much faster read--with lots of dialog (of course), incredible effects (I want to see them), and stage directions that, oddly, feel more like they're taken from a short story  than written to direct the scene. (Actually, that might make it an easier read than more regular plays.)

The Cursed Child could almost be a short story, or a pair of linked short stories (parts 1 and 2 perhaps). And the quickness of the read allows some inconsistencies to slip by almost unnoticed. Frustrating for purists, I'm sure, but the final effect is definitely intriguing. I would LOVE to watch the play!

Re-reading, rechecking, and reviewing (which can't always be done while watching a play), reveals plot holes and inconsistencies with the original Harry Potter canon of course. That's where the purists will be upset. But it’s certainly fun to imagine Harry as a hapless dad, Ron as… well, read the book… and Scorpius Malfoy as... Scorpius is great! The insights into different worlds and what-ifs in this story are very cool, and there are some wise lessons hidden in the time-travel and childhood complaints, making it an intriguing read for adults, as well as a fun one for kids… Imagine the darkness of book 7 combined with the innocence of book 1, perhaps.

Disclosure: My son got the English version—comparing fonts, formats and punctuation was fun!

author: Raven
title: you have to read it like you're watching people perform it
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
I am a huge Potter fan and I mean huge.  I have tattoos, cats are named after characters, I re-read the series at least 3-4 times a year, and have watched the movies so many times I lost count.  I've been waiting for this SCRIPT for ages.  Major emphasis on script.  I'm not sure why people are bashing it so hard.  Obviously this was written so it could be performed on a stage, it was advertised this way, there was no deception...did people not look into this before reading?  It takes some imagination to make this story really come to life, you have to read it like you're watching people perform it.  The story needs to be fast, a little silly, and come full circle at the end.  THIS IS A PLAY!  It needs to wrapped up quick and keep the audience interested/entertained in the theater and in doing that, yes details were over-looked over and you don't get the full Rowling experience. This is a collaboration and really we're lucky to even have it. Too many people are going into this thinking it's a new novel.  Get that out of your head, or yes, you'll probably be disappointed.

I love seeing old characters.  I love seeing their lives after Voldemort.  I love being back at Hogwarts. I love a new adventure.

I actually enjoyed reading this, it's something new, and it was fun.  It is your typical "butterfly effect" story line, but with characters I grew up loving.  I'm happy to read anything J.K. Rowling does with Harry Potter.  I appreciate this SCRIPT and wish I could see it performed live.  My imagination is pretty good, but I'm sure this looks amazing on stage.

Keep an open mind and just enjoy it for what it is.  Magic!

author: E. A. Solinas
title: When spares are spared (slight spoilers)
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
When the Harry Potter series ended, I knew that it wouldn't really be over. Not permanently. For one thing, there was too big and devoted a fanbase. For another, too much money to be made.

And I was right, with the 2016 release of a new movie set in the same universe, and "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child," a stage play that also serves as a sequel to the original series. While it lacks the narrative ebbs and flows of the books (three years pass in a few pages), it's a solid enough sequel that expands the story into the next generation -- there's dark overtones, plenty of new characters, and more magical shenanigans.

The story begins where the last book ends, with Harry Potter, Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger sending their children off to Hogwarts. But Albus Potter quickly finds that he's regarded as a disappointment by everyone there -- not is he pretty bad at magic, but he quickly becomes best friends with young Scorpius Malfoy... and is sorted into Slytherin. As the years go by, both Scorpius and Albus are troubled -- Albus by the weight of his father's legacy, and Scorpius by malicious rumors that he's actually the secret son of Voldemort.

Meanwhile, Harry and Hermione discover that a new, superior type of Time-Turner is being created, and Harry begins having strange dreams that hint that something horrible is coming. After the two boys use a Time-Turner to try to right an old wrong, they find that they've messed up the timeline -- and as they try to fix the mistakes they made, they soon find themselves in the grip of a terrible enemy.

Like most time-travel-centric stories, "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" becomes a little brain-twisty at times, but the core of it is essentially about two relationships. One is between the unlikely best friends Scorpius and Albus, two boys who seem like opposites... until you realize that both are burdened by the legacy of a father/rumored father. And the other is about Harry and Albus, a father and son who love each other but can't communicate well, and the clash between Albus' moody loneliness and Harry's overprotectiveness.

Admittedly the concept feels rather like a fanfic at times (especially the big reveal about a certain character's true identity -- no, I'm not going to mention who it is, but it's eye-rollingly fanficcy). However, it's a fairly well-written one, with some quirky dialogue ("I don't remember the last time someone asked my name." "What is your name?" "I've forgotten") and new characters who fit fairly well into the narrative. There are also some chilling glimpses of a Hogwarts-that-might-have-been, after twenty years of ruthless rule by Voldemort and his followers.

And of course, fans will see a lot of familiar faces -- not just Harry, Hermione, Ron and Draco, but a number of lesser characters in the past or alternate presents (such as Snape or Umbridge). And it does an excellent job fleshing out some of these characters, such as an older, grief-stricken Draco Malfoy, who ironically has more insight into Albus than Harry does. The scene where he and Harry discuss their families and experiences is one of the best of the play.

Probably its biggest problem is a few conversations that don't add much to the actual story or characters, but aren't well-written enough to be entertaining on their own (Ginny and Harry discussing Albus and his issues, which is quite cliched). It feels like it needed another rewrite or two in places, or a scene or two whittled down.

"Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" has a somewhat fanficcy flavor, but is a fairly clever story with some solid dialogue, and two strong character-driven subplots. I doubt I'll be watching it onstage, but the story itself is certainly worth checking out for fans of this universe.

author: Marie Pagan
title: Harry is still Harry
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2016
content:
Contrary to most of the reviews I have read, I did enjoy the book. Harry Potter was in my life for so long that it seemed like I was welcoming a dear friend back home.
While reading screenplays is not my favorite thing to do, it had the power of taking me back to that magical world. I did wish it was a book, with more details. Another thing was that I kept imagining Harry and his friends as all still teenagers and I had to keep reminding myself that they were parents.
All in all, I'm glad I wasn't deterred from buying and reading this story.

author: Garrett Smith
title: Different, not bad.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
As a Harry Potter book it leaves a lot to be desired. For instance, the fact that it's written as a play takes the immersion of the world out of the story and I find myself being yanked back into reality with each set change. Secondly there is quite a bit of the story that feels rushed, especially in the beginning. For the pros, while I thought it didn't read like a traditional Rowling story, it really conveys the fact that it isn't the Harry Potter of old, but rather the next generation of her storytelling with many familiar characters we love from the original series. I say original series because while this is technically the eighth book, it almost completely stands alone as the beginning of a new story arc. The story was worthwhile and kept me guessing a few times which was fun. There are moments where I got a bit choked up which was also a nice surprise because it says that while this wasn't the book everyone was expecting it to be, it still has the power to make me feel for the characters like all the other HP books before it.
*TLDR: different of course, but highly recommended.*

author: Bridge
title: A worthy addition to an outstanding series.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content: I wasn't sure what to expect when I started this book, but I can say now that I have finished it, I am very pleased.  Like many who have posted reviews here, I am a die-hard Harry Potter fan and have longed to see his story continue.  I have always felt that JK Rowling had much more to tell about the magical wizarding world, and was disappointed that there were no more books after "Deathly Hallows".  I think a lot of people were put off by this being a screen play.  It does not allow for the story to be fleshed out or for JK Rowling's lyrical telling of Harry's magical story to be heard as we are accustomed to in previous books.  It would have been an extraordinary book and I will always regret not having the chance to read it as such.  But, in the end, it is still a very good story and a very worthy epilogue to a tale that is so very dear to my heart.  If wishes came true, then this screenplay would be fleshed out to become the 8th book on the series, full of the magical writing that only JK Rowling can deliver.  But, I am happy to have had at least a glimpse back into Harry's world, and will remain hopeful that this is not truly the end of the story.

content:
I went in with all the warnings: it's glorified fan fiction, it's very predictable, it's just not the same as the originals, etc. (spoiler: it is all those things.)

So, when I started Cursed Child, I had low expectations. Perhaps that is why I was pleasantly surprised! Sure it was like fan fiction, but it was FUN fan fiction! If you can take it for that, it is a worthy read.

It lacks the complexity of the originals but makes for an emotional, yet needed, trip down memory lane. Therefore, 4 stars.

author: Laurie ‘The Baking Bookworm’
title: A good epilogue to the original series but not a fan of the screenplay format
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
I had mixed emotions about this book. First, I am a huge Potterhead.  I loved the first seven books in the series and was more than a little eager to jump back into Rowling's magical world.  But part of me hesitated with this book because A) it was written as a screenplay and B) while the plot was Rowling's idea, this screenplay was written by two other authors.  Would they get the feel right?  Would it fit in well with the first seven books?  Part of me wanted to know and part of me wanted to leave my knowledge of HP to the first seven books because they were perfection.

My curiosity won out.  I waited a whole .... day.  Yes, my internal dilemma lasted 24 hours.  I waited until August 1st to order a copy and it arrived the next day in all it's HP glory.  A big reason I bought it was that I didn't want to hear chatter about the book that would give away plot points. I had to read it for myself and what HP collection would be complete without the final book?

What I liked about this book:
- I got to revisit some of the characters that I loved from the first book and see what happened to them after the Battle of Hogwarts
- the time travel aspect was an interesting way to include certain characters
- the authors got Rowling's sense of humour right
- I adored Albus and Scorpius's characters and how they related to each other and their parents
- I surprised myself by adoring Draco and Scorpius more than other characters
- there were some great suspenseful scenes and a good twist
- you get to see a very different side to Harry, various characters and their relationships in a new light and even how a certain character regretted some of their past decisions

What I wasn't fond of in this book:
- there was a lot of jumping around with time travel which made it a little convoluted at times
- My biggest peeve, by far, was that I was not a fan of reading a screen play.  I did not like it.  Not one bit.  It felt awkward and didn't flow well. And I think by using this format the reader misses out on Rowling's immense talent of pulling her readers into her world with her vivid descriptions (that is IF she had written this book herself).  I would have much preferred for her to write a novel and if she wanted to publish the screenplay then do so as a separate publication.  But she apparently doesn't require my two cents before publication. ;)

- Now I'm going to show what a serious HP geek I am and sound a lot like Hermione.  If I'm not mistaken, some of the charms in the book were wrong.
In Part One Albus uses an Expelliarmus charm on another person's wand and the books says that the wand "is summoned to Albus' hand".  Um, I believe you meant to use Expelliarmus (disarming) AND the Accio (summoning) charm.  Expelliarmus only disarms or releases whatever the person has in their hands, it doesn't give it to the other person. {I'm such a geek}
Also, in Part Two they talk about whipping up some Polyjuice Potion to use that day.  If I'm correct, Polyjuice potion is a complex and very time consuming potion and when they made it in Books 2 and 4 it took weeks and time was of the essence in this current scene {Waving my Geek Flag high!!}
Overall, this is a good addition to the Potter universe but as I read my rating wavered all over the place.  I admit that it took me awhile to get into this book with my favourite parts clearly being the second half of the book (the first half had a very 3 star feel).  The last half is when the action picks up and wonderful secrets are revealed.  Oooo, right?

I consider this Harry Potter: The Next Generation.  An epilogue to the original seven book series.  While it does have its place in the Potter universe, the form that Rowling chose to reveal her latest work, via screenplay written by other authors, greatly diminished my ability to immerse myself into her world again.  Overall, I enjoyed the ride and I liked seeing how things turned out for my favourite characters.  I recommend it for fellow Potterheads and if the play ever comes to Toronto you know who will be there in all her geeky glory.

Favourite Quotes

Note: The following quotes will mention certain characters that appear in the book.  If you don't want a heads up skip this part of my review.

::: spoiler alert :::

Harry: I need your help.  I need your advice.  Bane says Albus is in danger.  How do I protect my son, Dumbledore?

Dumbledore: You ask me, of all people, how to protect a boy in terrible danger?  We cannot protect the young from harm.  Pain must and will come.

Harry: So I'm supposed to stand and watch?

Dumbeldore: No.  You're supposed to teach him how to meet life.

  --------------------------------------------------------------------

Dumbledore: Harry, there is never a perfect answer in this messy, emotional world.  Perfection is beyond the reach of humankind, beyond the reach of magic.  In every shining moment of happiness is that drop of poison: the knowledge that pain will come again.  Be honest to those you love, show your pain.  To suffer is as human as to breathe."

Dumbledore: Those that we love never truly leave us, Harry.  There are things that death cannot touch.  Pain .. and memory ... and love.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not quit what I expected when I thought I had it figured out by the third page. Fun to go back to Hogwarts.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 6, 2017
content: I would have preferred a full text story, rather than a play. But the images and compelling story still came through.

author: Jaimie
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: The script style was a little hard to foloow

author: Fred
title: Great story, but second half not as good
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: I really liked this play. I loved how time turners were used, and I really liked the alternate universes. However, there were some things I really didn't like that much. I loved everything about it until about halfway through, where I think it should have ended. The plot pulled itself to an end... then, in my opinion, a much worse story began. The only thing I disliked about the first half was how Snape instantly trusted Scorpius, and was able to give up his life so easily. I think it would have been a much better story if Snape and Hermione didn't trust him at first, and eventually when Snape found out he had to die, he wouldn't want to fix it at all.

author: Daniel
title: A delightful, Rowling-worthy fan-fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content: While J.K. Rowling didn't write this herself (something every HP fan should be aware of), you can still catch glimpses of her humor and wit in the characters, as well as the uniqueness of the story itself. Cursed Child manages to retain the themes the HP series: the trials of growing up, becoming your own person, making mistakes, learning from mistakes, and that people are far from what they appear to be. This book is a good read for any HP fan.

author: Sunny J.
title: We enjoyed the story
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2016
content:
It was a very interesting read - as always from JK Rowling.  We will take it in any form we can get it!
We enjoyed the story!  I saw it as how it is difficult and important to establish one's own identity from one's parents, even when one loves them.

author: MB in GA
title: Overall good—but bring your imagination!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
Just finished "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" and, overall, enjoyed it. Since it's lacking J. K. Rowling's prose and sense of story curve to move the plot along, one needs to bring some degree of character foreknowledge and imagination to the (mostly) brief scenes and stage directions. Or, in the words of Robert Frost:

"It asks a little of us here
It asks of us a certain height."

No spoilers—but from my point of view, the "relationship/alienation" thread running through the play's four acts successfully speaks to its audience (certainly to me!) and effectively binds the work to the authentic HP narrative of Years 1-7.

• Will "Cursed Child" become HP canon? I doubt it.
• Did the series necessarily need this addition? Probably not.
• Can I imagine what it would have been like had Rowling written this plot in an actual eighth book—without a doubt!

Having said all that—and not intending to "damn with faint praise"—I'm still quite glad I read it. :)

author: C. Maddox

content: So, did anyone else receive a version that goes to Page 280, and then starts over at page 233?  Once you hit Act 4 Scene 10 in our book, page 280, the next page is page 233.  It then repeats pages 233-280, and ends with the second page 280.

author: Juss B

she is excited to watch the play someday

Overall satisfied with purchase but little disappointed about kindle delay on the night of launch

author: George Wilson
title: and second I should state I really do not enjoy reading scripts
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2018
content: First of all I must state I'm a HUGE Harry Potter fan, and second I should state I really do not enjoy reading scripts.
