author: S. Shanahan
title: Canon...adjacent? (Spoilers for the plot)
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2017
content:
I was 17 when Deathly Hallows came out so I grew up with Harry Potter like a lot of these reviewers.  I own all the audiobooks and listen to them frequently.  I was so excited to hear a play would be brought to life and even more so that those of us without a hope of seeing it live in London would still get a chance to read the new story through the published rehearsal script.

I continue to have mixed feelings about the story as a whole.  There are parts I adore about this story, such as Scorpius being the greatest child ever, Draco admitting to his lonliness and vowing to bring his son up differently than how he was raised, the struggle Albus feels carrying the weight of his father's legacy and pressure to succeed.  And then there are parts that I struggle to reconcile with what I know and love about the HP series.  I cannot fathom the idea of Voldemort having a child - consensual or not, magical intervention or not - with anyone.  I can't imagine any amount of public humiliation at the Triwizard Tournament that would turn Cedric into a Death Eater and kill Neville at the Battle of Hogwarts.  I can't imagine Harry ever saying he sometimes wishes Albus weren't his son.  Even if he regrets it immediately, I'm not sure I could see him going that far even in the heat of the moment.

I had issues with the mechanics and plot holes that time-turning caused in Prisoner of Azkaban and had many of the same issues with the time-turning in this story as well.  I felt quite a bit like the entire hidden purpose of having a story involving time travel was just a way to bring back old characters for the fans to see again, although I don't feel any characters were done any real justice by that so it was often awkward.  Most of the characters felt at least a bit *off* to me; close to their canon personalities but not quite right.  I started referring to it as 'canon-adjacent'; it's easy to say it's a fan-made telling of Harry's future if that's easier to accept, but for a lot of people it's also a perfectly acceptable addition to the series.  Accept the parts you like, and continue to daydream and rework the parts you don't.  Fiction allows that kind of freedom for headcanon.

I would love the opportunity to see it performed live.  While this wouldn't change the issues I had with the plot, it would definitely be a more well-rounded experience with the story overall and I think I'd have a better appreciation for the story presented in a completely new medium for the HP canon.  I think I could forgive some of the more absurd points if I had a more complete picture of the experience, with the atmosphere and magic - both literal and figurative - I associate with the series as a whole.  I'm definitely saving my pennies for when it makes the trip to Broadway!

Overall, I flew through the book and enjoyed the experience of dipping my toes back into the world of Harry Potter after so many years of having no new material, but it's clear this was a fan work and not the complete brainchild of Jo Rowling.  Her approval and backing of it tells me that she's at least behind this tell of the future of her characters even if she didn't write it, which is a bit tough to think about given how different parts of it feel.  However, I don't think it's fair for me to do what so many fans have done by completely trashing it and writing it off.  I think it's given the fandom overall a new thing to discuss and debate and love (as many people do!) and that's important.

Overall rating: 3.5/5 stars

author: Celeste

author: Emma Tindall
title: Better than expected!
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2017
content: I've been hearing lots of things about how JK took liberties with her characters, turning them into something they weren't... but these accusations are simply untrue. The fights between Albus and Harry are not out of character, nor do they make me dislike either one. Albus is too headstrong and defiant to see who his father really is, and Harry is too consumed with trying to be right, good, and perfect, that he makes even more mistakes, especially about who his son is and should be. I really loved this, and I'm glad to be able to visit my favorite characters one last time. Thank you JK!

title: Daniel Radcliffe Fans Need Not Apply
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: So I liked it. It showed the good sides of my own house—Slytherin—and it had a lot to do with Goblet of Fire, which I think was my favorite of the series. I will say that if you're a fan of the Daniel Radcliffe Harry, you won't find any trace of him here. This is 100% book Harry—a grumpy, self-centered man with a messiah complex for better or worse who carries a piece of the darkest person ever's soul glued right onto his own. A hero, but one who struggles with those heroics a lot. I also thought the new characters were engaging and I'd follow more of their adventures if Rowling ever decided to write them

author: Book Huntress
title: A fantastical and magical novel
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2016
content:
This is a fantastical and magical novel that will make your world rock as you goes deeper into the story.

In this book, it tells us how the characters from the famous series of Harry Potter grow as an adult and how they handled their new life as a parent. Together with that, this book also shows us about the struggle of Albus Severus Potter (son of Harry and Ginny Potter) and how he and Scorpius Malfoy (son of Draco and Astoria Malfoy) became best of friends.

I loved this book even if this is not as awesome as the other books in the series. That amazing feeling you get when you read this is priceless. I know I’m not the only one who was shocked when we get to know the secrets of the past that even Harry and his friends weren’t aware. And it is kind of surprising too because I don’t have any idea that it is possible – which is really impossible to happen.

The characters are awesome, especially Scorpius Malfoy. I liked how he handled the situations. As for Albus, he is cool too, but I mostly noticed Scorpius in the story so yeah, I can’t praise him enough. And there’s the trio we will never – EVER – forget! They already have their own family here, and well, I think they changed a bit. They are not the trio we’ve known for so long, but, nonetheless, it never destroys how I imagined the story. Also, why should I forget Draco (My book boyfriend, shhh) and how he really changed for the better. He shows me how awesome he is like a father to Scorpius and that’s really something. He is the only character that shows big improvements here, unlike the trio that’s kind of still the same as they were before.

The plot and concept are good but, some of it is a forced one – if you get what I mean, it is like they just put it there because they just want it. And, I’ve got some problems too about some parts of it like the scene where polyjuice potion was suggested by Albus and… I won’t give any more details here as it might spoil some of you who haven’t read this yet.

Overall, this is a magical gift from my favorite author. I get to enjoy the ride again to Hogwarts, but this time it is not focused on the trio but on their children. Even if this is written in a play format, I was still able to enjoy it. Very recommended to everyone, especially to those Potterheads!

author: Julie Merilatt
title: Return to the Wizarding World
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content:
When we left an adult Harry Potter seeing his youngest son Albus off to Hogwarts at the end of book 7, there was no indication that the relationship between the two was complicated.  In this new installment, Albus struggles with his famous father’s legacy.  With his BFF Scorpio Malfoy, he schemes to steal a time turner to go back to the Triwizard Tournament to save Cedric Diggory.  Two inexperienced adolescent wizards playing with time is bound to go bad, and when they change history, mayhem ensues.  The time travel device could have gotten confusing, but I think it was well done here.  When the boys realize the consequences of their meddling, the adults get involved to try to prevent Voldemort’s victory.

Was this book a necessary addendum to the stories we already know and love?  Not really.  Was it entertaining and nice to revisit our favorite characters?  You bet!  Though it wasn’t as thoroughly engrossing and endearing as Rowling’s novels, it was still a fun return to the wizarding world.

author: MacG
title: This story is about acceptance and love and how sometimes it takes a crisis to make us realize what's really important.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2016
content:
Ok. Let me start off by saying that if you're expecting the "world of Harry Potter" in this book, you will be disappointed. The format does not lend itself to description. Its a play, not a novel. The depth and complexity in the characters and setting isn't there.  Also the reader needs to know the backstory before reading. It would be difficult to follow and/or get a deeper meaning from this story not knowing about the books. In this book, we find Harry as an adult with all the responsibilities and scars that a 40 year old parent can have. This definitely isn't the adventure story we Harry Potter fans are used to. That being said, I enjoyed every single bit of it. In fact, I loved it.

Some things to note: I think to really enjoy and understand this book, it helps to be a parent of a certain age. One of the reasons I think this play resounded with me is that Im a 45 year old parent who has teenage kids. Like Harry I've made parenting mistakes - some of them very costly.  Thankfully, Ive been lucky and have worked hard to come around the other side of some of those mistakes.

Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is a redemption story. Its about the baggage we carry in our lives and how it's passed along, many times unwillingly, to our children. It's a story about the complexity of relationships and how they shape and mold the people we become. Lastly, this story is about acceptance and love and how sometimes it takes a crisis to make us realize what's really important.

author: Amazon Customer
title: I enjoyed this book
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I enjoyed this book. I get why people think it was disappointing, and they're not wrong - it did read a bit like a fanfiction (a mediocre one at that), and the plot fell a bit flat. But to be honest, I don't think Harry Potter's original plotlines were as wildly original as people seem to think they were. Don't get me wrong, I LOVE Harry Potter, and I do think the original canon was better than this book - just not by as much as everyone else seems to think.

I liked the characters. I thought Scorpius was quite charming. Some of the original characters fell a bit flat for me - especially Ron. I'm not really sure what happened with Ron, but his role in the story was so minor that it didn't stick out to me. I wasn't over the moon over the plot, and it was predictable to me, but there were parts I really appreciated.

This book felt like a Harry Potter book to me, if only because I was as swept up in the reading of this book as I have ever been with one of the earlier Harry Potter book. It brought me back to being in high school and waiting for the books and movies to come out, being at the bookstore on midnight the day of release, and the glorious anticipation of waiting to find out what happened next. As a standalone story, this book is decent and would probably get three stars - but I gave it an extra star for the nostalgia factor. So I liked it. I would recommend it to any of my Harry Potter fan friends. Plus, it doesn't take long to read a play - so you may as well give it a go. :)

author: Rebecca A Seibel
title: A Welcome Visit from an Old Friend
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
I came to the Harry Potter fandom quite late - I didn't read the books until after Order of the Phoenix was already in paperback, my interest peaked by repeated viewings of the first three movies on TV. From that time onward, however, I have been a unabashed Harry Potter fanatic. And I truly don't understand the hate this is getting. Some of the most common complaints I've seen:

1. The script format - Well, read the description before making the purchase. It hasn't been a secret that this was the format Cursed Child would take.

2. It's too short - Yes, the script format makes for a quick read. But if the stories were as long as I'd like them to be, I'd never resurface from reading them.

3. Harry is wildly out of character - There are 20-some years, 3 children, and a career between the last time we saw Harry and this story. Did anyone truly believe we'd get the same angsty teenager we last saw in Deathly Hallows? Are you the same person you were even a year ago? Perhaps it would have been helpful to have a few glimpses of what made Harry into the person we see in Cursed Child, but it's really not that big of a leap to see the Harry we're familiar with in this older version. Same goes for the others - Hermione is still HBIC, I fell in love with Ron all over again, and Draco - well, he was a satisfying surprise. They've just all grown up.

Would I have preferred a story centering more on Harry, Ron, and Hermione and their lives now? Yes. Did I want to see more of how the Wizarding world had (or had not) changed in the aftermath of Voldemort's demise? Sure. But here's the thing - there was plenty I would have changed about the other seven stories as well. None of it changes how much I love them and this universe that JK Rowling has created. The story is still one of love, family, and friendship - and for me, that's what I had always valued in the Harry Potter stories most of all.

author: Kyle N.
title: A compelling read that suffers slightly from being labelled as the "eighth Harry Potter story"
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2016
content:
It has been a long time since a book has seen hype quite like this one (probably since the last Harry Potter book). Unfortunately, no book could live up that kind of hype, let alone this one. Labelling Harry Potter and the Cursed Child as the "official eighth story" likely did the biggest disservice to itself. Yes, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is written (at least partially) by JK Rowling and is set after the Nineteen Years Later scene of the final (at the time) Harry Potter book. However, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is not really the continuation of a seven-book series with an overarching and interconnected plot. It is the script to a play that happens to tell a story connected to the prior seven books, with input from the original author of said books. However, it is also the work of two other people and as a script is also intended to be seen performed. This is all important to consider when reading this book, because expecting too much from it is going to leave you disappointed.

As mentioned prior, this is the script of the play being performed in London. The play, directed by John Tiffany, and written by Jack Thorne, with the story worked on between Tiffany, Thorne, and Rowling. Taking place from where Rowling left off the last Harry Potter book, it follows Harry, now all grown up and with a family. Of this family, the story focuses on his youngest son, Albus Severus Potter as he starts his enrollment at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardy. However, things are different for Albus than they were for his father: he is sorted into Slytherin, befriends a Malfoy, and has to deal with fame in a different way (Harry was famous for his actions, Albus is famous for the actions of another). The play then delves into the relationship between parents and their children. When Albus finds a way that he thinks he can fix something tragic that happened in the original books, he ends up involved in something much more complicated than he imagined.

On its own merits, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child's story and characters are strong. The central characters of Harry, Albus, Scorpius, Draco, and Delphi are complex, and the story delves well into exploring its themes. These characters all have something straining their relationship with their family or how society views them in light of them family. This will resonate well with those have had similar struggles with their family. In addition, the story takes several twists and turns, and the format makes it easy to get through the story and see how it unfolds.

However, it's when taking in it's story and characters in the view of being part of a larger universe that some of the flaws in the story become apparent. On the one hand, the characters all feel accurate to their characterization from prior books, but as much older adults. For example, Harry is well-meaning and does what is right, but is often distracted with his personal problems and life that he often makes mistakes. Ron is a funny uncle and doting husband, but knows when to just stand by his wife, Hermione, and let her take care of things in her new fitting position as Minister. However, most of the original main cast takes a sideline in this story, with Ron and Ginny in particular not really doing much in the story (and Ginny's arc in the previous books was that she became someone who could stand up and do something when needed). In addition, some new details about the setting are revealed, and some of them feel a little odd. The big reveal about the antagonist's identity in particular seems a bit odd. It feels out of character with someone from the original series. It ties into the play's main themes, but does feel fan-fiction-y in logic. Though it is explained second-hand, so it isn't a stretch to infer it as not as true of a reveal as originally lead to believe.

Another important thing to remember is the format. This is the script of a play, and one from the rehearsal period. This means that there are rewrites that occurred between when this version was performed during the previews and when the play officially opened (this was done presumably so the script could be printed and released the day the play opened). In fact, the revised script will be released later next year. Also, while blocking instructions do exist, this is a script and not a prose novel. This was and is intended to been seen as a performance. However, as this play was incredibly hyped and most people can't afford tickets to London to go see the play, the script was released as a more accessible version. Like other plays, this makes it easier and more accessible to consume, it is arguably inferior to seeing full performance.

One's enjoyment of Harry Potter and the Cursed Child depends mainly on how much they're willing to go into reading it without expectations as an "eighth story" in the Harry Potter universe. It does not work as a part of the seven books that preceded it, but as a separate work still connected to what came before. Be willing to accept that, and you'll find a compelling story about family and the struggle to connect, just where the family is Harry Potter's.

author: Annatha
title: "It does not do to dwell on the dreams of how amazing this might have been, and forget how good it is"
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content: This was a fun read and it sounds like it's going to be a crazy amazing play. The writing wasn't as creative or inspired as a J.K. Rowling book, but it was fun to be back in that world for a time. I thought the plot twists were cool and worked well. It's true that none of the old characters felt particularly authentic. I think Ron and Snape received the brunt of this. At the same time, Albus and Scorpio were great. I had a fun time reading it, really couldn't put it down. As other reviewers have said, it reads more like a piece of fan fiction and that's really what it feels like. Nonetheless, it's a good piece of fan fiction. I enjoyed it a lot. If it was missing some of the soul of the series, I knew that going in, because J.K. didn't write it. But seriously, with the effects and everything, this play seems like it's going to be amazing. There's a big part of me that wishes this had been fully fleshed out into a novel. It would add the detail that we're used to in Rowling's books. That being said, I really thought it was great for what it was.

However, this could be due to the fact that it is a play and the cadence of writing is bound to be different. Overall, a great incite to the wizarding world but no comparison to the written adventures of Harry Potter himself.

author: Memphis Mom
title: A solid addition, but lacking something I can't put my finger on...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2016
content:
All the big people in my house are Harry Potter fans. J.K. Rowling is a very talented writer, and her books are engaging, witty and cleverly written. This book had an interesting storyline, and was a nice addition to the Potter story, but it was not QUITE as good as previous stories. I'm not sure if I was thrown off by the different energy it takes to read the lines in the play, the fact that J.K. was not the primary author so the "voice" was different, or the fact I was just left feeling like more could have been included.

All in all it is a solid addition, just left me wanting more and something a little more polished in the end.

author: LordZarbon
title: I would recommend, especially to young readers, but...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: For fans of the original seven, I think this is a let down. The tone was captured, and in general the script picks an interesting theme and topic, and again, familial love is very prevalent for this as well. At it's best, it's a compelling script that will hopefully get young people to consider theatrical scripts a serious art form and make fun to read. At it's worst, it gives a great Harry Potter flavor, but without JK's exposition in between dialogue (the format is mostly dialogue with a few lines of stage direction in each scene. Most scenes are short!) the story doesn't really seem all that substantive. Again, this is all just on the page. The beauty of the script is that so much of it seems 'unstageable'), it really makes me want to see it live!

author: Amazon Customer
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2017
content: Gift

author: Jazzy Mama
title: Remember, it is not a novel and appreciate it for what it is!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: It's very frustrating to hear so many people downing this work based, as it sounds to me, on the fact that they are not used to reading play scripts. They expected it to read like a full blown novel. It's not! It's a play script, and you must remember that that completely changes the dimension of the writing. That being said, my daughter and I truly enjoyed this story, and await the plays Broadway debut! I feel the stage will truly give the story its full depth.

author: Michael
title: Good, but nothing like the original series!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2016
content: Loved getting to meet new characters, and getting to read about the beloved characters from the original series! I found it took much longer to get into the storyear because of the script format. I wish Ms Rowling would write a new series in this world!!

author: AvidRiet
title: Nostalgia makes this a good read
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
This is a continuing story, based off of the universe creates by JK Rowling. This is written as a play, not a novelization. Some people may find the format annoying, but I wasn't bothered. It is a quick read, about 300 pages.

I was very hesitant to read this as I have such amazing memories associated with the original books. I am also prejudiced against trying to draw out stories long past their expiration. But, curiosity got the better of me! Although it lacked, for me, the magic of the originals, I found it to be an interesting story and really did a good job continuing the characters.

The story follows Albus, son of Harry. He is a child who is struggling with his identity as the son of a hero. He befriends the son of Draco and sets out to fix some of his father's mistakes.

I won't spoil the rest, but I felt intrigued throughout the story and recommend that fans give this a try!

author: Joe K
title: Real Talk: I Was Just Happy to Get To Hang out With Harry and Hermione and Ron Again
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
I can’t imagine what the weight of expectations must have been on J.K. Rowling and the creative team behind Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, and it almost struck me as meta-commentary that the story ends up being about Albus struggling in Harry’s shadow. This is a play that’s immensely aware of the shoulders it is standing on, and that tries for better or worse to embrace its difficult position.

Personally, I felt it succeeded quite well under the circumstances. While there were certainly some missteps here (it’s very show-not-tell; several of the central conceits seemed to me to contradict our previously existing canon or just struck me as implausible for this world; there are some very awkward implications about Hermione’s fate without Ron; Ron himself seems a little too broadly comic; I would have loved more trio time and at least a cameo from Neville and Luna), I greatly enjoyed being able to immerse myself in this world again. I really appreciated the choice to spend time revisiting well-traveled story territory and giving it new life and new detail, especially given that the story is in many ways more about the next generation as it was about the original heroes I came to see.

I also thought Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, in addition to exploring the reliable series themes of the vulnerabilities and blindness created by and yet the ultimate power of love, hit on something very real and very natural in focusing on sons struggling with the legacies of their dads and dads struggling with their own pasts in trying to raise their sons. We know how difficult it can be in this world to grow up the child of a famous or infamous father, and it seems like it would be exponentially worse in the world of Wizarding Britain, which is so obsessed with family and bloodlines.

I don’t think I would ever recommend someone start with Cursed Child (and if you’re reading this and haven’t read the series for some reason, fair warning: this is very much written for people who know and love Harry Potter, and please borrow my copy of Sorcerer’s Stone at your leisure), but I think it’s a worthy addition to the series, I’m extremely jealous of anyone who gets to see it play out on stage, and if this exemplifies what J.K. Rowling’s version of Harry’s future is I would love to read more of it.

author: Jessica Cope
title: Great story line
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2016
content: I did enjoy the story line but I found myself missing the usual first person point of view with every detail being told from one characters POV with his/her thoughts on everything. There were a couple instances I yearned for the usual extensive detail of JKR's other books. But overall I couldn't put it down and really enjoyed the plot twist!

Nevertheless, the script form just doesn't hold up against all the other great Harry Potter books.  Hope J.K. comes up with another book, not another script. author: Phillip Tomasso III
title: An excellent 8th installment!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2016
content:
J.K. Rowling, John Tiffany & Hack Thorne
HARRY POTTER and the Cursed Child
Arthur A. Levine / Scholastic
Young Adult / Fantasy

Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is not a novel. It is a play. The story is by Rowling, and was written by Rowling, Thorne, and Tiffany It is the eight Harry Potter installment, and premiered on a stage in London on July 30, 2016.

This book takes place some 19 years after the Deathly Hallows (Book 7). Albus Potter, the son of Harry and Ginny, is headed to Hogwarts. His biggest fear is the Sorting Hat. He does not want to wind up in Slytherin. Always at odds with his father, Albus knows he will never make it into Gryffindor. It is one more comparison to his father bound to deliver more disappointment.

On the Express to school, Albus befriends a boy sitting alone in one of the cars. Scorpius, like Albus, is plagued by the legend of his father. Although Harry's father was the Wizard of all Wizards--an impossible shadow to crawl out from under, Scorpius' father was the dreadful Draco Malfoy. No one likes him based on this fact alone, and the rumors that Voldemort might actually be his true father. No one, that is, except Albus.

When a Time Turner is recovered, a device allowing for time travel, the tale quickly spins out of control. Amos Diggory (who's son, Cedric Diggory -- the boy murdered in Goblets of Fire by Voldemort) wants Harry to go back in time and save his son; to make it as though the death never happened.

Taking it upon himself to make things right, to maybe impress his own father, Albus and Scorpius, team up with Delphi Diggory (Amos' niece), in an attempt to save Cedric from an untimely death. Their journeys back in time mess up the present. They change the future. Timelines cross.

The damaged caused may be too significant to fix. Harry, Ron, Hermione, Ginny, and Draco Malfoy are desperate to save Albus, and Scorpius. They fear the return of Voldemort -- and the possible present world where Voldemort isn't just alive, but where he rules the world! Time is of the essence. If the newly revealed prophecy comes to light, the world that they once knew, and loved, would be gone, changed forever!

The play is taut. The Acts, and Scenes perfectly laid out. The story is filled with emotion. It is most definitely a tale about father's and sons. Parents and kids. Depression and hope. Division and reconciliation. The final Scenes brought me to tears. As a fan of the Harry Potter saga, it was amazing to see this story end where Harry Potter's legacy began. Very emotional. I would give anything to see the play. I suppose I will have to hope they make it into a film. I loved placing this finished book on my shelf alongside Rowling's other titles.

Phillip Tomasso
Author of the Severed Empire Series
Wizard's Rise
Wizard's War
Queens of Osiris

author: S Kat K
title: Really Good, but Less Engrossing than the Originals
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2016
content: It was fun to go back into the world of Harry Potter. At first, the play structure distracted me, but before long I didn't even notice it. I think my only issue with it can't be helped. Because it is a play, it's considerably shorter than a normal Harry Potter book. I think one of the best things about those books is that you can get fully engrossed in the world and stay a while. The Cursed Child is so condensed in comparison. It's still a full story; you're not left hanging. It's just not quite the all-consuming experience that Potter fans are used to. The story line is fun, though. Overall, another great read.

author: Kaki
title: Don't expect 1-7 and you will happy.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2016
content: I enjoyed this edition. It is not the original nor did I expect that. Good ending and an easy, fast read.

author: Pauline Cathrine  Gleisberg
title: Not the Harry Potter you may remember but overall a great message
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: Honestly I was not expecting to have an experience like I had reading these books as a child. I expected Harry much more grown-up and I have to say I got when I was looking for on that front. I thought the authors did a relatively good job developing the relationship between Albus and Harry. The friendship between Albus and Scorpius was a bit forced… How many times did they have to say that they were friends. Overall I think the message of the book was that your actions no matter how seemingly small can have a profound impact on your future and the future of those around you. That being said I didn't particularly appreciate all of the resurrections and reprisals of characters that were supposedly left in peace at the end of last original Harry Potter book. I can't help but think that the authors put Harry and Albus in potentially traumatic situations  to draw them closer together. This is unfortunate but it is a particularly useful plot device considering that they were trying to have so much relationship development happen in so little time. Overall this was a great book considering the amount of action that is packed into less than 400 pages.

title: Remember, this is a play!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2016
content: I will start out by saying THIS IS A PLAY! It is not written like a novel, so if you aren't willing to overlook that, this is not a book for you. This wasn't a great book, but it wasn't horrible either. I actually enjoyed it. I am a bit sad about how quick of a read it was. I like how this was more about Albus and Scorpius. Harry, Ron, and Hermione take a back burner, along with Ginny and Draco. I will add that I am happy that I didn't re-read the HP series before reading this. I think that would have made it harder to enjoy. I do recommend this play to anyone who liked the HP series as long as they keep all this in mind :-)

author: Susan MacKay-Logue
title: Happy to be back with Harry
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: Being reunited with Harry Potter and the gang in script form is tricky business. The storyline holds to Rowling's twisty standards, but the format does not allow for her rich descriptions, which are so much of her writing charm. The tale is solid, but it is a quick read, which for many HP fans will not be enough. I loved reading the tale in script format, as my imagination could fill in the blanks, but I long for more Harry and friends and am sad that I have already finished it. I can imagine that the play is quite entertaining.

author: E. N.
title: The new book isn't really a book; it's a conversation in a shadow location dependent on your own imagination
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2016
content: The story was great and its message profound, yet it was written as a dialogue for use in theater, so I missed the great images that JK Rowling created through her prose. Even though the story is good, the absence of any information about the scene or background thoughts of the characters made it seem "plain". If you are a reader that focuses totally on dialogue in the story, you may be happy with this book.  For me, it was a shadow of the former books, but I award points to the writers for the story, though NO HOUSE CUP!

author: Michelle Hilton
title: Can't get enough of Harry Potter!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2016
content:
I'm a big Harry Potter fan and loved the 7 book series. This was an interesting follow up that let's you see what could have happened. It was nice to see what happened to the famous trio and even see former enemies work together.

People need to understand this is a SCREENPLAY and not a novel. You do not get the detailed imagery that you get with a novel. If you have never read a screenplay, you will be slightly disappointed. I'm looking forward to reading "Fantastic Beasts" next.

author: La La in the Library

date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: There were some really ridiculously cheesy parts and a pretty good sized coincidence near the end, and some small inconsistencies with the original storyline, like how long it takes to brew polyjuice potion, but there were more good parts and they were wondrously good. The main friendship in the story is fabulous. I also cried.

author: Lisa
title: Remember...this was made for theater.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 30, 2016
content: Yes some of the dialogue is cheesy.  Yes some of the situations have little development.  Yes they could not quite figure out how to get Ron involved in a satisfying way. Yes this is made for theater.  The best way to enjoy this book is imagining it being played out on stage.  The fact is, it was not made for readers so you are not going to get the same feel you did for the last 7 stories.  Personally, it was very nostalgic to revisit Hogwarts and these characters I loved.  I never felt like Malfoy had a satisfying ending or the redeeming moment that he deserved, so I loved that we kind of see that through his nerdy, incredibly adorable son.  If I am in West End and manage to get tickets, I would love to see this play out.  If WB makes a movie, I will watch it.  This can be enjoyable if you have the proper mindset.

author: Seth Robins
title: Great read. I enjoyed it for what it was
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2016
content: Great read. I enjoyed it for what it was...a play, and was not caught up in what it was not..a novel. I liked the addition of new characters, the unpredictable nature of all the characters (old and new), the vulnerability showed in all the characters, and the mystery as to who was really the cursed child--even after the work is finished, there is still the lingering question that has more than one answer.

author: Jaclyn L
title: It's Not That Bad
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
I am a HUGE fan of Harry Potter and JK Rowling, but even I think some HP fans got a little ahead of themselves with what their expectations for this "book" was going to be about.  A lot of the reviews on here are pretty telling of that.  I think a lot of fans were expecting typical Harry, Hermoine, and Ron high jinx which you just don't get from this story.  It lacks JK Rowling's magical touch, but that is because she didn't write it.  She came up with a story with these 2 men, and in turn these 2 men turned it into a play.  Play scripts aren't the easiest to read sometimes.  They tend to lack dimension and can have characters coming off a little flat.  For this particular story some of the flatness does come from the writing.  There are moments that could have definitely been better, but I also think some of the lack luster moments are nothing like that while you sit and watch the actors weave their magic into the characters they are portraying.
After all the negative reviews I read I was a little hesitant to start even reading, but half way through I realized it wasn't as awful as some of the more melodramatic reviews are portraying it to be.  Is it the same Harry that we've all grown up with no; but that's just it who is the exact same as they were 19 years ago?  Harry is almost 40 overworked and living a rather mundane life compared to his adolescent years.  The play deals with far more dare I say muggle issues and much less of the wizarding world magic we've all been use to.
This story won't work for everyone who is a lover of this series and I can see why.  For me this story has in no way changed how I feel about the series, as other have felt it has ruined it for them.  If you are on the fence I'd say read it. Definitely go in with an open mind.

author: Patt O'Neil
title: Would have preferred prose over a script, but an excellent story still.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2017
content: Like other Harry Potter stories, Ms. Rowling captures the emotional essence of the lead's friendships, and now family, and makes us experience the Wizarding world through his eyes. I would have preferred this have been written in prose as opposed to a script, but still a worthy addition to my HP library.

author: chad mccartney
title: harry
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 25, 2017
content: good books.

author: Laurie Prim
title: So nice to visit with friends again!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 29, 2016
content:
I’ve read all the Harry Potter books, and though I don’t share the, shall we say, obsession, that many people feel, I loved the first (Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone) and seventh (Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows) books, and really liked the five in between.

Reading this Harry Potter book feels different, obviously, than the previous seven, as it is written as a play. I liked seeing how much can be done using (almost) only dialogue, and I liked how it felt like slipping right back into the world of characters I—along with the rest of the world—came to know and love so well. I am not, however, a fan of time travel, which was central to this book’s plot so that detracted a bit for me. Still, it’s a fun, must-read book for the Harry Potter world, which let’s face it, along with Frozen, we’re all just living in.

I would love to see the actual play, and can’t imagine how they pull off all that magic on stage! (

author: Ajab
title: Scriptum
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
There are already quite a few reviews on instead of reviewing the book from my opinion, I'll just try and present some points on the nature of the book itself.

The first thing to note is that this is a play. It is not a novel, but a play. That's why a lot of die hard fans are upset: they're criticisms include how the plot moves too quickly, how there isn't the classic flavour of Rowling-ian style, and how it seems a bit haphazard. The truth is, they're criticisms are true, but misplaced.

This is a script for a play to be preformed in front of a live audience. It is not a novel. It is a play which has to be preformed within two or three hours, and which has dialogue which can be followed easily (complex style may be fun to read, but if you start trying to decipher what actors are saying you'll start to miss out on the dialogue).

So if you're going to buy it, remember this, it will read like a script. And like all scripts, it will have jumps in between, and the story will move quickly and will be limited by the logistical capabilities of the actual world. I think the analogy to the fanfic is a good one, and I think this is a good fanfic.

To conclude, I'd suggest you try and read some Pottermore from Rowling's website. If you like that sort of thing, you can purchase the book and read it. Or, if you want to truly enjoy it, go watch it in the theatre.

author: Caleb Marsh
title: Worth the read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: As a diehard Harry Potter fan I went into this book with an open mind and with modest expectations. I knew that it wouldn't be as good as the original 7, but I was not disappointed by any means with the product. It provided a sense of nostalgia to longtime Harry Potter fans while also telling a story worth any Harry Potter fan's time. I would recommend this book/script to anyone who enjoys Harry Potter!

author: Clarisha Blaylock
title: I am a HP fan so I liked it. However
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2016
content: I am a HP fan so I liked it. However, it wasn't as AMAZING as I hoped! Still worth the buy!

author: Chelsea Pulsipher
title: Nearly Perfect
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2019
content: The book is in great shape-havent read it yet but one slight rough edge on one side of the book. Otherwise, perfect.

author: Dan Chabas
title: Worthwhile, But What's With All the Hugging?
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2017
content:
In terms of a worthy successor to the cannon, HP & the Cursed Child is a bit frothy like a good latte after a lifetime of black coffee. Its plot is engaging but light & sentimental the way visiting the theme park must be. It is a script, of course, which means we're missing at least half the storytelling that we would see on the stage.  The Harry Potter universe is a comfortable place to live in again, but I can't imagine one trying to understand it without having read the books;  it seems like all the requisite explanations are there;  again, I think the art is in the stage production.  Although it approaches being derivative, the play almost counts on your expecting what's next to come. This isn't Doctor Who,  though, in which of late all the old villains seem to pop up, for no particular reason, paving over their previous selves.  In fact, my favorite character, without saying too much, is Draco Malfoy. He is wonderfully-rendered to play on and against our expectations. It is almost his story.  Certainly, no one has a better vantage point on the major theme of fathers and sons.  Reading Shakespeare to ourselves, we are always taught to create a theater of the mind. That's what has to happen here to appreciate this story as best as possible in script form. Otherwise, I'm waiting for the promised Broadway run, which will spawn a traveling performance that I'll be waiting at the station to welcome.

P.S. What's with all the hugging & outing of emotions. I'm American & I got squirmy. If Harry had spoken like this about his emotions, A- He would have received progressively harder chucks on the shoulder from Ron, & B- He would have been so emotionally-stable, the idea of running away from everyone & taking on Voldemort single-handedly would have been  impossible, end of story

author: Mario
title: Be Careful of Expectations
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content:
Expectations are dangerous things, and realize this is a play, not a full blown book. It's also a play of a series that's been done and finished for many years now, movies and everything, even if the world itself hasn't quite died with Rowlings great charity books and new Magical Beasts movies.

Still, this story is good. It fits Harry Potter, and is fun to read. There's just under 300 pages of actual story and because it's written as a play there's little to know description for any of the characters or settings as you're expected to know what they look like already, and the read is extremely fast. There's enough twists and turns to make this a great page turner and I'm happy to add it as the 8th story to my Harry Potter shelf.

If I had any complaints, it's that the story definitely feels written by a guy who doesn't really know the world or characters well enough and whose name I'll never see anywhere but on this book. A lot of the story uses repeated events to get itself going rather than inventing anything new, and sticks with replaying events already written by the master JK Rowling. As a result it is a rehashing story, but it's done well enough that I'll excuse most of it to call it a great play-book. The ending is also completely tied in an extremely tight package that one would expect from any "they lived happily ever after" story, rather than the world-changing events that happened at the end of the 7th book. While this isn't a problem for fantasy tales, I still feel it would have been better had something meaningful been added at the end instead of the two heroes looking out over the sunset. Then again, it isn't my story, and my expectations are always going to be greater than what's delivered.

title: Great book to read.

It was great reading this story and seeing the many changes in HP, Hermione, Ron and Draco as they were parents. Also many surprises that were found in this book as well - it had me slack-jawed and fast turning the pages to make sure that what I read wasn't real (hint - the alternate reality with no HP). Get the book!
The reason I gave it 4 stars was in some parts - it became very slow and tedious to try and read through.

content: "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" is like a reunion show for a sitcom you once loved or like the "Sex and the City" movie: the magic of seeing beloved characters once more, the sweetness of nostalgia, makes for an enjoyable experience. That said, the play format, and the way it necessitates telling rather than showing (I don't have a quote, but stage instructions like "he's clearly crushed" are sprinkled throughout) makes this installment a less-than-perfect read. That's not to say it wasn't a fabulous script. The scenes and pacing unfold engagingly, but as a book, it falls a short of J.K. Rowling's normal perfection.

author: Stephen T. Hopkins
title: Time
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 9, 2016
content:
The eighth book in the Harry Potter series titled, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, Parts I & II, is the script of a play set two decades after the last novel. Harry’s son, Albus, is at Hogwarts, and the play delves into the theme of parents and children, while using the structure of time to move the action. I liked it well enough for what it is: something different in form, structure and time period. I didn’t hate it much for what it isn’t: a big sprawling novel that absorbs one’s total attention like the earlier installments, a book I might have enjoyed more than this one.

Rating: Four-star (I like it)

author: M. Doenges
title: If you're old Harry Potter reader with a good memory of all the wonderful settings
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2016
content:
If you've never read Harry Potter, then this isn't the place to start.  It depends not only upon the general premise or some characters from the previous series, but also upon some very specific past plot sequences.  Indeed the plot of this book is very clever, hence the four stars.  If you don't already have a sense of setting and characters, you will not find enough here.  If you are Jonesing for the next Harry Potter book, again I'd say stop. This is not the next book; it's the next story.  Big difference.  As this is a play script, there is virtually no setting.  Unlike reading a novel with its rich descriptions of things and moods and circumstances, this is a play written sparingly.  The clever story hangs upon dialog and some simple stage directions.

If you're old Harry Potter reader with a good memory of all the wonderful settings, that you can call to mind as the play unfolds, and if you know the characters well enough to pick up with them much later, then you love this.  The new characters in the form of children are a wonderful addition.

author: Gypsi
title: Flawed but Enjoyable
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child - Parts One & Two is a play written by Thorne and Tiffany, based on a story by Rowling.  In it, Harry and his youngest son, Albus, have a difficult relationship.  The legacy of "Harry Potter" doesn't sit well on Albus's young shoulders; he feels exceptionally different from his father, and even perceives that Harry doesn't love him.

Albus and his best friend find themselves in an adventure that ultimately shows Albus's brave spirit and caring heart, yet nearly destroys the hard won peace of the wizarding world.

Many of the beloved characters from the Harry Potter past are in the Cursed Child in some form or another, from the Golden Trio to the Trolley Witch.  Some familiar scenes were revisited, which was poignant.  An iconic scene was recreated under slightly different circumstances; I'm convinced it was done just to make the fans blubber--and I'm not ashamed to say that I did.  The new plot itself is fun, serious, exciting--just like the original stories.

My difficulties with the Cursed Child were few, but definite.  I think that one of the adult characters had changed more than was believable.  I think that one of the child characters was a little too good to be true.  As for the mystery/secret/whatever it should be called, it was entirely too easy to figure out very early on in the plot.  Also, some of the scenes felt forced, as if the writers were trying too hard to wring out emotion.  For these reasons, I have to say that I "liked" rather than "loved" it.

Overall, the Cursed Child--while flawed--is a pleasant, nostalgic trip back to the Potterverse, and introduces new and endearing characters to the fans

author: Corie Lawson
title: Must read for Harry Potter Fans
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 19, 2016
content:
This book took me about three hours to read nonstop. Before I start this review, I want you to know that J.K. Rowling did NOT write this book, Jack Thorne did. This is written like a play, not a novel, so don't be surprised.

This takes place Nineteen years after The Battle of Hogwarts that took place in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows by J.K. Rowling. All the characters are grown and they have kids themselves. Harry is married to Ginny and Ron to Hermione. Harry and Ginny have two sons, James Sirius and Albus Severus and a daughter, Lily Luna. Ron and Hermione have two kids, Rose and Hugo. Professor McGonagall is the Headmistress of Hogwarts, Hermione Granger is over the Ministry of Magic and Harry Potter is the Head of the Department of Magical Law Enforcement.

I will not give a full synopsis but I will give some spoilers.

The beginning is a little jumpy. It starts with Albus' and Rose's first year at Hogwarts. It then goes to their third year. It then goes to the next summer when a criminal by the name of Theodore Nott makes a time-turner and Harry potter receives it. (All the time-turners were destroyed after the Battle of Hogwarts.)

Scorpius' mother then passes away and then a year later Amos Diggory shows up at Harry's house, knowing that there is a time-turner that exists, asking to bring his son back. Harry refuses and with Amos is a woman by the name of Delphi, who is the niece of Amos.

Delphi manages to tell Albus and Scorpius about the time-turner and gets them to steal it from Hermione's office. They then use it to stop Cedric from winning the Triwizard Tournament.With this, they change the timelines.

Later after all of this, they find out that Voldemort has a daughter with Bellatrix Lestrange and Harry and Ron have to save them. Delphi turns out to be Delphini, Voldemort's daughter. Her goal was to stop her father from trying to kill Harry Potter because it made him weak.

END OF SPOILERS

Overall, I thought this book was ok. It wasn't as bad as a lot of people said it was, but I enjoyed it. I wish that there was more about the older characters themselves as well. I do recommend this book to any Harry Potter fan out there.

author: Debar Southworth
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 18, 2018
content: Enjoyed the book

author: ExAnimo
title: Read With A Grain of Salt
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
While many readers have voiced their concerns over the writing style and how it pales in comparison to the original series, I would offer the following point. This work is written in such a style to facilitate live performances. As such, it seems unfair to compare the extent to which characters are developed and the overall plot complexity to J.K. Rowling's original series. The original seven were not bound by the added task of producing a narrative which can easily be digested in a spoken format (in addition to proving itself worthy of the original series as a standalone literary text).

With that said, I found the latest installment of the Harry Potter series to be an enjoyable read in the sense that it allowed me to revisit old friends made many years ago (even if only for an afternoon). Harry Potter and the Cursed Child reignited that childlike imaginative spark in me, which is the reason I fell in love with the world of Hogwarts in the first place. Without going into too much detail, the play focuses on the difficulty Harry and Ginny's son, Albus Severus, has with being the underperforming child of the "the boy who lived". Albus struggles with living up to the reputation of the Potter name, and subsequently becomes a bit of a loner who does not hold the same esteem for Hogwarts as his parents would have hoped. The piece also speaks to the difficulty Harry has parenting a somewhat rebellious Albus, who is often viewed by others to be "different". When Albus befriends the child of a certain former Slytherin house member with whom Harry shared several altercations with during his time at Hogwarts, Harry is tasked with determining whether he should intervene to keep Albus out of trouble, or rather to put his preconceived notions of Malfoy's only son aside and allow Albus to continue to spend time with his one true friend. In addition, Harry must also make Albus understand the difference between seeking out trouble versus confronting it when it presents itself to you -- a lesson Albus eventually learns throughout the course of the play.

If you're a fan of the original series, it's my recommendation you give this piece a try. It is a fast read, and an interesting spin on the original storyline - -  one in which a second generation of Potters, Weasley-Grangers, and Malfoys tantalize their parents and Hogwarts faculty members; a skill their parents mastered only 19 years prior.

author: Andrew Hanks
title: Great Read!  Fast Moving with Suprising ywists

author: Rev. Day
title: "Harry Potter" forever!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
content: I am spoiled by the depth and characterizations in all the other "Harry Potter" books and the beautiful renditions of the movies. I'm sure the play itself would be fun to see..The story line is good and some of it is compelling and easily visualized. I was frustrated by the characterization of Ron as a grown imbecile when he had been coming into his own at the end of the original story. This also left Hermione cold and more aloof than I desired. The stage direction seemed bleak in comparison to the richness of interactions of the characters in the movies  and that they were so faithful to the written words . Perhaps the fact that it is only a script is what has provoked my disappointment, But I'm glad that I purchased and read this new work.

author: Patricia
title: It's a play, not a novel!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
Reading a play is always different. It has a powerful plot line while spotlighting difficulties between fathers and sons, which is weird, given that we have known these fathers since they were 11 years old.  At any rate, we see some pretty unreasonable fathers and some pretty thoughtless teens.... and are given a dose of evil in between. I'm about to dig in for my 2nd read and am only sorry that it isn't/wasn't fleshed out into a novel.

A caveat: if you have not read the 7-book Harry Potter series, do not start with this play because you won't understand a word.

author: Cheshire Cat
title: Thoughtful plot; Love the characters
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
So what's the verdict? Did I like it? Yes. Yes, I did.

Now, this did not have the same magical feel as it would have had had it been written as a complete story and not just a play script. It's primarily dialogue. But I love dialogue, so that worked well for me. But descriptions, scene-building, etc, are mostly lost. I wouldn't recommend this to someone who has never read Harry Potter before, as there are a lot of assumptions made about what the reader should already know. I've read other plays where there is much more description, so comparatively I cannot give this 5 stars because I think they could have done more.

But what they did include - the plot, the character interactions - was quite profound. I don't want to give away spoilers about the main conflict of the story, but the questions that arise were really thoughtful. I imagine fans of the series may have had these same questions after reading the series. So I love how the big plot point was adddressed. It makes the characters think, but makes the reader think as well. I thought it was a really fascinating twist on the HP world at large.

Of course, what really touched me were the characters. This was really a multi-generational story. We get our middle aged favorites, as well as their children. I loved wrapping myself up in all my love for these characters, old and new. The thought that went into Harry's relationship with his son, Albus, was very touching. I really liked how the father/son relationship was explored in all its complexities and I was really moved by it. I also loved the friendship between Albus and Scorpius. I loved seeing them as individuals, who they were in regards to their famous/notorious fathers raising of them, how they came into their own at Hogwarts, and who they became as they sought out such an unlikely but absolutely necessary friendship with the other. They were the sweetest besties. Even the healing of other older relationships was quite touching. And, of course, there was a cameo or two that tested my tear ducts and gave my heart lots of feels.

Overall, I really enjoyed this extra glimpse into the Harry Potter world. I simply love these characters. I would have loved an actual novel instead of a play, but regardless, I loved the overall story (and would love to see the play live).

author: Amazon Customer
title: is not quite the perfect parent. But really
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content:
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, J. K Rowling, Jack Thorne, & John Tiffany.
“Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” is a play based on a story by J. K. Rowling, but written by Jack Thorne and John Tiffany for the stage. Set in the present, Harry, now a father of three is struggling with his relationship to his youngest son, Albus Serverus. Harry, it turns out, is not quite the perfect parent. But really, who is? Albus, in my view is a pretty typical teenager, unhappy and embarrassed by his famous father. In a misguided attempt to win his father’s approval, Albus and his best bud Scorpius Malfoy get themselves in a real pickle. As always, friendship is at the heart of any Harry Potter story, and I loved that the friendship between Albus and Scorpius was a strong factor in the plot. Scorpius is a delight and has some great scene-stealing lines. I don’t view this play as Harry Potter #8. It’s really just a short story that’s been turned into a play. I know there is a lot of outrage by some fans, who feel this work falls short of Rowling’s best, but I quite enjoyed the play; how could I not? It allowed me the opportunity to visit Hogwarts and all my favorite characters again.
Highly recommended for Potter fans everywhere.

author: Adam French
title: Time Travel???
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2016
content: Really fun read if your like me and excited about more stories in the Harry Potter Universe. Its best not to try to compare a stage play to a 1k page book. Its like complaining the TV series isn't as good as the Hollywood Movie. I liked the new characters but didn't like the time travel. Seriously why borrow events from the past? Be truly original.

author: songbird
title: it does not contain the usual quirky prose we've come to know and love from Rowlings
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: The working script of a play, it does not contain the usual quirky prose we've come to know and love from Rowlings.  The play starts with the last scen of Deathly Hallows, and through the magic of time travel revisits the events of Goblet of Fire.  Key elements of the story are the relationships between Harry and his son Albus, and Albus and Scorpio Malfoy.  The ongoing theme is how small changes in the past can mean large differences in the present.  As an adult who has read a lot of science fiction, I pretty much figured everything out halfway through the play.  Still, it was enjoyable to revisit the world of Harry Potter, and while I didn't love the play the way I loved the novels, I did enjoy reading it.

author: Danielle
title: Harry Potter's World Will Never Get Old
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
I was so happy to be transported back into the magical world of Harry Potter one more time. I never thought that would happen again and for that I am grateful. Overall, I'm glad I read the screenplay. I had heard many not-so-good reviews of the book and decided to go into it as blindly as possible. I was able to avoid any spoilers and was very aware that this was a screenplay and not a book and that it wouldn't be the same as a Harry Potter book, and that helped me to enjoy it more and just take it for what it is: another new Harry Potter experience.

HP8 is not perfect. The writing is often quite flat and SO FAR from J.K. Rowling's voice that at times the characters don't even feel like themselves (I'm looking at you, Ron...). It is largely plot and action based, and I'm sure the actors would bring so much more life into the script when performed, but to read it certainly felt unauthentic at times.

Where the old characters fall a bit flat, the new ones shine. Albus and Scorpius have an enviable friendship. It was interesting to see the children of two arch-enemies become best friends, completely disregarding their fathers' opinions of the other family. It was also interesting to see Hogwarts through the eyes of an unpopular boy who wasn't particularly good at magic or Quidditch. Albus' experience at school was the complete opposite of Harry's and, in my opinion, made Hogwarts feel a little bit more realistic.

I loved the theme of family in this book. It was so satisfying to see our trio happy with families of their own and jobs that were actually perfect for them. Regardless of how I felt about the actual choice of storyline, the writing style, or anything else, I still loved the book because it was another chance to be immersed in the wizarding world without knowing what happens next, and that is a rare thing that I haven't had the privilege of experiencing for many years.

Harry Potter is and always will be my first true love when it comes to books. The original Harry Potter books inspired and engrossed me like nothing has since, and have proved themselves to endure as phenomenal works for nearly my whole life.

I remember being six or seven years old and my mom purchased Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone to read aloud to me at night before bed. As they came out, I checked out the next books at the library and devoured them. I became obsessed with the series -- I had SO MUCH HP merch back in the day. Shirts, a backpack, decorations for my room, a clock, video games, literally everything. I had my mom pre-order the new books for me and waited at the front door for UPS to show up. I attended midnight releases of the books and movies as I got older. I literally grew up alongside Harry Potter and I am so grateful for those wonderful experiences, and I will continue to be grateful for any little extension of that world that I might get.

WARNING: SPOILERS AHEAD! IF YOU HAVE NOT READ THE BOOK, I RECOMMEND STOPPING HERE.

It was absolutely heartbreaking to read about Albus' trials during the first part of the book. I felt so sad for him to feel so lonely and useless at Hogwarts. I hated that he felt like a disappointment to Harry for being sorted into Slytherin. I wanted to help Albus and Harry to connect with each other and for Harry to be able to help Albus with his demons.

I was terrified during the portion of the time travel when Albus and Scorpius discover the alternate reality where Voldemort is ruler. I had never considered that alternative -- that Voldemort was victorious during the Battle of Hogwarts, that he killed Harry and prevailed to lead the wizarding world into darkness. I'm glad it was a short piece of the book because it was so horrible, but it was interesting to consider and also put into perspective a bit more that weight of Harry's greatness that Albus felt he had to live up to.

The back and forth time travel got a bit tiresome at times, but I did not see the twist with Delphi coming AT ALL. I love when I can be surprised by a twist or turn in a book and certainly was here, although thinking about Voldemort's and Bellatrix's daughter is pretty disgusting. It's very interesting that J.K. Rowling decided to make that canon.

One last thing -- THANK YOU to J.K. Rowling for making Hermione Minister of Magic! I could not believe what I had read when that was revealed and was SO PROUD of my frizzy-haired girl for coming so far. Hermione was the first character I remember ever truly LOVING and identifying with and it was so wonderful to see her turn out to be everything she deserved.

author: Chan Myae Khine
title: Not Perfect, But still HarryPotter-ish
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Repello Muggletum!

I've just finished it. Here's a quick review without spoiler.

Well, a bit of spoiler that wouldn't hurt your pleasure of reading. Albus Severus Potter was (checked below for spoiler) And Albus & Scorpius (Malfoy) are main characters. And there is one new character we would have never thought of otherwise.

Before you start reading, remember it is script for a play, not your usual novel. So, if you have never read a play, that'd be a bit odd. It goes by scene with dialogues and description of the actions of characters. I'm not sure about you but I wish I could watch the play, too! It'd be a magnificient one, I reckon.

It is so good that you could read a lot about many old characters with a balanced blend of new ones. As we potterheads are so attached to Harry, there are countless heartwrenching moments to witness the scenes between Harry and Albus.

Albus is, compareing to Harry Potter, ... I think I better not write this.

There are a lot of jaw-dropping moments, like double or triple twists, but as we all know good things win at the end (with some sacrifices) in the stories like Harry Potter, the feeling that this wouldn't end up this way always distracted me from feeling the scary or sad moments. This is, if anything, the only bad side about this book.

The book is fairly short, only like 2-hour read. I wish there were more scenes about the eldest son or the youngest daughter.

The ending, I meant the last words on the last page, is sort of cliche for a play. But the general ending of the plot after climax looks pretty HarryPotter-ish. As it is a Harry Potter book, SPOILER, (check below for spoiler)

Giving that the last book was published in 2007 the last movie was released in 2011, this is quite a uplifting retouch to our memories with characters we admire.

I've just learnt many hated this book. Again, this is script not novel. And yes, I totally agree that this is not as good as other books but how can you resist not to read this after 9 years of missing them?

Go read it and enjoy!

author: Jason Hampton
title: Fun read
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2019
content: Enjoyed this small look into the Harry Potter universe now. The characters don't seem quite the same as the books, but as a whole it was a fun fun read.

author: A. Johns
title: This is good as long you are clear what you're getting
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
content:
There seems to be some confusion from certain buyers of this "book" about what they are getting and comparing it to the original seven works of the Harry Potter heptalogy. This is a bound script book. It's literally the script to a stage play of a new story set in the HP universe. As such, it is almost all dialogue with very little of the detailed exposition that so many of us loved in the original series.

Keeping in mind that this is merely a script, I give the work 4 stars. Would I have loved to have seen it fleshed out into a proper eighth book - of course I would have. So would almost everyone who has read it, but it is what it is and as an HP fan I'm glad that the story has continued with the main three characters set 22 years in the future.

Without giving away too many spoilers, the story mostly revolves around the sons of Harry Potter and Draco Malfoy and their daddy issues that get them into lots of trouble. Of the two, I found that Draco's son, Scorpius, was easily the most entertaining and distinct character but Albus Potter was also well defined.

As far as the adults, Hermione is very Hermione-like and Ron is exactly what you'd expect a middle-aged Ron to be like. The one character that just didn't ring very authentic to me was adult Harry. There was just something off about his depiction and his relationship with his son Albus that didn't ring true to me.

It's a quick read being that it's a 300 page script book so be prepared for that. And maybe I had lower expectations knowing that this wasn't a "real" book, but I still think it's a very welcome addition to any Potter fan.

title: Four Stars

Would love to see the actual play. I do wish the story was a little more groundbreaking but it's very enjoyable to learn more about Harry Potter's life after Hogwarts.

author: Danielle Rohde
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2016
content: Fun, fast read.  Good for those wanting more of the Harry Potter series.

author: Joe
title: A great addition to the Harry legecy!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
I know there are a lot of neigh Sayers out there, but I really enjoyed the play.  As a director of theatrical productions I could picture the story as it took place on the stage in my mind.  Of course I had images of the original actors and their voices as I read it, but I thought it was conceptually a real achievement.
It has to be nearly impossible to take something so well loved by readers and attempt a new piece of art with it.  The only way to enjoy this is to allow that part of you that loves Harry Potter and allow your imagination and your love of the characters take you on another exciting ride.  Yes, some of the dialogue is a bit shaky and you can tell it wasn't written by J.K., but it's still pretty amazing.  I loved the whole father-son dynamic. It just flowed right from the ending of the original series.
My only regret is that I am not going to see the play tonight!  I want to know how they make all this wonderful magic happen on the stage.  Plays are not really meant to be read, but to be witnessed.  It may have been a mistake to release the play to the masses so quickly. Perhaps it would have been a smoother move to let the play speak for itself until word of mouth demanded a need for the public to read the script.  However, I for one, am thrilled that I was able to read this wonderful addition to the Harry Potter collection and am saving up for my ticket to see the actual show!

title: It was just like sitting in the theater again

content: I thought that this play was so clearly written that I could see the action in my head. As parents, the Granger- Weasleys and the Potters were true to life, not as you could have pictured them 25 years before. No one is perfect! Malfoy and Potter have boys that they can't figure out. Ron is still doing magic , jokes, and his interest in Muggle  driving hasn't changed. He and Hermione Granger have side parts. I loved the use of Polyjuice  as in earlier stories. Myrtle still exists. The worst thing about this play is I finished it in 2 hours. The best, I had no idea where it was going ahead of time.

author: Tom Shutt
title: Thank Dumbledore, It Didn't Suck!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
“All was well.” So ended the epic original saga of the Harry Potter wizarding world that so many of us grew up reading as children and adolescents. Despite the bodies, the bloodshed, the betrayals and broken bonds of brotherhood, all was well.

Well, perhaps not.

Opening onto a familiar scene—Harry Potter wishing his youngest son, Albus Severus Potter, a good first year at Hogwarts regardless of what house he is sorted into—this screenplay quickly sets the tone for how the rest of its story will proceed. In a whirlwind of snippets showing Albus’s first few years at Hogwarts in Pensieve-like rapid succession, we’re brought up to speed that Albus—indeed sorted into Slytherin House—is having a rough go of it at Hogwarts. He feels like a disappointment to his father, a stain upon the family legacy. He’s bold and decisive, and clever to boot, but isn’t blessed with the same abundance of friends or popularity Harry enjoyed/endured during his time at Hogwarts. To quote another popular play, he’s got a lot of brains but no polish.

And when the opportunity arises for Albus to redeem himself by rectifying one of his father’s greatest past mistakes, he jumps at it with all the reckless abandon a teenaged boy can muster.

From there, the script—and do not mistake this as a book, because it’s not, but rather a script for a play production, complete with stage directions—goes along at a pleasant clip, never slowing down longer than is necessary to introduce a new face or show off a new spell, of which there are a few.

You’ll feel familiar with the past characters, though as some other reviews have pointed out, it can sometimes feel more like fanfiction than a legitimate canon installment in the Harry Potter universe. Maybe it’s the subject of the story itself, but in many ways it falls short of feeling true.

The tone of the story, as well, lacks the same oomph seen at least in the later books in the Original Seven. The best I can describe it is: Imagine if Eoin Colfer had been commissioned to write a new Harry Potter novel. It’s for kids. It’s fun and fast and exciting at almost every single turn. Personally, I love Eoin Colfer’s books. He’s a genius for children’s literature. But when I step into a true addition to the Harry Potter canon, I want meat to the story, gravitas to the plot, and a huge amount of emotional commitment to the characters. And while I enjoyed what I read, it didn’t leave me with the sensation that I could read a whole series about the progeny of our original wizards and witches.

Ultimately, I very much enjoyed it for what it was. I laughed, I bounced my knees excitedly, and darn it all, I was almost moved to sniffles at one point near the end. The lightheartedness of The Tales of Beedle the Bard shine through here more than anything else, and if you’re looking for a sometimes tense but mostly joyful and refreshing romp with some childhood magic, you’ll enjoy spending a few hours reading this story as well.

author: Patti S.
title: HP and the Cursed Child
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2016
content: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child was a good read, but the stage directions were not specific enough.  It lacked the flow of the books written as novels.  I still read it twice and the second time it made more sense.  You need a good background and imagination to read this screen play.

author: Nicole Bryerton
title: Interesting turn in the wizarding world.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 23, 2018
content: I've never read a screen okay before. It was interesting not having all the surroundings to read about. But, it was interesting reading about the children of our favorite Harry potter characters. I just don't know if i was a huge fan of how the original characters were after they had grown. But, give it a read and see what you think.
