content: I must say that even thought the plot was interesting and I enjoyed to know what happened after the last book of Harry Potter, I must say it's not J.K. Rowling's usual style. And also I got the feeling that some of the characters have changed too much, not only in appearance, but also in their way of acting.  That's all I'm going to say. I wouldn't like to ruin the fun of reading it.

author: ,A. L. Green
title: Absorbing story, not really a sequel
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content:
You can't think of this as a sequel to the JK Rowling books because it is told in a different format (play vs book) and because ... ahem ... it is not actually written by J K Rowling. So if that's what you were expecting you will be disappointed. In addition, it tends to violate some aspects of the HP canon and unlike each HP book, it does not introduce any interesting magical or cultural aspect of the HP world to the reader.

Having said that, the story itself is quite interesting and really compelling in the 2nd half. I would recommend this as an interesting read on its own. But for the HP purists out there, give it a swerve.

author: Amazon Customer
title: If you go in with a good attitude and remember it is a play and meant ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
If you go in with a good attitude and remember it is a play and meant to be seen not read, you'll enjoy it. As a Harry Potter fan, I enjoyed getting a peak at what the future was for Harry and the gang beyond the epilogue in book 7.

Though one piece of the plot was fairly predictable, I still enjoyed it immensely. It in no way tops the the 7 book series but as I said above it was nice to have more to the story. It was an excellent way to spend my Sunday on HP's birthday.

author: Jean Carlos Tavarez
title: Happy to have the wizarding world revived
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: It was a good read. Sure it does not have the same feel of the novels written by J.K Rowling herself, but if you take that out of the equation it's a fun read. The story is pretty enthralling with some interesting twists  and the characters have changed a bit, but we do have to remember that "18 years" have passed and people in reality do change. If you are a Harry Potter fan you will probably enjoy the read, because it is a continuation of a great series, and you may find yourself wishing that is didn't end.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Though it had new characters and it was great to escape back to Potter land
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: Though it had new characters and it was great to escape back to Potter land, the story lines were not as original as advertised.

author: judy
title: A quick read.

author: Rishikesh
title: Too much time travel for my liking
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2016
content:
I am fed up of reboot/re-write through time travel ever since X Men: Days of Future Past. So, the number of instances time travel was used, was something I didn't feel comfortable with.

The only redeeming things for the play were few glimpses from the past of important events in Harry's life and good ending.

author: Engineer of Things
title: The play format kind of sucks, but it's not bad.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I am a huge Harry Potter fan and have been since the first book came out. Based on the reviews, I wasn't sure if buying the book was a great idea, but I enjoyed it. A few words of advice for fellow readers:

-The play format sucks. There's no getting around it. There's notes in italics on what the characters are doing, what scenery is changing, etc. Not ideal, but still readable.

-It gets a little corny. Go into it with a sense of humor, and also remembering that Harry was a bit bitter by the end of the 7th book. Relieved, yes, but still somewhat bitter.

*****SPOILER ALERT *******
-His son is in Slytherin. Happens in the first, oh, 15 pages, but that adds to the divide in the rest of the book and all of the teenage thinking that follows.

I honestly think it would be fantastic if not for the play format. But if you remember how all of the characters were and how they acted in the previous books, it's really not hard for your imagination to fill in the blanks.

It was very hard to read, being constantly distracted by the stage references.  I am thankful, however, that the screenplay was shared with the world, since not everyone has access to live theater performances.

author: Lord of the Books
title: It's a PLAY, not a book
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: Please understand that this is a play. It is not a book. There is minimal stage direction and little scenery description. It is primarily dialogue, but there are no clues as to how the person is speaking. I enjoyed the story. Truly. I would go see the play in a heartbeat. But reading this is not like reading Harty Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone. I miss all of the details from the books. It's also very short. But it's Harry Potter. That alone is worth 4 stars.

author: Amazon Customer

author: Dustin

author: Julie Ramsey
title: Different than what i thought
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2016
content: Ok the story i liked a lot. Enjoyed the characters new and old. Revisiting old friends and making new ones. They only thing is why couldn't they have put it out like a normal novel instead of a play. Or if you are going to put out a play, video tape it and have the option of seeing it as well. Overall the story was fantastic and definitely worth the read and i would love more.

author: Alicia @ A Kernel of Nonsense
title: Entertaining with a dash of nostalgia
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2016
content:
I tentatively include the label “Harry Potter, #8” for this play in the description above because ever since I heard there was going to be an eighth Harry Potter story, I’ve been wary of what to call it. I’m typically not a fan of “extras” after a series has ended. I usually regard these additions as optional canon because I feel most of the time it’s better for an author to leave well enough alone. So I approached Harry Potter and the Cursed Child in a different way, not as canon, but as a neat little “extra” that at the end of the day, I don’t necessarily have to consider a part of the Harry Potter universe. From the get-go, the play interfered with the headcanons I’ve created since the series ended. I’ve created futures for these characters and how their relationships have evolved and had a knee-jerk reaction to a particularly salty interaction between two characters at the beginning of the play. It was from this moment forward that I knew I wasn’t going to call this canon Harry Potter, but instead of focusing on the various aspects of the novel I couldn’t quite reconcile with my own thoughts on the HP world, I sat back and enjoyed the ride.

The focus of this play is Harry’s tumultuous relationship with his youngest son Albus. Uncomfortable with the extra attention that comes with being Harry Potter’s son, Albus feels like he’s destined to be a disappointment. He struggles with his identity throughout the story and because his father’s shadow looms large, it’s difficult for him to discover who he is apart from the legacy of his father. While I sympathized with Albus’ inner struggles, it was hard to find him entirely likable as he tended to indulge in self-pity at the detriment of other people’s own struggles. Harry finds it difficult to connect with Albus, who doesn’t seem to want anything to do with the famous Harry Potter, and this is where their relationship gets off track. It’s become almost impossible for Albus to separate how everyone perceives his father from who Harry actually is and Harry can’t understand the loneliness and social shunning Albus has endured at Hogwarts when his own view of the school is seen through a lens of idyllic nostalgia.

Of the secondary characters we are first introduced to, no one shines quite as bright as Scorpius Malfoy. This kid is what I hoped for when I imagined the new generation. He brings a lightness to the narrative despite the negativity surrounding him and his family’s connection to Voldemort. Scorpius knows how other people view him, but unlike Albus who seems to bruise under the weight of his ancestry, Scorpius remains defiant in a different sort of way. He is kind and loyal, willing to go to great lengths to protect the people he loves. Though many are determined to dislike him, Scorpius remains good-natured, confident that if given the chance, those with prejudice views will eventually see him for who he is and not what the imagine him to be.

Overall, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child was actually quite an entertaining read. I’m interested in the extra tidbits the play provides in terms of special effects, but even without it this story provided plenty of enjoyable moments and just the right amount of nostalgia.

author: Kindle Customer
title: A good read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: It's an amazing play, bringing the past into the present and getting everything  mixed up in the process. But the elements of the characters are still there, and if you allowed yourself to live through the original books, you mind will fill in the blanks.  They're still the same people and the world is still the same. A welcome memory!

I will go see this performed, somehow somewhere.

It's different than the rest of the series because it is written in play format, but it doesn't take long to adjust to it, and enjoy reading about the characters we all love and meet some we haven't met before.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Good enough for us die-hard Potterheads
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2016
content: I have to say i quite liked this 8th part of Harry Potter. I was quite worried that the book was going to be bad, due to the previous negative reviews I had read stating that it read like fan fiction and not like Rowling, however i was quite please with the outcome. I have to admit at times the characters did seem to act a bit too childish for my taste (compared to harry, ron and hermione's mature look on life.. but then again, they had harder life experiences than their children), but over looking that,  the main story was quite good and if you just really remind yourself that Rowling DID write this,  you can overcome the negative parts and learn to love the story as a whole. Recomended for any Potterhead out there!

I thought it was pretty great seeing them in a grown up and way more complex context. Harry's not perfect and he's not great at everything and he has emotional scars. Who wouldn't after what he went through?! I liked the plot, it was pretty cool revisiting some of the previous stories and I loved the alternate reality where Hermione was full on warrior resistance leader. As someone who has literally grown up with Harry Potter, as an adult fan this book is a success for me.

author: Tracy Whipple

date: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2017
content: I have read and heard a number of negative reviews from people that expected this screenplay to be the dynamic storytelling of the HP series combined with the cinematic powerhouse effects of specifically the last 4 movies. author: Annette brewer

I thought I'd be put off by the script formatting but I was able to read this book as a book not a script.  Again well done.

author: Robert Day
title: Four Stars

author: Frank
title: I can say its not my favorite story of all the books
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content: If you are a fan of the books and hesitating to read this new book, do so. Having grown up with these books and having read all the books more than once I look forward to sharing these books with my son when he is old enough to read. I was cautious to dive into this new story and finally I gave in and picked up a copy of this play. I can say its not my favorite story of all the books. However I enjoyed it and was glad to see the characters in their grown up form and working through life (work and raising the kids). I for one believe the characters kept their integrity. The characters did not change work for their families as evident by the struggle to raise the kids while exposed to the adult world of responsibility. The new main characters the children of the protagonist from the original books are a welcome addition to the story and like all the other books there is a moral to the story.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Pleased with the story, as long as you think of it as a stand alone story NOT the 8th Harry Potter book
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2016
content:
This was obviously one of the most anticipated releases of the year. Harry Potter has a huge following and many people from my generation (myself included) grew up with Harry. These books are hands down the reason I learned to love reading. There’s also a few things you should know about this installment, if you don’t already: its written as a script and while the story is from J.K. Rowling, it still had to be translated to a play form so we don’t get a lot of the descriptions and detail we are used to in the books. There were absolutely phrases I recognized and I was so appreciative of that. I’m not saying this is necessarily a disappointment, and I know it was necessary to adapt the story to a script. Still, I missed it.

That being said, did I enjoy the story? Yes, I did. I honestly did not have any expectations, because how could you when the story is told in such a different format? In a way, I think Rowling is smart to do it this way. If she had simply written another book, would I have been disappointed if it didn’t live up to the first seven? Probably. Most likely. But with a play..its new and original. Its a standalone, in a way, and I can appreciate it for what it is.

As for the story line, there were many aspects that were really heartwarming. There were elements from past books, and scenes with characters I never imagined I would see again. There are relationships I was happy to watch develop. I don’t want to say too much about the plot though. The story mainly follows Albus Severus Potter and his adventure. There’s not as much time spent at Hogwarts, not as much magic and spells, yet I still enjoyed it. It is not, by any means, a continuation of the series. It is a standalone play, but we do get to revisit our beloved characters one last time. There was so much nostalgia with this story!

The dialogue is also hilarious. Ron is still as goofy as ever, and Hermione is equally bossy.

“Ron: Honestly, every time I sit down I make an “ooof” noise. An “ooof.” And my feet- thr trouble I’m having with my feet- I could write songs about the pin my feet give me- maybe your scar is like that.”

Page 67

Harry is still same old Harry, and I was very pleased with his relationship with Ginny.

“Harry: I’d do anything for him.

Ginny: You’d do anything for anybody. You were pretty happy to sacrifice yourself for the world.”

Page 277

Oh and Scorpius was darling! I loved his character. His relationship with Albus made me nostalgic for the Ron, Hermione, Harry days.

I also really did love all of the references to Harry’s adventures from his childhood. I experienced some major Harry Potter nostalgia going through this play. The ending was also very poetic, in a way we ended where everything began. Overall, I was pleased with this Harry Potter story. It was a lovely tribute to our favorite characters, and we even learned a little more about some of them. My only regret is that I can’t see it on stage! Maybe one day :)

author: CORINNE
title: Great easy and fun read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
content: Okay so after reading this I went to the reviews to see what people were saying about it I am a firm believer is reading a book if you want to read it before you read reviews because every one has there own opinion. So first off no it does not seem like the writing of jk all that much however I did enjoy the book a lot which is why I gave it 4/5 people were saying it didn't seem like a harry potter book but I highly disagree I really think it does. Only thing I really didn't like about this book was that it sped through parts of his child's life that I would have like to read a little more into. Because in the harry potter books he was in year one in book one and so on and so forth I knew it wouldn't be drawn out that much but I did think that It would give you a little more information. Overall I would recommend reading this book I enjoyed it and it was a very easy and fun read.

author: Felicis
title: Good enough
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
content: It tells a good story and throws some old school goodies in for even the most hardcore of fans to somewhat enjoy. I'd recommend it as a light read regardless though I do keep it separate from the core books.

author: Karla
title: Would Buy Again
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 23, 2016
content: I had read/listened to some of the play spoilers before purchasing the book but it was still great to read it. Because Jo was one of the writers, this is tied to the Harry Potter series and I have been reading these for the past 17 years, I had to purchase and read The Cursed Child. I agree with many other HP book fans that this play is more of a standalone entity than a continuation of the series. The characters aren't very true to themselves, however, it is great to learn a little more about the next generation and see some interesting explanations (that could be true) for the original seven books.

author: Bootstrap
title: It's a plays to read. And I hate reading plays.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
This play was so good, I really liked reading it; could not put it down! It was the characters that we know, love, and grew up with-many of us. Along with new ones.  It was really awesome to go back to Hogworts with the younger, newer generation. The effects were(reading about them) were crazy! They set good scenes for the plot and they really built the action and tension and the stressfulness of the plot well!

I feel that this book is getting a lot of bad press because people are thinking, "oh, it's a Harry Potter book written by JK Rowling!" No, it's a PLAY ADAPTATION of the original story, that she came up with that was read a approved by her! Its says so right on the cover people! I mean come on, I know that going into it that it was a PLAY SCRIPT! I hate to break the news to you, but it reads like one too!
Regardless of that, the band of characters were great, and it was really enjoyable, and if you understand that it's, a script to a play that was approved by Rowling, you will really like reading it. It really makes you want to see the play.

author: 6thGraderReviewer
title: Example Headline
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2016
content: Example Review

author: Garin Hill
title: Fine
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2016
content: It was fun to re-visit Hogwarts but the plot was unremarkable. Harry Potter is predictable as a parent - uncertain and unsure of himself just as he was as a student - but still somehow manages to win. Overall, a good trip back to Hogwarts and a reminder of why I loved the original series.

author: Nilanjan De
title: Cursed child
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2016
content:
finally!!!! the official sequel to the series is here.
its  short book...light reading...and script format. To maintain the play mood as the story is a play...
back to the story.. its fast paced! no necessary bckground..evidet JK didnt write it..but touches are there.
character development is alright.though missed absence of George...
Little predictable... and never thought Voldy wil be into been so narcissistic!
Worth reading.as HP follower..

author: Amazon Customer
title: The Play was Good
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2016
content: It lacked J.K.s classic writing but the story was definitely the Harry Potter I'd grew up with. I recommend to every reader.

author: Amazon Customer
title: as a Harry Potter fan he loved the book
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2017
content: Bought this as a present for my husband, as a Harry Potter fan he loved the book

author: Amazon Customer
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Yes

author: topper
title: I did enjoy this book/play
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: I'm a 68 year old woman....who loves everything Harry Potter.  I did enjoy this book/play, as I enjoy all of Ms. Rowlings books, whether written in her other pen name or as herself,  I enjoyed reading about Harry's relationship with his children, and friendship with Malloy.  It was a little difficult to read it in play form, but on the whole was a fun read.  Joyce Dial, Wichita, Ks.

author: Laura Byland
title: Liked, but didn't love
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: If I could've, a more accurate rating from me would've been 3.5. This was an enjoyable read to me, mostly to get more time in exploring the HP world and revisiting favorite characters. However, it simply was no where near as good as the HP originals. Still a fun read for fans, though.

author: AMil
title: It reads like a play
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2016
content: It reads like a play, not like a novel, but the story is still as engrossing and fascinating as the other hp books. It's hp light, but worth a read.

author: Darknox
title: I liked it overall
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content: I liked it overall. I did have some issues with some of the plot points and how they handled some of the characters. Mostly because some what happens seems a bit deus ex machina.

author: RachelKati
title: It would have made a great book but
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content: While I loved revisiting the old characters; a lot of the detail we Harry Potter readers are used to is missing.

author: ronald.depaolo
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 21, 2016
content: Gift to my grandson

author: Adryan Clapp
title: It was a great, quick read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2016
content: It was a great, quick read.  However, don't hold it to the same level as the traditional HP series.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2016
content: Not as good as Rowlings' masterpieces, but a good continuation of the world she created.

author: Lovessalt
title: Good. Not exactly sure why J
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2016
content: Good. Not exactly sure why J.K. Rowling said that this could only be a play. It could easily have been a book. And it didn't quite get to why Albus had developed the characteristics he did develop. Nevertheless, I love all Harry Potter works, so I'll keep reading whatever the author writes.

author: tatum79
title: Happy reader- welcome back Harry Potter!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
Guys- listen... I'm presuming you all can read since you're upset about purchasing a script that states right on the listing that it's a script. If you chose to not believe it, or look past that detail, it's your own fault. Giving something low ratings because you believed what you wanted is unfair.

While I don't mind the script for the play, I am finding myself missing the magic of J.K.'s beautiful details. That woman just has a way with creating worlds, and characters that we have fallen in love with in each book.
But listen, we all went to Hogwarts for year after year, we know what it looks like in our imaginations. Dare I say we saw the movies and if your imagination is failing you there's always that to fall back on.
I am 2/3rds done with the book, and I am loving meeting the children of our beloved characters. Seeing who they turned into, what qualities were passed down from their parents.

This is an easy quick read, and a solid story on which to base a theatre production. I only wish I could travel to London to see it all done up on stage.

So tend to your broken hearts Potter fans, because at the end of the day, we got what we wanted... More Harry Potter.

author: Bee
title: Good book
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2019
content: I loved the book. It was great to give us a what happened after nineteen years later of the Harry Potter series.

author: Little busy quilter
title: Good read
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 22, 2017
content: Good book easy to read gives you a look into what could happen in the future would recommend to others

author: Diana M.
title: It's a fun read.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content: I went in knowing, full well, that JK did not write this. That being said, I was not disappointed whatsoever. This was a masterful piece of fan fiction. It misses many details that Rowling would emphasize but all in all very pleasant, very entertaining and worth adding to the collection (although, technically not the eighth book).

author: Raluca
title: A slight epic fail for such a great fantasy saga
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
content: I love J.K. Rowling and Harry Potter and I will always read whatever she writes. However, this is a weak version of Harry Potter. It is a nice read for the fans, you will enjoy it, it is easy to read and you will finish it in a few hours. However, I think Rowling's decision not to continue Harry Potter is legitimate after I read this piece. She really told the whole story and continuing it now makes no sense and only risks ruining the most amazing fantasy saga ever written.

author: E.L.
title: So if it doesn't "feel" like J. K
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2017
content: I can't remember the last time I bought a new release physical book! But I had to because Harry Potter! Have to keep my collection uniform! So. This is "based on an original story by J. K. Rowling." Keyword is based. This is NOT an original story by J. K. Rowling. Just BASED. So if it doesn't "feel" like J. K. that's because it's not. She had some say in it but It's not her writing the play. Her name is plastered all over it for saleability. And it is harder to read as a play. You lose a lot of information and personality and closeness as a play. But I did like it. I enjoyed seeing the old gang, including some faces I never thought to see again. It was cozy and comforting to be back at Hogwarts.

author: Aaron J. Towarak
title: Great story, not one of the books
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: I liked it, it's not one of the books and it shouldn't be perceived as such. It does come a little like fanfiction sometimes, character development is lacking. But I took it for what it was, it was about a family that wasn't perfect. It brought me back and it made me smile and almost made me cry. I grew up with the Harry Potter books and now he is all grown up with a family and so am I. I could relate and that life is not always magical.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Okay
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2016
content: Interesting form for a book. Worth reading, but hard to follow with peoples speaking as their parent and vice versa.

author: Chris Fried @ The Indie Athenaeum
title: Nineteen years later, Harry Potter, his friends and his family return in an engaging, all new story in the wizarding world!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
content:
Nineteen years after the end of the last book, Harry’s story picks up from the epilogue when he’s sending his son Albus Severus off to Hogwarts and takes it further. Albus, nervous about which house he’s going to be sorted in, makes some friends on the train to Hogwarts and learns about what happens when he’s put under the spotlight purely because he’s the son of the most famous man in the wizarding world.

As Albus and his close friends become more learned, they also become warier about the world they live in, thinking some aspects of it are unfair. They don’t trust the adults in their lives with how they are really feeling and thinking they can only rely on themselves. This, of course, gets them into a lot of trouble. But dark forces are gathering out on the fringes of civilized society and the Ministry of Magic is trying to figure out what’s going on. But will Harry and his friends be able to figure it out it before it’s too late and the lives of those they love are put at risk?

This story fits seamlessly into the Potter canon, as there are plenty of references to the previous novels. These references are very specific in this story, as they point to all different aspects of Harry's lifetime. The events depicted here don't contradict any of what has been previously established but they do add on to the canon in creative and unexpected ways. And the final scenes were very clever, suspenseful and well done, bringing the story full circle.

The middle of the story veers into science fiction territory here but I feel it is used well as a device to explore alternate points of view and the paths not taken had another choice been made. It’s presented in an exciting way that was riveting and kept me glued to my seat. It also has lasting repercussions going forward for the entire world. And the impact it has on those who participate in these events eventually do learn from the experience and apply it as they progress further into the story so I definitely can appreciate the consistency of character development that happens along the way.

There seems to be a soap opera element in terms of the main antagonist. I won't say anything more about that individual and their nefarious plan, other than that their origins feel very fan fiction to me. However, the presentation of that origin, how it was explained and the scenes in which it was revealed were quite mesmerizing, used for complete and maximum emotional impact. As a counterpoint, those final scenes were also quite agonizing, the most powerful and the most captivating. I challenge any Harry Potter fan to not feel something in the climax of this story. Harry in particular states something that rings so true, so plays to the theme of the story and encapsulates all of the Harry Potter stories to date so well that its resonance is very poetic. And the epilogue cements these themes home in a very poignant and appropriate way.

Resonance is the key word here, as it mostly rings true throughout the whole book. It successfully captures the embodiment of these beloved stories for the most part, with some minor missteps along the way.

I really liked the characterization of the children. Albus Severus can never seem to escape his father’s shadow no matter how hard he tries and their relationship is one of the strong spines of the story. Albus is awkward, emotional about himself and is as impulsive as any normal 14-year-old. He feels like a loser and a failure, especially in comparison to his famous father. While naturally, Scorpius Malfoy also considers himself a loser but finds solace in his friendship with Albus. His enthusiasm and embracing of his nerd-like tendencies provide some comic relief and a stark contrast to the darker aspects of the plot. Together, they are losers banding together to not feel lonely and try to achieve success in their ambitious endeavors, finding inspiration and strength in each other. Their camaraderie together is one of the true highlights of this book.

I do wish we spent more time with Rose Weasley-Granger as she was a scene stealer when we got to see her and very much the embodiment of her parents.

At times, it does feel like "Harry Potter's Greatest Hits" in terms of how the story plays out but instead of just revisiting them, it uses them to add a different and refreshing take on a scene or event. In that way, it feels good to revisit Harry's old haunts and familiar characters, like spending time with old friends after not seeing them for a long while. These scenes play an important part in the story and are used as a crucible that tests all the characters who endure them. As a play being performed, these moments must be true crowd-pleasers and hit the right emotional notes. Rave reviews of the play’s performance seem to bear this out, with plenty of cheers and applause being reported.

As a script, the dialogue should be read like this was a radio play. It uses words to express its performance, being expositional in nature and helping to paint a picture for the reader in their mind's eye. However, sometimes it can be so descriptive that the dialogue feels clunky like this line of Draco’s dialogue: “I'm not one for small talk..."

Malfoy has changed over the years but to talk about himself like that seems out of place. But when you consider the context of the script, the purpose of the dialogue is to explain something being performed on a stage versus being read as a conversation in a novel. So, to me, it acts as a shorthand for the reader/audience member, even if it doesn’t always sound completely natural.

The dialogue is mostly spot on for me at times and feels like the characters we know and love. But there are some places where it feels a little out of character. I don’t think Harry would ever say a particularly hurtful line to Albus like he does here, given his time with the Dursleys. But it does encapsulate his frustration with their relationship, especially as Harry astutely states that he grew up without ever having a loving father and how it can be difficult for him to be in this role.

Also, some pieces of the action feel out of character as well. For example, when Draco and Harry have a confrontation, the outcome of it seems off, especially given the vocation of one of those characters, supposedly at the top of his professional game.

I like the way it expanded on the Potter lore with some of the new characters while existing characters are given a larger role to play here. I also welcome the elements of the next generation of Harry Potter being utilized here and have a large part to play. Thankfully, the characters we all know and love from the books have plenty of things to do here. Combined, it makes for a great cast of characters to involve ourselves in throughout the story. Those we don’t get to see are name-dropped here and there, fleshing out the story and adding that familiarity to it.

There was one scene that was particularly ingenious and delightful, shining through like light through the dark, evil cloud that hangs over the story. This scene revolves around a particular object that plays a very important role. The way it is hidden and how others try to find the clues to solve this particular puzzle all felt very authentic and in line with the character who hides it.

Finally, the title of each Harry Potter book is very important, as it reveals an important object(s), character or group in each story that is central to the plot, adding a sense of curiosity and intrigue. By the end of each story, that importance is clearly revealed. This book is no different in its title, as prior to this book's release, we wonder who the Cursed Child is. Well, in this case, it’s not spelled out explicitly who the titular child is, though there are a couple of candidates who certainly fit this description. Whether this vagueness is intentional or the reader is meant to decide for themselves, I don’t know.

So, you’ve just read an adult’s opinion of this book. Considering that Harry Potter was written for children but equally enjoyed by adults, maybe you’re wondering what a child thinks of this book? Wonder no more, because I know what you REALLY want to know is what my eleven-year-old son thinks of the story. Here is his review, written by him:

I thought it was amazing. I liked all the action and it was really page-turning.

I thought the book was pretty interesting, coming out with showing who’s getting which house with the Sorting Hat and it gets me thinking that I want to finish the book because I want to see what happens next.

It was also interesting to see how the kids from the original books grew up, what jobs they had and how they did them. Seeing Harry with his son Albus, it was like they were almost opposite personalities. I thought it was special how their relationship changed over the course of the book.

I liked the antagonist’s evil scheme because it kept me reading. I thought they hid their identity very secretly and how they did so was amazing. I was real surprised when I found out who the antagonist was and then I wanted to keep reading it more.

Albus was really daring, along with Scorpius. He was smart and he followed what Albus did almost. Their friendship was good from the beginning. It was a really quick thing about how they wanted to be friends. It was like from the original books, as they were daring like their parents. It was brave for Albus and Scorpius of them that they wanted to use something that was illegal to bring someone back who had already died in the books.

That final scene was pretty epic, like in the final scenes in the other books, like in the first one with Harry against Professor Quirrell, in the fourth one where they were in the graveyard with Lord Voldemort and the fifth when they were battling in the Ministry of Magic. They all have big end scenes.

I didn’t like it when they didn’t tell about the first couple of years, they just went first year on the train, second year on the train and third and fourth.

I didn’t like that because they didn’t explain what they did in those years. There’s always a lot going on in those years.

I liked the ending scene the most because it was the final confrontation when they were all going to fight the antagonist.  It was very action-packed.

As a Harry Potter fan, I came away from this book feeling mostly satisfied with this new addition to the canon. It is as advertised, the “Special Rehearsal Edition”. This means it is only the script they used while rehearsing the play for the month prior to its official premiere. In the rehearsals being done from July 1st through July 29th, 2016, there was undoubtedly some fine tuning done, tweaking dialogue and refining the script better in preparation for its official premiere on July 30th. At that point, the script is locked in and considered complete.

As a result of this being a script book, each page is filled with dialogue along with some notes setting the scene, description of emotions on display and some directions telling you where the actors are placed on the stage. Your imagination has to do a lot of the heavy lifting and fill in the gaps in absence of watching this being performed on a stage filled with scenery. The plot does move very briskly because of the script format and it's a very quick read as a result. But it also is a quick read because there's a lot of white space on each page as a result of the script format of the book, with lots of spaces between lines. Both I and my son finished this book in a small amount of time.

However, if you only had to buy one edition of this book, I would wait for the Definitive Edition due to go on sale in early 2017. When that book comes out, this rehearsal edition will be phased out of bookstores and eventually be replaced with this one. The Definitive Edition will reportedly have some extra content from the play's creative team. Though I’m sure true fans will be buying both editions.

Once I read the Definitive Edition, I will be curious to see what has changed and what improvements have been made. In that sense, this book is essentially an unfinished and incomplete product, albeit one that is closer to completion than not. It’s a couple of drafts away from being one hundred percent complete, in my opinion.

Let’s face it, all true Harry Potter fans will be reading this book. But when you do, make sure your expectations are kept in check, as this is NOT a novel, it’s just a script book. It’s a stage play adapted into a book format, one medium adapted into another. Therefore, it's a different experience from reading one of her novels. It mostly captures the magic, feel, and tone of her stories but the script aspect of it is somewhat limiting at times.

It is also a new full-length Harry Potter tale with a new story by JK Rowling, something we haven’t had in over nine years. So, I do think you should read this book, as it’s an entertaining story filled with characters we’ve come to love, new characters to care about and a fast-moving plot that whisks you away to a land of magic once again.

Two Harry Potter fans, an adult, and a child, reviewed this, two different generations and two different perspectives. We agree on many things here and overall, we both enjoyed it very much. Bring on the Definitive Edition, as both my son and I can’t wait to read it.

author: Paul
title: Not epic but satisfies my HP itch (for now)
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2016
content:
As an avid HP I was both excited and nervous for this new "book".

PROS - it was a quick fun read, fun bonus bits for HP fans, new characters CONS - too short (could just be me wanting more), kind of weird storyline, where a typical HP book would talk about in a chapters worth is condensed into one page in Cursed Child.

TLTR: If you're a HP fan then of course you have to read it, if you haven't read the HP series at least twice then no rush to pick this up.

author: Amazon Customer
title: It's more Potter, What could be better?
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2016
content: It is a very fast read and written well. Others dislike this because it is in fact a play script and therefore doesn't read with all of the wonderful details and descriptions that a novel would have. However, it does follow the Harry Potter world and it is a wonderful addition. This product is definitely aimed at younger children in concepts and language, more so than the original Harry Potter series which I have read as a child and as an adult. Overall, I would definitely read this again and perhaps to my future children in a few decades to come.

author: JeanMM
title: Great continuation of the Potter series
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content: I love the way JK Rowling brings back all of the main characters we know and love with some interesting plot twists. A great though in my opinion too brief read

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not as good as the original books of course
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2016
content: Not as good as the original books of course, and I find the play format hard to read. Overall pretty good though!

author: E Chaney
title: Surprised
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: This is a great introduction to play scripts.  I was impressed with the story; however, it was a very short I was able to finish the book in a day.  It  is definitely worth reading especially if you're a Harry Potter fan.

author: Amanda
title: Good to reminisce about an old favorite
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I grew up in the height of Harry Potter mania. In the fifth grade my grandparents brought me back the original three novels from England and I was over the moon!! I grew up into my twenties waiting patiently for each installment to come. I still remember working my first job at Walmart on overnights and taking my break at midnight to pick up Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, going home and not even sleeping for 24 hours to finish. I've read each book about five times, some of them more than that.
I must also admit I'm a bit of a snob, I only just watched the first few movies recently because my seven year old wanted to after reading the illustrated version of the book. So when I saw this was coming out and that it was a play and not a real novel I decided I didn't want to pick it up. Well that lasted til noon on release day before seeing so many people reading it that I had to drop what I was doing, pack up the kids, and drive to two stores to get it. I sat down during nap time and read the whole thing in one sitting.
I am not a play reader, I never have been. Even being good in school I never finished the great works of Shakespeare or read any classics, they just aren't my style. Now to anyone afraid of reading this because its a play, don't be. I read it just fine and it sort of melded into a regular book for me after the first few scenes.
I originally was going to give it three stars, but rounded up to four because the story was really quite good and it was good to see old favorites back like Snape. RIP :(
I really liked the emotional parts of the story and the troublesome relationship between Harry and his son Albus. I love Harry, but always thought he was shown to be too perfect and I loved when he had some internal conflict and acted out of character. I also really liked the friendship between Albus and Draco Malfoy's son Scorpius. They truly had a deep connection.
The last two acts were a bit much for me. We had a watered down Voldemort comes back plot which was both too much and not enough. The writers could have went two ways: not done it at all and just focused on the relationship aspect of the story or they could have added a hundred pages and made it a full fledged plot. I get that this is a real play, but I'm sure that no one would complain of it being too long to watch in person!
Like other reviewers have said hopefully this is the end. I gave it a chance and liked it but unless there is a spin off series such as her American Hogwards I'm really not interested in another story. Harry is like a favorite old relative that you want to remember in their hayday, not their bitter end.

Always!

author: Benjamin K. Schmidt
title: Surprisingly lovely and worth reading, despite haters hating
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2017
content:
I think this book deserves to be on the high end of four stars -- I really liked it.

The only character that was really amiss was Harry, and the main problem there was his dialogue.  He just didn't sound like himself at all until later on and during the scenes with Dumbledore's portrait (who totally WAS himself, far more than Harry was, even though he was just a portrait and apparently wasn't supposed to be really real *rolls eyes*).  But I could still imagine real Harry doing the things he did in this play, just not the way he's portrayed as doing them here.

The rest of the story was wonderful, the time travel sequences deeply affecting and profound (and heartbreakingly hurried), and the idea that this whole production goes on in a staged performance is a bit mind blowing.  I'll have to see it myself.

I loved the new characters, and yes, of course it was all terribly hurried. IT'S A PLAY -- it simply has to cut to the chase.

***SPOILERS AHEAD***

And despite that fact, the timeless themes of friendship and finding surprisingly wonderful people in the least likely places (i.e. Draco Malfoy's progeny and the first Potter to be sorted into Slytherin) shined through the imperfections in a wonderful way.  I loved the closure that this story gave readers to Snape and how he would be remembered.  I loved the moment where broken-past-present Draco reflects on his relationship with his wife.  I loved the dialogue between Albus and Scorpius.  I loved Rose Weasley and wished we could have seen more of her.  Hermione as Minister of Magic was a bit tough to swallow (so soon??) but whatever.  Ron was funny.  The trolly lady growing spikes on her hands was a bit much. To be sure, I could imagine her doing something intense and scary to students trying to the leave the train.  It just didn't need to be spike hands  (－‸ლ)

Ok, I could go on.  But I liked it.  There was heart, there was closure, there were beautiful moments with great new characters.  It's not a Harry Potter book like the others, but it was a J K Rowling story worth taking the time for.  I'll likely read it again.

author: sherk
title: A fun read. Give it a chance.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
It is important to note that this is a SCRIPT, not a novel. Given that, this SCRIPT is good. I enjoyed reading it and being back in the wizarding world, knowing that all the characters I have loved for years are okay and still up to no good-- even their children. It was a fun read.
It is also important to note that our dear JK Rowling is not the sole author, as she was in the original 7 books. There are two other authors who contributed and, most likely, Rowling just approved and edited the final story. Knowing this, it is easier to accept that this is very different compared to the original 7 books.
I do have issues with certain aspects of the book and think that, in some instances, it boiled down to pure convenience, not logic. That, however, is not enough to make me dislike this script and regret having read it. I absolutely loved it.
I suggest reading it for yourself to form your own opinion but I believe that many fans are being too harsh on it, given the important notes I listed above.
The main thing I had issues with was how long it took Amazon to ship and deliver this book. I pre-ordered Cursed Child months ago expecting to have the book arrive on my doorstep on July 31 only to be disappointed and forced to wait until August 3 to receive it. I could have understood delivering on August 1 since the 31 was a Sunday, but the 3rd was a little much. I am not likely to ever pre-order a book from Amazon again because of this (and Target had a better deal-- $17.99 for the book and a free poster with book purchase).
Overall, this was a fun read and offered a great amount of closure for myself and the left over feelings I had after finishing Hallows.

author: Garrett Castello
title: A Worthy Emotional, Intense, and Fun Sequel to the Harry Potter Series
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: Despite being in a script format, this still felt like a Harry Potter book (also despite not being solely written by Rowling herself). The old characters are likable as always (though Harry and Draco specifically receive some sublime character development), the new characters are likable (for the most part), and the villain is intimidating and threatening. The story is full of many creative twists and turns, emotional moments, surprise reveals, unexpected connections, and a great mix of suspense and thrills. While not my favorite Harry Potter story, "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" most definitely earns its place as the eighth story.

author: Joey L.
title: Good, but different
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 20, 2016
content:
SPOILER ALERT: There are a few things (not huge parts or major plot twists) in my review that might spoil minor parts. Read with caution :-)

This is a good book. It was entertaining and a nice, quick read. A word of warning to Harry Potter fans: It is VERY different than the main books. It doesn't feel like a continuation of the book. It's a shame that it was marketed as the next chapter as, to be honest, I don't think it fits that well with the main book. There are some odd parts and some of the rules of magic aren't entirely consistent (The time travel aspect in particular is really bad.) However, it's nice to see new characters and old characters brought back. Some people really hate the way Harry is portrayed as he's kind of a jerk at times. However, I quite liked this. Harry isn't put up on a pedestal and shows human flaws. To be honest, I thought Harry was portrayed as flawed in the last two books of the main series as well, so I'm not sure why people are so upset about that aspect.

Overall, a good read, but don't expect it to be the same as the main series. Look at it as a JK Rowling endorsed fan fiction and you'll be much more satisfied.

author: Terrance Aldon Shaw
title: Mischief not so easily managed
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
content:
What a pleasure after so many years to hold a new Harry Potter book in my hands and dive with happy abandon into the strange, but warmly familiar magical world of J.K. Rowling's imagination. While this "rehearsal script" for a theatrical production (first stage in London on July 30, 2016) is frenetically paced and (at least on the printed page) lacks much of the novels' spirit of whimsy--their rich depth of colorful, if often superfluous detail--readers do get to reconnect with many of the most-beloved characters in the series once again, and there are a few interesting (and essential) new characters as well.  Young Albus Severus Potter finds it increasingly difficult to live in his famous father's shadow; Hogwarts for him is no Hogsmeade holiday, only his friendship with the shy and lonely Scorpius Malfoy offers consolation, and Scorpius is himself dogged by dark rumors about his parentage. Mischief and rebellion are in the air like a swarm of dementors, but this mischief won't be quite so easy to manage when the two friends endeavor to change history.

That's the story in its broadest outline. The plot of "Cursed Child" draws on the earlier books, most heavily "Prisoner of Azkaban" and "Goblet of Fire", but a thorough familiarity with the entire series is assumed from the beginning. This may be problematic for some Potter neophytes, while "purists" who claim to adore The Boy Who Lived but can't abide the notion of his ever growing up or changing (as real people so often do) will find a fair bit to complain about--but don't they always?

Yet, by and large, the source material is skilfully mined for its 'quantum possibilities', the resulting story is often quite clever and, in moments, moving, poignant, and insightful. Rowling has once again given us an engaging magical tale that is also a compelling story of relationships (fathers and sons, friendship and love, family past and individual destiny) human emotion, growth and the understanding that comes with experience and maturity.

Recommended with the caveats noted above.

author: kittybot
title: Good play, doesn't feel like 'real' Harry Potter.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: Once one gets used to the play format, this is actually quite a very smooth read.  Bringing back beloved characters from the Harry Potter septology, and expounding upon briefly mentioned or entirely new ones, with all the wonders of magic and wizardry, this is a worthy addition to any HP fan's shelf.  However, the story felt a bit 'tacked on' - squeezing another drop from the septology's plot, a bit contrived in its twists and turns.  I do quite like the ambiguous title and the sense of mystery throughout; how does the title apply?  Who is it referring to?  In the end, it's still nicely unclear, with more obvious candidates and more subtle suggestions.  Another thing that bothered me, however, is that the returning characters seemed rather.. out of character.  Typical speech habits, patterns of behavior, and even seeming personality traits have been lost or replaced.  This may be a side effect of the story being told pretty much entirely through dialogue, but none of the characters feel fully developed by the end, and the whole thing felt rather like fluff, like decently written fanfiction rather than Rowling's usual intense style (though of course she was not the sole author of the script).  I did find myself rather amused by the occasional descriptions of characters' behaviors, and bemused by descriptions of magic performed or experienced, wondering how on earth they managed to pull that off on stage.  Perhaps someday a video recording of the play performance will be released, and the story will feel a lot more immersive taken in its intended format.

author: Callandra

Some of the plot lines seem to go nowhere, but they might make more sense if it was seen as a play, instead of read as a book.

author: College Stealth
title: Uh, what's not to love?
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
I promise I won’t give any super big spoilers away.

As I started reading it there was some hesitation on my part because of the names of Harry’s children, as they are all characters from the past, named to honor them and it took me a moment to shake that they were not the Albus, Lilly, or James of before.  It also takes a moment to get into the grove of reading a play over a book itself.  One thing I was concerned about was not getting the emotion or the internal monologue of the characters throughout the story, that has not been an issue, as there are cues throughout that give insight into that aspect.  I found that it was very easy and adaptable to read, I know that this is a large point of contention, but it seemed natural to me.

This is a story that spans a lot of time, the transitions are clear, and it paints a very vivid picture of the time.  It uses transitions or snippets, think of Snape’s flashbacks growing up, to move through some phases or years at a time.  We start with Albus's first year, but we end at his 4th year.  As someone who wanted to digest as much as possible in the world of Potter World, this actually worked well for me.  There are elements where you're able to see Albus change over time, which I enjoyed.  The whole book is not structured this way, but early on in the play there is a leap of a few years from its initial start to when the action really takes place.

The primary action is based on Albus Potter, Harry’s son, who is a bit like and unlike his father.  Albus is faced with engaging at Hogwarts and adjusting to an environment in which he is living in the shadow of his father.  At the onset of the play you think that Albus is going to follow in the same friendships as his father, but it quickly is determined otherwise and Albus’s friend is a Malfory (you find this early on).  Albus attends at the same time as his cousin Rose, the daughter of Hermine and Ron (she takes after Hermine a bit more).  Albus and Scorpius (Malfory’s son) become really good friends and extend the universe of Harry Potter into looking at another family in a different way and with more glimpses of the Malfory who we occasionally saw towards the end of Harry Potter.

Harry himself throughout the play is struggling with some of his responsibilities in fatherhood, but his own lack of a father plays a role in his self-doubts of how well he is doing with Albus.  Harry was able to conquer Voldermort, but sometimes a teenager can be difficult, and very frustrating.  Harry's interactions with Albus remind me a bit of the weaknesses that Harry would show as a child, but was made better by Ron and Hermonie.  Meanwhile, James and Lily (siblings) play a bit of a tangential role to Albus who is the youngest.  Hermonie and Ron are also not very present in the story, but enough so that we at least have a sense of re-connection with them and what it is that they are doing in their lives, as well as their histories, which play a vital role. Ron truly is characterized by a lot of the humor that was once seen in his older twin brothers.

It's difficult to talk too much about what makes Albus function without giving away some important details, but this is more so his story, with his new friends, and how he is adapting in a seemingly different way than his father.  Albus wants to do right for himself and even the past of his father, which leads to the main story line of Albus re-visiting some of Harry’s past losses, in particular Cedric. Cedric’s father is perhaps the most heart wrenching of all elements of the story, still exactly where he was at the end of the last time he was encountered, mourning the loss of his son.  It’s an excellent re-introduction into the world of Harry Potter, as it intentionally goes through past memories, reliving some of them, as well as looking at them from a different perspective.

It's a play, which I think maybe hard to reconcile while reading.  Plays have very different styles than novels, hence why it wasn't necessarily just written by Rowling, but has contributors who take the story and make it into a play. There is a significant amount of imagination that has to go into the story, which is a bit different than Rowling's other books, as the actors are depicting the scene, as well as scenery that contributes to the imagery.  Again, I think it does a good job filling in these gaps.

Anyway, there’s a limited amount I can say, it’s pretty awesome.  I hope you enjoy it!

author: Elizabeth Woodrum
title: I'd like to see the play!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
First, let's just be clear that this is a script.  It's very clearly stated, but some reviewers seem shocked that it was not a novel.  Second, enjoy this for what it is.  I consider the play to be a continuation of the series, but it is a play.  It cannot have the intricate  storytelling of a novel.  If it did, it would need 100 stages and last for several days.  I enjoyed the little bits of new information about the adult versions of our trio and even seeing how Malfoy turned out as an adult.  I thought the overall story was good, though it has left me trying to do some math.  I'm going to have to read book 7 again.  Had it been a novel, I think that the characters would have been more fleshed out and perhaps truer to their book selves.  But, again, it's a play.  I consider it its own thing and am not comparing it to the books. I liked the overall story and there were some surprises in there. It was fast-paced because it's meant to be performed.  I got the rehearsal edition script and it's 308 pages of the actual play.

Also, to help some who complained about the format, it seems making sure you know how to read a script is a good idea.  Some complained about having to look to see who's talking and to read descriptions of the stage.  So, just to clarify, again, it's a script.  It is organized like any script.  I'm not an actor and the only scripts I've ever really seen are reader's theater scripts for classroom student productions.  So, the basics are as follows:

The character speaking is listed before the dialogue. The dialogue has no quotations because it's a script and the fact that it has a character name attached to it implies it's spoken.  There are stage directions in italics that describe what characters are doing and that set the scene.

If you keep in mind it's a play, you'll find it enjoyable.  I did. I read it in a few hours and there were a few parts where it was definitely a page-turner.  I'll now happily add it to my other Harry Potter books on my bookshelves.

author: Peter Rodrigues
title: Better to be watched than read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: Still a lightning fast, roller coaster read, but something was lost in the story without the visual of seeing this in person.

author: Kelly Zurp
title: I enjoyed it more than I thought I would
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2016
content:
I must admit that I waited to buy this book and began reading it with trepidation, due to all the negative reviews I read about it; but, overall, I liked the play and would like to address some of the things other reviewers have said.

First, should it have been a book instead of a play?  I would have liked to have had it be a book (or even a series of books, as we could have seen the development of the next generation), as that would have allowed more detail and character development, but the play was OK and if the authors were looking to tell a good story without spending too much time and effort to write a whole book, they succeeded.  The pace moved quickly, I'm sure prompted by the limited time a play would allow, but it kept me involved and there were a sufficient number of surprises to keep me interested.

A lot of people didn't like the people Harry and his friends had become, but I found them to be believable adult developments of the kids we knew from the books.  Was this the only way they could have turned out?  Of course not, but it was one, reasonable, way.  The only one who I didn't like was Ron, whom they made out to be little more than an insignificant, silly and almost meaningless piece of fluff.  Granted, in the books he was the least important of the trio, but he still played a significant role. In the play, they could have left him out entirely and it could only have served to improve things.  On the other hand, I liked the way Harry and Draco interacted.  And Ginny continued to show herself as the marvelous person she was.

The whole thing about time travel - a lot of people didn't like it.  Given that they had introduced time turners in the books, the canon certainly gives credence to the concept and it presented a lot of opportunities for Albus and Scorpius to meet some of the characters from the books and grow to know their parents better, which I think added to the story.  It also presented some alternative timelines that were interesting and helped the boys to learn several important life lessons.

Some said that this didn't seem to be written by J. K., but I thought there was sufficient body to the story and characters that her involvement was clear.  True, it wasn't up to her level of detail and magical fun, but to be fair, I don't know how much more could have been fit into a stage play.  The pace was much too fast for much more development.  As I said before, there were still enough surprises and development that I thought it was reasonably well written.

The gay thing.  First, regarding the boys.  Perhaps it was written a little touchy-feely, but both boys showed interest in girls, so I think their closeness was primarily from intense friendship, caused in no small part by their loneliness and rejection by the other students, and heightened potentially by latent homosexuality generated as a reasonably normal learning about relationships by sensitive young boys.  As far as Dumbledore is concerned, I know J. K. has stated that she always considered him to be gay, but the way he was written in this story, I'm not sure this applied to his feelings for Harry.  If it did, then his feelings toward Harry would likely be beyond simply gay and be more those of a pedophile, which would have gotten him into trouble at some point in his career as a teacher and headmaster.  I think the feelings he expressed toward Harry were more along the lines of the love a father would feel toward his son.

Finally, if I could find a major fault with this story, it is that it was a piece of fluff compared to the books.  In SS, I was drawn into the magical world by wonder and the fun twists and turns of the things Harry encountered as he learned about this world he was born into but didn't know at all.  As the books went on, the story became ever darker and more intense as Harry found himself driven toward his fate.  This made the stories more involved and attractive to older readers, such as myself.  The epilogue in DH was bordering on fluff and a bit less satisfying because it was so nice and predictable.  Upon finishing the play, I found myself feeling much the same way as I felt after finishing DH.  The play's story was enjoyable and drew me in, but the ending left me feeling a little bit sugary.

In summary, then, if you're expecting a story of the intensity and detail of the books, you'll be disappointed; but, if you read it accepting that it is a play and, therefore, must move at a faster, less-detailed pace, I think you'll enjoy the story.  Harry and his friends are still there.

author: ATX
title: HP4Life

author: Kevin Farrell
title: A bit different, but wonderful all the same.😊
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2016
content:
For the past three years, Harry Potter has been my life. I love the plot of the story, I love the characters, and I love the author. But this book is a little bit different...

If you didn't know, this book is a script book. So the writing is a bit different and a bit hard to follow. So if you are a Harry Potter fan, I will tell you this is NOT like the other books. It is a play in London.

Also, most people are upset about what house Albus is in. I know, it's different, but this book is supposed to show that Albus dose NOT want to be like his father.

But here's one thing that kind of upset me. I wish that the author was only J.K. Rowling. I think that the book might have been different if it was only her. But the other authors were still wonderful.

And lastly, the book lacked adventure. Which was also upsetting. But it was supposed to have a lot of heart and it definitely did.

So read this book. It will make you laugh, cry, and stay awake all night.

Enjoy!😊

Which makes sense because it is a play.  Those expecting it to read  like a book and are looking for all the little imagination details thrown in for them will be disappointed.  However, if you know the WW of HP then you should be just fine, you can imagine away without the extra details that everyone is used to in a typical Rowling release.  You may not love it has much as the original series but it is certainly worth the read.

author: Andrea K. Johnson
title: Not bad
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: This is not a bad read. I'm not sure how it works on stage. The time turner plot becomes a bit convoluted and overlong, but the characterizations make up for it. Scorpius is by far the best character in the play. Albus is a brooding, sullen and somewhat annoying teenager. Harry's clashes with him are believable. Harry could certainly be all of those things himself and at a similar age.  Hermione is probably what I pictured as an adult. Ron is ill served here and his daughter Rose seems like an alternate version of the character in the epilogue. Even the dialogue is changed, Maybe the time travel changed other things around.

author: Marc B.W.
title: It is all about perspective on how you take this "book"
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content:
Ok, let's be clear - this is not a book.  This a script for a play.  It has been lightly adapted, if that, to be a little easier to read like a book but make no mistake this is a script.  You need to remember in a script it depends heavily on verbal dialog, there is not a whole lot of internal thought or scene descriptions which are such a rich part of the HP universe.
If you go into this thinking it is going to pick up right where HP left off, you are setting yourself up for disappointment - as you can see by some of the reviews here.  Some folks have seemed to have missed what is printed on the cover - this is written by Tiffany and Thorn based on a story by Rowling.  She did not write this, she wrote a story that they have adapted as a play with much liberty I am guessing.  So Potterophiles who obsess over details will freak out at some of the liberties they took.
That said, the story if fine.  It is not without flaws in some of the character development.
SPOILER ALERT - things I did not like and did not feel were plausible - how Ron turned out.  He was full steam ahead as an auror with Harry.  He takes a deep third fiddle role in each reality as if the writers kind of dismissed him.  Although the roll as the funny Uncle I can see.  Cedric - in one reality a death eater.  Malarky.  I don't see this happening from being embarrassed in any scenario.  Just seems as the HP series reached an apex that not even a Slitherin went as dark as he did in the storyand he was a super popular Hufflepuff with a good, loving family.  So nope, that scenario we so unlikely it was a distraction.  Last the timeline of Delphi being born.  That who scenario is also a tad outlandish, I just don't see that happening.
Aside some unlikely possibilities, I enjoyed the visit back to the HP world.  I liked seeing the interaction between Harry and Draco and would have loved to see that developed more.  There were a few gems in their interactions.
Would I love to see an actual book fleshed out by JK herself (and correcting a few flaws), absolutely.  But this was entertaining as I think the play would be as well.

title: Harry's son and unexpected friend
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2017
content: A very enjoyable romp set in the world of Harry Potter, a generation after Harry's schooling, dealing with his son and an unexpected friend at Hogwarts.  The story is set as a screenplay, which in no way diminishes the fun.  A great read!

author: Loki Liesmith
title: Not perfect, but enjoyable enough
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 30, 2017
content:
A fun follow-up to the seven 'canon' Harry Potter novels, this one follows the sons of Harry and Draco Malfoy, now best friends at Hogwarts (to their parents' chagrin), as they try to live up to/live down their famous fathers' names.

It's not a perfect sequel, by any means, but the characters are interesting, the plot has a proper build and decent suspense, the play reads like a proper novel, and the tale ends with the reader feeling satisfied, if not elated. I'd recommend it for any Hogwarts fan hungry for more, as long as you're not a hardcore Potter purist.

author: JAS
title: Great story BUT.......
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2016
content: I love the story but found that reading a screenplay is not the easiest or most enjoyable thing to do (hence 4 stars rather than 5).  Whereas I would have devoured a novel, it took me several days to work my way through this.  Would much prefer that this story is put into novel form.  Also now understand that this book is the rehearsal edition and a "final" script will be published probably next year with the changes made to the rehearsal edition.  I, for one, do not plan on buying another copy just because of some modifications.  If you have not purchased this book but are thinking about doing so, it might be something to consider.  Am disappointed that, at this time, Mz Rowling is NOT planning on putting this story in novel form.

author: Debra  A Bryant
title: Albus and his best friend, Scorpius (Draco's only child) feel compelled to ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: While I can understand the criticisms of other readers, I still found this to be (yet another) fitting end of the Harry Potter saga,  The characters are some twenty years older with more worldly concerns. The conflict, as such, is between Harry and his middle child, Albus.  The son feels the extreme pressure of having to live up to the legend of his father, and the father has difficulty in connecting with his son.  Albus and his best friend, Scorpius (Draco's only child) feel compelled to go back in time to revive Cedric Diggory for his still grieving father.  Exactly what happens and who else becomes involved will remain unmentioned by me, but there are a few twists and turns involved.  I think this is a solid and believable part or the story line, and I was able to easily see the characters go through their motions on my mind's stage.

author: Dan'l Danehy-Oakes
title: Not quite up to the original series, but good.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
It's years later. Harry is head of Magical Law Enforcement, Hermione is Minister for Magic, and Ron runs the family Joke Shop. And, as seen at the end of _Deathly Hallows_, Harry and Ginny have three children, and Ron and Hermione have two.

Albus Severus Potter goes off - somewhat reluctantly - to Hogwarts, where he befriends Scorpius Malfoy. Both of them are Sorted into Slytherin, and they become fast friends.

But all is not well with Albus. He lives under the burden of being his father's son, and it irks him. He feels that he cannot please his father, and what's more, that his father doesn't need him - that his older brother James is Harry's real son and he's, well, the spare.

One evening, Albus overhears his father discussing, with the aging Amos Diggory, Diggory's desire that Harry use a time-turner to undo the killing of his son Cedric. Albus meets Delphini, who introduces herself as Amos's niece, and together they plot to do what Harry will not.

Of course, things go awry, and saying how would fall squarely into spoiler-land.

It's interesting to read this as a play, with almost all the plot advanced by dialog - though there is a fair amount of stage direction, too. Most of the old Harry Potter cast shows up in some form or another, and the world, once again, is threatened to be plunged into the Hell of Dark Magic.

The scriptwriter, Jack Thorne (Rowling and director John Tiffany collaborated on the story, but the script is by Thorne), does a pretty good job of capturing the characters of Harry and Ron, Hermione and Draco, a couple of decades on; and does an excellent job of presenting the new characters.

I enjoyed it a good deal, and will shut up now before I give something away that I shouldn't.

I would love to see it in the theatre, if for no other reason than to see how the magic is brought to life.

title: It’s a perfect quick read
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2018
content: It’s a great story. It didn’t quite live up to the original HP series but was a fun addition. As silly as it sounds some of the story was a bit unbelievable or didn’t quite connect the way I had hoped. The idea of time turning was great in its introduction in book three where they could only go back a few hours, but the idea of going back years and changing the complete history by casting a few spells just seems much too powerful to be messed with by any wizard. But otherwise I was very entertained and the author did a great job of bringing back that wonderful Harry Potter nostalgia and closure on the post Voldemort world.

author: HRSquire17
title: Story is a good one, play format is awkward
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2016
content:
It finished strong, and I got the sense of JK Rowling's voice in the characters particularly in the second half of the book.  I will admit I was put off by the play format.  It's awkward reading.  If she didn't want to write another book, then I'm not sure why she couldn't get any number of highly qualified best selling authors to take her play and novelize it, as they do all the time for movies.  I think of some of the top flight authors who have written the novel versions of the Star Wars movies for example.  They may have been shooting for artsy, it came across to me as lazy.

That aside, I thought the story started a bit slow and muddled and it just didn't feel like a JKR story, until about half way through then as I stated at the start of my review, it picked up, got me hooked like the original books and I got the JKR feel.  Overall for Potter fans it is clearly a must read.  It also shows that there are lots more possible stories for Harry and cohorts to be told.  I just hope that the next one is a novel.
