author: Alan Nitikman
title: The Cursed Child, Rowling Delivers Again
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content:
It is exciting to see JK Rowling back creating in the Potter universe. It's, as usual, a complex, character-driven story, with lots of surprising twists and turns. The theatrical medium is essentially different -- everything is handled through dialogue, stage action, and scenery (which is described in the text, but not seen). Rowling collaborated, but the characters and ideas were still clearly hers.

The consequences of the kids' actions were dire and interesting. Her work follows through on its premises and goes places that, traditionally, children's fiction wouldn't go. It is that willingness and imagination that puts her work  consistently in the realm of greatness. Fantasy, at its best, ask big questions and provides big answers that can be profound, in the right hands. Rowling's Potter series has so far always delivered.

No.  Is it a good story?  Yes.  I wish it had focused more solely on the kids and had had even less of the original Golden Trio (plus Ginny). author: Nath'l. D. Aiken
title: Harry Potter and the Honest  Review
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2017
content: I read it and I liked it! It was full of surprises. I know we'd all like to think that Harry was a model parent, but the reality is, parenting is hard. We all make mistakes, trying to find our way. Maybe the joy his first two children were kind of blinded him to the struggles Albus faced, just by being the son of the "famous Harry Potter". The alternate realities seemed to give some insight into the personalities of our protagonists. Reading a play is not easy. I would love to be able to afford to go to London and see this staged! It must be ...magical! (couldn't resist.) There are flaws but this is just the rehearsal script...the final version ought to be more polished! Plenty of *Spoiler* reviews here, so I didn't reveal anything. I think this book/ play is clever (as the Brits say). It's not our revered seven books, but if Jo did write this as a book for 39 year olds, she seems to have succeeded. And I borrowed my copy. Will be purchasing it shortly.

author: Ross
title: If you've read the HP books, you should read this.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
content: Full disclosure, I thought this was a novel and not a script.  Regardless, this is an excellent addition to the Harry Potter stories.  I liked the kids and how their parents struggled to relate to them and it also gave insight into what it's like to be an adult in this wizarding world.  The script format made it a quick read, but it was fun to imagine how this would be staged and no doubt, later filmed.

author: Apurva
title: which in retrospect was probably a good thing. I knew that it was written in ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2016
content:
I started into this book extremely skeptical.  I am an enormous Harry Potter fan, notorious for anxiously awaiting every previous book at their midnight release, devouring them all through the night and not sleeping until I completed them.  This book I never had that same anticipation for, which in retrospect was probably a good thing.  I knew that it was written in a play format, so that kind of made me leery.  But eventually I succumbed - I needed more of the Potterverse in my life!

So the book started off slowly and was honestly pretty corny.  It read a lot like the epilogue from HP7, if you understand what I mean.  About halfway through to book, it started developing and had some trademark Rowling twists and turns.  The little snippets of old characters that I missed so much made it completely worth the read.

My advice to you is to go into the book expecting it to be different from the previous books.  It is a very different format and therefore a very different read.  Lower your expectations - don't expect to have J.K. Rowling's intelligent flare for writing and skill of wit on every page, the way we have been used to in the past.  There will still be demonstrations of this in the stage direction and the dialogue, but it will be different.  With those expectations going into the read, I was thoroughly entertained and appreciative of this addition to the Harry Potter story.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Surprisingly Enjoyable
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
I went in this book with low expectations and expecting to hate it, much like I did when I first picked up Sorcerer's Stone. Once again, I found myself completely wrong and absolutely loved it. Reading the script was a new experience for me and I found myself enjoying it and easy to follow. The story itself, while there are flaw and a definite fan fiction hint, is fun and filled with new and old characters and one liners that are wonderful. I definitely felt like it was a possible future for the Boy Who Lived.

Is it by no means perfect? No. However I feel it has that magical touch that it's predecessors had and I do suggest any Harry Potter fans to give it a try.

author: Alicia
title: Amazing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: I knew when I ordered this book that it would simply be the published script. I wish I could have seen the production, but I wasn't going to travel all the way to London and I figured reading it would be the next best thing. With that in mind, I purposefully let my imagination go, envisioning the stage effects and emotional performances as vividly as I could. And I loved it! Sure, the story could have explored more new material instead of revisiting some old, but I enjoyed returning to this world anyway. I can't wait until there are live performances in America because I can tell the experience would be so much better!

author: R Ted Floyd
title: Fun Read

content: This was tough to like simply based on how much I enjoyed the original series but, it was a fun and fast read. Would be curious to read sequels if JK decides to write them.

author: Phyllis Ann Karr
title: Good Harry Potter Story, Less Than Satisfying Play
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2016
content: The Potterite in me was satisfied; the theater buff was not. I don't question that the London premier production is handling all these special effects magnificently, and wish I could see them do it in person. But if a school or community theater could manage them all, it would amaze me no end. And as a play, it seems largely to rely on these special effects, in an effort to beat the movies at their own special-effects game. The scenes are short and choppy; and it was sometimes difficult to follow which character(s) were the most focal ones. As a piece of theater, it came across to me as straining too hard to do too much. And even at that, I found there seemed to have been something crucial cut out in the subplot about Cedric Diggory. I should have preferred a more in-depth treatment with fewer scenes, but longer and more fully-developed ones; and something that school and community theaters could do more easily. I may be wrong: my fellow Harry Potter fans may find all the magic razzle-dazzle the important thing; but much as I have always enjoyed reading plays, I think I would have preferred this story in the form of an eighth novel, maybe even a trilogy of novels sequelizing the septology.

author: Elizabeth Thiel
title: Expectations fell flat
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2016
content: This was certainly an interesting jump into the future and the past throughout most of the script/book. There's not much more I can say without dumping out spoilers. Still worth the read for a Potter fan.

author: K. Stearman
title: Fun but different
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content: A new generation of Potters, but with many of the same problems. Nice reading format. Less complicated than previous stories, but very enjoyable all the same...

author: Robin Towler
title: Great book
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2018
content: item arrived quickly and was as described good book A+++

author: J. Schneider
title: It was good, but it felt like there was nothing new
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: It was good, but it felt like there was nothing new.  It was the same ole tricks.  It was a bit of a trip down memory lane and a good book.  I just wish there had been new spells and a new adventure.

author: Christopher Hutt
title: Golden Snitches get Stiches
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2016
content: If you enjoyed the original books you'll find something to like about this play, but there's no way it can meet the unbridled expectations of the original fan base, including myself. The lack of world descriptions and satisfying details left me hungry. It also went from 0-100 on teenage angst. A relevant topic for the children of famous parents, but a little hard to swallow. I suggest you read it, but read try and temper your hopes before you do.

author: justap77
title: Good story
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2017
content:
Great little journey back into the wizarding world, which is something a lot of us fans wanted.
Interesting time traveling story.  Also, I liked the arcs of the characters, notably the kids and Draco.

author: Ryan
title: Very good but perfect..
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
I definitely enjoyed going back in to the Harry Potter universe. This play didn't feel 100% Harry Potter to me. It was a great interpretation of what someone believed would happen later on in the series, but it reminded me TOO much like fanfiction. There are inconsistencies with plot and characters that couldn't really be overlooked.

That being said, I enjoyed the read and finished the book a lot sooner than I hoped I would.

author: Tam
title: Written in play format
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: Was surprised it was a screen play format of writing. It made it a little harder to picture the story unfolding. Enjoyed the new characters as well as those I knew from the series.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not as good as the classic books but still HP
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content:
I am such a big fan of Harry Potter and J.K. Rowling that it really hurts me to give four stars to this book.
It's good but it really seems like Rowling had little to do with the writing of it. It really feels like lazy writing appealing to clichés used in numerous previous stories.
It's still HP and I love it.

author: Nikki
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: Characters were developed because of the original author - not the writer of the play.

author: Salz5
title: A good script. DELIVERED LATE AFTER PREORDER,
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content: It's a play, not a book (but we knew that going in). All in all, a quick entertaining read. Thanks JKR for the glimpse into your world! Can't wait to see it live... Somehow, someway! I WAS extremely upset that it wasn't delivered until AFTER the book came out... And I had PREORDERED IT!

author: RON
title: It is very satisfying to find out what happens to ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2016
content: It is very satisfying to find out what happens to the main characters in the Harry Potter series, but they seem "flat" and stereotypical.

author: AvCheu
title: Potter and Malfoy are besties?!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2019
content:
Not what you think - it's their kids that make their way together at Hogswarts. Really dug the story, like father, like son. Still, I miss the deeper writing but it was still clever enough to capture my imagination. It was good to see the "old" gang again but as grown ups and how this future story harks back on a lot of things past so it gives a good grounding as well as "nostalgia."

I'm glad I read this - I don't know if I'll get to see it on Broadway but it has renewed my interest in the books again.

author: Brian Carl Quinones
title: I give it 4 chocolate frogs
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2016
content: If your a fan of the series it should be a fun read. Know that it's written in a play format. My one minor critic is that I feel the author is trying to justify some choices made in the previous books. Still a lack of people of color but that was a series wide problem. It hit a much better tone and mood than expected, just can't give it a 5 though.

author: PParks
title: Multi people enjoyed the book.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: Enjoyable read.  Read by four different people with different points of view.  Everyone enjoyed the  book.

author: Rebecca C
title: It's really good!  But different in regards to the flow of the previous books
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content: I really enjoyed this book!  I still prefer the originals better, but that could just be the way that it's written too.  A lot of people have said that it doesn't feel like a Harry Potter book, and I think it feels that way because of how Albus's life is supposed to go.  It's not about Harry Potter, it's about his son who is trying to figure out life.  Give it a try no matter how many bad reviews it has.  J K Rowling always out does herself, in different ways.

author: WGille2
title: Good but not grwar
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2016
content: Enjoyed but not her best work

author: Anne Hoch
title: The story was good, but compared to the original series it was ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: The story was good, but compared to the original series it was a little lacking.  It was not as well written.  I am glad I read it.

author: A. Gift For You
title: This was for the fans.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
This was for the fans.

I saw alot of posts pissing and moaning about how no one but J. K. Rowling should write about Harry Potter, but I felt Jack Thorne did good by the characters she created. The story even touched on some crazy fandom fanfics I have read and I thoroughly enjoyed it. There were even parts where I straight up cried.

In all, if you are looking for another Harry Potter book, this is and isn't it. It continues the story but in a different prose. With her novels, you view the masterpiece from a distance. With Thorne's writing style, I felt like a third wheel in an exciting, magical mess, frantically trying to piece together what was happening instead of it being methodically laid out to view.

It is for the die hard fans, which deserves 5 stars. For the casuals, definitely at least 3. Regardless, appreciate it for what it is, you bunch of filthy mudbloods.

author: Thomas J. Slover
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Good, but not as good as the originals.

author: akiiKOMORI reading
title: Just as Magical as the other Harry Potter Novels - only in Script form.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content:
A good majority of the people born in the 90s grew up to be Potterheads – myself included.
 Hearing about another Harry Potter novel coming out I was like, GASSSSSSSSPPPPPPPP!!!!!!
 That was like the most exciting news ever!
 But when I found out it was a play I was sort of discouraged.
 I had a lot of doubts about this novel/script when I first heard about it and after hearing several opinions I had to wonder how much I’d like it.
 After all that time, fans came up with their own theories about what happened after the Deathly Hallows and wrote fan-fictions that were actually really good.
 So to have their dreams and ideas get stomped on by a play…well, I can see where the mixed reviews come from.

Harry Potter and the Cursed Child follows the story of Harry’s son Albus, who’s starting his First Year at Hogwarts with worry. Living up to the Potter name isn’t easy, and apparently one day can change the course of your life forever. Harry, who is now the Head of Magical Law Enforcement has his own problems to deal with and being Father of the Year isn’t one of his priorities. While Albus struggles through school and tries to figure out how to be more than Harry Potter’s son, a devious plot starts to unfold with the threat of Voldemort’s return.

Reviews and opinions of other Potterheads aside, I didn’t really hate the eighth book as much as others did.
 It was certainly different but it still had that Harry Potter charm – just in script and dialogue form.
 I am also guilty of writing my own future fan-fiction, but it was nice to see what J. K. Rowling wanted for the Potter future (even if it wasn’t what any of the readers were expecting, and even though she didn’t really write the whole thing).
 I wish there were more books and more detail into the characters and their histories. What we got was just a glimpse of Harry, Ron, Hermione, Ginny and even Draco.
 To me, the book was just another story to add to the collection – something sort of separate from it.

Harry Potter and The Cursed Child was every bit as magical as any other Harry Potter novel – just with less detail. The characters are relatable (yes, even Draco and his son Scorpius who is still my fav) and believable. Maybe there was a little too much teenage angst but at least it was understandable. Albus struggling to be his own person and more than just Harry Potter’s son. It’s a burden, and even with Scorpius trying to be more than just Draco’s son.

In my opinion, anyone who’s ever read or written their own Harry Potter Fan-Fiction in the past several years will probably be somewhat disappointed by this script – I mean if I can be honest, it sounds a little bit like fan-fiction anyway. Still, this continuation of the Harry Potter novels is still very enjoyable and entertaining. I just wish I could see the play – or at least they should sell DVDs of it. I would definitely buy it.

4/5 Hearts of Love

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not bad
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2016
content: I liked it,though I wanted to love it,wanted more of the older cast,but not a bad start to maybe another great series

author: Amazon Customer
title: this is an entirely unnecessary story line
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2016
content: Yes, this is an entirely unnecessary story line. BUT it does put you right back into the the Harry Potter world which is all i really needed from this story. This was a fun and easy read. I have to add a bit of an eye-roll at all of the original character's jobs in this story. Our favorite witches and wizards basically run the wizarding world now...come on.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: good book if you like harry potter

author: hiramknick470
title: A grown up story
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content: I appreciated the story was much more grown-up. Instead of consequence -free adventure the adults had to consider more than just themselves.

author: PM
title: Need time to get used to reading a script
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2016
content: When you begin reading this story, you need to remember that it is a modified script (without director placement/scene notes).  It takes a little time to get into the flow of the script.  Once you become used to the flow, the reading of the book goes quite quickly.  Because of the time needed for a well-timed play, there are some holes that would have been filled if this were an actual book.  J.K. Rowling would have filled the gaps that are there for the play, but since a play usually runs about two hours, it is not possible to fill all of the holes.  On point is J.K. Rowling indicated this would be the last of the Harry Potter books.  This play leaves one opening where Delphi will be sent to Azkaban.  We know that several witches/wizards have escaped from Azkaban over the years.

author: DRGATB
title: If you loved the original, you'll enjoy the finale.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: This finale is a bit disappointing because of it's format and the limitations of its length.  Lot's of places where the reader, or at least I thought " no one would ever do/think/act like that...but because I was fond of the characters, I enjoyed this and didn't find it a waste of time.  Overall a a good experience.  As I was reading this, I kept imagining how it would be staged - and I suspect it would be great fun.  Will look forward to this coming to a "theater near me."

author: T. petersen
title: Flawed, but fun
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2016
content: I fun dive back into the world of Harry Potter, however, the playbook format may be off-putting to some readers, and it really does read like fan fiction. It relies heavily on book four of Harry Potter, and honestly Harry as an adult is not a whole lot better than Harry in Order of the Phoenix. That being said, I enjoyed Scopio's character (he was more interesting than Albus), and I did like seeing the gang back together. Long story short: Fun jaunt into nostalgia, but sort of misses its potential. Still enjoyed it and recommend it to fans.

author: Kimberly Bailey
title: The books were better - Looking forward to seeing the play though!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2016
content: I definitely enjoyed it, but the screenplay version of a Harry Potter story was disappointing in comparison to the richly detailed stories of the past. I felt like you couldn't get to know the characters in the same way and I read through it so fast. Looking forward to seeing the play though!

author: Jaydean Miller
title: Harry, Hermoine and Ron are back!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 5, 2016
content:
I read reviews that hated it due to the screen play format.  I did not find that distracting at all and enjoyed it.
Really good story line with fantastic references to other HP books and included familiar characters.
A good read, fun and kept me engaged.

author: Lorraine Swartzentruber
title: J.K. Rowling Enchants Us Once Again!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 22, 2016
content: True to form, J.K. Rowling did not disappoint.  Fans who are eager to hear more about Harry, Ron and Hermoine will be thrilled to add this book to their collection.  It is written in play form, but once you get into the story you don't really notice that anymore.  It would be a treat to see this on Broadway, but if you can't, the book is the next best thing.

author: Chelsea M. Mason
title: Because who doesn't love more HP, but you're not missing a lot....
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2016
content:
Honestly, who wasn't wanting more Harry Potter? It's why I finally caved and picked this up when my local grocery store had a sale if you carried a store card.
Because I live under a rock and was not paying attention, I did not realize this was the script for the play. However, as they say writing lives and dies by dialogue anyway, I was not majorly deterred.
I loved that this picked up one last 'what if' bit, and honestly answered a question I had had about Bellatrix Lestrange for a long time. Did I think the characters were maybe a little weaker and not as well fleshed out as in the books? Yes. Did I also think that because I was reading a script and not a book and not watching the play, that that had something to do with it? Yes, most definitely.
To any Harry Potter fan, this is a must add addition to your collection. It will give you pain when finished, as, once again, we must bid adieu to our beloved series. However, was it the end-all-be-all that was the last book in the series? No. I feel that while I found it very interesting to read and find out facts about the past and future in this series, it certainly did nothing to better the original books, simply add a little more interest. If you never pick it up, I don't think you're missing too much, but I do believe you'd find it worth your time if you do.

author: TeaCupRabbit
title: Your Harry Potter crazed family or friend would love it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 14, 2016
content:
I got this book for my Harry Potter crazed sister as a bribe to surrender the PS4 for a couple of weeks. The bribe worked and she really enjoyed the book, which is less of a book and is a script for a play. She actually liked it being more of a script and finished really quickly. A fun fact that I learned until after she finished the book was that she was texting her Harry Potter crazed friend (who already read this book before she received hers). After every chapter, she would text him her reaction.

As much as she loved the book, she's especially a fan of the two leading male characters, she did have a few issues with Harry and a couple of other characters. Which lead to her miniature rants on the problems she had and how she would improve them.

author: Greg Polansky
title: A Good Continuation
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2016
content:
In the epilogue to book 7, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, we saw that Harry Potter had kids. So did Draco Malfoy. Now we follow Albus Severus Potter and Scorpio Malfoy in an epic time travel adventure that sees them going back in time to try to change the future. What they don't think about is how their actions in the past will change the future.

If you're in need of a Harry Potter fix, then you will enjoy this. Yes. This is a play. But its better than nothing. You'll see what your old favorites are up to and learn more about the post-Voldemort world. No, it's not like the other books. Which is fine enough too. Just read it and make up your mind about it.

Also, as someone who got placed in the Slytherin house, I was happy to see certain events take place.

author: robin steele
title: Great story. Not as bad as others have said.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content: As a huge fan of all things Potter. I went at this with an open mind. I thought due to so many bad reviews that I wasn't going to like it. I did. Great story. Malfoy's is the best.

author: reugenio
title: a lot better than I thought
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2017
content: I received this as a gift, and was reminded why I loved the Harry Potter books in the first place. It was a lot better than I expected.

author: Russhelle P. Gremillion
title: Great job
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2016
content: I gave it four stars because it was written like a play but I quickly was able to bypass that. Love the future book and how it stayed true to the characters

author: Amazon Customer
title: Hooray for more Potter!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
content: Wonderful read! The first book I've taken the time to read since my kids have been born! I'm so glad I gave it a chance! The only reason I'm giving 4 stars is that it took me a minute to get used to the script format. Get over the fact that it's written differently and sit down and read this book!

author: Melissa Brookshire
title: I did enjoy reading about the "adult" version of our hero
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2016
content: As a "Potterhead," I of course would read anything that continues the Potter legacy. I did enjoy reading about the "adult" version of our hero. However, since it is in screenplay form, I did miss the details that were highlighted in the previous books. These wonderful details created strong characters and a mesmerizing universe that cannot be fully fleshed out in screenplay form. Also, the story spanned years and felt rushed. I would have loved to see Albus's character developed more, so I could actually comprehend his feelings and actions. Even with my minor qualms, I guess I should feel privileged that we even were given this continuation and an actual published version.  I definitely would suggest the reader to start the book with an open mind and the understanding that this book only scratches the surface of what could have been!

author: M
title: think of it as fanfic, not a harry potter book
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 28, 2016
content: Basically fanfiction with a weird plot, but enjoyable and resolves some character conflicts that were unaddressed in the books.

author: Shan B
title: It's a play not a novel, enjoy it for what it is
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2016
content: If you read and accept the book for what it is (a play script, not a novel), you should enjoy it. As i read it i could envision the play before my eyes and it will be an amazing play in London. *SPOILER* that being said, It's not nearly as good as the novels, and i did think the time turner plot was a bit cheesy and interferes with info from the 7 novels, and that was admittedly dissapointing. But I knew that being a play script it would need to be condensed and fast. I feel that the reviews giving 1 or 2 stars are disappointed because it is not like the 7 novels, which it isn't.  This script does not come close to the depth of story and characters in the novels. It is a play! To sum up, if you approach the book as it is, a script not an 8th novel, and accept it wont be as good, you should not be disappointed. A great addition to my harry collection.

author: B-Veg
title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is a fun read, and any Potter fan will probably enjoy ...

It seems like they tried to include every character from the original series into the story, and spent less development on important character's relationships.

title: You know

title: Different but good

content: Reading the book you can definitely tell the writer is not the same. The plot was entertaining but it definitely isn't like the originals.

content: Very creative carry-on of the original story, with room for another sequel.  Loved the flashbacks.  Don't see how they can do this on stage.  I guess I will just have to make a trip to London to see the play. If you have missed characters from the books, you'll be able to meet them again.

author: KR
title: Not like the original books but still good
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2016
content: A let down from the other books - I suspect it is because it was written to be a play. Still happy to have read it.

author: Sarah
title: Know what you're buying!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2016
content: Note that I haven't completed this book yet. I purchased this book knowing it was **not written by JK Rowling and that it is an **inspired fanfiction story. Please note that it is **written like a play script and does not read like a regular novel. The book picks up right at the epilogue of the last movie/book ends (19 years later at King's Cross station). So far the story is ok but you can tell it's fanfiction, so if you're expecting another Harry Potter masterpiece this may not be the book for you. I'm 82 pages in and they're already in the fourth year, so it moves quickly. I am a huge Harry Potter fan so I thought it was worth purchasing; ***however, I stress that this is fanfiction and is laid out as a play script!!

author: S. Pagliaccio
title: If only it would have been in book format
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2016
content:
I did not think I would enjoy this book as much as I did considering it is written in play form. It is very fast reading because of the format.
I wish the author would have just taken the time to make this into a real book, and then derived the play from it. I would have preferred more detail and background, more developing of the story. That being said, all in all - I feel it is worth reading. Had it been in book format and not play format, I would have given it 5 stars.

author: Jim Ray
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 23, 2016

author: nathan guilde

Everyone knows this book came as a surprise. Being written in a play format, I was skeptical. However, it was much easier to read than I had anticipated. The characters made sense. I think I might be disappointed in the lack of magic used in this story. There wasn't much at all.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Harry Potter and the Cursed Child

author: eric nelson
title: Four Stars

content: Read like a play of sorts. Was a gift for a fam member, but that's their input

author: Amazon Customer
title: Harry Potter Fan
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2016
content: It takes a bit to get used to reading the book as scenes, the first time I tried, I put it back down. When I gave it another try I read it all in a day. But then again I am a huge Harry Potter fan.

author: Heather L. McMillan
title: An Excellent Read for the Avid Fan, but Lacking in Depth of Story
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content: I am such a huge Harry Potter fan, so naturally, I am always eager and ecstatic to get anymore information from this world (past, present, future).  The fact that it was a screenplay made it a very nice, easy read.  I was able to finish it very quickly, in a matter of hours.  However, I felt the storyline was quite cheesy in parts and could have used a little more thought in development.  As an English major, I understand that screenplays require different aspects than a novel; however, I felt this was lacking in any real deep plot line in comparison to the other Harry Potter stories, individually and collectively.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2016
content: Very good but not as good as the previous ones

author: Christina Stanley
title: Old friends New friends
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2017
content:
I enjoyed this play for the simple fact that it felt like I was seeing my old friends again after a long absence.  Even though the new characters were great, I wish that the plot could have been theirs alone and not involved so much of the events of previous books.  This left me longing for more. :)
Wishing JKR would write a new wizarding world series. :)

author: nom de plume
title: Interesting
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: For a written play, it was pretty well done

author: dlovestojeep
title: Fun read with new characters, plot twists, and wonderful message of friendship and cooperation
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2016
content:
I read this book in one sitting and thoroughly enjoyed it. It was fast and engaging story.  I liked Albus Potter very much and felt like there was enough depth to his character to warrant another seven book series. That being said, I think there were some rough edges.

I knew reading a script wouldn't be my favorite kind of read, and almost everything I didn't like about the book could be put down to that fact. Reading a script is choppy, and without visuals or music, characters can feel very flat.  On top of that, there's not as much scope or time to give background information, explore feelings, or any of the usual methods utilized in a novel of fleshing out characters or evoking emotion. The screenplay was a unique presentation and I sincerely hope that I get a chance someday to see the play (or a movie), but I still wish it had been a novel.

The only other criticism I have is that the adults, which by now we know and love, have apparently regressed to their fifth year juvenile mentality.  You'd think that working together to defeat the dark lord, marriage, and kids would have given them at least a modicum of maturity.  Apparently not. They are continually, almost laughably, overreacting. Both their disagreements and their collaborations seemed very stereotypically pasted together, mainly because there wasn't time in the plot to delve into any kind of mature discussion. Fortunately, their interactions were kept to a minimum and my inner director had them tone the drama down to acceptable levels :-).

Overall, though, I would recommend this book as long as you are willing to read for fun and not take it to seriously.

author: Sherry Chiodo

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not Amazing, But Still Worth Checking Out
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2016
content:
Unpopular opinion time!

I was probably one of the few people who originally wasn't sure about reading this book. Yes, it's a Harry Potter book, but I had read up on it when this was first announced, and realized that J.K. Rowling didn't actually write it...instead, it was the 2 playwrights. In my mind, this was fine, but I didn't like the fact that they were marketing this as "another Harry Potter story" and "by J.K. Rowling" (I mean come on, you can't blame people for not thinking that it's written by her when her name is in big bold letters on the cover of the actual book!). However, I thought to myself, what kind of fan are you if you don't give this book a shot? I felt I owed it to myself to see where these beloved characters were in the future, and what the world was like for them now. But because of this, I went in with slightly lower expectations. I wasn't expecting that same love to come back, because after all...there's only one J.K. Rowling, and virtually no one can come close to this woman's amazing writing skills. However, I honestly greatly enjoyed reading this novel, and I even though I had my complaints, I loved being back in this world.

There is definitely a lot to love about this story: the magic, the strong friendships, and full of twists. Was the plot my favorite? No...I think a stronger plot could have been created, but I also remembered that this has to translate to the stage. So in that way, I understand why the plot was the way it was. The one thing that I thought came through very well was the emotional toll that all of the events of the past had on Harry, Ron, Hermione, Ginny, and Draco. I honestly felt their raw struggle while reading, and I thought the writers did an excellent job at translating this in the script. Obviously, everything that these characters went through in the Harry Potter series took a significant toll on all of them, and it changed them irrevocably.

But this does lead me to one thing that upset me a bit while reading. This is a common complaint, but these characters that I know and love and feel like are family, didn't always act how I would have ever thought they would. I found Harry to be extremely harsh and rude at times, and yes, Harry was always a bit blunt and sarcastic in the books, the extent his character went to in this book was so unlike him. Hermione is awesome as ever, but I felt that she was even dulled down a bit. And Ron, while definitely used as comic relief in an otherwise dark play, got relegated to a side role that had no depth. Now is this because our trio truly wasn't supposed to be the main focus of this story? I don't know, but this was the conclusion I came up with while reading, along with the fact that this is also a play and characters aren't always given the same amount of depth as in an actual book.

However, I did LOVE Albus and Scorpius (Scorpius just a little bit more though). They were both great characters, and I adored their friendship. This was where this book shined because it showcased how unique situations can bring together the most unlikely of allies and form the most beautiful of friendships. I can understand why people are shipping them (heck...I am too)!

Overall, I think that this is worth checking out for any HP fan. Is it going to blow your mind, absolutely not. Will every single HP fan like/love it? No. But if you go into this book with an open mind, remembering that J.K. Rowling only offered slight input into the story and didn't actually write it; along with the fact that this is not the 8th Harry Potter book, then I think you will enjoy it. It's very easy to forget that this is even written in play format as it reads very easy and smoothly. I will tell you one thing though, I would absolutely love to see this as the play. I'm sure that just reading the script can't even remotely compare to the emotion and the exquisiteness that the actors' would bring to these roles. Check this out when you get the chance and get back into that world that shaped so many of our childhoods. You don't want to miss it!

Happy reading :)

author: Chip
title: Guaranteed to Be Polarizing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
POTENTIAL MILD SPOILERS

I have been pumped for this ever since it was announced in 2015. I grew up with Harry Potter; I have read the books many times and havd watched the films many times. I own the ultimate editions so that I could have as many bonus features as possible. I recently bought the illustrated edition of the first book and plan on collecting the rest.

So it should come as no shock that my expectations for this story were very high. I read this script in just under 4 hours compared to the 3-4 days it would take me to read the books when they came out. So I had a lot to process quickly. One thing that stood out to me was, despite this taking much less time to read, the play feels epic and a good bit of time passes within it.
 Upon finishing, my feelings were mixed to negative. Some creative decisions were truly puzzling to me. But then I remembered that this is a play, not a novel or even a film. Visualizing this from a theatre perspective, I certainly gained an appreciation/understanding of why this story was told. Upon thinking even more, I want to re-read it and could find myself loving it.

Essentially, this story is about a parent and child learning to understand one another and appreciate one another. This is true for Harry and his son, Albus Severus and Draco and Scorpius (and another character that would be a huge spoiler that I won't mention). The contrasts between the fathers and sons are emphasized, hence why this story feels different from any other Potter story before. Albus Severus and Harry have almost nothing in common except blood. But what few traits they share are what bring them closer by the end.

Other beloved characters pop up. While they seem to behave in ways much different, we have to understand that they are at a different time in their lives and that (once again) this is a play. So certain things are played up for drama or comedy. Aside from the great new characters of Albus and Scorpius, I thought seeing Harry as a middle-aged adult was fascinating. My other favorite character was surprisingly Draco Malfoy.

If I have a criticism, it's that this story sometimes feels like a "greatest hits" of thr Harry Potter series. Upon re-thinking, I don't feel that way as much because it focuses on key events from the pass, not every event. It brings the past, present, and future together in a way that makes sense for the characters in this story. In my opinion, it actually does further the story quite a bit. And if Rowling or Jack Thorne ever did decide to continue this story, they certainly could take it to some interesting and different places.

My main issue with the play is not a big one, but it has to do with the villain. I like the villain, and the concept behind the character is interesting and plausible. However, I think an opportunity was squandered to go in a fresher, more inventive direction.

All in all, my opinion on this script has changed for the better. I actually appreciate the story and do consider it canon. There is an It's a Wonderful Life vibe to this story, and many of the creative choices do work, while some are more puzzling. Some plot points would benefit from a full novel or even a film in order to be fleshed out. However, I'm sure that watching the play is absolutely magical for any Harry Potter fan.

author: Lillian @ Mom with a Reading Problem
title: Can't see the play? Read it! Perfect for Fans of the series.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 11, 2016
content:
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child by J.K. Rowling is the long-awaited 8th installment of the Harry Potter series that takes place 19 years after the fall of Voldemort. Unlike the other books, this one isn’t a novel, it’s a screenplay for those (like me) who couldn’t attend the play in London this past Summer. Unlike most, I loved having this screenplay. I knew it wasn’t going to be a novel, that most likely it would fall short of my expectations but I was still excited. Can I just say that it met my expectations and then some!

I think the novel of this book is getting to see my favorite characters as adults, my own age, dealing with their kids and the hassle of every day life. Harry and Hermione work for the Ministry of Magic, Ron’s taken over the joke shop, Ginny is her mom….I seriously loved this! Harry after 19 years still has nightmares about the battle of Hogwarts, his role in it and his connection to Voldemort. It’s interesting to see the aftereffects, seeing the post-traumatic stress that surrounds these characters, the fear of Voldemort somehow returning, and the grief they still feel 19 years later for those they lost.

The real draw though is reading about their children and their adventures at Hogwarts. I loved Albus, like absolutely adored him. He’s a miniature Harry through and through. He’s constantly in trouble, an outcast and even in his own family has a hard time relating to his dad. It’s interesting to see how similar and different the story is to Harry’s own story. My favorite character of the book though is Draco’s son Scorpius. He’s misunderstood, an outcast like Albus, and somehow he understands Albus better than anyone. The two strike up a friendship very similar to Ron and Harry and I just love them. Scorpius is the exact opposite of his dad, but at the same time I believe he is who Draco could have been without the pressure to follow Voldemort.

The plot of the play revolves around an outlawed, not-supposed-to-exist time-turner. Albus gets his hands on one and well that’s the story, a misguided attempt to save a boy killed by Voldemort which results in big changes. I didn’t care for the use of the time turner in the story. I felt like it was too familiar for fans of the series as we’ve been there and done that when Sirius was saved. However I still found myself engrossed. I read the play in one sitting, about 4 hours. Remember even though it’s 300+ pages, it’s a screenplay. It does not take long to read dialogue. If you’re a fan of the series, I highly recommend you read it. It’s a fun, nostalgic romp with your best friends…erhm I mean favorite characters.

author: C. R. Collins
title: It's getting old that's hard.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
This book - it not's a novel - it's a script. It's a script to a good play that is about the difficulty of relating to your children and how strange it is it grow up. It's an amazing play (I've seen it) along with Hamilton it's a true innovation in just about every way.

The relationships between the characters are great and the abbreviated way the story is told works great - things build quickly and then the real story starts - full of great surprises and wonderful evolutions of the characters you loved from the novels and the scenes carry a great deal of weight when performed on stage.

It's a strange thing - as a friend pointed out - imagine if the next Star Wars movie only played in one theatre in the whole world and tickets were impossible to get so all you could do was read the script. I imagine people would be disappointed by that script too - but that's not the scripts fault - they've made an incredible experience in the play - and this helps for those that want the surprise early - or want to revisit that amazing experience.

author: The Irregular Reader
title: and counts as his best friend one Scorpius Malfoy
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
content:
I’m a huge Potterhead. I’ll admit it. Rowlings stories continue to be magical, even twenty years after Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone came out. I’m sure I don’t need to go into the back story of Harry Potter for this review, because if you don’t know it, why the heck are you here?

Cursed Child takes place nineteen years after the events of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows. Harry, Hermione, Ron, and Ginny are in their forties, and have kids in Hogwarts. This book focuses mainly on Harry and Ginny’s second child, Albus Severus Potter. Albus is very unlike Harry: he’s in Slytherin, for one, and counts as his best friend one Scorpius Malfoy. Harry, being Harry, and Albus, being a teenager, butt heads constantly, their personalities pinging off one another like rocks colliding in midair. I’m not going to get into the plot very much (or really at all), as I can’t find any way to describe it without HUGE spoilers (and god, but I hate spoilers). Suffice it to say that we get to revisit some classic bits from the original series, as well as find out some new stuff about the Harry Potter Universe.

Now for the nitty gritty: the book is not really a book but rather a play, which is going on in London right now (though again, if you didn’t know that . . .). What that means is: this book is written as a play, with dialogue and stage directions but little else. I’ll say the dialogue is spot on. I think the authors (Thorne and Tiffany) did a great job of capturing the characters. The dialogue flows like Rowling wrote it, and you can easily hear the character in the lines. the bad part of this is: it’s mainly just dialogue. There’s none of the little wonderful extras Rowling would slip in between the lines, the depth of field that makes the Potter Universe so compelling and so real. I’m sure seeing the play live takes care of most of that (can’t wait!), but in the reading you feel a little bereft.

The adventure is fun and engaging. The duo of Albus and Scorpius are just as compelling as Harry and Ron. And it’s great to see how the characters we already know and love, not just the big guys but also Professor McGonagall, Draco Malfoy, and others have gotten on since we saw them last. Potterheads are going to love this expansion to the universe. My only wish would have been to have the thing rewritten into novel form by Rowling, but perhaps that’s just me being greedy.

Get more reviews by checking out my blog!
[...]

author: T. Ferlisi
title: Not a Harry Potter Book. Great script.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: So here's the thing that I think a lot of the reviewers are missing. It's a play. I've been reading and interpreting plays for over a decade (I'm an actor, a director, a playwright, and a theatre teacher). There is a god plot behind this play, some meat for the actors to make it their own, a bit too much stage direction for my like, but not an obscene amount. There are some technical things that would be a little difficult to produce in live theatre, and it needed to start a bit later in the timeline (as watching actors age on stage is harder to pull of than on film). But this was a good play. It is NOT a Harry Potter book, and doesn't read like one, doesn't feel like one, doesn't do a lot of the things the 7 books do. It was nice to revisit this world in a new format with the fresh eyes of adulthood returning to characters that were familiar but completely different (like having coffee with a good friend from high school that you haven't seen in 10 years). A warm hug from a new friend. Read it (it's a quick read even compared to early Harry books). Enjoy the new mode of entertainment, it takes a while to get use to reading stage plays (which are written different than screenplays - which other reviewers are calling it).

author: William T. Lodge
title: Totally worth it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
Things you must understand:

One, this is a script for a play, not really a book. It reads like a play, the details offered are those you'd get in a play (stage directions and so on). It's easy to read but this is a different kind of Harry Potter book. Two, you won't have to worry about what they left out when they make the movie as you know they will. There isn't much that they could leave out. Three, if you were worried that this was going to ruin the series for you - don't. It holds up the Potter flag. You won't be disappointed.

In some ways, this reads like fan fiction. What happened if... and they got Rowling involved to make it all work. And it does work. You will enjoy the story, you will believe these are the same characters, and in the end you will care about what happens to them. I can't give it 5 stars mostly because I wanted an 8th book, and this isn't that, it's a lot less detail and a lot less story. But it was a whole lot of fun. If you keep in mind that this is NOT an 8th book but the script for a play, you will enjoy it.

author: Amazon Customer
title: While it's not the books Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is well-worth your time if you're a Potter fan
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2017
content: If you're looking for this play to be Harry Potter book 8, you'll be disappointed. However, I thoroughly enjoyed this piece! It takes off right where Hallows left off with the first scene being practically word-for-word with the final chapter of the novel. The play's main focus is Harry's second son Albus and Draco's son Scorpius. Since the focus is primarily on new characters and not on Harry, Ron, and Hermione, this has a different feel than the novels. It deals a lot with Harry's relationship with his son, which I thought to be a really well-written exploration into Harry struggling as a father. The overall plot is good. It's not as good as the novels, for it's kinda a smaller story. It's interesting to see the three friends older, but I wish the play showed more of them. It took a while for the plot to move, but when it did, I was hooked. There was a few cringe-inducing lines, but other than that, the dialogue was charming. It can get a little confusing at times, for this is meant to be seen performed on stage, not read. I would love to see the production when it comes to Broadway! Overall, if you want to see what happens after Hallows, this is well worth your time! Again, those expecting it to be Harry Potter Book 8 quality will be disappointed. But for what it is, it's a decent addition to the Potter universe!

content: My name is Shannon and I am 9 years old.  I am a Harry Potter fan and have read all the books and The Tales of the Bettle Bard. This book was pretty good.  I liked it as much as the original series, except I did not like the play format.  I would have preferred it be a novel, but I liked the story.  The story is so good! He is smart and funny and helped them in a lot of situations.  All in all, I recommend Cursed Child to other HP fans.

author: Craig MACKINNON
title: the 8th Harry Potter story
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2017
content:
Just to be clear, I have not seen the Cursed Child on the stage.  I know, not the least from my high school Shakespeare that reading a play is a far different experience from seeing it performed.  Unlike Shakespeare, JK Rowling's so-called "8th Harry Potter story" is written in the modern vernacular so it is easier to follow!

We re-encounter Harry Potter as he drops his children off on platform 9 and 3/4.  One child - Albus - is starting his first year at Hogwarts and is sorted, not into Griffendor house like his brother, sister, mother, and father, but into hated Slytherin.  There he forms an unlikely friendship with Scorpius Malfoy, son of Harry's arch-enemy Draco.  When bad things happen to Albus and Scorpius (as was inevitable), Draco and Harry, as well as Uncle Ron and Aunt Hermione, must bury the hatchet and work together to rescue their wayward children.  To say any more about the plot would spoil the surprise for the reader, and perhaps remove from the impact of the story.

It is not perhaps the plot that is most important, but Harry Potter fans can be assured that this "feels" like a Harry Potter story, it's just the format that's changed.  Rowling's signature flourishes and plot twists are on ample display.  At the same time, there is far more humour than in the novels, perhaps influenced by John Tiffany and Jack Thorne, Rowling's collaborators.  Ultimately, the biggest praise is to say that this really is the eight Harry Potter story, and if the main character is Albus Potter, Harry's fans will get to see him too, even back at Hogwarts as we remember him from Stories 1-7 (how that comes into this story you will have to learn for yourself!).

The format - reading a play - is not ideal, but for those of us who have not been able to jet off to London or New York can make do and enjoy the story nonetheless.

author: Joe Shandra

content: Without giving too much away, HP's son, Albus, travels through time and revisits familiar scenes. Keep in mind this is a play- there are more punchy jokes to get the audience laughing, and the plot is simplified (not nearly as many angles or reveals as previous books) but I really think this is the only way the final part of the story could be told. The books are untouchable and there's an absolutely magical quality that can't be recreated. Go into the script without comparing it to her books and you'll find that this is an elegant end to the HP story. Giving only 4 stars because it's apparent to me that this best translates on stage.

author: emerald28
title: Victim of high expectations?
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2016
content:
I really don't understand all the negativity about this book.  I've been a big HP fan for years, of course, and was eagerly anticipating the release of this play.  I don't think it was as good as the original seven novels, but I didn't expect it to be.

It seems the main problem people have with this story is that they feel the characters didn't behave as themselves.  I disagree.  Harry, Ron, and Hermione were never perfect people; they often 'forgot to remember' lessons they'd already learned, and acted in selfish and reckless ways.  I think it's perfectly reasonable that Harry would grow up into someone who gets overwhelmed easily by circumstances he doesn't feel he can control and who acts more out of emotion than out of rational thought (which is how he always was).  Similarly, it's more than believable that Hermione grew up to become a by-the-book Minister of Magic... when was she ever not by-the-book?  Rose judges Slytherins for being Slytherins not because her parents didn't raise her well, but because she's a child and children are influenced to some degree by their peers, no matter what their parents do or say. I think one of the best things about all the characters in the HP world is that they are written as flawed, and even though they learn from their experiences and grow as people, they are still flawed - to have them not be would be completely unrealistic.

I really enjoyed reading this book.  The plot of it wasn't as great as the original seven, but how could it be when it wasn't written entirely by Rowling?  I don't think I'd sit through a 5.5 hour play version, but I'm glad we got to see another chapter in the HP world.

content:
By all means, this is not as epically charged as the original book series. Some characters return, and that is where the magic is its most powerful. As an avid HP fan for over a decade, I can honestly recommend this story to HP fanatics that have always wanted kist that little bit more from the magical world.

I do believe that to see this on stage would change the way most view this script; it's meant to be watched and not read. But it's a great compromise for fans who cannot attend the London show.

Is it perfect? No. Did I smile, and laugh, and feel? Absolutely. And those familiar Potter feelings are all I could have ever wanted from a new HP book. Even if it did feel fanfiction-y. I'll read it again, and again, and again.

author: ViolettePen
title: Not my favorite HP story, but I'm glad I gave it a chance
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2016
content:
Talk about a trip down memory lane. Harry Potter and the Cursed Child takes readers (and lucky theater patrons) back to J.K. Rowling's Wizarding World for one more adventure with beloved characters and new friends and enemies. The script splits its time between the adults and their children, mainly Harry and his younger son Albus, whose relationship is strained under the weight of their family's legacy. Things don't get much easier for Albus when he's sorted in Slytherin and befriends Scorpius Malfoy, the son of Harry's still-nemesis Draco Malfoy. But after eavesdropping on a conversation between Harry and an elderly man still grieving over his son, Albus resolves to steal a Time Turner and fix one of his father's biggest mistakes - a decision with potentially dire consequences.

As excited as I was about Cursed Child, I had my reservations since Rowling didn't create the story alone. But I quickly found myself settling in for the ride and enjoying myself, even laughing out loud at the comedic bits. Most of the returning characters were portrayed accurately (or, matching my impressions of older yet recognizable versions of themselves), and I remembered why I loved (or hated) them all over again. The new characters were also wonderful, especially Scorpius. Yes, a Malfoy was my favorite character this time! But he's kind, nerdy, a voice of reason for Albus, and a hopeless romantic for Ron and Hermoine's daughter Rose. Reading a script was an interesting experience, too. The bare-bones stage directions allowed me to imagine or recall each setting and spell however I chose, and I appreciated that.

I have a BIG problem, though, with Delphi Diggory. It's not her character per se, but her true "parentage"... It defies logic, from who her parents are (really?!) to the timeline of her birth (and the implications her mother's pregnancy would have had on past HP events). Some fans have also criticized the "queer-baiting" in Albus and Scorpius's friendship. I can see where they're coming from... but it reminds me of a similar debate over Frodo and Sam after the Lord of the Rings film trilogy was released, and I didn't agree with that opinion. All I'll say here is that it made sense to me for Albus and Scorpius, two young and awkward boys who are shunned by their peers, to become as close as they did.

Anyways - yes, I'm happy with Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. It's not my favorite HP story by far, but I'm glad I gave it a chance. Now I'll be jealous of anyone who's fortunate enough to see the play.

People who were expecting a whole new series to be folded into these pages were destined to be disappointed. It is probably time to move on from Harry Potter and stop expecting so much from a series geared towards children. of course it is going to disappoint as adults. This play was a fun read that gave me A LOT of feelings, and I am grateful for it. not everyone will get a chance to see this play live so it is nice to have the script. Rowling has expressed her desire to move on from Harry Potter, and it's time we let her.

I did enjoy getting a glimpse of the next generation of wizards and witches in the magical world of Harry Potter. This book would be confusing and frustrating to read for those unfamiliar with the other books and films because it implies and references past storylines.

Having never read any of the previous Harry Potter books but loving all the movies, I decided to dive in and read Harry Potter and the cursed child by Rowliin, Tiffany, and Thorne. Although I struggled at first with how the book was written out for a play script rather than a normal novel. However once I started to get a flow for how it read I could not put the book down. I found myself so fascinated by every thing that was happening I loved seeing harry and his great friends Hermione, Ron, and Ginny from a different angle as parents all grown up. I thought the story moved a long at a fun and magically fast pace, which kept me interested and excited about what was going to happen next.

 I highly recommend this book to anyone. If you loved the old harry potter books or movies, you will enjoy reading this one as well. It takes you on a exciting adventure through the magical world of Hogwarts with some of the original characters and locations as before. This will reignite those wonderful memories you had with the old adventures with Harry and his friends. In comparison this will give you a new and refreshing adventure with there kids and how they go about fighting dark magic with great twists and turns through out the whole book.

title: Returning to the World of Harry Potter!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 13, 2016
content: Oh my, there are so many negative reviews for this!  I'm a big fan of the original HP series too.  We won't go into how many times I have read the series, because it's a lot.  And here are my two cents.  This newest installment isn't a HP novel, and it doesn't read like one.  It's not even by J K Rowling, though her name appears on the cover.  However, I still enjoyed the story.  It was interesting to read Harry as an adult, struggling with his teenage child.  The play does feel a bit like fanfiction in spots--the time turners, the alternate universes--but at least it's fanfiction endorsed by JKR.  I enjoyed the story, and reading it made me miss the Golden Trio so much that I now need to re-read Books 1-7 for the umpteenth time!

author: Michael J. Wood
title: it's understandable why some would express a bit of disappointment in this latest entry into the Potterverse
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Let's just get this out of the way: This is a script, not a novel. It says that. On the cover. Above the title. Why people seem to be surprised and/or confused by this is beyond me.

That said, it's understandable why some would express a bit of disappointment in this latest entry into the Potterverse. While reading a script it is entirely up to the reader to imagine things such as location and dress. It's not an immersive experience the way a novel is. Perhaps, for this reason, people are missing out on how truly wonderful a piece of work it is. Perhaps, without the assistance of Rowling's prose, this is why people are claiming it "reads like fan fiction".

If that is the case, it's one of the finest examples of "fan fiction" I've ever read.

The story focuses more on Harry and Ginny's son Albus and his friendship with Scorpius Malfoy. The two young men bond over their unfortunate legacies...both having to live up to (or live down) their infamous fathers. Both are intriguing characters and the story takes a particularly interesting turn (spoiler-free pun intended).

Give it a read. Read it carefully and give what the characters say time to resonate. Use your imagination to build sets in your mind. You all have an idea of what Hogwarts looks like. Tap into those image. Then you can enjoy the story for what it is, which really is quite wonderful.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Good Story - Read it with an open mind!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Just finished reading Harry Potter and the Cursed Child. It is in script form but I didn't find that distracting at all. I enjoyed the story although it was "softer" than the original series. You get to see into the hearts of Snape and Dumbledore along with visiting with some of the other favorites of the original series. If you like Harry Potter (or love it in my case) then you'll appreciate this extension.

I understand some of the disappointed posts but we all know this wasn't written by Ms. Rowling and sequels are rarely better than the originals.  This story is post Harry Potter and the children in this story know nothing of violence and loss, unlike their parents, so their actions/reactions are understanding.  Harry Potter and gang have also lived in a post chaotic environment in the numerous years beyond what occurred so to some extent, their reactions are somewhat acceptable.  I encourage you to read this book with an open mind.

author: Whitney R
title: I enjoyed it
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
SPOILER FREE

Harry Potter and the Cursed Child was amazing and emotional and would be for any Potterhead. The script format was confusing to follow (hence the 4.5) but I loved the storyline(s). You have to approach this script focusing on the storyline, the world-building, and the characters. NOT the fact that you're reading a script of something supposed to be performed...otherwise you'll become irritated and not enjoy what's happening. The beauty and allure of this story, for me, is that it allows readers to revisit the magical world of Harry Potter and his friends. Yes, it's a play, not a novel. NO, J.K. Rowling didn't completely write it. Yes, it's a lot different than the books we grew up reading over ten years ago-but the characters are different-they're adults, married, with children and jobs. The story is emotional, frightening, and funny even, some characters are pretty snarky.  ;) I got watery eyed during several scenes and really liked several lines-one being from Harry- "I've never fought alone...And I never will." (*SOBS*)

CRAZY things happen in this story-alternate realities, nightmares- you will be shocked, you'll cry, you'll laugh, and your heart and mind will be flooded with the memories you had of the first time you met Harry Potter.  What I would give to see this on the stage....

author: Amazon Customer
title: Fantastic plot, subpar writing
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
One thing people need to understand before going into this is that it is NOT a novel, it's a playscript. I personally think that they made a mistake releasing this as a script where JK Rowling should have written it as a novel. First, the plot: it's genius. It incorporates the Time Turner used in The Prisoner of Azkaban, and it advances the plot in all the right ways, especially the nostalgia it brings. It brings us back to scenes from the original book series and it's really interesting seeing how Harry Potter and Draco Malfoy's sons tamper with time (or don't tamper with it).

The biggest problem is the writing. It's evident that this was not written by JK Rowling. The dialogue just doesn't fit the characters, especially Harry, who's attitude and temper has changed completely. It just doesn't seem natural at all. The dialogue also comes off as really cheesy sometimes, with dumb puns and one-liners that JK Rowling would never write (and for some reason they keep using the word "discombobulated" throughout the book which was annoying).

It's obvious as to why many people will be disappointed with this. But it was hard for me not to smile in scenes where they revisit major scenes of the original books, and see them from different perspectives. The plot twists that are here are fantastic, and it should be made into a movie eventually (WITH TWEAKED DIALOGUE). I enjoyed these things so much that I was able to overlook the weak writing. Give it a try.

title: and the story line is good. I did think that a few parts seemed ...

content: First of all, this is a script, not a book.  I knew ahead of time that this was a script and that doesn't bother me nor affect my 4 star rating. author: Stephanie
title: This play is quite good, is it like another Harry Potter book
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
This play is quite good, is it like another Harry Potter book? Not really. Anyone who expected that is going to be sadly mistaken. A script is not a novel and does not come across as one. You are not going to be transported to the wizarding world as easily and it is harder to connect with the story and the characters. You need prose or to see it performed for that. But, if you can use your imagination to transport yourself into this world, you won't be disappointed. The characters you love are there along with new ones, the story is very grand and reminiscent of the books. The story is more about relationships between characters as opposed to an overly magical setting and experience. I thoroughly enjoyed seeing how relationships between some of my favorite characters have evolved as they grew up more and their relationships with their children.

I've read other reviews that said the story and characters are flat and two dimensional, again I believe that is a problem with the way a script reads versus a novel and I think many people are going to be expecting something different. I've also read that people found inconsistencies between this and the books. I didn't notice anything major, but I also have not read a lot of the extended universe material.

Overall, I really enjoyed the story and format and this is definitely worth a read.

However, the beautiful logo, binding, and page quality made for a great aesthetic experience, even when I was frustrated with the story. The tale overall was not terrible- I loved Scorpius and Albus Severus and their friendship, but there were many other ways the story could have gone. In the end, it was a delightful return to the world of Harry Potter, but not as spectacular as I had hoped.

author: monstoppable96
title: Spoiler: Scorpius Malfoy is the best part of the book
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child was a very fun read.
For me, this script book was a very fun addition to the HP universe. I felt that it didn't detract from the original series at all, and stands as it's own "expanded universe" sort of title. It walks the line between "Canonical Potter Story" and a fun experiment with familiar faces. The character interactions are wonderful. I especially enjoyed the characterization of the Malfoys, who seemed to steal the show in every scene they appeared.
There were some nit picks and plot holes throughout but they were pretty minor.
Overall, it was a lot of fun to get back into Harry's world. Cursed Child seems destined to be the black sheep of the franchise...which is fitting because Albus Potter is really the same way.

author: HaoKaren
title: the plot offered nice surprises for me
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
First of all, I'm not blind to the plot holes and how people were out of character sometimes in the book. I understand a lot of the frustration from other reviews. Here's my take on this: this story is meant for a play that's roughly 4 hours, and need to appeal to both kids and adults and none Potter fans.

Truth be told my review is purely biased based on how much I've missed the Harry Potter series and craved for new material. the story is not nearly as intricate as JK's books, the plot offered nice surprises for me, even though some 'surprising arcs' you can definitely see them coming.

The best comparison that I have for the play is Star Wars the Force Awakens to the old school Star Wars. Was the 7th episode the best? No. Did it play with my nostalgia for the originals? Yes. Did I willingly let the movie play on my emotions? Yes. Did I enjoy the new story? 100% Yes!

On the other hand I have to say I saw the lower ratings first hence lowered my expectations. But there are some material in the book that made me very much excited for the actual play! I cried reading this book! Multiple times as well!!

I believe because I was roughly Harry's age when I first read the originals, and now I'm well into my adulthood and facing the same 'family dilemma', which led me to relate to the story again. If you go into reading this book with an open mind, I'm sure you'll enjoy this book as much as I did!

author: Karen
title: I've read so many negative reviews about this written script and I see why people don't like it. (A) This is not a pure work ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 26, 2017
content: I have been a Harry Potter fan ever since the books came out. I've read so many negative reviews about this written script and I see why people don't like it. (A) This is not a pure work of JK Rowling , there are 2 other co-authors.  So, the characters that we've grown to love seems "out of character" because of different word choice. Again, this is not purely a JK Rowling work. (B) This is written for a play format, thus the characters in the play have to state out loud the emotions they are feeling. How can the live audience know what they are feeling if they don't say it out loud? Unlike in the original books, we know what's going on inside their minds because we are reading them off the book. Thus, again, the characters seem "out of character" because of this. (C) The book/script is fast paced because the whole script/book covers Albus' journey through Hogwarts up to their fourth year (I think). It is unlike the original books where each year has one book dedicated to it. This is my objective review. lol. Now, I docked off one star because (spoiler alert), why is Albus devoid of talent? Like zero? Not even one? I thought we inherit intelligence from the mother, isn't Ginny a vivacious talented witch? He is brave, for sure, but his stupidity caused all the trouble in the world. But I guess that is why we have a story. Harry's son got insecure, so he starts on a reckless/stupid journey to prove something.

author: Jen
title: It Had To Be Written Like This, Or The Play Wouldn't Have Worked
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
I understand that many fans of the series were disappointed. for those who are going to read the book, a warning: This had to be written for the stage. It couldn't have all the usual backstory or magical parts because imagine trying to reenact that on stage. There was an absence of magic, yes. Time also moved a bit too fast for my liking. But it was a good read and I would like to point out how difficult it would have been for it to satisfy everyone. I believe that there's still hope for it to be written as a novel. fingers crossed!
SPOILER: the part that really bugs me is the trolley lady. It was so Un-Harry Potterish. It reminds me of something I would see in Percy Jackson. I couldn't get over that part. I eventually had to convince myself it was some sort of twisted magic
