author: DianeMc
title: Enjoyed it
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content: I am a big fan of Harry Potter and was wanting to read more about the post Voldemort story. From Albus' fear of being sorted into Slytherin and his initials being ASP - a kind of snake - I suspected he might go that way. Thus is Albus a  kind of Sirius Black in reverse. And even though Harry couldn't have been happy about this, at least he and Ginny didn't disown Albus like Sirius' mum disowned him. Albus has to deal with much by being the child who is quite different from the rest of his family - something I can relate to! Like Ron, he has a lot to live up to with previous illustrious family members. Couple that with ones troubled teen and pre-teen  years and it is no wonder he has difficulty with his relationship with Harry. We can't expect Harry to be the perfect dad. We can't expect all Slytherins to be evil. This is much like real life. Personally, I couldn't put the book down for long and really enjoyed it. I feel bad for those who didn't like it but perhaps if they read it again with the above in mind they'll like it better.

I wish this were a novel instead of a screenplay, and I also wish the antagonist was not Moldy-Voldy's kid. That is OOC to me. I can't see The Dark Lord, who was not only determined to not share magic, but also to not die, ever thinking he would need to possibly procreate. Shame on you, JK..Voldemort (most precious, in his own words) would not think himself fallible, nor would he be willing to share even the tiniest piece of his magic or DNA to create an heir. "Bad guy" should have had a different origin.

author: Eliot Simcoe
title: Just know this book is NOT written by j.k. Rowling. Do not expect the same style
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2019
content:
I am happy i bought this overall... The book itself is not in any way written by j.k. Rowling. Do not expect her style of writing. It is however approved by her so i feel that's an important point to note.

This on my opinion is a fantastic book to have it you are a true Harry potter fan. It dives into the young Albus' life. And tells a different kind of story than Harry potter ever was. It is not about Harry anymore, but about his son. It is a lot about their bonds and how harry is learning to be a father now at this point in life.

It's the first time i have ever read a play besides in school. I read it in one day. It is not a long book. I mean it's like 300 pages but the text is spread out quite a bit. I had a great time reading it too... After starting, and this is the reason for four stars, it got slightly confusing with the quick flying through the years of Albus' life. I did not enjoy that particular part of the book very much and that's the point where i really noticed the different writing styles the most. i thought to myself i never would have gotten through all the Harry potter books of they were anything like that. I feel it could have been some thing like, beginning at Hogwarts, giving the background needed to get the story then go on to four years later and tell the story. That part was annoying and it's something i knew was going to end and i was just like, okay when will it be done. That is the only critical thing i have to say about the book. Which is pretty good since I'm choosy about my books. The screen play does not bother me a bit, I actually felt more there in the story than a lot of other books.  The story itself was great, i thought the characters were spot on,the personalities perfect, ups and downs and stuff i didn't expect but that added to the story so much. i love the overall additions this adds to the HP library... I still separate the Harry potter books in my head from this book but it's probably just because i have only read it once so far. I ummm love Harry potter, it's the best series i have ever read. I can read the books over and over.

AS a side note; I watched a documentary type deal on j.k. Rowlings decision to allow Jack Thorne and John tiffany to make this and she said she refused dozens of offers over the course of years before allowing any third party people touch her Harry Potter story. She did not decide on this book lightly. It is a great story and i would say a must of you are a Harry potter fan like i am. Even if it's separate In your head from up you'll be glad you read it, i was anyway. Hope this helps someone to decide. It's money will a on my opinion.... Also where else are you going to get an entire days worth of entertainment for $10??? Worth it!

author: Matthew Jenkins
title: Always, y'all...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2016
content: My advice to anyone who was not into the "style"this was written in, read more plays. I'm not saying things as a dig but as genuine advice. I thought this play was deadly. Once again it takes some wreckless children to try and save the world. But the best part is, it never feels formulaic. My biggest hope for the future of Harry Potter, is that off of the success of this play we get more expansion into this rich and (wait for it) timeless universe. Always y'all, always.

author: Peg Anne
title: Not quite what I expected
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content: This book did not have the intenseness I have found in the other Harry Potter books.  Perhaps because it was written in play form, but I don't think the characters were as developed as in the original series.  Perhaps I was expecting too much but I don't think a lot of effort was put into it.  Seems they were expecting it to be a success because of the name.  I enjoyed the book but will probably not reread as I have done the others.  (Probably have reread the series 3-4 times.)

author: Moonkyu Han
title: Was MUCH better than expected
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2016
content:
If you are looking for Harry Potter 8, this is not it. It is somewhat of a continuation of the series, but the feel of it is a bit different. I would have suggested that they take off the Harry Potter in the title of the book and called it something else to stir people away from their expectations. All in all, i really enjoyed it. I was a little hesitant to read it at first because of all the negative reviews, but i felt like the writers did a great job with this story. The set up and the pace is a little bit different from the original books because it's written as a play. However, after reading the book for 5 minutes, i was hooked. I read it in one sitting (it's not a long read). It wasn't a perfect book (it had its up and downs), but i thoroughly enjoyed it and was really entertained. Please note though that is not much of a story about Harry, Ron, etc.. It is a story about their kids. With that being said, it did also did a good job of revisiting old memories I had of Harry and his friends.

I am a huge Harry Potter fan and i think this was a great little spin off to the original story line.

author: Ilana Eisenhart
title: Fun & Fast Read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
I found the 8th installment to be a fun and fast read.  I enjoyed being immersed in the wizarding world of Harry Potter again.  This story focuses on the next generation of wizards, specifically Albus Potter and Scorpius Malfoy.  These two sons of famous nemeses form an unlikely friendship during their first year at Hogwarts.  The play fast forwards time quickly through their years at Hogwarts while also presenting the reader with each sons' difficult relationship with their fathers.  Harry Potter, the beloved orphan-turned-wizard hero who everyone loves has difficulty bonding with his middle son.  What an overwhelming reputation for a son to live up to!  Scorpius has to deal with his own problems and devious rumors that make him an outcast as well.  The friendship between Albus and Scorpius plays out nicely and leads to a fun and eye opening adventure that causes many problems to be solved.

As much as I liked this book, I felt it was a fast read and left more to be desired.  I missed the detailed descriptions of the wizarding world that I loved in the original books.  This book/play moves faster and doesn't have the same attention to detail.  But that shouldn't stop anyone from reading this book.  I loved the way the angst of being a teenager and parenting a teenager was played out.  The story still focuses on friendship, courage, and love, which was so much a part of the previous books.  I would recommend this story to all Potter fans, who I am sure have already finished it!  I do hope to see the play one day.

author: REB
title: Hard act to follow but well scripted.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 10, 2016
content: Well written but in play format rather than novel. Did not feel the scenes were as fully developed.

author: Ryan
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2016
content: Great for Harry Potter Fans, but it is different than the previous books.

author: MischiefManaged
title: Gutsy
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 2, 2016
content: It's been over 9 years since the events of "Harry Potter And The Deathly Hallows." Introducing a new story now, in a few format, is nothing less than brave. Constructed notions of how Harry, Hermione, and Ron's characters continue and develop are put to the test here. Regardless of how you feel about that there's no denying "Cursed Child" succeeds in every way a new story should. It takes risks, cares about its characters, and crafts a world we want to revisit again and again.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Wish there was going to be more..
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2016
content: Although I agree with the overwhelming negative reviewers that this is Fanfic. However, I genuinely believe any potter head can at the very least find themselves wrapped in the "story" here. I know it's not true to JK Rowling, although I know she put her two cents in, if only just that. It is still Harry Potter, and I love the characters, the world it's set in, and despite the fact that it's really kinda weird. I still love it and wish there was more to come.

content: I certainly hope to see this in production here in San Francisco but I would be amazed at how the myriad of scene changes would happen. This is a story about legacy and how we all wish to muck around with the "what ifs". But in the words of another franchise: "time travel gives me a headache."

author: dee
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016

author: Sonia
title: Storyline Wrapup

author: Alex D
title: but was terrified that this would become just another cash-in sequel like so many other franchises seem to do these days
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
When this was announced I was equal parts thrilled and terrified. I was thrilled and the idea of seeing what the Wizarding World had been up to since the epilogue of Deathly Hallows, but was terrified that this would become just another cash-in sequel like so many other franchises seem to do these days. I should have known better than to think Rowling would tarnish her creation by simply cashing in. What's been released is an exciting, well crafted extension of the original 7 novels that, in some ways, fixed some of the issues I had.

Without saying too much, I really loved this. It is not entirely perfect, but it is damn near close. The play format took a second to warm up to (I haven't read a play since college) but once I got up to speed, I felt like the format actually worked better than expected as it allows so much of the reader's own imagination to fill in the gaps that would otherwise be descriptions in a prose novel. Because of the play format, the pacing is a bit different than in previous stories, but again, it works quite well. The amount of story told between these covers is larger than I'd ever anticipated. And though the pacing maybe lend itself more towards theater, this is a Rowling story through and through. Do not worry that working with two other writers may have watered down the J.K.-ness of this tale. There is no question that this up to par.

I cannot wait for a full production of this to hit the States. With so much action, magic, heart, and visits from characters and locations both new and old, this is sure to be a hit.

author: Aaron
title: I am a big HP fan, and I loved this book
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
I am a big Harry Potter fan. I read all the books, seen all the movies, etc. When I started reading the reviews here, I was worried this book would have been a huge disappointment. Well, I just finished it and I loved it. Sure, it is not like one of the previous books written by JK Rowling, but it is a very nice, exciting and moving story with all the characters we love. I highly recommend it to all Harry Potter fans.

SPOILERS - SPOILERS

The authors of this book did a good job capturing some crucial moments in the Harry Potter history. I was moved when I read the part with Severus Snape, it was hard to read the final part where Harry has to witness his parents' death.
The only thing that drives me crazy, but this happens all the time with time-traveling stories, is that I kept on wondering why Harry and friends did not decide to just go back in time and kill or capture Voldemort when he is young. Wouldn't that be easy?

author: kelly wolfe gruber
title: No spoilers
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content: I'd like to say ahead of time that I was aware that this was gong to be in script format before I bought it. I'm also a huge Harry Potter fan, having read the entire series around 8 times, so I was very excited for this. This is a good read in general, but definitely doesn't stack up to the original series. The style is very different and the plot feels thrown together and not as meticulously planned out as the original series. The plot is reminiscent of fan fiction about the characters as opposed to a published work, and is at times outrageous. I felt that parts seemed out of character or not compliant with statements J. K. Rowling has made about this timeline. This being said, this book was enjoyable to read. I found moments poignant and humorous. I enjoyed Scorpius' character a lot. My advice would be to not expect this script to be as amazing as the series. Treat it as a separate work.

author: njwright
title: Love the books, like the play
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 9, 2017
content: The screenplay seems so rushed... I understand it can't be that long because the play follows it, but it needed more. The storyline is very interesting.

content: It is written like a play book so it might be hard for some at first. This book closes the Harry Potter series.  You aren't left wondering what might have happen as they grew older. The book takes the very last scene in the movie where their children are boarding the train. Now all the characters we read and watched are parents and their children are the new generation. I enjoyed every minute of it and this book has given the closure that I feel was needed.

author: kjohnson
title: Not the original HP books, but great overall!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: This is not the original Harry Potter books, but it was a great read. I enjoyed that we learned more about Harry and his life after Hogwarts. I also loved how we got to learn more about Draco and that Scorpius was not what I would have expected. I wish we could have gone more in depth with the characters like a typical HP book, but we have to remember that this is a play, not a novel. I really enjoyed it overall!

author: Chris Mc Hugh
title: Great Addition!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: Just like every other Potter fan I was thrilled when this was released. I reordered it for my kindle so t would be there first thin in the morning.It is written in a screen play format, so that's something new and it didn't bother me at all. The scenes to me felt rushed and I didn't realize how short the book was till I blinked and I was done. $14.99 for such a very short book is a bit extreme but being the Potterhead that I am I had to have it when it came out. But knowing now I should have waited for the price to drop some before purchasing. But over all it is a good addition to the rest of the Harry Potter books.

author: Sue Goodrich
title: Would have preferred a book to the play.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2016
content: Too many people have complained that this is written in the form of a play. For lovers of the series, it's a bit hard to adjust to the lack of detail, and the time jumps can be awkward. But it shouldn't have been a surprise to find the script between the covers. It's interesting to see how the children have adapted to the legacy of their parents. I'm glad J.K. decided to make the story available to those of us unable to attend the play in London. We can only hope for new books in the future.

date: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2016

author: RJ Guggemos II
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2016

author: drdannelly
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016

author: Janet J. Moreau
title: Back to Hogwarts.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2016
content: It is a little fast at first. It seems to go through many years in a short time. But it has a twist that you never expect. I feel very comfortable with the characters.

author: Keith Carter
title: Great Story, Good script.  BUT IT IS A SCRIPT. keep that in mind.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2016
content: As a play script this is quite well done.  I enjoyed the story and thought it was well thought out and developed and it had enough twists to keep it interesting.  It is however a script and not a novel.  For those not used to reading scripts I imagaine they would find this a challenging read.  Much is left for actor's, director's interpretation in terms of emotion of the actor.  It also uses stage notation which if one is not used to reading would make the story more difficult to follow.  In all it is a play I hope to see a production of at some point, or a movie.  As a high school drama coach my thoughs were often about how difficult this play would be to stage and how difficult the effects would be to produce on stage.  I understand the British production has done a very good job of bringing the story to life.  The scrip could also easily be addapted to be a movie, and in some ways would be better suited that a movie production.

author: s marberry
title: so I've been reading Potter books since I was 11 and was fortunate enough to kinda grow up with Harry because most ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: Okay, so I've been reading Potter books since I was 11 and was fortunate enough to kinda grow up with Harry because most years if there wasn't a new book out there was a movie. So, of course I was super stoked for this one. Without giving away any spoilers, I will say that it is a lot darker than I expected to the point that it became a bit of a slog around act 3. Also, keep in mind that it is a play script and not a novel so it does lack some of the richness of description as you would have in the books. I would not recommend this for someone who is not very familiar with the Potter universe simply because without the visuals or more descriptive language they would probably miss some of what is happening. It also reads a bit like fanfic, complete with a Mary Sue. That said, it was still an enjoyable trip down Nostalgia lane. All your favorite characters make appearances (even some you might not expect to see) and is worth adding to your collection if you love Harry Potter.

author: DAFKirby
title: Very good
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: The book surprised me several times and allowed me to relive some of my favorite reading memories I would love to see the play.

author: Sven A. Helms
title: Not for the one who cannot recall past books or lack imagination.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2016
content: Not horrible by any means.  It is a little hard to read and follow until one gets used to the format.  I think it would make a better book and I look forward to a movie.  Once I started getting into the story, it was over.  If you lack imagination or creating an mage in your mind about what is happening, you may not enjoy this book.  Very little character and scenery description, you will have to make it up or recall from other books as you go along.  Could have been so much more.  I get that it's a stage play and they want you to see the play, but could have provided more for the reader who will not have an opportunity to see the play.

author: Nick
title: Good read for all Harry Potter fans
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2017
content: Reading a play rather than a novel was a bit difficult, but overall it was an excellent story. A lot of other reviews complain about the quality of writing and the plot. You're certainly not getting the next Harry Potter book because it's not a book! You will however learn more about our beloved characters and their children.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: Haven't started yet.

author: DCJr
title: Satanic Witchcraft For Children
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2017
content:
Harry Potter returns (were they ever really going to let him disappear?) After the books and the movies, we now have the play. Next I expect there will be the pop karaoke album, the puppet show, and the interactive wizard work out DVD with bonus spells.

They're just not going to let this guy retire are they? 142 years from now they'll have an actual 'Harry Potter Flying Broomstick' and The World Quiditch Championships will replace the Olympics, though instead of holding it every four years, it will be held every four hours, except on Christmas Day when it will be take place every forty minutes – and that will be enforced by law.

So, is this any good? Well if you like bespectacled (or should it be, bespeckled? No, that means having spots. But then Harry Potter is a teenager, so he may have spots. 'Cause you get them at that age. But that has nothing to do with wearing glasses. Just like peaches have nothing to do with suspension bridges. Now where was I?) Oh, yeah if you like bespectacled nerds who are forever waving their symbolic phallus wand in people's faces, then you may get into this. If, on the other hand, you believe that Harry Potter has introduced children to the black arts of Beelzebub and has corrupted the whole world with his evil satanic witchcraft then you probably won't. Mind you if you believe that you probably also believe that aliens from outer space invented Chicken McNuggets, 9/11 was carried out by Santa's elves and Kim Jong-un should win the Nobel Peace Prize. There's also a nice padded room waiting for you at the local asylum.

So Harry Pot Plant fans will love this, but they love anything with his name on it. If Ted Bundy changed his name to Harry Potter he'd become loved and revered overnight.

Hey, there's an Idea. J.K. Rowling's next book should be 'Harry Potter and the Charismatic Serial Killer'. I bet it would still sell millions.

author: awesome sauce
title: Awesome Sauce!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: Great read! The only thing I would have changed was the style of writing. Wish it could've been a story format rather then a play.

author: Steven H.
title: Great Book - but don't pre-order

author: P. Thompson
title: Good But Expensive
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
First of all, this is a play. It's not going to read the same as the books. You're not going get any kind of fleshed out story. That fact did not prevent me from enjoying what I was reading. I did read it all in a single sitting. I do think the price is quite steep for no more than you're getting here.

Second, I could hear Ms. Rowling's voice the same as in the books so I'm pretty sure her hand was definitely in the plot. I could actually hear the familiar voices saying the lines and even without a lot of description of the scenes, I was able to see the action in my head. So kudos for that to whoever did write it.

I would, however, love to see more of Albus' earlier Hogwarts years. I felt they were not given the attention they should have been in order to get a better feel for his attitude about being the second son of the famous Harry Potter. Considering how little we do see of those early years, I have my doubts that seeing the play would be any more satisfactory.

Overall, I do think this is worth the read but definitely wait until you can borrow from the library. A $15 price tag is just ridiculous for no more than this is.

author: E. Mcc
title: Fun, but not the original.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2016

author: Patrice Fagnant-macarthur
title: Enjoyable if You Don't Expect the Magic of the 1st 7 Books
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
First of all this is play. I knew that going in. With children involved in acting, I have my fair share of experience reading scripts as I help them run lines. Still, it took some getting used to. Gone is J.K. Rowling's finely crafted prose. What is left is dialogue and a few brief descriptions. It requires much more use of imagination.

I honestly would love to see it performed. I could easily imagine it as a movie with a great deal of special effects. I have no idea how they could handle all of them on the stage (even given the huge budget they must be working with.) It's also hard to imagine anyone but Daniel Radcliffe in the role of Harry Potter. As I read the book, I pictured the actors from the original set of movies.

The story is not up to the standard of the first seven - it would have been a miracle if it could have been- but it was enjoyable. It picks up where Book 7 left off. In fact the first scene is actually the last scene of that book, with Harry and Ginny and their children at Platform 9 3/4 sending Albus off to Hogwarts.

One major story line focuses on the strained relationship between Harry and Albus. There is a great deal of time-turning going back to scenes from the original books and changing history in the process. It also allows now-deceased characters such as Cedric Diggory, Severus Snape, and even Voldemort to play a role.

Overall, this is an enjoyable story as long as you don't go into it thinking you are going to get a repeat of the magic of the first seven books.  There are some definite plot holes in the story and much of it is a reworking of things that already happened. But still, it was fun to reenter the world of Harry Potter and see what the future held for the characters.

author: K. Williams
title: A walk down Memory Lane
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2016
content: More like a short story.  I would have liked it better in regular prose versus the play format, but it filled a nostalgic "Potter-gap" by filling in the story line nearly 2 decades after the Battle of Hogwarts.  A pleasant walk down memory lane while getting to know the next generation!  I think it certainly left open the idea that Voldemort & his followers are not all eradicated, so perhaps Potter World will be returning.....

author: Bibliomaniac
title: Go In with a clear head and you won't be disappointed
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
After reading some of the negative reviews, I have to say that a lot of uninformed readers went into this story expecting a Harry Potter novel written in JK Rowling's previous style - i.e. same as the Harry Potter series. They forget that this is a script to a play that's supposed to be watched; the brilliance and emotion would come from how the actors enact it on stage with all the lighting, props, sets, costumes and action. This isn't a Harry Potter Eight book - that's the thing people should understand before even attempting to go into this. There will always be naysayers, but I for one am glad that I get to read the story, even though I may never get to watch the play. Imagine - if she didn't release this, you won't get to know the rest of the story if you couldn't afford flying out to London and buying theatre tickets - along with hotel stays and whatnot.

Now on to the story. I was so happy to revisit my favorite characters (naming them all might spoil the story). My heart ached with a nostalgic feeling when seeing Albus and Scorpius interact with people that were left behind. I think Rowling wrote this to put some of her regrets to rest, to say things that were left unsaid in the Harry Potter books. This book is a new story and closure (for some characters) all rolled into one. This is for those who loved Harry, Ron, Hermione and all the other brilliant people that Rowling brought to life.

I am glad of all the new things I learned about Harry and all his friends and foes. Yes, I am very very happy that I read it. 4 stars is because all the previous Harry Potter books were much longer and in depth, with a more defined storyline. For any true Potterhead, this is a must read though.

author: Jenn
title: I am a 4th grade reader and I love the Harry Potter series
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2016
content: I am a 4th grade reader and I love the Harry Potter series. Harry Potter's kids are so different from the seventh book. It gets better but it still is different from the rest.

author: Alohamora Open a Book
title: Characters aren't consistent with original series.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content:
I give Harry Potter and the Cursed Child  by J.K. Rowling (sure there is some dispute on how much she wrote) 4.5 out of 5 stars in my book review that I promise to not give any spoilers.  HP and the Cursed Child is an all around is a fun fast read for high school students and up.

I know there are a lot mixed review on this book, but I still say definitely give it a read.  Though, there are a few things that it is best to remember going into this book.  First, you have to remember that this book is a script. Scripts are different from your traditional novel.  To be honest, I forgot that at first.  The first 20 pages or so was a little frustrating b/c I wasn't getting the detail in the setting, characters, story development, etc.  However, after I remembered that little, but crucial, detail I really got immersed in the story.  I have always felt that it is too hard to compare the books to their movie counterparts.  They are different, and they each have different strengths.  I feel the same thing applies with a script to a novel.

There were several things that I really liked with HP and the Cursed Child.  I really liked reminiscing with the old characters.  I really liked seeing the story continue.  There are some awesome quotes/lines found in the story that I had to write down.  I'd love to share all of them with you, but I promised you no spoilers.  Therefore, I'll share just this one from Scorpius, Draco Malfoy's son. "I, uh, I opened a book.  Something which has- in all my years on this planet- never been a particularly dangerous activity." This quote makes my librarian book loving heart smile.  Even though Scorpius is not my favorite (I was never a Malfoy fan either), I LOVE this quote.

Now, it is true, and somewhat shocking that a Harry Potter book didn't earn a perfect 5 star rating.  Though, I've always been a tough grader and that doesn't change.  I'm not comparing the script to the other books b/c they are different (script vs. novel), but I am judging the book as part of the series and that is where it falters.

Since Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is a continuation of the story I was disappointed that the characters were not always consistent with who they were in the first 7 books.  Hermione was known for being clever in the original series, but I didn't think she was her consistent witty clever self in this book.  I felt there were inconsistencies with Ron and Harry's characters as well.  I don't want to give too much into why they were inconsistent b/c I don't want to spoil a single aspect of the story.  However, it is the inconsistencies with the characters that is the major reason for the less than perfect score.

I still thoroughly enjoyed reading the script book.  I found myself feeling many emotions in the reading.  I was incredibly happy. picking up the book, and concerned, worried, sad, curious, surprised, and more.

author: Amy Jesionowski
title: What did I think? WHAT DID I THINK??? It was another Harry Potter story: I freakin' loved it!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content:
What did I think? WHAT DID I THINK??? It was another Harry Potter story: I freakin' loved it! Bear with me, "I solemnly swear that I am up to no good." (Kidding, I'm going to do my best to make this vague and spoiler-free.)

If you loved the story so much, then, Amy, why only 4 stars?? It wasn't the fact that it was a script - within a page or two, it really was very easy to make the transition to reading it as a story (stage directions as description, being able to follow along with the dialogue and not hearing the speakers name before each line, etc.). A point on the sparse descriptors in the stage direction: because of its lack of in-depth descriptions, it challenges the reader to really use their imagination, and I found this wonderful (I understand, however, how those that are not like me, i.e., total Potterheads that devour everything HP and Pottermore related, may have had trouble with some of the act and scene segues). So, on to the explanation of the 4 stars and my reasoning behind it: the first, and probably the easiest, is that the dialogue did not always sound exactly like JKR's (this, I do find understandable, as it was written along with Jack Thorne and John Tiffany); second, the end felt a bit rushed (it can be argued that this plays into the urgency of their actions, but I think a bit more in the happenings department really could have enhanced it); and lastly, it BEGS a sequel as I felt there was a HUGE question, as well as a few minor ones, that need more resolution, but alas, I have heard that JKR is completely done with Harry Potter, so this may never happen. :(

In all, I highly recommend this book to any and everyone that loves the Harry Potter world. Really great fun!!!

"Mischief managed."

title: Read it for yourself
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2016
content: This is not a book. This is a play that's been bound like a book. This is not a story about The Boy Who Lived. This is a story about a lonely boy who's burdened by the shadows his names cast. There is a lot of beauty, and warmth, and growth contained in these pages. If you buy this, if you read this, read it in one fell swoop. Don't pick apart each scene. Be as steadfast as Snape, and as wise as Dumbledore, and see it for its whole and not its pieces.

author: Kathy Ludwig
title: Enough to satisfy curiosity
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: Fun and fast read.  I found this to be a fun story, however less believable at times than Rowling's first 7 books. This is probably due to the fact that there is much less detail in a script when compared to the original books. As a play I can see where they can fill in those details with talented acting and set props to make it very entertaining. This book reminds me more of an outline for a full story. I was hoping for more details about their lives over the past 19 years but not much was offered. Instead it really built upon the friendship of albus and scorpius and their complicated relationships with their fathers.  Overall a fun read and just enough of a peak into the current life of Harry Potter to satisfy curiosity. Would definitely recommend to harry potter fans. As for those who haven't read the books yet (maybe you have been hiding under a rock for the last 15 years) they are definitely worth reading before diving into this one because absolutely nothing will make sense to you if you have not read the books.

author: Emil Balic
title: Obviously not JK Rowling material but still a great read and a great adaptation for life after the original books.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: OBVIOUSLY its not going to be like the other Harry Potter books.. its not freking written by J.K Rowling. Get this fact through your head first before purchasing and expecting the same phenomenon we had with the books that were written by her. I was so intrigued to see how one of the outcomes could be for life for all the characters from Harrys life and how it turned out to be put into a play. Overall it was great. I had 0 complaints, the plot was cheeky, had unexpected turns, and its very nice and warming inside to see life after Harry and Hogwarts for all of our favorite characters. Especially reading about everyone's kids and how they are all to continue on to hogwarts and how they all cope and which adventures they run into. Ofcourse id love to see JK Rowlings actual Adaptation of life for all the characters after ther books but we all know that, that wont happen because it just isnt right. Nevertheless this was a nice distraction, a nice reminder why im so obsessed with the wizarding world of Harry Potter and it was a nice plot. Dealt with alot of feelings and it was certainly touching and very beliveable.

title: If you don't like plays, this is not for you. You have use your imagination here.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2016
content:
Huge HP fan. It is written as play, which has built in limitations. And the reviews posted so far seem not to understand those limitations.

The story line well plotted out and well written. The alt worlds and problems with time travel, well thought out.

Should JKR ever decide to expand the story into a filled out book, I have no doubt the reviews will be much better.

If you don't like plays, this is not for you. If you have an active imagination, you will enjoy the story.

author: elizabeth
title: this was really good..
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: I must admit, that I had reservations reading this book in the Play mode....I would much rather read novels.But, this was really good...no, it didn't take me back to Hogwarts, nor to Platform 9 3/4.....it took me to a little theatre, all glowing with gas lamps, seats in a semi-circle around the stage, and lots of mysical, magical happenings. Yes, it was different, more brash, more confronting and the characters now trying to cope with their own children, trying to keep them safe, just as Dumbledore and the Weasleys, Hagrid , etc had been doing for Harry, Ron Hermoine and yes, even Draco all those years ago....It got me in from the start, even though I thought Ron could have been a bit more aggressive, I thoroughly enjoyed the read, and read it in a couple of hours. I was satisfied with the ending, and I agree with J K Rowling that it is THE END. Thankyou, Harry, Hermione, Ron, and especially J K Rowling for the wonderful world you opened up for me, and millions of others .......

author: L. M. Bryski
title: Written as play, good plot and characters
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: Written in play format, this novel is enjoyable but not as filling as previous J. K. Rowling works. As a play format, the focus is on characterization and plot as told mainly through dialogue. In that manner, the book succeeds in being entertaining and engaging. The plot is well-thought out. The 'fan service' is well taken care of with references to previous events and even involving previous novel characters within the plot. I wouldn't mind rereading this as a full novel, however, as a lot of the attraction of the Harry Potter series is the multilayered characters and environment descriptions. Still, the bare bones feeling of this play does deliver by keeping interest in the story.

author: C. Liang
title: It's a screen play.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 18, 2016
content:
I don't know Jack Thorne's work, so I can't say if this is how he presents his plays. I don't know how much of a hand or say Rowling had in this production and the screen writing.

I understand the frustration with this novel and the plausibility of many things and how it all connects together with the 8 novels.

First, don't read this as a regular piece of literature. This is a screen play. These are scripts, lines for the players, so I read it as so. Scripts can't be read the same as literature. Example: look at how many times Hamlet had been remade and portrayed differently each time. One line can be repeated several ways and the effect will be different each time.

Second, time has passed. Harry and everyone are no longer teens. They are adults, parents who have kids, and they are working. So yes, I expected them to change in some way. Did I expect Harry to be a good parent? No, he never had stability in his life. And I think they tried to show that in his parenting skills or lack of.

Third, This is the Magical world. And right when we think we know the world, another thing pops up and suddenly we question it and try to see how it fits into the magical world. Yes, poly juice potion takes a while to make, but this is a screen play! Think of it like a movie? The protagonist will some how have the key/answer/solution and they somehow have what they need to make everything right again. So yea, this screenplay does fit into the cliches of movies.

And seriously? Humiliation to an extent could change Diggory. But becoming a Death Eater? Sure, we just don't know how bad the humiliation was to him and the effects of it to know how he became one. There are several gaps in this play because of the ever changing universes, and it seems we have to fill in those gaps and attempt to understand how a character changed. Isn't that part of screen plays?

But really though, Delphi's parents? I'm still trying to manage that. Although, her name did give away her role as an oracle/prophecy from the beginning... And we know that's bad news.

author: Virginia sypulski
title: Satisfactoryread

author: A Trashbag

content: Now, I am a huge Harry Potter fan, but It didn't feel like they were the same characters at all. The book was good, but thinking about the characters I couldn't think of them as teens. This book was good and I definitely recommend it . Sorry this review was short, I  broke my writing arm and it's hard to write.

author: Nathan Hopson
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2016
content: Part one felt like a fan fic but then part two made everything great

author: HappyCoder
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2016
content: Great book

author: Kolien Owens
title: It's Great in it's Own Way.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2017
content: I bought this book when it first came out, but then never read it because of the mixed (bad) reviews. Maybe it was because I came in with such low expectations or maybe it was just because it's a great story, but I loved it. Yes, it's different from the original books. It's more character and dialogue driven, it is a script afterall, and because it's a script we miss out on some of the details that help really bring a story to life.  Also, it's a little more mature, Harry and the gang are forty now and some of the jokes kids won't relate to. But I don't think this story is really for children. Many of us grew up with Harry Potter, but now we're adults. This book deals heavily in relationships, mainly between fathers and sons and I think it did a great job. I know that many people were mad with how Harry acts towards Albus, but if there is one thing this book teaches us is learning that those you love aren't perfect. Though this book differs from the first seven it still has the components that made those seven great; adventure, heart and friendship. Also guys, it has time travel. Let me repeat, time- butterfly effect- travel. Which helps to tie it back into the world of the first seven books. The while time I was readibg it I thought; I can't wait to see how they do this on stage.

Still, I loved seeing old friends.

author: justme
title: Enjoyable, despite some mixed feelings -- Spoilers
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
I had really mixed feelings about pre-ordering--and even reading--this item.  I don't particularly care for reading plays, if I did, I would have read far more classical literature.  I was also concerned because I thought this might change the way I view the other items of the Harry Potter canon. With some trepidation, I finally pre-ordered yesterday and scarfed down the story today because I wanted to dig in before spoilers start boiling out.  The jury is probably still out on whether we'll see a movie adaptation of the play, so... Dig in, I did...

To be honest, yes, I do have some mixed feelings.  The confrontation between Albus and Harry broke my heart a little.  After everything Harry has been through, Harry after all should know that others' words and actions do sometimes leave hurts and ripples...  But, Harry is, of course, frustrated and let the heat of the moment get the better of him--he's only human.  It makes sense to me though, that the survivors of the wizarding wars' offspring would struggle a bit to find their own identities, especially the offspring of some of the younger, more notable characters' offspring.  Notoriety casts a long, warped shadow and humans (whether muggle or magical) are often cruel.  I so think these scripts do shift long-held character building a bit in places, but one does have to remember the adults lived through a war and a significant amount of time has passed since the first seven books.

I did really like some things in these scripts. I really liked Scorpius.  I thought it was wonderful that Albus and Scorpius were portrayed as not being afraid to show--and (gasp!) even talk a little about the fact that they really cared about each other and their friendship really meant something to both of them.  In mass media, it's so rare to find stories where young men express platonic friendship and emotions that go along with it. There are also a few telling scenes with Draco Malfoy that I really liked here.  Particularly where he says he always envied Harry's friendship with Ron and Hermione (I think any reader with a functioning brain realized that he was always jealous of the quality of friendship(s) between Harry, Ron, and Hermione) and that it can be very lonely being Draco Malfoy.  And where he tells Harry that Scorpius is all that he has now and is genuinely worried for his son.  Yes, in the past, Malfoy was more than just a misunderstood bad boy; he was a downright dangerous prat in a lot of ways in the original books (but he was also a product of his damaged up-bringing having been raised by fundamentalists).  Let's face it, though, Draco could have just taken off and gone after Scorpius on his own son, had he wanted, and maybe not changed at least a little over there years.  While I don't really know that I hold to the stance that he "owed" Harry a "debt" of any sort after the events in _The Deathly Hallows_, I think this definitely shows that Draco has changed a little over the years (whether thanks to experience, Astoria's influence, or so on, we will probably never know).  If Draco had been more like Lucius or the young, arrogant Draco we first begin to know from the original books, he probably would have just tried to save his son (and only his own son).  I also liked the wee peek of Snape that readers get in one of the timelines.  In the end, I think Albus and Harry are on their way to reconciling and I think that's okay.  It shows that not all relationships do--or should--come easily.

I'll admit that at first, I was a bit put out at the time-turners' role in kicking off the bigger events.  Time travel stories are always a bit tricky, I think, because people either seem to love or hate them.  It does make sense to me that post-war certain elements of wizarding society might seek out people to make new time-turners since the known ones were destroyed an the battle at the Ministry (_The Order of the Phoenix_).  Disregarding potential wrong-do-ers, especially amongst the collectors of artifacts, I can see the post-war appeal of the time-turner.  I also think it was a shame we didn't at least get a peek at Astoria and Draco's interactions, because she sounds interesting.  Between the advice she gave Scorpius about sweets and making friends, and Draco's (brief) reminiscence, it seems a bit of a loss (even though this wasn't the Malfoys' story).  I can see where some Cedric Diggory fans' noses are going to get (at least) briefly put out of joint, but... Well, I kind of feel like readers never got to meet Cedric to a great extent before he died in _The Goblet of Fire_.  While it's profoundly sad that a seemingly mostly-kind, thoughtful boy died so needlessly (as a "spare"), it's not like readers had known him well from book one all the way to book four (_The Goblet of Fire_).  In the end, though, I think this volume honors the "fallen" characters of the original books well.  War leaves marks in many ways.

Overall, reading this was time well-spent.  I do wish it had either been a bit longer at least taken me a bit longer to read, considering the $15 cost of the e-book... But, I'll live... LOL I'm glad I read it myself before media coverage and reviews could sway my thinking more (not that I always give such things much weight).

author: Shedwreck
title: Great
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2017
content: Great book. Huge fan of the Harry Potter series. Anyone that is this is a must own. Written like a play so its a different read just a heads up. Definitely worth the money. Don't miss out on this book go get it.

author: Charlee
title: Keep an open mind
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
The story of Harry Potter continues nineteen years later with his son Albus. Being Harry Potter is difficult enough, but being the son of the legendary wizard proves to be harder. Through this story, both Harry and his son learn that no one is perfect and that darkness never completely goes away. It can live in each of us.

This is the latest installment and sadly sounds like the last. I ordered it without hesitation and immediately started in on it, never setting it down. Finishing it within just a few hours, I was disappointed when it ended. Not because of the way it ended, but because the story was over. The whole story. Harry Potter was the series that got my daughter into reading. It's a series that I have read myself more than once....something I never do with a book no matter how good it is. I know there were a lot of people that were unhappy with it, but I wasn't one of them. Too many people I think were expecting another Harry Potter novel. It's not. You need to go in with an open mind and keep your expectations to a minimum. Was it perfect? No. Did it sometimes leave more questions than answers? Yes. But I enjoyed it anyway.

Even though this installment is in script form, it was just as enchanting as the others and managed to carry me away to another world. I'm not going to go into details about the story itself because I don't want to give anything away, but I was not the least bit disappointed. I can honestly say that if this is the end, I'm going to miss Harry and his friends and family. It's been a fun ride and one I wouldn't have missed for the world. Thank you J.K. Rowling, for giving us one final go around. It was worth the wait.

author: Shell
title: ... to be able to read a play to really like this story
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 22, 2016
content: You have to be able to read a play to really like this story. Because it's a screenplay, it's in script format and it has more jarring and sudden changes than a novel or movie. If you're comfortable with this style, it's a good story. It doesn't have the depth or complexity of a book or movie, it's very linear and has a single story line with only one or two very short side threads. A lot of people who I've heard complaints from sounded like they were judging this as the 8th Harry Potter novel rather than a screen play. It isn't. It's still a fun read though!

author: Luvtoo Reed
title: Surprisingly engaging
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2016

author: Amanda Grimm
title: Overall, a great Book....
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content:
I’ve loved Harry Potter since I was a child, when the first book came out. I was a bit disappointed when I heard another book was coming out, for two reasons. One, because, I’m like ‘what could it be about? It had such a closing ending with the Dark Lord defeated.’ And the other reason was because it wasn’t in normal story form, but in the form of a play. And not everyone can understand what was going on. So, when I was given the book as a present, I was a bit hesitant about it. However, I was surprised on how well the book was. True, it was a bit off putting, how the book was written, like I figured it would be. However, I was able to catch onto what was happening rather quickly.

One issue I had with it, was that it was moving so fast. The other Harry Potter books only had everything happen in one year, but this book had quite a few years passing. I did like how Albus was a very ‘real’ character that everyone could relate to. He understood that he wasn’t going to be the perfect child, and he had siblings that he felt different from. His father was this famous person, and everyone in his family but him was put into the same house.

Overall, this book was good. I laughed, I cried, and I also wanted to throw the book across the room. I felt that Delphi was a bad character, but I didn’t expect her to be Voldemort's daughter. That one threw me for a huge loop! And I did like how Harry was able to travel back to his infanthood, and help Albus when it was needed.

author: Stephanie Parsons
title: Good add to the collection
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2016
content: It was a good read. It did seem more like fan art however, it was a delightful read

author: Grodd

content: Good fun with genre mash-ups, a poignant refreshing of established cast along with a clever generational leap for the wizarding world. Recommended to any Potter fan who if won't mind reading a script instead of a novel.

author: Adam

date: Reviewed in the United States on September 26, 2016
content: Not the best of the series by far, but still quite good.  I thoroughly enjoyed it.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not true HP, but decent enough...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
It's been nine years since "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows" came out. Nine years since my favorite book of all time came to an end. So the announcement of an eighth Harry Potter story seemed too good to be true. And finally, "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" is here. It only took a day to read--partially because the play-format makes for a quick read, and partially due to my fevered excitement to see what the epic trio of Harry, Ron, and Hermione were up to now that Hogwarts is so many years behind them.

Without giving away too much of the plot, "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" finds an adult Harry struggling to bond with his teenaged middle child, the most troubled of his three children, Albus Severus Potter. In turn, Albus struggles with living in his famous father's footsteps, as well as dealing with the complications surrounding his relationship with Scorpious Malfoy, the son of Harry's former school tormentor, Draco Malfoy. Most notably, however, is Albus' struggle to process the consequences some of Harry's school-day actions, and wondering if there is anything he can do to make up for his father's deeds. Though Harry and Albus at times seem as different as day and night, both are plagued with the unrelenting desire to "right" the "wrongs" they perceive, even if fate often has other things in store.

While the magic of the original seven books is somewhat lacking due to the story not being in the prose format that we Harry Potter fans are accustomed to, it was still a pretty good story. The overall theme is something that has been done plenty of times before, but seeing beloved characters work their way through it creates a feeling of nostalgia for the original HP tales. Also, much like the HP movies tended to pale in comparison to the rich stories created in the books--reading this, I got the impression that it paled in comparison to what the stage production must be like. I feel like the story likely resonates a lot more effectively in the format it is meant to be experienced in, and can only hope the play is taken "on tour" in the U.S. one day.

"Cursed Child" doesn't quite go as deep and dark as some of the later Potter books, and overall, this story feels a lot more light-hearted, and even fan fiction-like at times. Regardless, it is still full of surprising revelations, despite some being easy to see coming. This book probably isn't the epic return of Harry Potter that fans have been waiting for, but it does satisfy the desire to return to Hogwarts one more time, and to get a "check-in" on the characters we grew to love so much during the Potter era.

So while this story does not live up to the seven Potter books before it, I think it is enough to put a smile on the face of true HP fans.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2016
content: A good story, well written, and a quick read.

author: D. Price
title: This story is FUN and not as CURSED as it has been made out to be....
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 14, 2016
content: I read ALL of the reviews about this story, negative-neutral-positive. I think some may have read TOO much into this. Agree...this reads like fan fiction. That's not entirely a bad thing. The best part is...it's JK Rowling ENDORSED fan fiction. It is a story that, in my opinion, is not really needed, but didn't hurt anything in the franchise. I feel that way about Fantastic Beasts. The original book was a reference tool for the original stories. Now we have a screenplay and movie created out of that is thinly connected to Harry Potter using history. These stories are just fun. There are preposterous situations, characters and scenarios that are a HUGE stretch...but that's okay. I have my seven books that I get to re-invest in as often as I want. HPATCC is/was a quick read and a, kinda, nice "Where are they Now" story. The best part is...one them stayed from the original series...and that is the value of loyal, loving FRIENDSHIP. In the original 7, Fantastic Beasts screenplay and this story...it is universal throughout. In my book...that IS the best thing out of all of it. It is also why I gave it 4 stars. Lastly...there were comments about what Harry would/would not do. I would suggest re-reading "Order of the Phoenix"... Harry was quite different in that book that "Cursed Child" had a deja vu feel to it...

author: doc pat
title: Love anything Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2016
content: The script was good and an interesting story. I did miss all the details of the earlier novels. Am sure the play fleshes out all the details. Do hope to see it someday.

author: LW
title: A little like fan-fiction...but still intriguing!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 15, 2016
content:
I have to admit, I'm a Harry Potter nerd, but I'm not so obsessed that I turned my nose up at the idea of a play-turned-eighth-book kind of nerd. I was really excited to read this one!

Well, I was a little disappointed. It read like more of a fan-fiction novel than the original Harry Potter books, and I found it to be a little over the top in regards to its occasional cheesiness. Sometimes the dialogue of the characters didn't seem to fit the personality of the characters from the previous novels. In my opinion, the whole thing seemed a little bit rushed and forced.

However, because I'm still a huge Harry Potter fan, I still had to give it 4 stars due to my pure excitement about there even BEING an eighth book. I will admit there were some twists and turns in this book that made it pretty interesting.

author: Ashly
title: Not written by Rowling, but still enjoyable
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2016
content:
I think an important thing to remember about this is that it's a play script, not a book. I would love to see the play at some point, but unless they travel to a city near me, this is the closest I'm going to get. J.K. Rowling did not write this, it's based off a short story she may (?) have written by herself or with the play author, not totally clear on that one.

On to the review: I enjoyed this. I didn't LOVE it, like the originals, but I enjoyed getting a glimpse into the adult lives of HP characters. It's been awhile since I've read the books, so I could be wrong on this, but some of the characters seemed a bit off to me (probably due to them being written by a different person). That was really the only thing that bugged me. But, this has renewed my desire to make time to reread the series this year.

author: C. W.
title: Probably most enjoyable in person
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
After finishing the screenplay so quickly, I figured I'd leave a review (especially after seeing all of the scathing hate notes people have left for it, sheesh). For me, it's hard to say how I feel about it, only that I don't think it's that bad. Like some have mentioned, it does have a bit of that HP spark from the books, though it's hard to feel engrossed in the world from a screenplay. I mean, think about A Very Potter Musical: Would it have been nearly as funny or as popular without being able to watch the live performances? I bet a lot of the comedy and even the heartwarming moments would fall flat if it had been only released as a screenplay. Bless Starkid for posting it for free on YouTube. Based on what I imagined from the stage directions and what descriptions were provided, I'll bet it would be really powerful to see live, with all of the acting and special effects, and I hope the show is successful enough to go on tour.

Note: Spoilers to follow, so continue reading at your own risk.
Again, SPOILERS BELOW.

---

What I said above doesn't excuse the problems with plot/characterization that I can't imagine feeling great about even with a live performance. So off goes a star because I can't reasonably give this 5 stars if I don't feel it's as amazing as 5 stars, you know? Certain screenplays deserve that; not this one.

So, I'll start with what I liked about reading it:
- Scorpius! Scorpius was lovely; he's my new favorite character and the source of some of my favorite lines/scenes. I hope his actor pulled them off as well as (or better than) I "saw" them in my head. I will go to my grave believing he's part of the LGBT community and no one can convince me otherwise. I love how horrified he was at the prospect that people thought he hated doing homework and reading books.
- Albus as a Slytherin: I need more positive Slytherin characters. Thank goodness we now have at least two more.
- Albus and Scorpius's friendship
- Draco's change of heart and the obvious love he has for his family; I've always admired that about the Malfoys and I'm glad it was touched upon here.
- The ambiance created by certain scenes, such as the Dementors and so on. I really wish I could see how these worked in person.
- Hermione's roles of power: She's still got it. Attawitch! Also her rebellious Alternate Universe.
- Athlete!Rose, though I wish we'd been able to see more of her/have more development of her personality. I kind of wanted her to team up with her cousin, but whatever. I like that she's into Quidditch and isn't all about books, which sets her apart from her mother.
- Dumbledore chiding Harry for Albus's name: Oh, the meta.
- Snape, Snape, Severus Snape
- Everything to do with the blanket tugged at the heartstrings (I only mind a little what had to happen to it in order to make the plot work.)
- The adult relationships (mostly): Harry and Ginny, Draco and Astoria, Ron and Hermione
- The Hagrid scene

What I disliked/felt uncomfortable with/was confused by:
- We have a time travel plot (oh the problems with time travel plots I can rant about) and we use it on Cedric? You know, I feel bad for him and all, but I would think Albus would feel more strongly about maybe Teddy Lupin's parents? Or Fred? I mean, I disagree with him trying to save anyone, but I'd understand him trying to do it for them. Why use it on Cedric when the fourth book is so much more effective as is (which this play spent the whole time establishing?).
- Bellamort is canon. Wut. So much DO NOT WANT with that visual. I guess in a way it makes sense, but I kind of hoped the Cursed Child would have more of a complex arc than a typical "I'm evil because of my Fatherlord" shtick. (Didn't Draco or his family notice Bella was pregnant during the books? Seems like a really obvious thing that would be hard for her to hide.) I liked Delphie as a character better when she seemed interested in saving a life. Though I thought the twist at the end made it a little better. I felt horrible for Harry sticking through all of it; our poor hero has had enough trauma, don't you think?
- Harry wanted to end a friendship on really stupid assumptions that I thought he'd resolved by the end of the Battle of Hogwarts. What the hell, Harry's characterization. Does he not remember Snape and Lily's friendship? At least nearly every other character called him out on it.
- Oh yeah, we're casually having a Blood Ball for Voldemort Day with Muggleborn screams emanating from the dungeons.
- I wanted to know more about Craig Jr. RIP dude, we barely knew ya.
- I don't buy the bit about Parseltongue at all. I wish it hadn't been necessary for the plot because the books tied that loose end up so neatly and it feels all unraveled again.
- You refer to Neville and never show him (or his family) once? Boo.
- The Trolley Lady, holy hell
- I wouldn't have minded Ron being a bit more serious, since he seemed more like comedy relief from his dialogue/mannerisms.
- Um, I'm not the only one who was stuck with feeling like Albus/Ron kissing and flirting with Hermione was both hilarious and incredibly weird, right? I'm not mad about it, just incredibly uncomfortable. Again with the whole Albus and Delphie thing, too.

But yeah, I did feel a bit of the Harry Potter magic come back while I read it, and for that I don't regret reading it. It's got a flawed plot and I don't agree with how they portrayed all of the characters, but it was entertaining enough for a few hours. I can't really trash it when there's so much missing when you haven't seen it live.

author: LukasM
title: A hope for further books in the furture
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Well, I just finished the script-writing and I should better wait some time to write an impartial review free from emotions and such.
But due to so many others ignoring it, I join the majority.

As for the most here I am also a huge Potter-maniac, reading the books over and over again, and new stuff is always a big deal for us.
I assume most negative-rated comments are led by too big expectations according to this short story.
Whats more, I don't want to SPOIL many things, so I try to focus on the main plot: the time travelling.
Yeah, that's worth discussing it. I have to admit it's somehow not the best inventive approach for bookwriters, especially for Harry Potter franchise, which thousands of fanfictions are covered with hypothetic mindgames based on time travelling.
Then, bringing back the ultimative evil in form of Voldemort's (one SPOILER more) unknown daughter, wasn't necessary at all.

But hell, that are the only things I really can complain about. After 9 years of waiting for new stuff I am very pleased with this little e-book.
I was aware all the time that The Cursed Child would never be as good as the book series. Never. Thus my expectation was very low, and that's why I am very happy now since it's doubtless no bad creation considering it is in fact a theatre play.

So I would suggest frustrated fans to calm down a bit and then think about it again later.
As for me, I'm looking forward to new books in the future, real books which can't be read in several hours.
Having in mind, that time travelling is gone as a plot from now on is a great thing to hope for future projects.

author: Jeanie G
title: Still Great writing no matter what format!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2016
content:
4.5 stars.  "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child". (Parts One and Two). Rehearsal Edition

Being a skeptic about sequels I ordered this book mainly because I am a closet Harry Potter "groupie".  Yes, I read the books in my 50's and have "Pottermore" on my computer favorites!

Besides being a "sequel" the book is presented in script form, written as a read through and directive for scene settings of a play.  How can any of those things compare to the addicting words and characters of J.K. Rowling?

Well, it hit the mark for my unquenchable thirst for continuing the saga of Hogworts and it's favored alumni.  I felt an immediate connection to Harry's, Hermione's and Draco Malfoy's children.  The story of Albus and Scorpius had a more contemporary feel but I loved the fact that the old favorites were included and given some closure.  It took no more than a chapter to adjust to the literary structure and from there my mind assimilated the words easily and went into picture mode.  I loved the story and the characters and felt a seamless continuation of the original series.

My only lingering thought is:  "How will this go over as a live stage presentation?"  A movie?  Sure.  But a live stage may be a difficult venue to keep the drama and electric charge alive without the special effects.  Although I will be in line for a ticket if it comes to a venue near me!

You immediately see Rowling's engaging writing and development of the new characters.  I am sure Thorne and Tiffany made the way easy for adaptation to play format.  Their biographies show their success in that venue.  All should be proud of this addition to the Potter family of books!  HP fans...definitely pick this up!

￼

The characters Al, Scorpius, Rose deserved a book and the plot, especially of the children and their time at Hogwarts deserved to be a well thought out and written book.  J.K. Rowling owes us a book.  I also liked reading about Harry, Ron and Hermoine as grown ups and their alter universe as well.  Draco too.

title: A great story
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
I had wondered why so many people are disappointed in this play precisely because it is a play. I mean it was always going to be a play, but then I thought, who can blame anyone with the ridiculous promotion that encourages it. Even here on Goodreads it's described as Harry Potter 8!!!!

Plays are a lot different to read than books. Minimal description and often little direction. Shakespeare, it seems only managed one memorable one, "Exit, pursued by bear", but this actually reads really easily and well and at the end I really felt like I'd read a new chapter, even though it's in this form and would clearly be better seen on stage.

I look forward to seeing this in 2034 when it comes to Australia😀

author: Amazon Customer
title: A very good script - can't wait to see the play
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
Warning: This is not a novel.  It is not another fully fleshed out volume from J.K. It is a rehearsal script for a stage play.

Reading it can be difficult, although I quickly adapted and was able to immerse myself into the story.  Yes, the action moves very quickly and relies heavily on familiarity with the series for comprehension. There are a few plot holes that will enable die-hard PotterHeads to nitpick ad-nauseum, but overall the narrative stands as an acceptable addition to the series.  I won't harp on the shortcomings because they are far outweighed by the good exemplified by the relationship development between fathers, sons, and friends.  Harry and Draco find commonality as loving fathers that are having relationship difficulties with their sons who are best friends.  As stated, I can't wait to see this on stage.

However - If you're reading it to read a really well-written, interesting story about a world you care deeply for......you will get that. I absolutely loved it! There was a more grown-up, philosophical feeling to this book than there was to the HP books, which I liked better than the HP books, but that's because that kind of thing really appeals to me. author: Raman
title: Love you amazon
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
Been waiting forever for this, and it finally arrived!!! Love you amazon!

I just finished reading it, and it's really good, though I can't see it as the "official eighth book". For me, it's a really well written fanfiction. I can tell JK Rowling was not responsible for the actual writing, because at times the characters are a bit ott and not quite canon. They don't always sound like the Harry, Ron, and Hermione from the book. And Draco Malfoy is far too cheerful and friendly with the trio (even calling them by their first names). Professional McGonagall is also way out of character. The ending was kind of rushed and also too good to be true (everything fell into place all at once), but otherwise it was a cute, funny and heartwarming read. Like I said, it's a really well written fanficition, but definitely not the eighth Harry Potter book!

I would recommend this to any Harry Potter fan, but don't read it with too many expectations! The storyline is definitely not as complex as the Harry Potter series, but if you're looking for a light, enjoyable read to pass time, then you'll like it.

author: Natasha Dunn
title: It was a good book, but short
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2016
content: It was a good book, but short. It was nice to know how the adult lives of the original characters turned out without getting too invested in the new characters of the children.

author: Alex
title: Nothing Wrong With It
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
I'm 25 and have been reading the books since they came out. I think, looking at the negative reviews on here, that people are failing to look at this as it's own separate entity. And I hate to break it to you, but humans do in fact CHANGE as they age. Everyone is saying "Harry would NEVER do this. Ron would NEVER do this. etc etc". First off, it's two decades down the road. Harry could've reasonably turned into a violent alcoholic with a foot fetish. It happens. That's life. Also, this IS NOT a Harry Potter book. It's a script based off of a play that was the product of three different people. Also, it's a script. It will NOT read the same "intricate" way as a book nor will it have the same feel.

As a stand alone story, I enjoyed it. Harry and the other characters are essentially just grappling with the normal things middle aged people do, just with a magical twist. There's a humanizing aspect to it. And while I absolutely loathed Albus as a character, I still enjoyed it. It was overpriced, definitely. But if I think of it just as a Harry Potter side piece, it's enjoyable and a good read. But no, it's not another installment in the series. And I'm honestly baffled at how many people seemed to miss that memo, even after Rowling herself stated it pre-release. Regardless, it's enjoyable unless you're a Harry Potter snob and have absurd expectations. 3.5/5

author: T Turner
title: Pretend it's a fan fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
Spoilers ahead.  Pretend this is a fan fiction and you won't be disappointed.

I loved learning about Album,  Scorpius, Draco,  the relationship between Harry and others, and the touching sentiments before imminent death; I adored those aspects. For that alone I enjoyed this script.
The reason I say pretend it's afan fiction is because I'm sorry JK  Rowlings but you wrote such a tight series to start with that people know your characters as well as you.  Voldemort quite simply would not have a child.  He wouldn't.  He didn't love and obviously sex can occur without love but he didn't want an equal.  There is no way he'd have risked a child. Throughout his entire life needed to be the only special one. The only heir of Slytherin.  He killed his father for crying out loud. Family meant nothing to him. Power,  for himself alone,  and self sufficiency was all he cared about. He was not getting freaky with Bellatrix. Nooope,  he'd have created another horcrux first.  Then there is the issue of time turners, say one did survive,  it's sort of a lame way out.  This isn't Back to the Future and no one wants it to be. I'd have preferred this to be some sort of what if dream/spell than actual time travel.  I get that I'm an adult reading about a faux magical world but I guess time trave of this magnitude is just a bit much for me. That's why it feels fan fiction.

But again going back to the characters was awesome.  Ron,  always my favorite, remained my favorite.  Draco was perfect.  Great to hear their voices again. Take it with a grain of salt and enjoy hanging out with the characters we grew up with.

author: S. Tiss
title: A quick and satisfying read.

content: This is a script, not a novel or even a novella, and should be treated as such.  For those who have never read a script before, that could present a bit of a challenge.  The story is in the dialogue and not all the other elements (from simple to detailed) that a story on a page may include.  A glimpse into the set and the staging help bring things to life if you have some theater or scipt reading experience, but may be distracting if you don't.  With that caviet, I did find the tale quite enjoyable.  The voices of the characters, both known and new, rang true to me and the story itself felt like it belonged in the world of Harry Potter.

The plot is a bit cliché, but I was just happy that I got to read more about the characters that I grew up with. Shouldn't you be happy about it to?
