author: MacDhai
title: It is what it is...a play, an epilogue to the HP books, and an interesting character study
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
Sure, I would have preferred this be a full fledged novel.  And I'd love to see it made into a movie (or two) someday so that it could be fleshed out more.  But at the end of the day, JK Rowling wasn't looking to launch a next generation series, and the entire project was conceived start to finish as a play.  And as a play, it actually works very well.

I have been fortunate over the years to see many stage productions, and reading some of the negative reviews, many of them feel like either the reviewer is not as familiar with how plays differ from books and movies, or they just didn't want it done as a play in the first place.  A script for a play is really only a piece of the finished production, so in order to appreciate HPCC, it's important to visualize the actors, costumes, sets, lighting, the orchestra...in other words, visualize a play.  It's not a movie, it's not a novel, and this script never will be without an adaptation and expansion.  Plays do move through time at a rate that feels different, they do throw brief vignettes at you to get you between the bigger scenes.  It's just the nature of the medium, so criticisms like that are more to do with plays in general.

As far as the story goes, I don't disagree that it's less meaty and complex than the HP books.  I don't disagree that recycling material from the books is not as good as a full "next generation" novel fleshed out with it's own stories and feel would have been.  Which is why I agree with some reviewers who call this an epilogue, an extension of the last chapter of HPDH.  So what's the point of this play?  What is it's raison d'etre?  In a word, the characters.

Once you accept this work as a play and an epilogue, it becomes a vehicle to see what life after Voldemort looks like for these characters and how they are all affected by what came before.  And in that sense, it does have the complexity that some claim is missing...but it's a complexity of characters and relationships rather than a complexity of story.

SPOILERS--READ NO FURTHER IF YOU HAVE NOT READ THE BOOK/SCRIPT.

There are some great elements in this play.  Albus getting sorted into Slytherin, Scorpius and Albus becoming best friends, just about every word Scorpius says, and the strained relationship between Harry and his son.  Now, a very frequent criticism I've seen is that "Harry Potter would never say he wished Albus wasn't his son!  He'd never sacrifice time with his family for work!"  And yet, these are the same struggles that every parent faces, so those moments actually made the story feel more real and relatable.  Watching Harry try to have a reasonable discussion with Albus, only to lose his temper and say something he regrets when Albus pushes his buttons...that happens to good parents, and it's not like Harry doesn't have a history of losing his temper!  But his moral center immediately brings the realization of his mistake and the attempt to fix it.  That's the whole point of this play.  It's not happily ever after...it's life, and life is messy, and Harry is not infallible (and he never has been, which is what makes him interesting).

Slytherin is still Slytherin.  Some critics seem to think the events of HPDH would have redeemed the house, but the reality is that the noble acts of some house members just aren't enough for the world in general to automatically embrace the house that produced every Death Eater.  In truth, the real criticism should be at the books for having so few non-Slytherin baddies (Peter Pettigrew notwithstanding).  It would be nice to live in a more forgiving world, but sadly, this aspect is also realistic, and as long as Slytherins are expected to act like Death Eaters, they will likely live up to their reputation.

The Cedric situation does suffer from not having enough of an opportunity to breathe. If the source of the prophecy was covered, if it was better established as the reason these events are unfolding in the first place, it would have felt better...but again, play vs. book.  But Cedric turning bad isn't as crazy a stretch as some might think.  Someone once said to me, "I don't think you can truly hate unless you've loved."  Yes, Cedric is honorable...and popular and handsome and universally loved.  So take all that away from him and is it so hard to imagine a slow spiral into darkness?  People never want to believe this can happen, and are always surprised when it does.

A weak point that would benefit from a meatier adaptation is how Delphi engages Albus in her plot.  It comes across as lucky coincidence instead of an expertly manipulated series of events.  But it wouldn't take too much to fix this for a movie adaptation.

Finally, there's the widespread disappointment that Albus and Scorpius aren't gay.  If anything, the trend of inserting gay characters into every franchise lately has started to feel like token attempts to seem progressive in many cases.  The fact that a character is heterosexual shouldn't be any more relevant than being homosexual.  They're just people.  But, if it makes everyone feel better, maybe they're both bisexual and afraid of ruining their friendship by changing its nature...and it just happened to be a girl that is Scorpius's second choice.

So yes, time turners and tournaments and prophecies and offspring of villains aren't the most inventive or original story mechanisms that could have been explored.  And yes, reading a play will always be less satisfying than reading a book or seeing a movie or seeing the fully produced play performed.  But taken for what this is (a character study rooted in real life relationship challenges set as an epilogue to a beloved series of books), Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is what it is...and that's not a bad thing.

Rowland's vision of what things were like later in their lives, the maturing of the characters, and the exploration of how things could have been if other choices had been made. Advice for new readers: stick with the book until the end.

author: Alexis B. Cano
title: I eagerly suck up any additional stories or writings I can from ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2016
content:
I feel I must start this review by saying that I am a die hard Harry Potter fan. I have all the books on audio and listen to them on repeat on a daily basis. They are my "background noise" or "white noise". I can quote whole sections at a time with Jim Dale as he reads it. I eagerly suck up any additional stories or writings I can from JK about the wizarding world and for that reason alone I love the play. With that being said, I am disappointed by the obvious lack of JK's skill in this play. It is obvious that it was written by someone else and only approved by her. There is a lack of detail in the storyline and more flat out bashing you over the head with information. The story also seemed rushed as compared to the books. This might be because it was meant to be enjoyed as a play and not as a book, but I found it to be a little disappointing. From this point on I warn you of spoilers!!!

SPOILER ALERT
SPOILER ALERT
SPOILER ALERT

The story picks up at platform 9 3/4  19 years later. Already I am annoyed that some lines are spoken by the wrong characters, but maybe I am the only one that picks up on that.  Albus becomes best friends with Scorpius, Scorpius and Albus become best friend, Albus and Scorpius are attached at the hip, inseparable friends... We get it. They bash you over the head with it. Unlike JK, who let's you discover character development through character behavior, these guys flat out tell you over and over and over again. I found it a little insulting, but maybe it comes across different in the play. I hated the lady that pushes the trolley. They changed her from a human witch into some strange bogart like morphing monster. It seemed out of line for the wizarding world and rather uninventive. I find it more likely that there is a spell or barrier that keeps the students on the train and not a monster cart lady that is as old as time.

I did like hearing about where Harry, Ron and Hermione are now. I find it perfectly natural that Ron is a huge jokester now. We all knew that he took over Fred's spot in the joke shop and with his wife being in a serious position like the minister of magic, it makes sense that he would balance out the relationship by being over the top funny. I also liked the way they portrayed Ginny and Harry's relationship. Ginny always did seem more insightful than Harry so when he flies off the handle at Albus it seems natural that she would comfort him and be able to reassure him that Al will forgive him.

I always thought there was something between Bellatrix and the Dark Lord so to hear they had a daughter seems entirely natural. There is easily enough time between when we see them at the beginning of book 7 (July so probably already pregnant but not showing) and when the snatchers bring Harry to the Malfoy’s for her to have had a baby.

Over all, I am glad to have further information on where everyone is now, but I am disappointed in many parts of the plot, the way it was written and the lack of JK’s input. This won't be something I listen to on repeat, but I will likely still read it once a year.

author: E.P. Clark
title: Not the Novels, but Still Fun for HP Fans
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
4/4.5 stars.

I had very mixed feelings about how to review this.  I'm a huge HP fan, and so reading this was of course super-exciting for me, and I did really enjoy it.  At the same time, it was clear to me that reading a play script is not the same as reading one of the novels.  I've heard great things about the play and by reading the script it sounded amazing; however, the script in and of itself, while interesting, was a less fabulous experience than reading the books.

Of particular interest to me as a writer was the fact that the script, by leaving out (as scripts do) all the "slow" stuff that fills up novels, was a less rewarding reading experience.  Scripts by their nature can't have any internal monologue or reflection: everything has to be said out loud, or portrayed by the actors' physical movements on stage/screen.  Scripts also have very minimal descriptions of settings and background, and the action is by necessity compressed.  The result is something very spare--I finished the entire thing in a couple of hours--that is more like a sketch than a book.  It's a book in which the author has taken the common command these days to "tighten up your writing" and "cut filler" to its maximum possible expression, and the result is something that is not really a book.  All the empty space on the page between is just...empty space on the page, lacking the depth that the novelistic form provides.  Which is not to say that this is bad, per se, it just highlighted for me the unique benefits of the novel, which allows for a depth and introspection that other forms do not.

All that being said, Harry Potter fans like me are probably going to enjoy this.  Aside from the genre differences, reading it was more like a cruise through a greatest hits album with the occasional original track thrown in than a fully-fledged new book, but a lot of the old magic is still there.

author: Misha
title: Plausibly Plotted Potter Play
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2016
content:
This review is 98% spoiler-free!

I finished reading this snappy read about an hour ago. I haven't really read any reviews of it, other than some of taglines like "So many twists!" There are no more twists to this story than any other Potter story. Perhaps the cruelest twist, then, is in expecting readers who have never read a play to hope it reaches them as emotionally as the first seven stories did.

Without the narrative and inner voice to accompany what is little more than dialogue and stage direction, the authors are forced into weaving slight contrivances into the dialogue to help shepherd the reader into understanding the motivation behind any given character in any given scene. In the end, it works, but I wonder how many readers get that far without becoming frustrated.

The story centers around Albus Severus Potter - remember reading that name in 'Deathly Hallows' and almost being moved to tears at the significance behind it?  It seems that Albus isn't all that interested in what made mom and dad name him that; in fact, his priority appears to be in coming to grips with being the son of Harry Potter.  Another of the main characters is a kid named Scorpius Malfoy - who also seems to be having issues living up to his own father's best wishes.  Through a series of encounters, and early on in the story, we learn that Albus and Scorpius, who somehow have found themselves to be kindred spirits, are contriving to step back into the past with a Time Turner to right a wrong and make the world a better place.  It wouldn't be much of a story if they succeeded in doing just that, so there's all sorts of misunderstood actions and missteps along the way.  You don't have to read too many books on time travel to know that sometimes things can really go wrong with the slightest of actions.  A temporal butterfly effect.

In true Rowling fashion, things get off to a bang, and there's loss of life at stake (on a massive scale) depending on whether or not the Potter and Malfoy progeny can undo what's been done.  Of course they can't, not on their own.  And even then...

There are some minor complaints about the writing - at times, it seems as though this is a story wrapped up in a Trivial Pursuit game; many names from the past are re-introduced, as can be expected in any series that has run this long, but often we are met with obscure names that may have been mentioned once in an early chapter of an even earlier story in the set - and that's the only mention. Are the authors offering a nod to the true Potter geek? I didn't consider these moments as roadblocks, but they were certainly distracting and seemed to be shoe-horned into the text in as unwieldy a manner as could be expected.

The story was very good, everything a true Potter fan could have hoped for. Among the best-written parts in the play are the redemption and acknowledgment of past courageous acts for a number of well-known characters; this seemed to also be a nod to true devotees who may have felt certain characters' sacrifices, both known and assumed, went unappreciated for too long. I don't want to spoil anything, so I'll leave that up to your imagination as to whom I'm writing about. Regardless, these passages could have been written in a ridiculously syrupy manner, and perhaps if this were a traditional novel, that would have been the case, but the stage is too swollen with action for characters or audience to dwell too much on them. The authors are, to paraphrase one exchange, planting acorns for the ride home and for the weeks to come.

One thing that stands out to the even mildly observant reader is that trying to stage this play as written would be a courageous endeavour. There are seemingly hundreds of scenes scattered through the acts, and the magic is deeply ingrained throughout - how certain actions could be translated to the stage are beyond me, but that's happily not my job. It does make me want to see the play in person, however.

What would be even more interesting would be to see how it could be brought to the cinema screen. It would be interesting to see it happen, but it would have to occur with at least one major change in the cast - Alan Rickman's passing would demand someone that could handle Snape's lines - not much of a spoiler, since it's already been revealed that the play involves a good deal of time travel.

So anyway, a good read, almost a must-read for the true Potter fans, with a gentle warning to approach with caution - remember it's not a novel, there is a good deal of reading between the lines required in order to follow along without getting too frustrated.

I read through it without stopping—and I look forward to reading it again after I see it on stage.

content:
Loved bring the kids in especially since one of Harry's sons was in Slytherin House. His son became friends with Draco Malfoy's son.
together, they had to get over the hate between their two families. They had to come to terms with beings sons of famous dads in the wizarding world. Together, they had an adventure to save the wizarding world.

author: David Townsend
title: Needs More of Rowling's Voice
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
I finished the new book. The plot was good, but it wasn't quite the real Rowling. Scorpius was the best character for hearing Rowling in the writing.

Even though I enjoyed the book, I miss her Dickensian detail and sense of humor. It felt a little fan-fictionish because it lacks much of Rowling's humanistic and humorous voice.

This play make me appreciate the later books all the more. I miss Rowling's clever and intricate descriptions of weird and wonderful people, places, and things. Plays don't have time for that the way novels do.

Still, a quick summer read -- not something that you can say about most Harry Potter books.

Okay, George R.R. Martin, it's your turn to get a book out.

The play may get a five star rating, but I'm unsure because the script is somewhat vague as to scenes, settings and intended portrayal.

author: A human
title: Ya know? I didn't hate it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2019
content:
This is a script. It's not a movie to watch, it's not a book to read. It's missing all of JK Rowling's clever descriptions and adverbs after every line of dialogue. It completely forgets that Tonks had a baby before the end of the last Harry Potter book and it assumes that Hermione Granger would join a bureaucracy rather than stay as an auror. It feels very much like A/U fanfiction at times with some of the characters they bring in, but it also explores some moments in a way that really were interesting and refreshing. I liked what happened to Harry, Ron, Ginny, Hermione, and Draco and how they all handled their kids being in Hogwarts... I just ended it feeling like at the end I was never to take it seriously as a part of the Harry Potter universe.

If you don't regularly read scripts, this will be challenging to enjoy. But you can get through it, it just requires a significant amount of imagination.

author: T4T
title: I enjoyed this book because I LOVE the harry potter series so it was very fun learning about the kids and finding out so much!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2017

author: D.J.
title: spoilers.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content:
Some incongruity with the original stories were small bumps.  I've read better-managed time travel!  I hope it's less confusing on stage.  I realize reading a play is a different experience than reading a novel, but this seemed to lurch from one thing to another.
I rather liked the relationship between Scorpius and Albus as it developed.  I didn't like the way Ron was portrayed at all.

title: Good read - writes itself well into continuity of the series...
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2016
content: A nice touch to continue the fascination with the boy who survived. Somehow feels complicated to create a play like this but - of course - it works... it's JKR after all!

author: Skye Robinett
title: Pretty good
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2016
content:
It was better than I had expected after reading some of the reviews on it. I liked the book overall and have always been a huge fan of Harry Potter.

It wasn't as good as the seven books in the original series. I did really like the story though and closer to the end I had a harder time putting the book down. I totally recommend it to anyone who has read the previous Harry Potter books.

The format is interesting and if you're not used to reading this type of format, it takes some getting used to. It is ultimately easier and faster to read than a normal book format

author: Amazon Customer
title: It was not my favorite format but was still a pleasure to "revisit" the ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 30, 2016
content: It was not my favorite format but was still a pleasure to "revisit" the Harry Potter family.  The story was interesting and ingenious as usual with these stories.

author: JWhite
title: Read!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2016
content: Definitely a J.K. Rowling book! Great story, can't wait to finish it! Package was nicely packed as well.

author: Positivoadiario
title: I wish they come up with a Dumbledore series!!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2016
content: let's face it: it's not a book and it was not written by JK Rowling. It's OK. I liked it, but it's not as deep as the other ones.

author: Jack
title: Good...Not Great
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 16, 2016
content:
This story was written more like a play, by a pair of playwrights with J.K. Rowling. Had it been written by just J.K., it would have been better. As it is, the thing is good, but not the great it could have been. Throughout, it leaves you asking: "why would Harry's kid want to do such a thing?", and it never supplies an answer. To show daddy up? To declare independence? To....what?

"To crate phony TV episode like drama" is all I can think of. So much of it revolves around going into the past...with no valid reason for doing so. Still, what there is is well written, and interesting. I don't regret having made the purchase, or spent the time to read it, but it did not cost a lot, either, and it was short. I recommend it to Harry Potter fans, with the warning that it is not quite what they may expect.

author: MV Martin
title: Solid follow up
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 6, 2017
content:
I wasn't really feeling the script-style but it was a good story to follow the previous books. I found myself reading it as a regular book. For example, instead of something like:
Harry enters the room
"Harry: Good morning, Ginny"
Ginny looks at Harry
"Ginny: Good morning"

I did more of a mental adjustment: "Harry walked into the room and said good morning to Ginny. "Good morning", said Ginny.

Nothing major to make you want to not read it, but it did take some getting used to.

author: Lindsay S
title: It read a bit like fan fiction
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: It read a bit like fan fiction, but for me that is mostly because the voice was off. BASED ON a story by JK Rowling, not WRITTEN BY JK Rowling. Despite that bit of disappointment, I was happy to read about the familiar characters again.

author: Mike Heinrich
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2016
content: A little hard to follow in screenplay format but good

author: Lynda Alexander
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2016
content: Excellent!

author: RRP
title: Well Done. Mischief Managed.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content: For a play, I thought this was a worthy edition to the Potter canon. But it’s not great like the books and it’s not written by J.K.Rowling, so it shouldn’t be judged as such. The epilogue of The Deathly Hallows serves as the jumping off point to the story. What could be more appropriate and welcome?  The adventure centers around Albus, the estranged son of Harry, and Scorpius Malfoy who, after both are sorted into Slytherin, become close friends. In a misbegotten effort to prevent the death of Cedric Diggory, by the use of a forbidden and illegal time turner, they rain down disaster and darkness on the Wizarding World and their own families.  Lots of scenes from the original 7 books are revisited and we are treated to some alternate realities in which, for one, <spoiler>Ron and Hermione never fall in love and get married and Harry Potter is killed by Voldemort. </spoiler>It’s not nice to try to change history.  It has somewhat of an “It’s a Wonderful Life” vibe in places.  Some of the ways the boys unintentionally change history are overly fanciful and fan fictiony, but the script fits in. Potterheads  should not be outraged, and I was not disappointed. There are lots of cameo appearances by many beloved and hated characters from the books and movies, and I believe it when I read what a crowd and critic pleaser the actual West end play is.

author: Isa Bee
title: Very entertaining!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2016
content: If you didn't know that this book was a script and didn't keep up with the news/hype prior to the book being released, then you really don't have room to judge or be disappointed. For those of us (us Harry Potter fans) who actually kept up with this play knew exactly what we were buying. I am very pleased with the story. It was entertaining. I could not put it down. I love that it is a play. In a world that prizes itself on books turning into movies, it is quite refreshing to have a wonderful story turn into a play. I docked a star because I do agree with most of the readers, the characters were flat at times and didn't resemble what I know of them. Since the story is all about Harry and Albus's relationship, I think the ending was unfulfilling and unresolved. But overall, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child was full of adventure and entertaining to read.

author: Sandy Farmer
title: 4 Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 15, 2018
content:
Husband bought me Harry Potter and the Cursed Child when it published. However he bought me the hardback copy (which I would have told him is the version I wanted had he asked, but he surprised me). Yet reading a physical copy of a book is just about impossible for me right now. What reading I do is mostly done on my phone a page here and there throughout my day, 15 minutes here while nursing the baby, and another 15 there before bed. And that's why I put off reading this book for so long. I actually ended up borrowing this from the elibrary just so that I could read it on my phone. And it feels good to have finally read this finale.

I didn't have high expectations for this continuation. That's mostly because I always worry that a series that has ended doesn't always need to be revisited (even the ones I loved the most). Sometimes the original ending is where things need to stay and let our imaginations fill in the rest. So I just went in with low expectations and that being said I really ended up enjoying Harry Potter and the Cursed Child.

The old gang was much more involved in the story than I originally expected. While I assumed they would be present in the parental nature, I didn't expect the roles to be as prominent as they were. The story is as much about Harry's relationship with his son Albus as it is anything else. I enjoyed the fan service included throughout. I was pleasantly surprised with Draco's role and how much his character has changed since we last saw him. While I did enjoy this change if I'm being honest it is hard for me to imagine him this far changed from who we're used to seeing. In the same way I was surprised with how much of a role the old gang had in the story, I was also surprised with how little of a role Harry's other kids (James and Lily) and even Ron and Hermione's kids had.

Albus and Scorpius form the other main section of story. It isn't easy being the son of Harry Potter. Nor the son of Draco Malfoy. These two bond over their lack of other friends. I was quite concerned that the writers were going to turn the friendship between these two boys into more but I'm so glad that wasn't the case. They do have a bit of a David and Johnathan kind of closeness between them which I really appreciated seeing. I love stories about deep friendship.

I was also unsure about the villian of this story. Because this is a single story, the writers didn't have time to build up an evil to rival Voldemort who was complex and slowly revealed over the course of seven books. I didn't want old V to be the villian of this story also considering everything our characters did to defeat him in the original 7 books. I was happy with how things worked out even if they weren't completely unpredictable.

The most important part ofHarry Potter and the Cursed Child was the father/son relationship between Harry and Albus for me. There were parts that had me concerned about the direction of this story and the characters but in the end I was happy with how all the pieces played out. Throughout the majority of the book I was thinking I'd probably only give this 3 Stars, but the ending brought it up to 4 Stars for me. Have you read Harry Potter and the Cursed Child? What did you think? Let me know!

author: MsChris

author: Amazon Customer
title: A little heavy on nostalgia
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
Overall, it appears to be a wonderfully technical production. I'm sure it's something to behold in person.

It came across to me, however, that some of the dialogue points were laid on thick (Dumbledore's painting is highly emotional, which doesn't fit into D's character at all).

It was also disappointing to see Hermoine, Ron and Ginny diluted to caricatures of their more nuanced characters.

It seems the playwright ignored the less is more approach in favor of over explaining certain emotional motifs in some misguided attempt at tapping the HP nostalgia cash cow.

I will say, Harry is well-rounded and makes for a somewhat-touching emotional arc in this play.

content: This is a great follow up for any fan of the Harry Potter series.  I loved the idea of strange and new friendships, finally putting to rest two family's long standing disagreements.  I loved how the Malfoy name finally has a hero to add to it, further proof that there is good everywhere.

author: Debio14
title: Pleasant quick read with almost the Harry Potter feel.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2016
content: I really enjoyed continuing the adventures of Harry Potter and hope that this is not really the last we hear from him.  Although it was clearly stated that this was a play I wasn't use to the format and I did find myself confused at times and had to flip back and forth. However, my experience reading this one will make me much more likely to try reading one in the future as I did get the hang of it. I did feel that it was being told by J.K. Rowling however, it did lack much of her descriptive details. All in all I do feel like this writer captured the Hogwarts and Harry Potter feel and I would look forward to a full book. I would recommend this for all ages that wants to hear about the adventures and misadventures of Harry's son and unlikely friend. You will also learn the fate of our beloved characters and what could happen if you play with time.

author: Brian Duckworth
title: (NO spoilers!) A must-have for Potter fans:
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2016
content:
Excellent play! No, it's not quite the same as reading the original series, but it's a really well-done supplement to them. The story draws you in pretty quickly and you definitely get emotionally invested in the characters. Will it be your absolute favorite? Probably not, but it's definitely worth the read.
Pros:
- New characters are incorporated into the HP universe pretty seamlessly.
- All events, locations, etc. are accurate to the original books. No changes/liberties taken to "make it work" with a new story.
- Modified perspective! While Harry plays a very large part in the story, he's not the main character and he's not always seen in a favorable light.
- While being a continuation or sequel, this play deals with a lot of characters and events from the original series. The events of the past play a central role in the current plot and important characters from the originals add depth or at least thoughts/opinions that weren't given the first time around or, better still, given in retrospect.
- Now that it's been 19 years since the events of the originals, some of the characters reflect on actions and circumstances of the past. It adds a new perspective because not all of them like who they were back then, nor think their actions were the best option. Hindsight's always 20/20, right?
- The physical book is great quality, comfortable holding while reading, and looks fantastic on the shelf with its predecessors.

Cons:
- This is a one-sitting read. Short and straight to the point. The plot flies by pretty quickly without lingering much on details.
- The style, being a play, leaves a lot to be desired as far as what characters may be thinking as opposed to what they are saying. Everything you know and learn and understand comes from dialogue only. Of course this is the nature of a play, but when you're accustomed to full novelization (as we Potter fans are) it's a bit lacking in unspoken emotion and imagery.
- One of the "pros" above was that this is a sequel that ties-in well with its predecessors. That is true, but there are moments while reading that feel almost TOO tied-in. That's to say that it feels forced sometimes; like certain people or events, etc. were put in there purely to have something recognizable in a new story.
- While J.K. Rowling undoubtedly had a large part in creating the story/plot, you can definitely tell that she didn't pen the words herself. That's not to say it isn't well-written (because it is), but there are subtleties, word choices, phrasings, etc. that show another writer's imprint. You may not even notice these subtleties at first, but the overall "feel" is different. Again: different does not mean bad.

All in all, I'm glad I've got this play in my Potter collection and it was an enjoyable read. I recommend it to anyone who has read the complete series and is itching for more. I don't, however, recommend it to a "casual" fan - a.k.a. someone who has not read the entire series or who was never that emotionally invested in the story. This play relies very heavily on the assumption that you know all the details of the original series off the top of your head. Without that knowledge, a lot of the actions/events/etc. wouldn't make much sense.

author: Amazon Customer
title: Not what I expected
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 9, 2016
content: While Harry Potter and the Cursed Child offers exciting new insights into the wizarding world for avid HP fans, the voices of many of the characters, namely Harry, Hermione, and Ron, will ring as slightly off for those who have read and reread the books.  Some parts are also a tad generic, but other than that it is a fantastic read that will keep you guessing-and cheering-untill the last page.

author: M. Kolacy
title: I liked the story

author: Jim McDermott
title: A Wonderful Addition to the World of Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
Very excited to read the newest story in the world of Harry Potter and I wasn't disappointed. Albus Potter is a wonderful character, as is Scorpio Malfoy, and the ways these characters echo and also change the stories of their parents is a delight.

In ways that I don't want to spoil it does revisit old territory, which is not what I expected. But the choices that lead to those moments are very strong. This is a story about children dealing with living in the shadow of their parents' histories (and their parents struggling to deal with the same thing). It's rich terrain.

I suspect some readers will find certain big character moments towards the end a little less satisfying, in large part because this is not a book, where everything gets spelled out on the page, but a script. There's a lot of magic in these pages, but there's undoubtedly far more on the stage.

With the publication of the script Rowling announced she doesn't expect to return to the story of Harry Potter again. While I understand her decision, I hope she'll consider more stories about Albus, Scorpio (and also Delphi, Rose, James, Lily and all the rest). She and her co-writers have added a lot of interesting toys in this latter-day wizard world that we barely get to play with.

Last note -- loved every Ron moment. He's only gotten more fun as a character.

author: Summerlike
title: None
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
80% like, 20% dislike (not "hate")
Okay. First things first. So a lot of people have expressed their feelings of "hate" for this book. LET'S GET THIS STRAIGHT, PEOPLE. I DO NOT HATE THIS BOOK. The only reason this book gets 4 stars is because the characters are not themselves, but I'll get to that later. FIRST, I speak directly to those who haven't read it yet, ignore the bad reviews. THEY are saying what THEY think. YOU might like it. So go on, buy the book, and give it a try. SECOND, (my opinion) THE BOOK IS F******G AWESOME. The plot is interesting, and a lot of people don't agree, but (spoiler alert) I kinda like the Time Turners. And a Time Turner that only goes back 5 minutes at a time? YESSS!!!!
Now, for the bad parts. As a lot of people have already said J. K. Rowling did not write this book. I completely agree. Again, the characters are NOT themselves. Since when has Harry been this grumpy? And why have they turned Ron into a Fred substitute? How can Draco suddenly talk to Hermione with respect? That's all I have to say

author: Gunnison Trail Rider
title: I was delightfully surprised with how much I enjoyed it. My one complaint
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: Being a huge HP fan, I was skeptical that the magic of those books, which increased in volume with each new volume ;-), could possibly be replicated in a screen play format.  So skeptical in fact that I wasn't even planning on buying this, where I had pre-bought each of the HP books just as soon as they were available.....but once we reached the publication date, I couldn't resist the allure of buying it with One-Click for my Kindle.....I was delightfully surprised with how much I enjoyed it.  My one complaint, as you might expect, was that it ended much too soon.  Whereas the HP books would give me days of reading pleasure, I finished the Cursed Child in only a few hours.  But the magic was definitely still there!

author: Kelsey Bogan with Don't Shush Me!
title: Cursed child is a fun experience, NOT a jk Rowling potter book
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
Word of warning:this was not written by jk Rowling, it was written with her approval. Her name is on the cover because the study uses her characters (which she created in the original series). This is not an "8th Harry Potter book" and does not compare to the original series. It is, however a simple and fun reading experience. Judge it for what it is not for what it isn't. It is not a jk Rowling book.

(The Review)

Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is a fun and funny romp through several years and situations in the Potter-verse. Follow Harry and Albus, and Draco and Scorpius, as they try to navigate the post-Voldemort world while trying to establish relationships with each other. Fathers struggle to let go their pasts and accept their sons as they are, while sons of the famous and infamous alike struggle to find their footing and make their own identities in this world. While the dialogue-heavy script book lacks much of the detail, emotion, and magic that J.K. Rowling effortlessly captured in the original series, Cursed Child will still be a must-read for Potter fans everywhere, who have waited more anxiously for a return to this world than for their Hogwarts Letter all those years ago. For fans, this story will satisfy those who have missed these characters these past 9 years, and who wish to check in with them and see what they are up to. Those looking for a true "8th book" will be disappointed in this script book, but those looking for a simple continuation of the world will find enjoyment in what is offered herein.

Final thought: I enjoyed the ability to return to this world that so truly touched and shaped my life enough to overlook the weaker aspects of the script book!

author: college mom
title: Decent read and story
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 29, 2017
content:
I didnt realize it was a screenplay when i bought it, but i liked it anyway.
The story is quite believable.

author: Captivated Books
title: Loved the story
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2016
content: Loved the story!! It was wasier to read than I expected.  I felt the ending was a little lacking however. Kind of like they just ended it to end it.  Like they just couldn't come up with a super great finish. Still very entertaining and followed along with the original story!

author: Sebastian Zavala
title: Suitably entertaining
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
No, it wasn't written by JK. Rowling herself, but Harry Potter and the Cursed Child does feel as part of the same universe. The story takes some of the establishes characters to unlikely and interesting places, and the new ones, including Albus Potter and Scorpius Malfoy, are well developed and likable. The interesting part, though, is in the play's presentation; the text DOES have many moments that left wondering exactly how the hell they are supposed to solve them on stage. Reviews saying the play is awesome and complex definitely aren't kidding.
The play does turn very expository from time to time, and dialogue isn't always the best, but as a brand new adventure with both familiar and new characters, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child works reasonably well. It's addictive, entertaining and somewhat predictable--can't wait to read the final text (this is a rehearsal version) and, god willing, to watch the actual play someday!

author: Amazon Customer
title: the story is pretty good but it is written as a play

I think Rowling needs to go ahead and fill in the story as a book or film the play so fans in fly over country can enjoy it.

author: E. Ziegler

Spoiler: When they go back in time, Ludo's words have changed. I do like that you get to finally see why Harry heard screams in the maze.
Even with the issues I did enjoy it, I would have preferred a boom written solely by jk, but this is much better than nothing.

author: Gilbert G. Ortiz
title: Great but need another.....
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2016
content: Very good story as usual, would love another, the only thing it's a screen play. A true book would have gotten another star Harry potter cannot be long enough.....ever...the best series I have ever read.

author: Diane H. Kenyon
title: While I'm sorry it's not a novel, it's still well worth the read!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
My sister asked me what I thought about this book, and I told her it had me spellbound. It pulled me in so quickly that I read it in one sitting. While it doesn't equate to the in-depth delight of reading the previous 7 books, anyone who likes Harry Potter should read this book.

It's hindered, of course, by it's format. It's a script, and so much of the magic of the novels is missing. Being limited to dialogue and stage direction means that this story, while enchanting, lacks the full bodied delight of the novels. The setting descriptions are very sparse, we don't truly "see" the characters, and without being able to watch the actors on stage, we miss the nuances that would be given to us through introspection and narration.

However, I truly loved this glimpse into the future of our beloved Harry, Ginny, Hermione, and Ron. Seeing them navigate adult responsibilities and parenthood is a lot of fun. And the glimpses of other beloved characters (McGonagall, Draco, etc.) was like finding out that while yes, you did indeed already eat the whole cake, there was still a bit of frosting left over to enjoy.

author: Shantala Shenoy Nayak
title: There were parts that I adored, and there were parts that offended me, especially me - a brown Potterhead.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content:
*Spoiler Free*

Harry Potter and The Cursed Child - the most awaited book play script of the year, is storming the book world (2 million copies sold in the first 2days) and is making fans around the world giddy with excitement to be finally reading a new Harry Potter book.

Needless to say, I was no exception. Which is why, before I started reading this book, I tried to keep my expectations on a realistic level (tried is the operative word here), especially considering J.K.Rowling hadn't written this one.

Though I must say, that I was also a little nervous, because this series was magical perfection in my eyes, and I couldn't imagine how this play script could top that. In fact, without Rowling, I was sure of this being a step down; which is probably why, I am not as disappointed with it as many of the others are.

What is Harry Potter and The Cursed Child all about?

It's marketed as the 8th Harry Potter book, and that, I must say, is only partly accurate. Or at-least it depends on one's perception.

It's very much a continuation of the original story. In fact, it starts right where the epilogue ends - with Harry, Ginny, Ron and Hermoine dropping off their kids at Platform 9 and 3/4. So, in that sense, yes, it's the 8th story.

But there is also a disconnect, which makes it unfair to call this the 8th of the Harry Potter series. It doesn't have the multi-faceted narrative, the strong characterization; and while it puts a grin on your face, it's incapable of evoking the depth of feeling the earlier books were able to arouse with ease.

Of-course most of this is because it's a play-script. And not a book. Which is why, I am not taking any points off for this.

I am only mentioning this, in the hopes that people keep this in mind, as they start reading the book. Because I have read too many negative reviews of this book, on the grounds that it is a play script. I mean, it's written right on the cover. What part of that was not clear?

Yes, I wished for this to be a book. And I wished that it would have been written by Rowling. But it's a play script, and I am not going to judge a thing adversely because it was something that it expressly claimed to be.

Of-course, being a play script doesn't excuse every thing (and I will get to those things later in the post).

Read full review at SHANAYA TALES DOT COM.

author: Amazon Customer
title: It's a play.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2016
content:
I liked this book for its ability to put me back into the Harry Potter Universe. This was the biggest plus for me.

A word of caution for other readers is to remember that this is a script. It isn't as detailed or character driven as the books themselves because it is meant to be performed. And as a piece that is meant to be performed I felt that it was well done. I would enjoy seeing the characters make this come to life.

There were somethings that I did not like in terms of the story - but I felt that the money that I paid for the book was worth it - especially to have the ability to be placed back in the Universe of Harry Potter. It was also nice to have a real closing to the story more than the chapter at the end of the 7th book.

Overall enjoyed the play.

author: Amy Levine

author: Marcus Cotton
title: Definitely not as bad as everyone says.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 23, 2016
content:
When I first heard that JK Rowling was collaborating on a play based on her beloved Harry Potter characters...I was curious.  I'm one of those people who firmly believes in waiting to see the end result; I try my very best not to board the hype train or the hate train.  And then, they announced that this play, "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child," would be published in a book form so that all the people who cannot see the play could still experience it.

After waiting and the play's premiere, the book was finally released.  The conses seems to be on the negative side.  Everything ranging from mixed to negative all the way to the extremes of panned by critics and audiences.

And I just don't get it.  I finally picked up the book and read it, and I have to say I thoroughly enjoyed it.  A lot of the flack seems to be towards the format.  "Harry Potter and the Cursed Child" is not actually a book...it's a published version of the script for the play.  A lot of reviews I saw when it came out were slamming the book for this.  Honestly, I think it's unfair.  The people who were anticipating and following the news of the release of this book should have seen it coming.  The articles I read explicitly stated this was the play's script in script format (as opposed to book format).  The negative reviews I've seen make it sound like the reviewers had no idea this was gonna happen.

Aside from that, the other reviews focus on the story's content.  I will admit, as much as I liked it, it wasn't perfect.  But, then again, it is a (spoilers) time travel story, and those are seldom perfect.  But I liked the plot and I liked the characters.  Yes, a lot of people complained that some characters (such as George Weasley and Neville Longbottom respectively) do not show up.  In my opinion, that's for the best.  Cramming as much of these characters as possible would have been merely fan service; they don't serve a purpose to the plot and thus weren't needed.

I will admit, I did have my issues at times.  My biggest being was that I felt Harry was acting extremely out of character at the beginning.  It was a little jarring at first to see him act so... un-Harry-like.  But, we have to remind ourselves, "this is Harry 20 odd years later."  Of course, in 20 plus years, a person is going to change.

Albus and Scorpius were my favorite characters in they book.  They developed nicely over the story as they struggled to find their identities living outside of their fathers' shadows.  I also liked the relationship between Albus and Harry.  You can see their struggle to understand and bond with each other and you can't help but feel for them.

There were other issues.  I felt some moments were rushed, especially in the beginning (it jumps from Albus Severus' 1st year to his 4th in like 10 minutes).  But overall, I really liked the story.

All I'm saying is, don't let the seemingly overwhelming sea of negativity dissuade you.  If you're curious, then read it.

author: May Angelou
title: Parenthood Is Tough
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 17, 2019
content:
I’ll admit it. I’m not a fan of the Harry Potter series. Having read it long ago, I thought it overblown and seriously lacking in imagination. Witches, wizards, giants, werewolves, vampires, unicorns, dragons, invisibility cloaks, flying broomsticks…none of these things were NEW. I’ve read about all of them elsewhere and often in greater depth.

But this book reminds me why J.K. Rowling’s magical novels resonate with so many of her readers. Like Buffy the Vampire Slayer when the series was truly great, it was never just about the magic or the monsters. It was about people, their nature, characters and the way they react when confronted with problems and life choices. Even written as a play, that’s what comes through in this startling script.

Harry’s struggling with adulthood, fatherhood and the threat of Voldemort coming back. As always Ms. Rowling surprises, taking the story in unexpected directions. We meet old characters and new, dicey situations, read about risky behavior and monumentally stupid decisions. Hey, what’s life without idiotic choices and awful consequences?

After this, I think I’ll re-read the original series. You can’t go home again. But maybe you can re-assess some of your old opinions.

author: Kelsey W
title: Enjoyable read, clever continuation
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2016
content: Just finished, and I found this latest installment in the series to be something I was emotionally invested in. I'm glad it wasn't just a reiteration of the prior books, which is what I think many people were hoping for. I also liked that the original characters have changed, as well they should. Scorpius was adorable, and the friendship formed was heartwarming.  I do think because of the script format that some of the connection you get from jk's introspective narrative gets lost, but that's exactly why I'm now very interested in seeing this performed, as it was meant to be.

author: Kayla
title: Unexpected Joy
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content: Not what I expected, but in a good way! I think too many people forget that this is supposed to be an on-stage play production and the script-like dialogue would be the samd as if you were reading a Shakespeare play. Following the script-like dialogue wasn't difficult and it didn't impact the story at all, as in it definitely didnt make me feel separated from the characters. And also a reminder that J.K. Rowling didn't write it herself so don't assume the writing will be the same. Great book/play, I really did enjoy it and I'd recommend this to any Harry Potter fan.

I know this book has been getting both positive and negative reviews, but I actually liked it. At first I was not sure what I was feeling in regards to this being written in a play form, but once you start reading you can just glide through the writing.  It was a really easy and fast read.

I love the Harry Potter series, and although this was not the greatest book of the series it still was exciting to get back into the Potter craze.  I loved that this brings so many characters back to life and also brings some new characters to this adventure.  I really hope this is not where this ends, but we will see.

I definitely recommend at least giving this a try if you are a Harry Potter fan.

Thus, for me I felt like there was a lot left on the table in areas such as character and plot development.  As a Harry Potter fan, though, I'll still probably read anything she puts out related to that world.

author: Smartest person alive
title: Decent Read
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2017
content: Good book, definitely not like the originals.

author: Hannah
title: It felt like closure.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2016
content: Something you have to remember before reading this is that this is meant for a play, and not written by JK. She had control over it, working with the playwrights to make sure it stayed true to the Harry Potter world. As it is written for a play, of course it's not going to be extremely detailed. IT'S A PLAY. I'm not a fan of reading scripts, so that was difficult to get past for me, but you get used to it. As far as the storyline, it's a bit of a stretch, but if JK approved of it then I accept it. It felt like closure for a series I have loved since I was a child, a closure I didn't know I needed. And some people have said that it felt like fanfiction.... well it is, it's just original author-approved fanfiction. All in all, I think it's a pretty good book.

author: Mark Baker - Carstairs Considers
title: A Different Trip to the Harry Potter World
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2016
content:
When I first heard that there was going to be a play sequel to the Harry Potter series, I was intrigued and hoped at some point I’d get to see it.  When they announced they were going to release the rehearsal script, I was happy, but didn’t plan to buy it right away.  I should know me better than that.  Yep, I caved and bought Harry Potter and the Cursed Child the week it came out.

If you aren’t yet familiar with the world of Harry Potter thanks to the wildly successful novels and equally wildly successful movies, then this book isn’t for you.  It assumes you know the backstory to what happens here, and if you don’t, you will be positively lost.  There are references to events and cameos by characters from the past books.  However, if you are already a fan, you’ll love diving into the latest story.

What is most notable about this book is that it is a bound copy of the rehearsal script for the play.  That means it reads very differently than a novel.  Essentially, it gives us dialogue and minimal stage direction and even less description.  It’s a different type of read, and you need to be in the proper mindset going into the book as a result.

The play actually opens with a scene we are already familiar with - the epilogue of the final novel.  In it, we see an adult Harry Potter sending his middle child off to his first year at Hogwarts.  From there, we see Albus Severus Potter landing in the unlikeliest house in the school and making a surprising best friend.  We breeze through a few scenes before really landing on the heart of the story, which involves time travel, alternative realities, and a chance to save an innocent from dying.  But when things go wrong, can Albus Potter undo what he has done?  Can Harry Potter work with his son to save the day?

I’ve seen some fans complain about this book being glorified fan fiction, and I can see their complaints.  The plot seems a little wacky overall, not the carefully thought out books in the series.  Yet, every time I started to feel that way, the characters pulled me back into the story and I forgot my complaints.  If you know and love these characters, it’s hard to not cheer for them.  I still feel like the basic premise of the story doesn’t sit completely right, but I don’t mind so much.

And that’s because I love the core cast of characters, and it was great to see them again.  I’m not sure I bought Ron’s personality in the story, but that’s my only real quibble with the characters.  There was a surprise ally along the way, and I loved seeing that relationship develop.  There were some truly touching moments as well.  Many of them were predictable, but that didn’t make them any less touching.

Those used to the immersive world of the Harry Potter novels will definitely miss that here.  Once again, we are reading a play, which is mostly dialogue.  The details of Harry’s world aren’t here because we would see that on stage.

And maybe that’s part of the reason I always had a hard time getting truly into the world like I would the books.  I kept picturing actors on a stage as events unfolded.  And the short scenes always made me think of how the scenes would change for an audience.  I tried to picture how they’d do the magic on stage as well.  That was distracting, although it is a personal issue.

The book is only 300 pages, so shorter than most of the novels.  Couple that with lots of white space because this is a script, and you have a very fast read.  Again, I think this helps explain some of the complaints from fans.

While I don’t think this will ever be anyone’s favorite book in the series, I’m certainly glad I read Harry Potter and the Cursed Child.  If I ever get a chance to see it, I’ll jump.  If you are a fan, go into it expecting a play script instead of a novel, and you’ll be just fine.

author: Josh Mauthe
title: Not without its flaws, but its ambition, love for the world, and sense of wonder go a long way
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2016
content:
“The eighth story,” says the tagline for Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, and yet, whether this counts as the eighth story is up for debate from the get-go. What, exactly, was Rowling’s role in this? Was she the true author of the tale, or is this, as many have claimed, basically glorified fan-fiction? And even if Rowling really is the auteur behind it, do we want to count a script for a play as the eighth true entry in the Harry Potter books? And as if all that’s not enough, even if we accept all of those things, how are we really supposed to judge this as anything but an incomplete vision, a partial rendition of something that can only truly be experienced on the stage?

They're all valid questions, I think, and I'm not sure I have answers to any of them. I love the Potter series a lot, but I'm not a die-hard; this isn't something I grew up with, but something I came to in college and afterward. And so, while I'm curious about Rowling's role, as a movie geek who's pretty much a strong advocate of auteur theory, I'm okay with accepting Rowling's authorial stamp, as nebulous as it is (and even though I'm quite curious myself as to how much she contributed, even if I have my own theories). And the question of how it fits into the canon, or if it's a "true" eighth volume...honestly, it doesn't matter as much to me as I know it does to some who grew up reading this world. I just want to know if it's a good story.

And the fact that it’s a script? Does that hold back that story? Well, if you mean, “did I spend half of my reading time wondering how on earth you could possibly stage something like this,” the answer is an unequivocal yes. The play we have the chance to see the script for is a dazzling, incredibly ambitious work, one that strikes me as a jaw-dropping work if it was properly accomplished. Because make no mistake: this is a play, but it’s one that embraces the world of Harry Potter. If what you expect is some tight, one-room drama, think again; there are wands glowing, spells flying, people transforming, flights taken, objects coming to life, and even a montage of time somehow evoked. This is a play done with ambition to spare, and while I can’t imagine how it’s accomplished, I can’t deny that reading the script made me so, so jealous of those who have a chance to see it.

But can we judge the story that we’re given? I think we can – and more than that, I don’t think it’s nearly as bad as some people do. I’ll try to steer clear of spoilers here beyond, say, the first few scenes; suffice to say, Cursed Child revolves around Harry’s son, Albus, whom we first met in the epilogue to the 7th book (a scene which opens this play). As Albus goes to Hogwarts, he’s forced to deal with life growing up with a very famous name, and the realization that whoever he may be, he’s certainly not his father. And that tension – on both the part of a frustrated Albus and a baffled adult Harry – provides much of the emotional richness of the play. Indeed, like the best Potter books (and if it means anything, I’ve always gravitated to Azkaban and Half-Blood Prince as my favorites), Cursed Child uses its plot as much as a way of exploring emotional territory, here engaging with reputations, parental expectations (as well as the difficulties of parenting), reminders of the past, guilt, and so much more. And it does so while delivering a far, far more ambitous tale than I expected, one that could easily have been an 8th novel in the series.

But would it have been? There’s no denying that there are definitely scenes and ideas that feel off about Cursed Child, and it’s not just about the fact that a central mechanic and idea of one of the books feels like it’s been majorly retconned to make this story work. Nor is it the sometimes gratuitous fan-service in the form of characters and callbacks (indeed, even as I admit that some are a bit much, there are more than a few that made me smile to read, and I can’t deny that reaction). No, as much as anything, it’s the occasionally iffy character work, because whatever else you can say about Rowling, you can’t deny that her characters lived and breathed in glorious ways. And while there are some great turns here – Albus is good, but his best friend (another child of a Potter alumnus) is even better, and adult Harry is a compellingly flawed character (a fact that’s caused much consternation, but ultimately ranks as one of my favorite touches of the play) – there’s also more than a few who are served poorly, and the fact that many of them are women is even more disappointing. (To waste Ginny in the play is one thing – she wasn’t much of a character in the books – but to squander Hermione’s presence and character so much is far more disappointing.)

And yet, for all of those flaws, I can’t deny that I really, really enjoyed Cursed Child. Would I rather have had this as a novel by Rowling? Undeniably. It might have been the same; it might have been better; but whatever else, it would have her voice, and that doesn’t always happen here. But even for that, as I read Cursed Child, I remembered just how rich and incredible Jo Rowling’s world of magic really is, and even as part of me wanted to cynically grumble about callbacks and cameos and retcons, I can’t deny that there’s so many moments that worked for me. And while the plot is serviceable at best, there are glimpses here of the imagination and scope that made the series so memorable, whether it’s a brief window into the worst possible outcome of things, a plunge back into a rich mythos, some perfect character beats, or even just the sense of imagination at picturing some of these things on stage. No, Cursed Child isn’t maybe the “best” 8th book we could have gotten, and I know some will say it’s not even a book. But in a lot of ways, I think it keeps Rowling’s spirit, world, and characters alive, and even if it gets a little fan-servicey, it’s done with love and respect, and with an imagination and scope that does the world right.

author: Danton M.
title: Keep an open mind and you'll like it!
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: I zipped right through this play, not because it's easier to read than a novel, but because I was interested in learning what was going to happen next. While I think the short scenes are a distraction, essentially jumping from one group of characters to another, that's my sole complaint. In some of the novels, particularly the last couple, Rowling got far too wordy for my tastes, so seeing the action as a play was a joy for me. The new characters, particularly Scorpio and Albus, were fun to follow, and I considered their relationship developed as fully as most other HP novels. But don't take my word for it--read it yourself!

author: PD
title: The Magic Awakens

content: I was hesitant to read this because I love Harry Potter so much and I knew many people who also love the series didn't like this book. I tried to see it as it's own piece of work that gave me a little more of the HP world I love so much. While it doesn't compare to the original canon at all and there are many flaws, it's still an intriguing story. It's such a fast read because it's just dialogue which also makes character development more challenging. If anything, this made me really want to see the play live. I will probably not re-read it as I do the original series but I don't regret purchasing/reading it.

author: davidslaura
title: I did like it! I mean
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
I did like it! I mean, I think I did.

I have a feeling it is much better on stage.  I also believe that, had Rowling chosen to write this as a book, and not a play, it would be getting much better reviews.  Rowling's writing isn't allowed to exist and wrap itself around us as the original seven books do.  Instead, everything is stripped away.  Good for an actor's "show, don't tell."  Bad for us who can't see anything.

That being said, Rowling could still create a plot that drew me in, excited me, frightened me, compelled me, and encouraged me.  Worth a read. For those of us though who will never be able to travel to London to actually see the play... for those of us who could never afford to see it: well, Rowling has shorted us a bit.

Oh, and spoiler:

Was anyone else disappointed that the homoerotic undertones between Scorpius and Albus weren't further developed?

author: Kimber
title: This book is still getting too much hate....
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2017
content: I am a devoted Harry Potter fan. When I heard that this was coming out, I was thrilled. I was also thrilled about it being set up as a play. This book was assigned to me in a playwriting class. When I started it, my smile sort of began to fade. It was a little difficult getting into, but as it progressed, it got so much better. By part two, I could not put it down. I loved the idea of getting to see the 19 years later. This story follows Harry's middle child, Albus, as he goes to Hogwarts and befriends an unlikely person. Part one of the book is a slow escalation to the nearly falling apart of a world all Harry Potter fans know and love. Granted, this book is very different than the other seven, but it can stand alone on its own two feet. If you are a Harry Potter fan, I suggest giving this a try. It might not be your cup of tea, but don't knock it until you try it. Even after a year of being on the shelves, this book still gets hate. I can see the point of view from people who dislike and like it. I had feelings from both perspectives, but I have read it again since the first time.

author: DHY
title: Get off your high hippogriff
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content:
Firstly, they play receives 4 out 5 stars because I felt some lines could have been better scripted. Now it was made clear this is the first edition of the script. So perhaps some lines will improve. Secondly, I felt the play was exactly what I expected. It's a play. It's short and entertaining! For the overly critical, get off your high hippogriff. Had Ms. Rowling written this same plot as a novel you'd be calling it a masterpiece. Some of you are giving it 1 star because it's not exactly what you expected and now you're throwing a fit. It's like giving a hospital a 1 star rating because you stuck a cucumber up your butt and now you're dissatisfied because this just wasn't what you expected and the ER can't get it out fast enough. Like it's not the plays fault you're an idiot no more than it's the hospitals.
To everyone that hasn't read it: have an open mind and enjoy the adventure.

author: NenetteU
title: Whatever the format, it's the story that matters
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2016
content:
As what the other reviews have mentioned, the play format was the letdown for this book. But that's just it; nothing else about the book was a letdown.  I knew I was buying a play script - got me hesitant at first - but my desire to read the story won out.

Nineteen years since the battle at Hogwarts, Harry is back with his friends fighting with forces from the dark side.  He is also struggling in his relationship with his adolescent son who thinks he has a lot to prove being the son of a very famous wizard.

All that made the last seven books treasures are here:  magic, thrill and excitement, creative imaginings, triumph of good over bad, valuable life lessons.  Surely we can forgive the format, couldn't we?

author: Cecilia A
title: Decent Eighth Book
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child
J.K. Rowling, John Tiffany, and Jack Thorne
Scholastic
July 31, 2016
321 pages
Review- 4/5 stars
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child is the book every Potterhead has been waiting for since they first finished Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows. Except it isn't what we were expecting. This eighth installment in Harry Potter's world is a script, and is being performed as a play in London. I hadn't read anything about the play, so going into this book I had no idea what was going to happen. However once I got my hands on a copy at midnight, I devoured it. Harry Potter and the Cursed Child was a very entertaining and enjoyable read.
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child takes place nineteen years after the events of the Battle of Hogwarts. It is the story of Albus Severus, the son of Harry and Ginny Potter, and Scorpius the son of Draco Malfoy. Both boys feel like outsiders at Hogwarts for difference reasons. Albus is a Potter that was sorted into Slytherin, and Scorpius is rumored to be the son of Lord Voldemort himself. So they instantly become best of friends.
Albus Severus was overall a likable character. He was a bit angsty and dramatic for some reason, but he did have nice character development. Scorpius , however was a amazing this entire book.He was definitely my favorite character. Scorpius was funny, geeky, optimistic, and very charming. Occasionally he was a little angsty, but never as much as Albus. I did enjoy reading about Scorpius and Albus's friendship, and how it grew stronger over the course of the book.
One thing I really wished that Harry Potter and the Cursed Child had more of was the classic characters. I would like to have known how Neville, Luna, George, Hagrid, ect. were doing. It would also have been nice to get to know Hugo, James, Lily, and Teddy Lupin better.
Harry Potter and the Cursed Child also followed Harry, Ginny, Hermoine, and Draco. Harry's scar has been hurting for the first time in many years, and he is nervous that Voldemort will come back. His wife and two best friends believe him, but his long time enemy Draco Malfoy thinks he is making it up. However, when Albus and Scorpius go missing Draco and Harry team up together to find there sons.
My biggest disappointment of Harry Potter and the Cursed Child were the adult characters. Ron, Harry, and Hermoine were all completely out of character. Ron was an idiot, and Hermoine was not as intelligent or determined as she was in the original Harry Potter series. This was very disappointing because Ron and Hermoine are two of my favorite fictional characters of all time. The character that was distorted the most however was definitely Harry. In The Cursed Child Harry was self centered and kind of cruel. Not only did he tell Albus that "sometimes I wished you weren't my son" (p. 41) but he also tried to prevent Albus from being friends with Scorpius. In doing this, he threatened Albus and McGonagall. I was really not happy with Harry's character in this book. The one adult character I really did like was Draco Malfoy. He was realistic, and it was nice to see more of his emotions. His love for Scorpius was really sweet, and nice to see. The Malfoys were the best characters in this story,
Now let's talk plot. While reading The Cursed Child I enjoyed the plot. Looking back at it, I have realized how fanfictiony and unoriginal it is. The time traveling plot was basically Back to the Future meets Harry Potter and the Voldemort's child plot was something I read in fanfiction. The other confusing part of this play was when Harry transfigured into Voldemort. Can wizards just transfigure into other people? What is the point of going through all the work to make Polyjuice Potion then? This was an extremely unclear scene in the story. Though the plot was certainly flawed, it was still a lot of fun to read.
Overall Harry Potter and the Cursed Child was an enjoyable read. If you are a fan of the Harry Potter series, I definitely recommend picking it up. If you have read it, please let me know your thoughts because I am dying to discuss it with somebody.
-Lucy

author: R. Silva
title: Homage and Deconstruction
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2018
content:
This is the script to the stage production of the authorized Harry Potter sequel, and it focuses on the budding friendship between Harry's youngest son, Albus, and Draco Malfoy's son, Scorpius.I read this in two sittings at the Shanghai Library (they don't let you borrow English-language books). It has great pacing, and is definitely hard to put down.

This script does a lot of different things. It is at once a homage to the Harry Potter series and a deconstruction. Some fans are going to balk at the deeply flawed version of Harry, who is trying to hold together a strained relationship with a son who is pushing him away. However, the dialogue is strong in many spots, and the characters of Albus and Scorpio are excellent. Their relationship is really what holds this story together.

The plot relies a bit too heavily on time travel, and on some of the less interesting tropes of that subgenre, but it still manages a few clever twists and surprises, especially toward the end.

There are lots of scenes geared toward pulling on the heartstrings of fans, and many of them were effective. There is some humor too. Scorpio gets many of the best one-liners, while the use of Ron for comic relief felt a bit clunky.

In the end, in spite of some unevenness, this had a solid emotional impact delivered in a satisfying story.

author: Stacie Eirich
title: Adventure, heart and a testament to the power of friendship & family, a must-read for HP fans
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content:
** spoiler alert ** Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, the much awaited 8th book in the wildly popular and new classic series Harry Potter -- is actually a play in 2 Parts, 4 Acts. Based on a new original story by JK Rowling and John Tiffany -- the script has been written by Jack Thorne, and performances of the West End production in London opened the same day as the book's release (coincidentally, also Harry Potter and JK Rowling's birthday--July 31).

The play is set 19 years from when we last saw Harry at the end of Deathly Hallows (Book #7) -- Harry now works within the Ministry of Magic, is married to Ginny and has 3 children. The story focuses on Harry's second son, Albus Severus, (namesake of both Dumbledore and Snape). In his first year at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft & Wizardry, Albus makes an unlikely best friend - Scorpius, Draco Malfoy's son. Albus also gets sorted into an unlikely house -- the house of Slytherin.

Albus and Scorpius soon find themselves on an adventure through time, back to the Tri-Wizard Tournament, which took place in Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (Book #4) over 20 years in the past. Not surprisingly, they find out that changing events in time is a dangerous & tricky ordeal with dire consequences. They will need the help of their family and friends (including Harry, Ron, Hermione and other well loved characters from the series) to right their wrongs and return to the present time.

The play primarily explores themes of father/son relationships and friendship - the strengths and weakness of both. It is a quick, fast-paced read; I received my copy in the mail on Monday and had it read by Wednesday evening. It is a must-read for any Harry Potter fan, although as a play it lacks the descriptions a novel would have had time to flesh out. As a play, however, it includes stage directions that allow readers to imagine beyond the text -- and it is packed with both action and heart. After a successful run on London's West End, perhaps it will come across the pond, giving American Harry Potter fans equal chance to relive the magic, seeing "The Boy Who Lived" once again.
