author: Chrisy
title: Spoilers!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2017
content: I went into this book expecting not to like it too well because of the reviews, but as a Harry Potter fan, I knew that I would have to read it eventually. The play format was hard to get used to at first but after a while I started to get into the groove of it. However, the story line started off slow and was kind of depressing. The main focus is on Albus Potter, who seems to be the complete opposite of his father and resents living in his shadow. He seemed to be very lonely and depressed in his life and the only positive thing is his best friend Scorpius Malfoy. About 1/4 way through, the book starts to get better when the boys decide to help out Amos Diggory, who wants to use a time turner to bring back his son. Albus and Scorpius make several attempts traveling back in time trying to change the past but all their attempts create terrible butterfly effects on the present. I did enjoy reading about Snape (very briefly) in one of the alternate realities traveled to since Snape is my favorite character, but like other people have pointed out, all the time travel stuff does kind of read like fan-fiction. The book was ok but I was sad that the main characters of the Harry Potter series just seemed to have just gotten old and boring.

title: Four Stars

title: Satisfying Follow-up to HP Series
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2017
content: I would have preferred a novel, but when you practically grew up with Harry, you'll take what you can get to stay in touch. This story was everything I wanted it to be--without being predictable. Of course,  you know it has to have a satisfactory ending, but you also know from other HP books that you can't expect plans to succeed without mishap and sometimes without tragedy.

Also it would've been nice to have a more expansive story, as it was it was over all to quickly leaving something to be desired.

My granddaughter loves it.  I only got though 1/2 of Act 1.  Nothing against the book, just the style.  As I'm reminded by the girl, it wasn't for me in the first place.

author: Jayme Erickson
title: A great follow up to show us what our favorite characters are up to
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2017
content:
It has now been 22 years since the battle of Hogwarts and Voldemort's ultimate defeat. Harry and Ginny are married with three children: James, Albus, and Lily. Ron and Hermione are married with two children of their own. This account revolves around Albus, the misfit of the family. He is so afraid he will be sorted into Slytherin and in his first year his worst fears are confirmed. These seem to be Harry's worst fears too. An unexpected friendship with Scorpius Malfoy makes the relationship between Harry and Albus drift even further apart. After overhearing Amos beg Harry for what he believes to be the last remaining time turner in existence, Albus gets it in his head that by saving Cedric Diggory he can right all his father's wrongs.

I really liked this installment in the Harry Potter saga. The screenplay format made it a quick and easy read. There was a lot of emotion and feeling. The middle part of the story was phenomenal. Without giving too much away, I loved seeing the alternate versions of the wizarding world. The reappearance of so many beloved characters was a real treat.

The one thing I didn't like is that I felt like some of the characters weren't true to their nature's from the previous books in the series. Snape and Draco in particular. Though I did enjoy the direction they went with Draco and hearing his entire story made me understand more. Also, McGonagall was much more lax as headmistress when as a teacher she was extremely strict and a stickler for rules.

I would give this one a4 out of 5. I liked it. It had some really great parts while others fell flat. The resolution to the main plot was good but I thought the resolution to character relationships I thought was lacking. I would've liked to see a bit more development there. It is definitely worth reading for fans of the series!

I am endeavoring not to give away spoiler's in my review. I enjoyed this book. I read it realizing it would be in script form, it is a play after all. I was also in the frame of mind that it would be like a fans story of Harry Potter, telling a story of what they would have imagined occurred after the 'nineteen years'. I did not expect another JK Rowlings book.
The story told in stage form was pretty interesting and I enjoyed reading about familiar names and thought the plot a good one. Although in my mid 60's I am an avid Harry Potter fan and remember shedding a tear when  Deathly Hallows2 showed in our local cinema. First time I have known the whole Cinema stand up and applause at the end of a movie.

author: Bradley S.
title: I disagree with one reviewer who felt the play did not feel like a Harry Potter story
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2016
content: I read some of the negative reviews before buying and reading Cursed Child. I wasn't to excited to get started reading the play format so finished a couple other books first. BUT... Once I got into the story I could not put it down. I disagree with one reviewer who felt the play did not feel like a Harry Potter story. The script format did make for a somewhat ackword flow to the plot. A lot happens from one scene to the next and most scenes were very short. But I could easily visualize the characters and environment as if I was viewing a movie. There were references to many of the events from the movies and I felt this added to my enjoyment of the play. The story is suspenseful and and has some unexpected surprises. There is a cliff hanger between parts 1 and 2 that heightens the suspense. I would like to have read this as a novel; maybe we will see one in the future. I did see a WB teaser trailer on You Tube for a Cursed Child movie... to be released in 2018. It looked legitimate.

author: C. Jefferson
title: An Interesting Glimpse into Harry's Future...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2016
content:
The Boy Who Lived. The Chosen One. The One Who Defeated the Dark Lord. One might think that Harry Potter is fearless. He's up for any challenge. But no one told him that moving on, raising a family, and trying to have a normal life would be more challenging than anything he's faced before.

And one of the biggest challenges for Harry is his son. Albus Severus and his dad have never really clicked. The connection between them doesn't feel the same as the connection Harry has with James. And when Albus is sorted into Slytherin and becomes friends with none other than Scorpius Malfoy, the divide only grows wider. A divide further complicated by the rumors that Scorpius may not be Draco's son. A divide further complicated by Harry's scar acting up. And a divide further complicated by a centaur's vision of a darkness around Albus.

For Albus, living in his father's shadow is challenging. There are expectations. And it's always made very clear when he doesn't meet them. But there's got to be a way for him to do something to break beyond that, right? Something he can do that makes him stand out on his own? And with Scorpius at his side, he's sure he can accomplish anything.

--

I'll start by saying that if you're not a big reader of plays, this one might be a little challenging. They don't read like prose. They're not meant to. And you often have to fill in some of the action and internal monologues based on your own reading of the characters. That's just part of dramatic works as casual reading.

The story here is engaging. I enjoyed getting a glimpse back into the wizarding world. You'll find your old favorites and even some new characters that are a part of the next generation. And the flashbacks to Harry's childhood that were left out of the original novels were also very telling.

Is this another epic Harry Potter adventure? No. But I don't think it's meant to be. It's not a seven-novel saga with a major arc. It's a single story, focusing on the future of the wizarding world, and reminding us that the past can come back to haunt us in ways we never imagined. And those ways are exponentially more when magic is involved.

I've seen some comments online to the effect of "I've read better fanfiction." And while I don't want to get into a whole debate in this review, I don't see how that is necessarily a standard of what makes for a good story. For one, it diminishes fanfiction as something "less than" quality published work. And I've read many fanfics that were better than some published work. And secondly, what's the point of the comparison? Just because you've personally read something you think is "better" than something else, it doesn't--by default--make that something else bad. When I give a book a three or four star rating, I don't say "But I've read 15 five star books that were better so this is awful." Context is important, and I think it's something that we as readers and reviewers need to remember. /soapbox

If you're a fan of Harry Potter, pick this up. If nothing else, you'll get a few hours of entertainment and enlightenment out of it. And you'll get to go back to Hogwarts one last time...

author: John-Eric
title: I Didn't Want to Like This
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 31, 2019
content:
I avoided it. My son told me about it, and I said, "It's not part of the original seven. It's not official. J. K. Rowling said she wouldn't write anything more to the story." But I was curious. And I tried to be open-minded. So I read up on it. I read up on J. K. Rowling's involvement and her take. And I thought, "Huh." She seemed to back it 100%, and to have supplied the key details. And I gave it a try. And I was captivated. How to take a story that seemed to wrap up into a happy ending and complicate it with a future? This does it. Stunningly. And sheds additional light on the original seven stories. So glad I gave it a chance!
And yet — upon further reflection — I have to downgrade my rating.
I'd like to give it five stars for characters, 3 for plot.
Let me explain. (spoiler alert)
I LOVE Malfoy's son Scorpius. He beautifully complicates and enriches our understanding of Slytherin. Ambitious to prove himself to his father, but otherwise a wonderful guy. And in love with Rose.
I appreciate Albus and his complex relationship with his father.
I love the greater depth, courage, honor, and humor we get to see in Snape.
I'm grateful to see Malfoy with greater depth.
Harry? Not so much. A disappointment, for the most part, though he comes around. Would he really put his son's safety over his son's happiness? Perhaps. If we're willing to see him parenting in ways that are consistent with his upbringing while seemingly inconsistent with his values. All those who loved him tried to keep him safe when he was growing up — safer than he wanted to be, over and over. And don't we raise our children as we were raised, by default? Any change in our parenting has to be continually worked for, in my experience. To my chagrin, I keep hearing my mother's words coming out of my mouth when talking with my son and daughter — words I cringed at as a child, words I see my children hurt by. Yuck.
But the real issue with this play is time travel.
It's a tricky business.
The time turners are used carefully in book three of the Harry Potter series.
These are used in ways that stretch credulity beyond the breaking point.
To go so far back in time and to change things this much. Would anything be the same? Would the differences be so subtle, the first time around?
And still — though I struggle with the time aspect, I deeply enjoy this play.

author: M. connery
title: Subtract one more star if you don't like reading scripts
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content:
Having read scripts in the past I can still see the story through it.
That being said I now regret not being able to see the actual play, And how the action and special effects are managed.
Since this is not a written book you cannot see how the characters are portrayed  in such great dimension, this would be provided by the actors on stage.  This being said here are my opinions.
First of all there are two protagonist groups Harry's and his son and best friend.
With regard to Albus, not enough of his life before Hogwarts is discussed, so how he turns out prior to the beginning of the script is only insinuated in later scenes. Thus, while Harry had a few points in his favor before he spoke a word in the first book, Albus starts in the negative and goes lower before proceeding to redemption.  This is mirrored in Harry's path through this story as well.
Whereas books 1-7 had fully developed scenes from daily life with hints at later chapters at the beginning, this story had snippets.  Only when the main arc begins does the story feel fleshed out.
The main arc involves the use of a magical artifact introduced in book 3, and it's results read like a episode of Dr. Who, but allow it's protagonists to mature.
The culminating scenes, while full, were less satisfying than prior books(eg. The chamber and Riddle, Sirius' escape, the graveyard, etc).
The antagonist seemed to be a macguffin destined to mimic the Potter men's issue instead of a true villain.

While it seems I'm being very negative and my review I must now explain why I gave it four stars.  The story reads like a play that was based on a movie that was based on a book.  If you are a potter fan you can fill in most of the blanks and see the wizard world we fell in love with.

author: George Hui
title: Great book... Exciting but predictable... Spoilers are included in this review
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
So here's what I'd say. Get the book but don't try to guess what will happen because it's too predictable. It's like Back to the Future. (That's what my dad said) If you like a surprise do not keep reading. The next part is a spoiler...

Ok so the book takes place 19 years after book 7. Albus Severus Potter is Harry's son. Albus and Harry do not get along with each other. What makes it worse is that Albus gets put in Slytherin. He makes friends with Scorpius Malfoy, who is Draco Malfoy's son. Soon Amos Diggory comes to ask to go back in time using the Time-Turner the Ministry of Magic found to revive his son Cedric Diggory, who was killed by Voldemort. He says that he has discovered news about the Ministry of Magic finding a Time Turner. Harry lies and says that they haven't. When Albus hears this conversation he thinks it is unfair that Harry lied, and that so many people died protecting him or because he existed. So since Albus thought this, he and Scorpius embark on a mission to save Cedric. They team up with Amos' niece Delphi and foil Cedric's first event in the Triwizard Tournament. This changes the history books but not enough to save Cedric. Therefore, Cedric still died, but Albus made his cousin not exist. They go back in time again to foil Cedric's second event. They humiliate him and cause him to lose that event as well. But this made him angry. He became a Death Eater, and the only wizard he killed with Neville Longbottom. However, Neville killed Nagini, so since he died, Voldemort took over the world and killed Harry, so Albus didn't exist. It was down to Scorpius to save the world. He discovered Snape, Hermoine, and Ron had an organization by themselves... secretly. Then they used simple Shield spells to undo the damage. Everything returned to normal. But remember Delphi, Amos' niece? She was really Voldemort's daughter. She used a spell on Amos to make him believe she was his niece. She tried to go back in time with Albus and Scorpius to stop Voldemort from trying to kill Harry so he would never lose his power and have been able to take over the world. They got stranded by Delphi, but Albus finds a way to send a message to Harry. Harry and his group go back in time with Draco's hidden Time Turner. They save the two kids and prevent Delphi from doing anything. In the end Harry talks to Albus and develop a better bond.

author: Britt Kay
title: Worth. It.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2016
content:
Here's the deal: I liked this.

I think a lot of us uber fans have to reconcile the fact that we can like something a lot without worshiping it in the manner we may have worshipped the original.

It's a great story, and I had missed these characters so much, so much that I didn't even realize how much so until I heard Ron, Hermione, Ginny, Dumbledore, Snape....and Harry speak again.

You cannot understand this play without being a super fan, as there are memories and allusions and hints that you must infer, or they go unexplained.

I respected this. An ode to the super fan....and a glimpse at the future we all imagined when we turned the last page of book seven.

This book may be far from what you imagined and you may hate it...and it doesn't radiate with the charm and language and color of Rowlings' novels, but it made me happy. I got to visit old friends.

I think that's the point.

author: Amazon Customer
title: It must be the most beautiful production.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2016
content:
If I could hop onto a plane right now and go and see this play performed I would. It must be the most beautiful production.... I wouldn't even know HOW they could make it into a reality. I wish wish wish I could see it..... What a blast from the past! While I do feel this book felt a bit 'fan fictiony,' I actually really enjoyed it. I was open to not enjoying it and willing to give it a bad review if needed - I am always truthful and honest with my ratings on books. But - luckily I loved it:

The book takes place 19 years after the Battle of Hogwarts and we follow Albus Potter, Harry's son, who is struggling to live up to the Potter name. There's a lot of conflicts in his life, from a hard relationship with his dad to his pretty grim Hogwarts experience - and so when something happens that means he could change the past and inevitably the future, he grasps the opportunity only to ROYALLY f*!k things up.

I am someone that never rereads a book. That said, I hadn't been swept into the Harry Potter world since I was a kid and I was really nervous that this book would ruin a major part of my childhood. Yes, I was one of those complete nerds who would be standing outside of the bookstore at midnight dressed as a witch, waiting for the release of the next book in the series..... don't judge me.

I'd tried my best to keep away from everyone else's opinions until I'd read it but some people had told me they were really disappointed - I still tried to go in with an open mind though. With that in mind, I really don't understand why people were disappointed in this book! I found it captivating, page-turning and thoroughly gripping. OK, the writing wasn't earth-shatteringly good but it's written in the form of a script and I think they did a damn good job at making it as good as it could be.

I enjoyed being reminded of certain things that happened in the original Harry Potter books that I'd long since forgotten about. I enjoyed catching up with the characters too (although I can never really remember Ron being quite so classically humorous.. I always thought of him as quite ingeniously sarcastic and dry rather than 'trying' to be funny). I am still not sure what I think about Draco's character, he changed the most out of everyone to me - a lot of character development which is always a good thing, but I liked him as the bad boy. Just my opinion.

The plot wasn't as mind-boggling as the original books, it was short and quick and had a direction all of its own and there is nothing wrong with that. You can never beat the original HP books - but I definitely think this book is worth a read nonetheless.

author: Jen Lipson
title: HP Cursed Child
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2016
content: This play was a very entertaining read and a nice way to look into the future of characters. Many people don't like the play format and would rather have a novel. When you attempt to recreate something that is so beloved their is a risk you could ruin it. This play gave you a new perspective to the story you once loved. Its not super touchy feely which makes it more authentic. Some of the plot twists were put in for shock value but the true essence and themes of HP are all here. Appreciate it for what it is and not for what it isnt.

title: Brought back some memories. Not sure how much JK ...

author: Lorena
title: Interesting and fun
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 7, 2016
content:
I really enjoyed the read. Unlike many people, I knew that the book was a script, not a novel (that was made very clear), so I didn't have high expectations.
My rating is 4 because it was more than I expected, it was smart and fun. I see JKR in the story and sequence of events, even though the style is so different.
However, I didn't buy the way some of the characters were represented, Ron, for example, was of a really different personality than in the novels, and I really don't believe he would turn out like that, they weren't fair to him. The way some of them "spoke" was also quite different from their usual tone, but again, I didn't expect it to be perfect, so it was good enough.

author: Go Go reviews for AMAZON
title: It is a play and must be read as one - I really enjoyed it and look forward to seeing it on stage.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2016
content:
I liked this play quite a bit and now have told my husband we need to plan a trip to London to see this on stage. This is not written like a book it is a play - if you think this will read like a book you are wrong and may not be happy with reading this installment of Harry Potter, but if you have an open mind about reading a play I believe you be pleasantly surprised by the story - you need to read not only the dialogue but the stage directions to really get a feeling for how this reads and the feelings involved in this story,  Loads of emotions and teenage eye rolling is going on in this play - I loved as I am at the age Harry and Ginny are at raising their teenagers and it is not easy to say the least.

I will not spoil it as I had no idea what to expect before reading this play and I really liked it - I had not read anything about it so I would not feel one way or the other before reading this and am glad I did as I am now looking at the reviews and sorry to the haters but I really liked this play - the story goes on with the Potters raising children and the challenges that comes with the choice - kids will be kids and do what they want even when we raise the well - but I love that we revisit the these characters and their lives and what is happening in the wizarding world.  You will enjoy the update on their lives and families - anyone who loves Harry Potter will enjoy this glimpse back into that world - even grown up they still are intriguing as a new generation takes Hogswarts by storm.

Read this play with an open mind and you will see what a fantastic play this has got to be - now I just need to figure out how to get tickets and get myself over there to enjoy this play as it should be done.  I cannot believe anyone really did not like this play - it was a fantastic trip back to the love I felt the first time I discovered Harry Potter.  Keep your mind open to what this must be like on stage - emotional ending and yet beautifully done/

author: Books and Things
title: fun trip back to Rowling's world
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2016
content: While there were some things that struck me as odd about the story line, there was a lot to enjoy. The characters we know and love are all grown up (as are many of us), and the book reflects notable changes of personality and maturity. I'm looking forward to seeing the play and thought it was quite clear that I was purchasing a script and not a novel.

author: mer
title: Feeds your need for HP
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2016
content: NO SPOLIERS. Let's face it, JK Rowling could write a haiku about Hagrid on a piece of toilet paper and millions of people would fork over $10 for it. This was a great story, it fed my desire for a new HP story, a hold over until Fantastic Beasts comes out. It's a very quick read, maybe quicker if, like me, you are already familiar with the script format. Most characters remain true to what we expect from them, there are a few disappointments. Yes there are some gratuitous appearances but I appreciated them for the most part. The plot is kind great if you don't overthink it... just enjoy it for what it is.

title: A Good Book

content:

About half way through this book it sucked me in, and I could not put it down until I knew the ending. I thought that this book was a great addition to the Harry Potter series.

This was a good book, but one thing that really bugged me was that this book lacks many of the rich details that I have become accustomed to from reading the other Harry Potter books. But overall I would recommend this book to anyone that wants a quick read.

author: Keith Moser
title: Fast read, lots of nostalgia, but a little too fan-fictiony to be 5*
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2016
content:
Copied and pasted from my Goodreads review (spoilers are clickable over here: [...]
Wow.

Wow!

I don't want to talk too much about anything because JK Rowling is asking everyone to #KeepTheSecrets, but I guess that's why they make (view spoiler) so I'll do my best to avoid writing about anything specific (and when I do have to go into details, I'll just use the spoiler tags). You're warned. (Quick note to app users—apparently the spoiler tag doesn't work in the app. If you didn't have to click to see the all caps "spoiler tag" above, maybe don't proceed unless you've read the book.

I haven't read the Harry Potter series since I've joined Goodreads, so I don't have any reviews or official rankings of them. I've always said Goblet of Fire was my favorite book, although all of them are probably 5* (perhaps I'll reread the series next year!). I enjoyed reading Tales of the Beedle Bard when it came out and I'm always ready for anything Jo wants to give us from the wizarding world (although I did quickly get bored of Pottermore—perhaps it was the slow rollout of content).

I flew through this book in a little over 24 hours. Not too surprising given that it's a play (340 pages of script are a lot easier to read than 340 pages of a novel), but it did feel good to simply devour more Harry Potter fiction. It was great revisiting the characters I fell in love with so many years ago and meeting new characters Rowling created. (I think it's important to point out that the play, as far as I can tell, was written by Jack Thorne and was based on a story created by Thorne, Rowling, and the director, John Tiffany. If I had to guess, the overall outline of what happened/who was introduced was all Jo [her world after all] with some creative additions from Thorne & Tiffany, but the actual acts and scenes and lines are all Thorne.)

What amazed me most of all is how what I read was actually happening right now on a stage in London. I've read plenty of scripts that require a fantastic director to put up (e.g. The 39 Steps & Peter and the Starcatcher—both of which I read after seeing them on stage) but this probably tops them all. It should come as no surprise that the Production Credits list someone as in charge of Illusions & Magic. But still, even simple bits like (view spoiler) are eclipsed by descriptions of (view spoiler), (view spoiler) or (view spoiler). I mean, HOW?! I really want to go to London just to see this on stage.

But I think it would excel more as a magical play than it does as a script. The story was interesting (view spoiler) and it was great to go back to Hogwarts and the Ministry of Magic, but it still didn't quite click. (view spoiler) It feels like a cheat to introduce a new type of magic that felt similar to an old type but without explaining all of its differences. Also, there were plenty of times characters did or said things that felt so out of character. For instance, (view spoiler) and grown-up Ron felt like he was just trying too hard to fill Fred's shoes.

There also felt like there were some plot holes with what I remember from the previous seven novels. Perhaps things changed after Voldemort was defeated in Deathly Hallows but wasn't (view spoiler)

In the end, the play feels a little too much like fan fiction and not enough like a Rowling addition to the series. I actually now wonder how much approval she had to give and how much Thorne & Tiffany came up with on their own. It was great seeing old characters again but everything felt a little too convenient (especially this HUGEST of spoilers: (view spoiler) Seriously, WTF?!). But, I still flew through the book and I'm sure the play is amazing to watch... If I could give this 3.5* I would, but for now, I'm rounding up because it was still a lot of fun to read despite its problems.

title: Enjoyable Read, not on the same level as the original books
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2016
content:
As a Harry Potter fan, knowing going into it that it would be a play (and reading so many bad reviews) I was expecting just another edition in the series - but not holding my breath.
This book was an enjoyable read, and I do not regret my purchase.  Though it is not as great as the main 7 books, I read it for fun, not for critical thinking or as a "fine piece of literature". I don't find myself overly analytical of books unless I get bored reading them - and this book definitely kept my attention.
The characters weren't my favorite, and I was a little disappointed at some of the development of Harry, Ron, Hermione and the other adults as compared to their childhood selves. But that's ok - and now I want to see the play!

author: Sydney
title: Normal harry potter plot line compared : *No spoilers*
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2016
content: OK if you're looking for the usual Harry Potter plotline this is not for you.  The usual Harry Potter plot line is they are all at home about to go to the Hogwarts express (Harry's children this time).  Something a little odd happens before they go.  They arrive at Kings Cross go through the border get on the train say goodbye to everyone. They all talk on the train meet people arrive at Hogwarts meet Hagrid if their first years.  Then they're all sorted into their houses they all have a big feast the headmaster make a speech and they all go and sleep.  Suspicious things start to happen the new trio which in this case would be Albus Severus Potter, Scorpius Malfoy, and Rose Weasley  go and try to save the day. Get in trouble all along the way but end up saving Hogwarts. In this book this whole book extends over 4 school years and Rose Weasley is barely in.  But if you do want to see an adventure this might be for you. Some characters disappointingly were not in the book. People such as Luna Lovegood, Teddy Lupin, Victoria  Weasley,  Molly Weasley, Arthur Weasley, Seamus Finnegan, Dean Thomas, George Weasley, Bill Weasley, Fleur Delacour, and many others. Neville Longbottom was included but he never actually spoke.  I mean I like the book but it wasn't quite Harry Potter it was not as exciting as it was to read the other ones. You still should buy the book no it's not quite hairy Potter but everyone knows you're anxious to read it. So do because I still like the book and when they no longer sell this version I can say I have it.

title: Worth the read
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: I like many grew up during the HP generation. I started reading these books when they came out during my elementary years and finished the last book in my senior year of high school. I was so excited to be able to revisit the magic again. I think it's definitely worth the read. It's definitely a different tone because JK Rowling didn't write this play by herself but it's still super fun getting to go back to the world of Harry Potter. So for that reason I say it's worth reading. Just as long as you go into it realizing it's a play written by three people and not just in JK Rowlings voice. I also like seeing the original characters as parents and being able as an adult to relate to them navigating parenthood.

author: Sarah Alexander
title: News Flash: Plays Must Be Read Differently Than Novels
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2016
content:
For most of the reviews complaining about this play, I can only say this: It's not Her, It's You.

(First of all, it was made perfectly clear by everyone involved in the project that this is the script of a play and not a novel, so maybe read the description of what you're buying before you whine about it).

A play is a fundamentally different animal and must be read differently than a novel. Your brain must process the information differently. It's a completely different experience. A script is a starting place, it's just the words and the plot. All the magic is filled in by directors and actors and lights and sounds. The magic of a script is how it comes to life in front of you. The script is just the beginning.So of course time is going to move quickly. Of course there is a lot of short hand. Of course the dialogue itself on the bare page without having life breathed into it by an actor is going to seem lacking.
Like reading Shakespeare in school and finding it dull then seeing the Royal Shakespeare Theater perform the same play that brings tears to your eyes -- this is a play and it's meant to be seen.

As someone with vast and extensive experience in theater, I can see the potential for the magic lurking between the words on these pages. I can picture how many special effects would have been brought to life and know how breathtaking that would be. I can see when a line that might read as hokey or flat will bring tears to the audience's eyes if delivered with total truth by an actor in the moment of the drama. If you haven't read a play since Romeo and Juliet your freshman year of high school.... do yourself a favor and acknowledge that there is a lot more to reading a script than merely looking at the words, that the problem here might be your lack of understanding and imagination rather than the script itself.

Not to say that it was wholly without flaws. There was one plot point in particular I could have done without. But expecting this to be another Harry Potter novel isn't fair because that's not what it is. It's a new Harry Potter story, but it's not a new Harry Potter book. The magic in this story is seeing it on stage and watching the world come to life around you. Of getting to dip inside that world for just a little while. Don't expect it to be the same as the novels, because it's not and it was never intended to be any more than Harry Potter World was intended to be another Harry Potter adventure. It is what it is and if you don't like it, that's fine, but don't be a baby about it.

Also. The idea that JK Rowling owes anyone anything is ludicrous. If you don't like her books or her play or anything else she produces that's fine. But she doesn't owe the fans anything. She doesn't owe the world anything. It's her world and she can do what she wants with it. She is not responsible for your feelings, good or bad. It isn't fair to heap that on her.

title: Well done, but not Harry Potter!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2016
content: I enjoyed this book enough to finish it. It was well written and stretched my imagination, especially beyond the world of possibilities created in the original Harry Potter series. With that said, though, it does stray quite about from the story line and does it pack as much of a punch. It is noted, though, that this is written from the perspective of a different main character, Harry's son, and in a play format, as opposed to a novel. Overall, well done - 4 stars.

author: Burgundy
title: I know that this isn't the perfect harry potter story
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 20, 2017
content: Listen, I know that this isn't the perfect harry potter story. The book as a script is weird. BUT the play is so beautifully done and truly wonderful. While the play does have some rough spots they are small enough that the rest of the play overshadows the flaws. The effects are magical and amazing. Don't judge the story of Cursed Child based on the script book. The story of the Cursed Child on the stage is a sight to behold.

author: Rand S
title: Loved it. Definitely very different reading a screenplay instead ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 2, 2017
content: Loved it. Definitely very different reading a screenplay instead of a book, and I wish it was a book instead,but the dialogue was still engaging and the story overall was very fun.

author: Margaret Hryczyk
title: Love the old characters
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2016
content: Love the old characters!  The book is written as a play so it is not typical HP books.  It is  a little difficult at first but the story is compelling.  After the first 100 pages, one is used it the style.

author: GaryE
title: Very good story
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2016
content:
This screenplay is just a good story . . . even more so for those of us who are big Harry Potter fans. If you read the Harry Potter books this is pretty much a must read.

Being a screen play this is a pretty quick read so if you are planning on reading this for a day at the beech or whatever bring more than just this because a quick reader can easily get through this in under three hours.

author: Brenda
title: Reading a play again was like being back in school
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2016
content: Reading a play again was like being back in school. Definitely a lot more fun to read than King Lear! I would have preferred a novel. The storyline was good and ticked along at a rapid pace. There was a large cast of characters but it never became overwhelming. Personally I would have preferred more character development and in particular the adult Harry, Draco and Hermione could have been fleshed out a bit more. Instead they were more or less the same as their teenage selves and it was hard to find them credible. The next generation characters were also heavily reliant on the previous Harry Potter books for their development and motivation. A fun read for Potter fans but could do with an accompanying novel to fill in the gaps

author: Jonathan J. Carr
title: Great!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 31, 2016
content: Great! Would've given 5 stars, but I kept wanting it to be in novel form. Because it is in play form, it lacks the nuances of a novel. But, the play does bring back the magic that we love from the original seven books. Great story, great characters, great theme.

author: Nick Haskins
title: its ok but...
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2019
content: i don't like how its all like James and then whatever he just said, but if j.k Rowling  had done it by her self then it would be better so yea.

author: Yvonne Rucker
title: The plot was great and worth the effort
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2016
content: It took some time to get used to the screen play writing interest of the regular novel format. The plot was great and worth the effort!

author: Wendell C. Thomas
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2016
content: READING this play seems less effective that reading the printed story.

author: C. Sokol
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 29, 2016
content: A fun read!

author: Ginger Eterno
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2016
content: This is a perfect addition to the rest of my Harry Potter collection.

author: Jennifer Orloske
title: Good, but not great.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2017
content: I definitely thought this book was worth reading. It did take me a while to get used to the way it was written however (as a play). I thought it was a good book. I can see how people who read the other Harry Potter books recently didn't like it as much, but since I haven't read those books in many years I didn't feel the need to compare them to this book. Was it good? Yes. Was it the best book ever? No.

author: Roberta L. Bing
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2016
content: Thumbs up. 👍🏽Thumbs up. 👍🏽Thumbs up. 👍🏽Thumbs up. 👍🏽Thumbs up. 👍🏽Thumbs up. 👍🏽Thumbs up. 👍🏽Thumbs up. 👍🏽Basically, a decent but very quick read.

author: Milagros Arroyo
title: Harry Potter and the cursed child
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2018
content: Loved it as much as I loved the play on Broadway. Just keep in mind you are reading a script for a play.

author: My2Girls
title: Good but predictable
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2016
content: I don't usually post reviews and I have been a long time fan of Harry Potter.  After reading the reviews I did not rush right out and buy this book but ultimately I did and I read it in one afternoon and enjoyed it.  If you go into the book with the thought that it is going to be just like the first seven then you will be disappointed.  I thought the plot flowed nicely and was engaging yet predictable which is one reason I gave it 4 stars.  I also thought that it would have been a much nicer read if it was not in a script format.  I would have much rather have read it in a traditional format...another reason for the 4 stars.

author: Krystal-Leigh Brown
title: I would recommend reading it out loud with a group of friends
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2016
content: It is written as a stage play.  I would recommend reading it out loud with a group of friends, as it is a play.  The story itself is nothing amazing, but I appreciate it.  I'm sure it's a huge difference watching it as a play.

author: Joanna N.
title: Didn't know
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2016
content: I wish I would have realized it was written like a script. It's interesting but not enough to binge read for me.

author: Vib
title: you will enjoy this book
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 31, 2016
content: Without going into too many details, I'd say that if you are a Harry Potter fan, you will enjoy this book. A quick 4-hour read, it doesn't introduce too many new characters and uses the background from the first 7 books. The book is written as a play and gives little opportunity for the author to describe the emotions/feelings experienced by the characters, something Rowling did amazingly well. The plot is slightly predictable and the ending is weak. It doesn't add too much to the story narrated in the earlier books either. Having said that, it brings back memories of the magical world that we haven't been in touch with since long making it a fun read nonetheless.

author: Norma Ramirez
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2017
content: Ok

author: Magicgas
title: Haters are going to hate.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2016
content: Simply put, this is a transcript of a play. If you do not understand the medium, your expectations may be off.  The story captures relationship and provides a retrospective/reflective experience for the reader.  The true test of this content lies with the actors playing on stage. Haters are going to hate.

author: Murph
title: Stick with it
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2016
content: It took nearly the entire first act for me to warm up to it and the. I got into the story. Interesting direction to take with the story but I am not terribly fond of the mechanism they used. It worked out in the end.

author: Kindle Customer
title: Pretty good
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2018
content: So I read a few reviews before purchasing this book and I thought it was going to be rubbish, but it turns out it was a pretty good book. I had just finished The Deathly Hallows and I decided to get the next in the series. However since it is a playscript  it is not really like a JKR book, but more of a story told through character dialogue. The only other negative I can think of is that it didn’t take me that long to finish.

author: Carson Gleberman
title: Great fun, a little treacly
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 14, 2016
content:
On the page, some lines explicate HP philosophy too directly,  almost clumsily. But perhaps onstage they deliver meaning well amid the swirling spectacle of all the special effects.
Because Harry is an orphan, and the setting is largely boarding school, the books only explore parent-child relationships obliquely. This work fills that gap satisfyingly while staying true to the original characters.

author: rail8
title: A Story Line Cursed by Lack of Imagination
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 12, 2017
content: This is the script for the play and does not have the background activity to support it that the regular books in the series have.  LEaves much to the imagination and is found wanting.

author: ars220
title: It's great story for those who love Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2016
content: I read this myself and bought it for my 5th grade classroom.  It's  great story for those who love Harry Potter; I loved having some old characters back in the story.

author: Becca K
title: I enjoyed the story and it was pleasant to feel like ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 21, 2016
content:
I enjoyed the story and it was pleasant to feel like I was catching up with old friends because there are only a handful of new characters and there are not any real new story lines, anymore and I might have a spoiler.

It was entertaining and a fairly quick read.

author: Kjfletch

content: Most of the reviews here say the book is bad but i do not. There are some wierd things in the  book like in the begining it skipps several years at a time . Also harry sucks ron is plain wierd. the darkness they see around albus is never explainded and the onlf cure is against anyone in the book is draco's wife. But other than that i would say read it if you have spare time rwad it it is acuay not bad.

author: Joseph Lee
title: Stays true to the essence of Harry Potter
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content: It had the core of what we as fans love about HP, albeit a very vanilla version. It was fun reading about how the characters we fell in love with are still the same and yet have gone through challenges in the years since the Battle of Hogwarts. The addition of the children make the story well rounded and they become the stars of the story. The same themes of friendship, loyalty and sacrifice are all still there and those are what captivated me through the first 7 books. The story is fast paced and it's a quick read. I'd love to see the play. I think the story will play itself out better on stage.

author: Making Good Stories
title: Cursed Continuation
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2016
content:
Harry Potter. A character and a series that defines a generation. Having grown up alongside Harry, Ron, and Hermione, the Harry Potter series has been near and dear to my heart since I first picked up The Sorcerer's Stone. So when I learned that Harry Potter and the Cursed Child was going to be published for us to read, I was both happy and hesitant - happy to see what more might be done and hesitant to have the ending from Deathly Hallows changed in my mind.

As Harry and Ginny's son Albus first attends Hogwarts, the apprehension that Albus feels stems from his trying to live up to his father's reputation and expectations. When Albus befriends Scorpious Malfoy and gets sorted into Slytherin, he becomes more and more distant from his father, and Harry's temper eventually gets the best of him. When the opportunity arises that Albus can change the past, he takes it, not realizing the drastic and dark changes it could spark. Albus's actions bring back the pain in Harry's scar, leading him to fear the return of unspeakable evil and confront the consequences of his and his son's actions.

A play is a different beast than a novel, and it's always a touchy subject to revisit a cultural staple that played an integral part in people's childhoods, but this play that visits the famed 19 years later in the Harry Potter world does a good job of developing the characters, both new and old alike so that it still has that Harry Potter feel. Events took place a little too rapidly for my preference, and it was filled with areas in the plot that raised more questions than it answered, but it was an entertaining foray into life after we left the story.

Overall, I'd give it a 3.5 out of 5 stars.

author: Danielle St. Onge
title: I love HARRY POTTER
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 5, 2016
content: I love HARRY POTTER. I knew it was in a play format, doesn't change the fact that I still miss all the narrative in the character's mind though.

author: A. Pond
title: A fun read for Harry Potter lovers
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2016
content:
I had heard a lot of mixed reviews about this book and quite a few spoilers that planted my feet firmly on the "I'm never going to read that book" side of things. Someone even told me that the Weasley's were the villains in this book! For all those reading this review and have heard the same thing, let me put your mind at ease. That's absolutely not true. But that's all I'm going to say as far as plot and whatnot go because I don't want to give any spoilers. I'm not going to be one of those people.

I will say that, because this is written as a play, it takes a quick minute to get the hang of how to read it. It was slow going at first because I kept skipping over the name of the person who is saying the line and then thoroughly confusing myself. Tip #1: read the name of the person who is saying the line. It's important. Eventually you get a handle on it and then it's like reading any other book.

Well, except that pretty much all the descriptions are missing from this book. Because it is a play, you don't get a lot of details about the setting or what people look like or what they are thinking, which I really missed. But I ended up really enjoying the book! Despite the spoilers, I finished the book more pleased than I was expecting to be. But, I mean, my expectations were really low so take that as you will.

It's a quick read, it's a fun read, especially for any fellow Potterheads. It's worth the afternoon, if nothing but to revisit some of the magic of Hogwarts and the Wizarding World that we've been missing.

author: Jeremy Hilbish
title: Unique to the others
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2016
content: I was glad to see an addition to the world of Harry Potter, but it is just that. An addition. Cursed child could never really live up to the seven books, but this works as its own stand alone project. Bravo.

author: Jessica
title: Something Nostalgic This Way Comes
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 4, 2016
content: Though this read like a fanfic, I couldn't put it down. Yes, it is in play form, and yes, they tie back a lot to the base series, but I have never wanted to see a play more, and got Rowling approved insight to the characters.

author: Amazon Customer
title: The GF liked it......
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2016
content: I bought this for my girlfriend so I could play video games.....she finished it in a day......damnit rowlings.

author: GothicRose
title: A fantastic trip..
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 2, 2016
content:
Back into the medical world of Harry Potter.

  The twists and turns keep you guessing along the way.  Who would have thought the day Draco and our beloved Harry would find ac cause to get behind, together!
  A very quick read...I finished in just a few hours while doing other things about the house as well .
As a Theater arts  major reading a script is far from New for me, for some it may be a bit awkward if they are not used to it.

author: Rose M. Martinez
title: Enjoyed with reservations
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 8, 2016
content: I really enjoyed it, but would have preferred a narrative form.

author: Emily Nedry
title: I must start this by saying that I love the Harry Potter book series
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 1, 2016
content: I must start this by saying that I love the Harry Potter book series.  I have read each book (1-7) 4-5 times each.  I started reading them as an adult, so I did not grow up with them as many did, but they are some of my favorite books.  I was worried I would not like this script; that the story would not truly be under JK Rowling's "umbrella" or feel like her story/voice, and would disappoint.  I must say I was pleasantly surprised.  I thoroughly enjoyed reading it.  It took a little more work to imagine as it is a script, and I felt the characters were left very unexplored, even the ones we know so well and love. With the passage of time, they have all, as expected, changed and I think they (and we) were short changed by not having them flushed out more.  I am sure the actors playing these parts in London will bring a nuance and depth to the characters that you cannot feel or see by just reading lines; however, I do wish it was a book.  I think it is a really neat story that could have been done more justice in a book.  I do feel a bit cheated in that regard.  I wish she had taken the time to do it properly (as I see it).  I am happy to have purchased it and read it though, and I will do so again and again because I enjoyed the story that much.  Hopefully many of you will give it a chance,and find that the overall feel and direction of the story is very much fitting of the series and Rowling as I did.

author: Niña Tan
title: It is about struggles, redemption and love. A truly remarkable screenplay. It quenches the Harry Potter fans' thirst for an 8th
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2016
content: The book is about struggles, redemption and love. A truly remarkable screenplay. It quenches the Harry Potter fans' thirst for an 8th book. But, it leaves them wanting for more... a 9th book perhaps?

author: Juanita
title: Four Stars
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 5, 2017
content: fine but the paper was broken

author: R Zimmer
title: writen as a play a bit harder to read
